European Community Commission President Jacques Delors clled for a swift convening of a meeting of the G-7 countries following the instability in today's trading on world money and stock markets.
He told a pess conference here: "G-7 should meet discreetly and quickly."
Delors said if the dollar were o fall further against the mark to levels around 1.60, the European Monetary System would undergo a "test by fire."

Delor said the current problems in the markets had been caused by excessive growth in financial trading, excessive deregulation and the failure of the fundamentals of the world economy to adapt themselves quickly enough to changing circumstances.
He said it was "profoundly unjust" to blame it on recent ncreases in West Germany.
The Pacific Stock Exchange said its closing prices will not be released this evening due to malfunctions within the Exchange's omputer system.
New York Stock Exchange chairman John Phelan said the stock market underent a significant correction today but he did not characterize it as a crash.
He also said the NYSE wil open tomorrow on time.
"The market underwent a significant fall and a significant devaluation of assets of which we are all concerned," he said
Speaking to reporters, Phelan listed several reasons why the markt fell today.
He said stocks have been going up for five year without a correction.
He also blamed inflation fears, rising interest rates, a lowe dollar and problems with Iran.
"All came together in a very nervous market" he said
"It's the nearest thing to a meltdown that I eve want to see," Phelan said.
Phelan said what he meant by meltdown was a snowballing effect where selling fed o itself.
Phelan said the NYSE is going through its standard procedure before trading begins tomorrow.
Those procedures include checking with member firms on their liquidity margin positions, and backlog.
"We know of no firm that has a significant problem, but that could change a any moment," he said.
Asked for advice for the average investor, Phelan said, "We do not know where th market will end up."
The Dow Jones Industrial average declined a record 508 poins to 1738.74.
Volume was a record setting 605 mln shares, almot double the previous record.
Phelan, in response to a question on declines in foreign markets, said he believes there is no los of confidence in the global economy.
He added that the underlying fundamentals of the U.S. economy are still strong, and that corporate earnings alo continue to be firm.
Phelan explained today's record descent as being the result of a confluence of factors, including the globalization o markets and the proliferation of new securities instruments.
Those two factors alone have made the market moe volatile, he said.
Phelan also said a major factor in the decline was the fact that there hs been no major correction in the five-year bull market.
He also pointed to risin tension in the Mideast Gulf.
The New York Stock Exchange was in constant contact with the Securities and Exchange Commission about a possible halt in all trading on th exchange, Phelan said.
"The consensus was that it is better to let th market try to work itself out," he said.
In addition, Phelan said that with the global nature of trading there is no guarantee that halting trading on the New York Stock Exchnge would have served any purpose.
Phelan said he was in contact with the Treasury department, White House and the Federal Reserve, but that the contact was made as a matter o routine.

U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker met West German Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg and Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl today in West Germany and agreed to support the Louvre pac, the Treasury Department said.
The Treasury described the meeting as "a very positive, private meeting in Frankfurt, West Gerany which had been agreed upon last week.
"The parties agreed to continue economic cooperation under the Louvre agreement and its flexible application including cooperation on exchange rate stability and monetary policis," the Treasury said.
The Treasury said Baker and Stoltenberg "are consulting with their G-7 colleagues and are confident that this will enable them to foster exchange rat stability around current levels."
The Louvre pact is an agreement between the Group of Seven leading industrial countries including the United States and West Germany to promote curreny stability.
Baker was scheduled to visit Scandinavia and Belgium this week and the department earlier refused to release details of his travel itinerary, citing securiy considerations.

President Reagan is concerned about th record drop in stock prices but remains convinced on the basis of administration talks with financial experts that the economy remains sound, the White House said.

White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater aid in a written statement that Reagan "watched today with concern" the decline on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 500 points.

The statement said Reagan had drected administration officials to consult with leading financial experts, including the chairmen of the Federal Reserve, the Securities and Exchance Commission, and the New York Stock Exchange.
"These consultations confirm our view that the underlying economy remains sound," itzwater said.
The hite House statement, issued about 45 minutes after the stock market closed, appeared designed to calm investors worried about U.S. economic propects.
We are in the longest peacetime expansion in history.
mployment is at the highest level ever.
anufacturing output is up.
he trade deficit, when adjusted for changes in currencies, is steadily improving.
And, as the chairman of the Federal Reserve Bord has recently stated, there is no evidence of a resurgence of inflation in the United States," Fitzwater said.
He said Reagan was keeping close watch on te markets in the United States and in countries, where waves of selling developed on Monday.
"We will continue to clsely monitor these developments," Fitzwater said.
However, his three-paragraph statement gave no hint of wht, if any, action Reagan might take if the stock market plunge continues.
The percentage drop of 22.6 percent on Monday ws the second largest ever, exceeded only by the 24.4 percent drop on Dec. 12, 1914.
It easily eclipsed the fll of 12.8 percent on Oct. 28, 1929 which helped spark the Great Depression.

Reagan and his top advisers discussed the market crisis, wich came on the same day American naval forces retaliated for last Friday's alleged Iranian missile attack on a U.S. flagged Kuwaiti tanker in the Gulf, at a White House issues luncheon.
Presidential aides told reporters ater the luncheon an official statement was likely to be issued when the markets closed.

Yugoslavia's ambitious eonomic recovery and anti-inflation plan faces major hurdles before it can be implemented, Yugoslav economists and Western diplomats said.

Prime Minister Branko Mikulic on onday proposed new taxes hitting high income earners, moonlighters, property and interest on savings as part of new government plans to rein in the country's 123 pct inflation.
He also poposed price and wage restraint and the trimming of repayments on the 20 billion dlr foreign debt in line with currency earning abiltiy.
"The taxes will anger many Yugoslavs struggling with soaring prices and will be resisted in Parliament," a Western diplomatic sourc said.
Yugoslav economists said Mikulic's draft plans left many questions unanswere.
"It was a list of goals, not concrete measures," said a senior Yugoslav economist at a leading Yugoslav research institute
The state nws agency Tanjug was more optimistic.
It said the proposals indicated "real economic reforms" were comin.
Further details of the program, which Mikulic summarised in Parliament, are to appear i the days ahead, and the draft has to be debated and voted on by deputies in November.
"The goals are good," a leading Belgrae economist said.
"No one can arge with that.
But the million dollar question, as with all government programs here, is how the will be implemented."
Zoran Popov, senior research fellow at The Belgrade Institute for Industrial Economy said te existing system made many of the proposals difficult to put into effect.
"A change in the the system f taxation requires changes in the constitution," he said.
"Mikulic's speech tells us what he wants t do, but not how."
"It may be anti-inflationry," one diplomat said.
"But the question is how can you tax a black economy and how will te government find out who has two jobs or more than one home."
Economists and diplomats said the proposals could be resisted by deputies from several of Yugoslaia's constituent republics and provinces in defence of regional interests.
Such resistance has blocked the nationwide implementation of federal government economic policy on man past occasions.

Allied-Signal Aerospace Co, a unit of Alied-Signal Inc <ALD>, and Ovonic Imaging Systems Inc signed an agreement to develop full color, liquid crystal, active matrix flat panel display for use in cockpit instrument display systems, Ovonic Imaging said.
The isplay systems are for use in airplanes and spacecraft.
Under the agreement, vonic, a unit of Energy Conversion Devices Inc <ENER.O>, will receive payments of about 4.5 mln dlrs over two year based upon completion of certain development milestones.
Treasury balances at the Federal Reserve rose on October 16 to 12.813 billion dlrs from 9.985 billion dlrs on the previous business day, the Treasury sai in its latest budget statement.
Balances in tax and loan note accounts rose to 28.398 billion dlrs from 28.117 billion dlr on the same respective days.
The Treasury's operating cash balance totaled 41.211 billion dlrs on October 16 compared with 38.102 billio dlrs on October 15.

U.S. warships destroyed an Iranian oil platform in the Glf on Monday and the Navy also raided a second oil rig in retaliation for Friday's Iranian missile attack on a U.S. flag tanker, the Pentagon said.
President Reagan and Defense Seretary Caspar Weinberger warned Iran of even stronger countermeasures if the military escalation between the two countries continued in the volatile waterway.
Reagan said he ordered the strike on the first pltform by four U.S. destroyers, which fired about 1,000 five-inch shells at the Rostam oil rig 120 miles east of Bahrain in the central Gulf.
A short time later, Nvy personnel boarded a second Iranian oil platform about five miles to the north and destroyed radar and communications equipment before leaving the structure, the Pentagon said.
Defense Department sokesman Fred Hoffman told reporters that the second platform had been abandoned by Iranian personnel during the shelling and destruction of the first rig.
The United tates said both platforms were being used to keep track of Gulf merchant shipping and to launch speedboat attacks on such shipping by Iranian Revolutionary guards.

Gulf and estern Inc's publishing unit, Simon and Schuster, said it agreed in principle to acquire <Woodhead-Faulkner (Publishers) Ltd>, a British-based publisher of professional and consumer books, for undisclosed terms.

Upon completion of the proposed trnsaction, Woodhead-Faulkner will become part of Simon and Schuster's International Group, which in the U.K. includes Simon and Schuster trade books, and Prentice Hall academic texts.
Simon and Scuster said that Woodhead-Faulkner will continue to publish under that name.
The company will continue to e under the direction of Martin Woodhead, who will report to Henry Hirschberg, president of Simon and Schuster's International Group.
Woodhead-Faulkner, founded n 1972, publishes international banking, finance, and investment books.

Culp Inc, citing lower margins, said it expects income from operations in its secnd quarter ending October 31 to be lower than in the same year-ago period.

But Culp said that due to a capital gain from the sale of its Culp Industrial Fabrics unit, net income for the quarter should be higher than the 1.5 mln dlrs, or 35 cts per share, it earned in th 1986 third quarter.

Culp also said it expects it will be difficult in its current fiscal year to match the 5.2 mln dlrs it earned for the year ended May 2, 1987, even if it included the capital gain from the sale o the division.
Canada's economy is strong and the outlook remains positive despite the sharp fall of stock prices on Canadian and othe exchanges, Finance Minister Michael Wilson told the House of Commons.
"I look with some confidence in the performance in the economy...I think we have a sound economy in Canada," Wilson said in response t opposition party questions.
Wilson, noting the relative stability in the Canadian exchnge and bond markets, rejected opposition demands to take some form of action.

"There has been both quite good stability in both the (currency) exchange and bond markets this mornig and I don't see any reason why we should try to take action that's anticipating somethnng which might not happen," Wilson said.
The Canadian dollar held steady around the 77 U.S. mark today while the Toronto Stock Exchange's composite index was off 292.20 points to 3,306.0 in late trading Monday.

A major South African mining house on Monday reported two of its gold mines suffered huge losses as a result of a black miners' strike i August which crippled about half the country's crucial gold mines.

Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Company, one of the six major mining houses, said the two mines suffered a combined net loss of 9.7 mln dlrs in te three months to end-September compared with a profit of 8.6 mln dlrs in the preceding quarter.
It was the first indication of the real economic impact of the biggest wage strike in the history of the gold mining industry, which accouns for nearly half the value of South Africa's total exports.
"The results were pretty disastrous, primarily due to the impact of the strike" Ken Maxwell, head of Johannesburg Consolidated's gold division, told a news conference in Johannesburg.
"We haven't recovered from the strike yet," he said, adding that 70 perent of underground mining at the group's biggest mine, Randfontein Estates, was halted by the three-week strike.
Johannesburg Consolidated and its controlling company, the giant Anglo American Corp., were hard-ht by the three-week miners' strike, but refused to disclose production losses.
Anglo American is due to report its quarterly gold-mine profits later this wek.

The European Community is willing to offer limited concessions to the United States on one of two major issues whic threaten to poison their trade relations next year, an EC commission spokesman said.
He said the offer would be made at a meeting later this month between U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter an EC External Relations Commissioner Willy de Clercq.

EC Farm Commissioner Frans Andriessen told agriculture ministers meeting in Luxembourg that the EC is willing to make some temporary arrangements to lighten the impact on U.S. Exports of an EC plan to ban the sales of meat from animls fed with growth hormones, the spokesman said.

Washington has said it will take trade reprisals if the EC proceeds with the ban from January 1 and if European countries do not quickl cut back what it sees as unfair subsidies to the makers of their Airbus airliner which are harming U.S. Manufacturers.
It claims the hormones ban has no scientific basis and will rob i of 130 mln dlrs' worth of exports a year.

Diplomatic sources said the Yeutter-de Clercq meeting will take place in London and will also involve the aerospace ministers of France, Britain, West Germany an Spain, the countries involved in the Airbus project.
FMC Corp said its Marine Colloids division was awarded a patent for anti-iing fluids thickened with carrageenan seaplant extract.
The company said the patent covers glycol-based anti-icing solutions containing gel-forming carrageenan in an amount sufficient to thicken the fluid and promote its adherence o surfaces.
FMC said it intends to grant licenses or use of its patent to interested chemical producers and equipment users.
British Foreign Secretary Sir Geoffrey Howe backed the United States' attack on an Iranian oil platform on Monday and said it should not worsen he Gulf crisis.
"The United States is fully entitled to take military action in exercise of rights of self-defense, in the face of the imminnt threat of further attacks," Howe said in a statement issued in London.
The United States said its forces destroyed the platform on Moday in retaliation for an Iranian missile attack on a U.S.- flagged Kuwaiti ship last Friday.
Referring to that attack, Howe added, "I trust the Iranians wil fully understand that continued attacks of this kind will only enhance justification for firm action in self-defense."

At a press conferenced in Luxembourg during a meeting of European Community (EC) ministers, Howe was asked about statements from a seior Iranian official who said America was now involved in a full-scale war.
"It would be profoundly undesirable and quite unjustified for Iran t react in that way," he said.
The Dow Jones Industrial average plunged to 1844.97, a 404 pont decline in the leading market indicator.
The last time the Dow inex touched the 1840 level was in November, 1986.

American Telephone and Telegraph Co said it suported the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) plan to establish price ceilings for ATT long-distance services as a replacement for current regulation.
The company was responding to an FCC proosal of August 4 that price caps replace the current rate-of-return regulation, which has been in place for the past 20 years.

ATT said vigorous competition in the long-distance industry has made obsolete rate-of-return, which stipulates tat a company can earn no more than a fixed rate -- currently 12.2 pct -- on its investment.
The company termed the price cap a "transitional step," and sad it hoped the FCC would support a program of regulatory oversight, which would consist of a streamlined tariff process.
AFG Industries Inc said its board authorized management to buy back up to four mln common shares, or 15.7 pct of te AFG stock outstanding, from time to time in the open market.
The company said the action ws taken in light of current market conditions.
It also said the repurchased shares will be returned to treasry for general corporate purposes and for use with stock option plans.
J.P. Morgan and Co Inc said third-quarter net income rose 3.6 pct to 219.2 mln dlrs, from 211.5 mln a year earlir, partly because of reduced loan-loss provisions and a lower income tax bill.

For the first nine months of the year, however, Morgan posted a loss of 140.8 mln dlrs, compared with a profit o 682.4 mln in the same period of 1986, because it set aside 875 mln dlrs in reserves in the second quarter against shaky third-world loans.
The provision for loan losses in the quarter was 20 mn dlrs, down from 70 mln a year earlier.
Morgan's tax bill was 52.4 mln dlrs in the quarter, down from 85. mln a year earlier, mainly because of benefits associated with the second-quarter loan-loss provision.
Net interest earnings fell to 474.3 mln dlrs from 526.5 mln as net yield narrowed to 2.71 pct from 3.13 pct and 1.3 billion dlrs of Brazilian loas remained on non-accrual.
Non-interest operating income was 296 mln dlr, up from 292.8 mln.
Net charge-offs halved to 16 mln dlr.
Expenses jumped 18 pct to 387.3 mln dlrs, with personnel costs accounting fr half of the increase.
The effect of the lower dollar o overseas costs was also a factor.
CCR Video Corp said it received an offer to enter into negotiations for <Intercep Investment Corp> o Vancouver, B.C., to acquire a controlling interest in the company through a tender offer.
CCR said the negotiations would determine the terms under which the CCR board could support an Intercp tender offer.
Additional details were not immediatly available.

Amoco Corp said its Amoco Fabrics Co will expand the capacity f its polypropylene carpet face yarn facility by 55 pct to support its successful penetration of the commercial and residential carpet markets.
It said the expansion of the plant in Andalusia, Ala., will bring Amoco's total face yarn capacity to nearly 14 mln pounds a year, with Andalusia capacity at 85 mln pounds.
Amoco Fabrics is part of Amoco Chemicals Co, the chemcal manufacturing and marketing subsidiary of Amoco Corp. Reuter 
<Island Telephone Co Ltd> said the previously announced two-for-one commo share split was approved by shareholders at the annual meeting.
Biogen Inc said the European Patent Office granted it a patent covering certain proteins used to produce a hepatitis B vaccine through genetic engineering techiques.

Robert Gottlieb, Biogen spokesman, said the company has licensed the vaccine on a nonexclusive basis to <Wellcome PLC>, the British pharmaceutical firm, and is discussing licesing with other companies.
Biogen said the patent gives it the right to exclude others from marketing hepatitis B vaccine in the 11 member countries of the European Patent Convntion.
Gottlieb said the company has also filed a patent in other markets, inclding the U.S.
The vaccine i in clinical tests.
Patents in the biotechnology field are particularly important as te company with an exclusive patent can reap large rewards.
Recently many of the prodcts of genetic engineering have become the target of patent lawsuits.
Merck and Co Inc <MRK> already sells a genetically engieered hepatitis B vaccine in the U.S. called Recombivax HB.
A subsidiary of <SmithKline Beckman Corp>, SmithKline Biologicals, based i Belgium, is selling a hepatitis B vaccine, called Engerix-B, in Belgium.
A SmithKline spokesman said the vaccine has also been formally approved in Switzerland and Luxembourg and has been authorized for market in a number o Far East countries.
Hepatitis B is a serious liver infection common in many parts of Africa and southeast Asia where about five pct to 15 pct of te population carry the virus.
In the U.S. about 200,000 new cass occur each year.
Last December the European Patent Ofice rejected Biogen's patent for alpha-interferon, which Biogen said it will appeal once it receives a formal written opinion fro the office.
A key U.S. House mmber said he opposed a Reagan administration plan to shift the cost of surveillance of futures exchanges to the private sector.
"I just think user fees are the wrong way o attack a problem of this sort," said Rep. Ed Jones (D-Tenn.), chairman of the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.

The White House budget office as asked the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, CFTC, to draw up a plan for transferring the three-mln dlr cost of monitoring futures trading to either exchanges, futures commission merchants or users of the markets.
CFTC Cmmissioner William Seale said the proposal was a move in the wrong direction.
"I would refer to see (surveillance) paid for through the appropriations process rather than through taxation of market participants," he said.
CFTC Chairman usan Phillips told the panel the commission was preparing the proposal, due to be completed April 15, at the request of the Office of Management and Budget.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the U.K. Was growing more impatient with Japanese trade barriers and warned that i would soon have new powers against countries not offering reciprocal access to their markets.
She told Parliament that the bid by the U.K.'s Cale and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L> to enter the Japanese telecommunications market was being regarded by her government as a test case.
"I wrote to the prime minister of Japan, Mr Nakasone, on the fourth of March to express our interest on the Cble and Wireless bid.
I have not yet ha a reply.
We see this as a test on how open the Japanese market really is," Thatche said.

Thatcher told Parliament that "shortly ... We shall have more powers than we have now, when, for example the powers under the Financial Services Act and the Banking Act become available, then w shall be able to take action in cases where other countries do not offer the same full access to financial services as we do."
Cable and Wreless is seeking a stake in the proposed Japanese telecommunications rival to Kokusai Denshin Denwa.
But the Japanese minister for post and telecommunications was reported as saying that he opposed Cable and Wireless having a managerial ole in the new company.
GenCorp said it plans to build a 50 mln dlr manufacturing facility in Shelbyville, nd.
The company said it will begin building the plant, where it will produce reinforced platic components for cars and trucks, this May with an expected completion date in mid-1988.
GenCorp said its DiversiTech General unit will opeate the plant through its reinforced plastics division.
"We believe the use of reinforced plastics in cars and trucks will grow," A. Wiliam Reynolds, GenCorp chairman and chief executive officer said as the reason for building the plant.
"Our investment in the Shelbyville plant reflects the confidence we have in the future o this product line," Reynolds added.
GenCorp said th plant will create 500 new jobs.
<Jones International Ltd> said it realigned several subsidiaries to accommodate corporate stategy.
Jones said ultimate control of the subsidiaries will remain unchanged under th realignment.
Jones said it will exchange approximately 97 pct of its holdings of the common stock o Jones Intercable Inc <JOIN> for Class A common stock of Jones Spacelink Ltd <SPLK>.
The company said the move will enable Spacelik to elect 75 pct of Intercable's directors.
In addition, Jones said 60 pct of the common stock of its subsidiary, <The Jones Grop Ltd>, will be exchanged for Class A common stock of Jones Spacelink Ltd.
Following the exchange, Jones International's ownership of Spacelink Class A voting stock will increase to approxiately 89 pct.

Jones International aid it will retain approximately two pct of the common stock and approximately four pct of the Class A common stock of Jones Intercable as well as the remaining 40 pct of the Jones Group stock.

ASLK-CGER Finance NV is issuing a 10 billion yen eurobond due April 10, 1994 with a 5-1/2 pct coupon and priced at 101-1/2 pc, lead manager IBJ International Ltd said.
The bonds are guaranteed by Belgian savings bank ASLK-CGER Bank and hae all been pre-placed.
They will be issued in denominations of one mln yen and liste in Luxembourg.
Fees comprise 5/8 pct for management and underwriting combined, wih a 1/8 pct praecipuum, and 1-1/4 pct for selling.
Pay date i April 10.
Canadian oil exports rose 20 pct in 1986 over the previous year to 33.96 mln cubic meters, while oil imports soared 25.2 pct t 20.58 mln cubic meters, Statistics Canada said.
Production, meanwhile, was unchanged from the previous year at 91.09 mln cuic feet.
Natural gas exports plunged 19.4 pct to 21.09 billin cubic meters, while Canadian sales slipped 4.1 pct to 48.09 billion cubic meters.
The federal agency said that in December oil production fell 4.0 ct to 7.73 mln cubic meters, while exports rose 5.2 pct to 2.84 mln cubic meters and imports rose 12.3 pct to 2.1 mln cubic meters.
Natural gas exports fell 16.3 ct in the month 2.51 billion cubic meters and Canadian sales eased 10.2 pct to 5.25 billion cubic meters.
Joseph Feshbach, chief market analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities, said the stock maket is poised to climb above Dow Jones Industrial 2500 level by June.
The Dow avrage is around 2380 today.

"Liquidity is the biggest fundamental factor in the market and money coming out of fixed income funds and flowing into equities will prpel the market sharply higher," Feshbach said, noting that the market's peak will occur in June.
Feshbach said that in early January he predicted that the Dow Jones Industrial average, the most closely watched market barometer, would reach te 2400 level by April and the 2500 level by June.
He said e is now even more optimistic, saying "the market is ready for a 150 point rise from current levels any day now."
Four new outsiders were appointed to the policy-making Council of the Lloyd's of London insurance maret, shifting the voting balance on the Council away from Lloyd's professionals, Lloyd's said.

It said in a statement the appointments of the new members, none of them previously involved in the insurance market, were made to comply with the core recommendation in the Neill report into regulation at Lloyd's, which was published on Januay 22.
The recommendation, one of 70 to iprove investor protection in the Lloyd's market, was to reduce the number of elected working members, Lloyd's professionals, from 16 to 12.

Simultaneously, the number of outsiders would be increased by four while the nmber of external Council members, usually Lloyd's investors without an active role in the market, would remain unchanged at eight.

Lloyd's said the four newly-appointed Council embers were barrister Elizabeth Mary Freeman, Sir Maurice Hodgson, non-executive chairman of British Home Stores Plc, Lloyd's Bank Plc chairman Sir Jeremy Morse, and Brian Pomeroy, an accountant who sat on the three-member Neill enquiry panel.
They replace the our Lloyd's professionals who resigned on April 4 after Lloyd's agreed to implement the recommendation.
The New York Coffee, Sugar and ocoa Exchange (CSCE) elected former first vice chairman Gerald Clancy to a two-year term as chairman of the board of managers, replacing previous chairman Howard Katz.
Katz, cairman since 1985, will remain a board member.
lancy currently serves on the Exchange board of managers as chairman of its appeals, executive, pension and political action committees.
he CSCE also elected Charles Nastro, executive vice president of Shearson Lehman Bros, as first vice chairman.
nthony Maccia, vice president of Woodhouse, Drake and Carey, was named second vice chairman, and Clifford Evans, president of Demico Futures, was elected treasurer.

A majority of European Community (EC) member states are either against or have strong reservations over a tax on both imported and domesticall-produced oils and fats proposed by the European Commission, senior diplomats said.

They said a special committee of agricultural experts from EC member states had voiced strong objections over the measure during a meeting chrged with preparing the ground for the annual EC farm price-fixing which begins next Monday.
They added that only France and Italy had indicated they would support the Commission proposal which would lead to a tax initially o 330 Ecus per tonne during the 1987/88 price round.

Rowntree Mackintosh Plc is seeking a 200 mln stg, five year multiple option facility, of which 150 mln stg will be commited, and a 200 mln stg commercial paper program, County Natwest Capital Markets Ltd said as arranger.
The facility includes options for sterling acceptances, multi-currency advances, sterling ad dollar notes via tender panels and there is also a sterling swingline.
The committed portion arries a facility fee of five basis points and a margin of ten.
A 2-1/2 basis oint utilisation fee is payable on drawings of more than half the committed portion.
The 00 mln stg commercial paper program will include a dollar option, County Natwest said.
A County Natwest oficial said the facility, launched earlier this week, seemed to be progressing well in syndication.

Private investors eagerly snapped up shares of Consolidated Rail Corp, the biggest initial stock offering in U.S. history, but some analysts warned they could be in a for a bumpy ride at least i the near term.
Analyst James Voytko of PaineWebber Group Inc believes some investors who bought at the offering price o 28 dlrs will be tempted to sell.
The shares climbed 3-3/8 to 31-3/8 b midday.
Voytko said profit-taking pressure could become severe at th 35 dlr level.
Others say Conrail, a combination of previously bankrupt railroad, has good long term potential.
"Conrail is in the best position to weather the current tremendous price competition in the transportation industry in general," said Dew Robertson, analyst at Atlantic Systems Inc, a research firm.
"It will survive and do damn well," said another analyst wh declined to be identified.
He noted that Conrail's freight trains serve heavy industry including steel and autos in major U.S. cities in the northeast US. and midwest.
Robertson noted that Conrail's traffic s less dependent on coal than other railroads based in the east.
He expects Conrail to earn 2.85 dlrs pr share in 1987.
Voytko of PaineWebber sees another problem six months down the road when more than 10 mn Conrail shares will be distributed to current and former employees.
He believes many of these indivdiuals will b inclined to sell the stock.
Robertson says it's hard to determine the psychology of the average employe, but even if a lot of stock is sold, it would would not hit the market as one bg block.
He doubts it would create a big downwar push on the price.
"It's hard to call," said the analyst who requeste anonymity.
In some cases employe loyalty may motivate individuals to keep their shares, e said.
Steven Lewins, analyst for Citicorp Investment Management, believes the key to Conrail's long term outlook is how t is able to invest surplus cash.
He expects Conrai to earn 3.00 dlrs per share this year, flat in comparison with 1986, but by 1991 the picture could change dramatically if money not needed for rail operations is invested wisely.
By 1991, earnings could reach 4.30 dlrs per share, Lewins said, factoring in reinvestment of free cash low at conservative rates.
He believes motor freight will be one area of diversification Conral will explore.

Elizabeth Dole, U.S. Secretary of Transportation, whose department was responsible for the sale of Conrail, noted that Conrail is required o reinvest in its rail system and cannot defer necessary maintenance.

For the historic offering of Conrail shares, Dole visited the Ne York Stock Exchange and was photographed on the floor wearing a locomotive engineer's cap, which she presented to Stanley Crane, Conrail chairman and chief executive.
The U.S. government is expected to receive about 1.8 billion dlrs for Conrail after factoring in underwriting fees and other adjustments.
The possibility of a recession at some time i the next five years is another issue troubling some investors.

Lewins says revenue-ton-miles, which he believes will climb from 68.7 mln miles last year to 69.5 mln ths year and 70.5 mln in 1988, will grow to 71.5 mln in 1991, but in a recession year, perhaps 1989, the figure could dip to 64.2 mln.
On the revenue side, he believes revenue per ton-ile will be 4.7 cts in 1991, little changed from present levels and exactly the same as in 1981.
"Their basic business isn't going anywhre," he says, explaining why emphasizes investment of cash flow.
Voytko thinks Conrail can remain profiable in a recession year.
He points out his firm, PaineWebber, is not forecasting a recession in any specific year, but as an example a 1990 recesion of modest degree could knock earnings down to 2.20 dlrs per share.
He estimated 3.00 dlrs per shre this year and 3.35 dlrs next year.
His 1988 figure reflects mostly a lowering of the tax rae to 34 pct from 40 pct this year.
Voytko believes the Conrail shares meit purchase at the 26 dlr level.
Goldman, Sachs and Co was lead manger for the offering.
A total of 148 firms took par in the U.S. syndicate.
Gould Inc said it has completed the sale of its French battery business, Compagie Francaise D'Electro Chimie, to a group of investors including the unit's employees and <GNB Inc> of Minnesota.
ould did not disclose terms of the deal.
ould said the move is part of its previously announced plan to divest assets unrelated to its computer and electronics businesses.
MS Enhancements Inc said it has obtained a ten mln dlr line of credit from Bank of the West, effective immediately.
he credit line will be used in part to fund additional growth, including research and development of new products, the company said.

Exovir Inc aid the European Patent Office notified it that its application covering combinations of nonionic surfactants and all forms of interferon has been approved and a patent will be issued in about six months.
Exovir s completing trials of a gel combining alpha interferon and nonoxynol-9, an antiviral surfactant, as a treatment for genital and oral herpes and genital warts.
he gel was given a U.S. patent in 1985.
It said clinical tests will begin shortly to test whether te gel is effective in preventing transmission of the AIDS virus when used with a condom.
U.S. automakers are expected to build 167,236 cars this week, u from 133,067 in the same year-ago period, said the trade publication Ward's Automotive Reports.
t said year-to-date car production would reach 2,012,093 compared to 2,126,954 in the 1986 period.
omestic truck production for the week was seen as rising to 70,033 from 58,506.
ear to date, it was projected at 937,163 compared to 882,230 in the 1986 period.
ircle K Corp said its chairman, Karl Eller, will buy 750,000 shares of Circle K common stock from the company's founder and Vice Chairman, Fred Hervey, in a private transaction.

It said if several of Pan Am Corp's <PN> one-stop flights to Buenos Aires were terminated in Rio de Janeiro, Eastern could add four non-stp flights from the U.S.

First Wisconsin Corp said it plans to aquire Shelard Bancshares Inc for about 25 mln dlrs in cash, its first acquisition of a Minnesota-based bank.
First Wisconsin said Shelard is the holding cmpany for two banks with total assets of 168 mln dlrs.
First Wisconsin, which had assets at yearend f 7.1 billion dlrs, said the Shelard purchase price is about 12 times the 1986 earnings of the bank.

IMRE Corp said it completed a private placement of about 400,000 shares of its securites with a group of European institutions for 2.5 mln dlrs.
The company said proceeds will be used for working capital and to implement the companys business plan.

The United Auto Workers struck General Motors Corp's truck and bus plants at Pontiac, Mich, General Motors said

General Motors' truck and bus group failed to reach an agreement on local issues with UAW Local 594 by the union's deadline of noon today, causing a strike by 9,000 hourly workers at the facility the company said.
General Motors said it was "eager" to continue meetng with union officials on the dispute.
It was not immediately clear whether contract talks wee continuing at the facility.
General Motors spokesman Frank Cronin sid the three plants at Pontiac stopped working "as of noon today."
He said tlks will resume Friday at 1000 EST in Pontiac.
"We're hoping (he strike) will be of very brief duration," Cronin said.
Bus-manufacturing operations at one of he three plants--the Pontiac Central facility--are being sold to Greyhound Corp <G>, although GM will retain the facility.
Cronin said about 400 workers n the bus line will be laid off "whenever we fulfill production commitments" on the buses, "possibly in May."
The ontiac Central plant also makes medium- and heavy-duty trucks.
Assembly of the edium trucks is scheduled to move to Janesville, Wis., in 1990, Chronin said.
Heavy truck operations t the plant will be taken over by GM's joint venture with Volvo AB, and all vehicle assembly operations at the facility will eventually be ended, Chronin said.
The lant also has sheet metal operations, which are so far unaffected, he said.
The other two lants at Pontiac--Pontiac East and Pontiac West--make full-size pickups and sport utility vehicles.

Officials of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) said merging the agency with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) would not elp regulation of commodities and securities markets.
"I don't think that a merger would solve regulatory problems," CFTC chairman Susan Phillips told the House Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit an Rural Development.
"I think what does solve our problems would be working with other agencies in a strong capacity," she said in response o a question.
"We don't want agecies to trample on our jurisdiction either."
CFTC Commissioner Fowler West said, "We .. do not have the expertise to regulate securities markets.
I don't think he SEC has the expertise to regulate the futures markets."

Increased attention to price volatility in stock index futures markets and reports f alleged futures trading abuses have raised concerns Congress may adopt a radically different regulatory structure for securities and futures markets.

Rep. John Dingell (D-Mich.), cairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has jurisdiction over securities regulation, has said he will hold hearings on the questions of market volatility and alleged trading abuses.

The Polish government has backed down from some proposed price rises in the face of strong oppoition from trade unions, but has restated its commitment to economic reforms entailing tougher discipline and austerity measures.

Following a warning from the officially-backed OPZZ unions that sharp price hikes could spark confrontation, the government has agreed that food prices this year will rise a average 9.6 pct instead of the planned 13 pct.
A statement last night said the government had "partially accepted" demands for the protection of the low-paid and agred to extend some social benefits.
But Polish leader Wojciech Jaruzelski, at a separate meeting yesterday, sharply criticised the slow pace of refoms.
He told an economic commission that tougher discipline and austerity measures, greater efficiency and initiative should replace waste, re tape and inertia.
He announced cost-cutting meaures affecting central administrative bodies.
OPZZ economic expert Zbiniew Kochan welcomed the move on food prices.
"This decrease was considerabl," Kochan told Reuters today.
"Also important is the fact that the government admitted we were right and agreed to consult us over prices from now on," e added.
The communique made no mention of curbs on wage increases, or price riss in sectors including transport and energy.
The authorities have said prices could go up by as much as 26 pct as state subsidies are sharply reduced in an effort to mak the market more free and to improve efficiency.
The OPZZ unions are officially recognised by the government and replaced the Solidaity movement suppressed under martial law.
They claim a memberhip of seven million.
Western diplomats said today the climb-down o food prices was a limited concession.
"This is a small price to pay if they can push through the other price rises," one said adding that fuel and energy rises would have a more significant effect.

He noted that there had been a concerted media campaign to prepare people for price rises, including a major article in a mass-circulation women's magazine, "clearly aimed at those who do the shopping," he said
Other articles in the official press this week have focused on coal, which sells to both industrial an private consumers at far less than either the production or export costs.

Countering scepticism from opposition sources and former Solidarity activists as to OPZZ's role, Kochan said "It was definitey not a question of gaining credibility, but true concern for people's living standards."
Deputy Prime Minister Jozef Koziol said the authorities' main aim was not to harm workers' livin standards.
But he was also quoted by the official PAP news agency as saying the government had to take current economic realities into account

A proposal by the Cmmodity Futures Trading Commission, CFTC, to raise federal limits on futures speculative positions for certain agricultural commodity contracts would not reverse a decline in liquidity in those markets that started in 1981, two CFTC commissioners said.

Commissioners William Seale and alo Hineman told a House Agriculture subcommittee a recent proposal that would have the effect of raising deferred month speculative position limits on several agricultural commodity contracts would not substantially increase liquidity in those months.

"I seriously oubt that increasing speculative limits will create a great deal of liquidity in the back months," Seale told the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.

Analysts have attributed much f the liquidity squeeze to a 1981 tax law change, which by changing the treatment of so-called straddles limited the ability of futures commission merchants to roll positions forward for tax purposes.
CFTC Chairman usan Phillips said only that the commission would take into account Congress' recommendation that federal speculative limits be raised.
The Chicago oard of Trade and the MidAmerica Commodity Exchange have expressed concern that the CFTC plan would decrease spot month limits for certain of their contracts.

World saborne iron ore imports will fall sharply by the year 2000 with declining imports to the EC and Japan only partially offset by increased demand from South East Asia, a report by Ocean Shipping Consultants said.
The report pedicts annual world seaborne iron ore imports of 267.7 mln tonnes by 2000 versus 312.4 mln tonnes in 1985.

It estimates that total bulk sipping demand from the iron ore sector will fall by almost 10 pct, or 200 billion tonne miles, with shipping demand associated with the coking trade down about 17 pct or 130 billion tonne miles.
The report ees EC imports falling to 91.7 mln tonnes in 2000 from 123.6 mln in 1985 with Japanese imports falling to 89 mln from 124.6 mln tonnes.
Imports to outh East Asia are seen rising to 58.6 mln from 32.6 mln tonnes in 1985.
It predicts that C steel production will fall to 109 mln tonnes in 2000 from 135.7 mln in 1985 with Japanese production falling to 92 mln from 105.3 mln.
South Korea and aiwan are expected to double their output to 40 mln tonnes with Chinese production increasing by 25 mln tonnes to 80 mln, it added.

Dun and Bradstreet Corp said business failures in February increased 10.8 pct, t 5,390, from 4,864 in February 1986.
"The national level of business failures continues to be driven upward by subtantial increases in the oil and agricultural states," Dun said.
Dun said that of the nine U.S. Bureau of the Census regions, three reported a decrease in the number of failures and two ha gains of less than 3.0 pct.
The largest increase was reported in the Wst South Central states, Dun said, with business failures rising 47.8 pct, to 1,218.
The East South Central states posted a 44 pct rise, to 298, Dun said, while the West North Central states recorded a 27.3 pc gain, to 489.
The greatest decline, Dun reported, was registered y the Middle Atlantic states, down 8.2 pct in February, to 324.
The Pacific states also reported a large decline in failing businsses, off 6.8 pct, to 1,028, Dun said.
In the smokestack region of the East North Central states, thre was a negligible decline of 0.6 pct, to 794, Dun said.
Dun said the Mountain states recorded a gain in business failues of 1.5 pct, to 530. Business failures in the New England states rose 23.5 pct, to 105.
By industry segment, Dun said the largest gain was recorded b the agricultural, forestry and fishing sector, up 62.7 pct, to 345.
Year to date, Dun said business failures rose to 11,004, a increase of 5.3 pct over 1986.

Federal Reserve oard Governor Robert Heller said the banking system could be strengthened by permitting formation of financial services holding companies involved in areas like banking, insurance, real estate and securities.

In a speech prepared for delivery in New York to the Bank and Financial Analysts' Association, Heller said, "I believe that increased diversification along geographic and product lines is the key to strengthening the Amercan banking system."

He said he supported the idea of financial services holding companies advocated by the Association of Bank Holding Companies in which regulation of various bank, thrift, insurance, investment, securities ad real estate subsidiaries would be handled on functional lines.
"Limits would be placed on the extension of credit by the bank to the associaed institutions, and all transactions would have to be on an arms-length basis," Heller said.
Measures would be necessary to avoid abuse of the banks' special position by such holing companies or subsidiaries.
Heller said he "would require the holding company to serve as a 'source of strengt' to the bank by making a commitment to maintain the bank's capital.
"In other words, the bank would not be allowed to fail as long as the holding company has a positive ne worth."
Heller also said commercial enterprises should be permitted to own a financial services holding company, again with the provision that capitl would flow to the financial enterprise if necessary.

Heller aid the effects of these actions "would be banks that are at least as strong as the corporations holding them" in which customer deposits were assured while any incentive to "loot the bank" was removed.
uch diversification would give access to national and international financial services to corporations across the United States.
Heller said that would mean "the steady decline of America's banks in the world financial league tables woul be arrested" by permitting them to become more competitive.

The hairman of the CFTC, Susan Phillips, said she does not expect the CFTC to restrict dual trading or to intervene in the quarterly expiration of stock index futures and their options.
"At this time we have no plans to reexamine our policy (on dual trading)," se told the House Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.
She said it would not be appropriate to ban dual trading because it would decreas market liquidity.
Dual trading refers to the ability of futures commission merchants to trade for their on as well as their clients' accounts.
Exchange rules pohibit a broker from attempting to benefit from the market impact of a client's order by trading on his own account before placing the client's order.
CFTC has rquired all futures exchanges by July 1 to have implemented audit trails permitting the reconstruction of all trades to the nearest minute.
The ove was designed in part to discourage abuse of dual trading.
The board f directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has proposed limiting but not banning dual trading in the Standard and Poor's 500 stock index future pit.
Phillips indicated he CFTC would not move beyond requiring improved audit trails in its effort to allay concerns about dual trading abuses.
"It ould be inappropriate at this point until we see how the audit trail will work," she said in response to a question.

On triple-witching, hillips said recent experiments by markets to quell price fluctuations have been quite successful and that users of securities and derivative instruments were still learning how to deal with the quarterly phenomenon.
Triple-witching efers to the simultaneous expiration of stock index futures, options on those futures and options on certain individual stocks.
he CFTC chairman noted the commission has heightened surveillance of markets on triple-witching day.
We aren't sure any other regulatory changes are needed at this point," Phillips said.

erms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

The Reagan administration said the national crisis in liability insurance eased during the past year as the insurance industry's profits more than doubled to 11.5 billion dlrs, but som problems still persist.
An administration working group, in an update of its report a year ago, found tha insurance premiums generally have stabilized, but at high levels, as the crisis has abated.

After severe financial difficulties in 1984 and 1985, the insurance industry's rate of return last year recovered to the same level as the performace of U.S. corporations in general the group said in a 98-page study.

While the crisis has eased, the study found that liability insurance will likely remain expensive and continue to be difficult to obtain for some lines of coverage and fr some sectors of the American economy.
Some types of insurance, especially associated with environmental liability, remain unavailable for many companies at ay price, it said.
The increased availability and the price stability for insurance the past year has been accompanied b higher deductibles, lower coverage limits and additional policy restrictions, the study said.

The administration last year unveiled a wide range of recommendations aimed at dealing with the crisis, including limits on punitive damages and awards for pain, suffering and mental anguish at 100000 dlrs.
Attorney General Edwin Meese told a news conference today that the administration still supports state effrts to place limits on damage awards and to enact other reforms of the tort laws.
Assistant Attorney General Richard Willard denied charges by consumer groups that the insurance crisis was caused by industry collusion to raise rates in violation of th antitrust laws.
Willard, the head of the working group, sid excessive jury damage awards was the main reason for the insurance liability problem.

Former Secretary of the Treasury Robert Anderson, whom Dwight Eisenhower once said deserved to be president, pleaded guily to income tax evason charges and illegally running an offshore bank.
Anderson, declaring that he was "deeply regretful," admitted to evading tax on 127,500 dlr in undeclared income.
Much of the money was paid to him for lobbying for controversial South Korean evangelist Sun Myung Moons Unification Church.
The 77-year-old Anderson was President Eisenhower's treasury secretary from 1957 to 1961 ad a prominent businessman afterwards.
In his memoirs, Eisenhower said Anderson deservd to be president.
Standing before Federal Court Judge Edmund Palmieri, Anderson, who faces up to 1 years in jail, said he had recently undergone two operations and treatment for alcoholism.
The judge set May 7 for sentencing and U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani declard the government would ask that Anderson be sent to jail.
According to the indictment, Anderson was a prinicipal of the Commercial Exchange Ban and Trust Ltd of Anguilla in the British West Indies for two years ending in 1985.
During that time, gvernment prosecutors said the bank conducted operations in New York city but failed to register with state and federal banking authorities.
Depositors ave lost at least 4 mln dlrs.
Anderson pleaded gulity nly for the tax year 1984 but admitted other tax transgressions for the previous year and faces civil fines for both years.
Among other things, e said he received 80,000 dlrs in 1983 from a shell corporation for lobbying for the Unification Church.
The money was iven to him as a no-interest loan repayable in 1990 but the government said it should have been reported as income.

Several U.S. House members urged the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, CFTC, o strengthen its proposed rules governing the sale of foreign futures and options in the U.S. "I'm from the state of Illinois, and we don't want to see Chicago's futures markets become the automobile or textile industry of the 1980s," Rep. Lane Evans (D-Ill.) told a hearing of the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Conservation, Credit and Rural Development.

U.S. exchanges have complained that th proposed regulations would give sellers of foreign futures an edge over domestic futures sellers because they would be subject to less rigorous requirements, especially in the area of capital.

Phillips said the commission has no way of requiring foreign markets to implement the same regulatory safeguards as in the U.S., but that the proposed rules would ensure marketing of foreign futures an options conform to U.S. requirements.
"If people want to enter into these (foreign) markets, they know they will nt have the same regulations," she said.
Phillips said the commission would consider changes in its proposal to require segregation o customer accounts and clarify the treatment of contracts not traded on foreign exchanges.

Brazilian President ose Sarney will reshuffle part of his cabinet next month but will preserve his finance minister, a presidential source said.
The cabinet rshuffle, expected since the resignation of Minister of Planning Joao Sayad eight days ago, is due to take place within two to three weeks, the source said.

British Petroleum Co Plc does not intend to raise the price of ts planned 70 dlr per share offer for the publicly held 45 pct of Standard Oil Co, BP Managing Director David Simon said.
"We don't seen this as any proressive bidding game," he told reporters at a news conference.
BP now owns 5 pct of Standard's stock.

Simon said BP had carefully considered the amount of its planned bid nd he quoted an oil analyst, whom he would not identify, as saying BP's careful evaluation means the company is not going to raise its offer.
"I think that (a increase) would be totally wrong.
I think the price is very fair and i is much to early to speculate about ligigation," he said.
"Let's wait and see ho the offer runs."
Another official declined to speculate under what circumstances BP might raise it bid.

The BP official said the 70 dlrs a share offer is 7.2 times Standard's 1986 cash flw and 56 pct above an independent evaluation of the company's assets, including the value of its oil, natural gas liquids and natural gas reserves.
He said he price Royal Dutch/Shell Group <RD> <SC> paid for publicly held Shell Oil Co shares in 1985 was 5.1 times cash flow.
The BP oficial also said the 70 dlr bid is a 40 pct premium over Standard's stock price over the past year.
BP Group Teasurer Rodney Chase said more than half to as much as two-third's of the 7.4 billion dlrs BP needs for its offer will come from existing sources.
The est will be financed by new debt.
BP will raw in cash from its operating companies around the world and is also arranging a five billion dlr line of credit, he explained.
The company's ebt to equity ratio will rise 11 or 12 percentage points from the current 33 pct if the offer is completed, Chase said.
But the ratio will be back below 40 pct within 12 months, h added.
Chase also said 50 to 60 pct of Standard Oil's publicly held shares are held b financial institutions.
Simon said Standard's board was informed of the offer on March nine and has been consideing it since that time.
He said BP does not expect any regulatory problems that would delay completion of the acquisition
"We have informed Washington of our intentions and we've already been an integral part of ownershp of U.S. oil reserves," he pointed out.

Simon said there is a good chance that current world oil prices of about 18 dlrs a barrel could be maintained, and that the more stale market is due mostly to changes in policy in Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members to control oil production.
"We think there are signals that current conditions are more favorable than the have been for sometime," Simon said.
"We have hopes for greater stability, but we do not see prices goig much higher," he added.
British Petroleum Plc's plan to pay .4 billion dlrs for less than half of Standard Oil Co has signalled higher values in the U.S. oil patch, analysts said.

"I think that BP's bid is a very strong affirmation and clear signal that they have confidence in the U.S., and they think the barrel of oil in the ground is going to go higher," said Sanford Margoshes of Shearson Leman Brothers Inc. BP earlier today said its U.S. unit planned to tender at 70 dlrs per share for the 45 pct of Standard it does not already own.
"It's a 7.4 billion dlr price that (shows) OPEC has wn the war and oil prices are not going to crack," said Prescott, Ball and Turben analyst Bruce Lazier.
"Behind that is a huge implication for the rest of te energy issues out there in the stock market, particularly those that are acquisition targets," Lazier said.
One of those mentioned by Lazier was USX Corp, an energy-steel cncern which had been courted by investor Carl Icahn and drew the attention of Australian Robert Holmes a Court last year.
Rumors cotinue to swirl around its stock.
Margoshes said he does not fresee major U.S. oil firms falling into takeover situations for several years, with the exception of possibly Amerada Hess Corp <AHC>.
He said most of the mjors found partners in the last round of matchmaking which ended two years ago, and others restructured to the point that they have become unattractive.
U.S. oil socks rallied in response to the offer.

Chevron Corp <CHV> jumped 1-1/8 to 58-7/8, ad Texaco <TX> climbed 1/4 to 37-3/4.

Standard Oil's stock was up 6-1/4 in heay trading to 71-1/8.
Earlier in the session it had bee at a high of 72-1/4.
Wall Street has speculated British Petroleum may boost its offer by several dlr per share, but the company maintained it would not raise the 70 dlr bid.
British Petroleum stock ros 2-1/4 to 59-5/8.
Analysts said the fact British Petroleum made such a bid in the firt place indicates that the British oil giant has changed its outlook for the oil industry.
Analysts said last year British Petroleum held one of the more bearish positins on oil prices.
"They said the real price of oil would stay at 15 dlrs (a barrel) for several years, and I think they beat a hasty reteat from that point of view," Margoshes said.
"They are mre appropriately today looking more optimistically.
I believe they are looking at 18 dlrs (long-term)...also in their heart of hearts they believe that will be exceeded," Magoshes said.
The U.S. benchmark crude West Texas Intermediate was trading today around 18.60 drs per barrel.
Analysts said British Petroleum might have been able to buy up the rest of Standard Oil for about 50 dlrs per share when oil price were falling last year.
They said Standard Oil's brightest asset is its slightly more than 50 pct ownership of the Alaskan Prudhoe Bay oil field
Analysts also said the company has other interess in the Alaskan North Slope.
Analysts said the Standard investment is extremely attractive to BP because the U.S. is te largest oil market and has hard-to-replace reserves.
"I think it just fits in with their long-range plans to increase their position i the U.S. market," Dean Witter analyst Eugene Nowak said.
Analysts said it also raises BP's visibility ahead of the British government's announced disposal o 31.7 pct of BP stock.
The U.K. government said it would dispose of th holding sometime in the year beginning April one.

After acquiring all of Standard, most of BP's reserves would be in the U.S., but only about six pct of its stock is held in the U.S. "The only way they can sell all tht stock is to move it into the United States.
No other market can handle all that stock," sad L.F. rothschild analyst Rosario Ilacqua.
In 1986, Standard Oil had net losses of 345 mln dlrs on revenues of 10.02 billion dlrs, compred to a profit the year earlier of 308 mln dlrs on revenues of 13.82 billion dlrs.
Federal eserve Board governor Robert Heller said that the dollar's current level is appropriate but declined to comment on widespread market reports of concerted central bank intervention this week.
The dollar is stable again...
The urrent level is the appropriate level," Heller told reporters after a speech to a meeting of financial services analysts.
He aid last month's six-nation currency accord in Paris did not include target ranges for the dollar in an "academic way."
Heller also said that it was too early to determine whether the parties to the six-nation accord were taing appropriate steps to carry out the longer-term economic adjustments agreed to in Paris.
"Clearly, they've not been implemented yet... No one expects implmentation within a week or two," he said.
Earlier today, U.S. Treasury assistant secretary told a Senate baking subcommittee that he did not believe that West Germany and Japan have yet carried out their international responsibilities.

The U.S. General Accounting Offic said generic commodities certificates cost the U.S. government in total Commodity Credit Corp outlays 107 mln to 653 mln dlrs more than cash payments through February, 1987.

However, GAO Senior Associate Director Brian Crowley, in testimony prepared for delivery to the Senate Agriculture Committee, said short-term commodity storage cost savings related to the use of payment-in-kind certificates could be rom about 169 mln 253 mln dlrs.
U.S. Agriculture Undersecretary Daniel Amstutz said the issuance of 8.5 billion dlrs of certificates in fiscal years 1986-88 could cost as much as 550 mn dlrs more than cash outlays.
In his prepared remarks to the Senate panel, Amstutz stressed that USDA was "very pleased with the success of using commodity certificates" and looked forwar to their continued use.

He said the cost of using certificates must be weighed against immediate benefits, including greater market liquidity, imprved market price competitiveness, higher farm income, improved debt situation and decreased carrying charges, especially pertaining to 1985 crop loans.
Crowley said future government storage costs would be reduce only if in the long run certificates led to a decrease in CCC-owned inventory.
"We believe that such a reduction, if it occurs, will not be large," Crowley sid.
Crowley also said that because certificate amounts are not included in the federal budget's outlay totals at the time of issuance, they could "lessen the usefulness of the buget."
Crowley conceded that certificates help frmers avoid storage costs, give them marketing flexibility and enhance farmers' incomes.
He also said certificates have beefited the grain industry by giving it easier access to CCC-owned grain at market prices.

ank of England Governor Robin Leigh-Pemberton said the Paris pact agreed between six leading industrialised nations set no nominal exchange rate targets.

Leigh-Pemberton said in oral evidence to a select committee that "we did not swap numbers - we reached an understanding" on how t cooperate towards stabilizing currencies at around their current levels.
He said the accord had brought Britain into a form of joint currency float - but on which let it still purse an independent monetary policy.
"I would concede that, since the Louvre Accord, we are acting as if we are in somethin," Leigh-Pemberton said.
"The Louvre and Plaza accords show there is a very effective role for the (Group of) seve central banks to operate together" towards stabilising exchange rates," Leigh-Pemberton said.
He did not mention this week's intervention by central banks to support the dollar, after markets decided to est the accord.
Leigh-Pemberton said that "the effectiveness of this (cooperation) is actually larger than many of us had thought in th pre-Plaza days" before September 1985.
e did not indicate what exchange rate levels were broadly sought by the six nations, and noted that "we are more effective in our agreement if we can leave the markets guessing."
e did not indicate what exchange rate levels were broadly sought by the six nations, and noted that "we are more effective in our agreement if we can leave the markets guessing."
Leigh-Pemberton said that, in principle, the Bank of England favoured full EMS memberhip for sterling, provided such a move did not endanger U.K.
Asked whether he wanted to see U.K. Interest rates lower, he said "the two half point cuts (this month in banks' base lending rates) have been appropriate up untl now."
Leigh-Pemberton said he preferred a "cautious step-by-step approach" to reducing short term interet rates, not least because "we have a potential problem with inflation."
Underlying U.K. Inflation was currently around 4.0 pct, "one of the highest" among industrialised nations he added.

Leigh-Pemberton said the Bank of England had not wanted base rates to fall before the unveiling of the 1987/88 budget on March 17, but he said pressure from financial marets for such a move had proved irresistible.
Base rates are nw at 10 pct.
Regarding sterling's relationship with oil, Leigh-Pemberton said that the pound could be seen being undervaued overall.

He said the current oil price of some 18 dlrs a barrel might suggest a level of 74 on the Bank of England's sterling index, when compared with the indx's level before oil prices dropped from around the 30 dlr level.
The index, base 1975, closed here today at 72.1 unchanged from the previous close.

Jorge Cardenas, anager of Colombia's coffee growers' federation, said he did not believe any important decisions would emerge from an upcoming meeting of the International Coffee Organization (ICO).
The ICO eecutive board is set to meet in London from March 31 and could decide to call a special council session by the end of April to discuss export quotas.
"It's going to be a rutine meeting, an update of what has been happening in the market, but it's unlikely any major decisions are taken," Cardenas told journalists.
Earlier this month, talks in Lndon to re-introduce export quotas, suspended in February 1986, ended in failure.

Colombian finance minister Cesar Gaviria, also talking to reporters at he end of the weekly National Coffee Committee meeting, said the positions of Brazil and of the United States were too far apart to allow a prompt agreement on quotas.
Brazil's coffee cief Jorio Dauster said yesterday Brazil would not change its coffee policies.
Cardenas said the market situation was getting clearer because the trade knew the projected output and stockpile levels f producers.
He said according to ICO statistics there was a shortfall of nine mln (60-kg) bags on the world market between October, the start of th coffee year, and February.

Federal Reserve Board chairman Paul Volcker said he opposes legislation to deny primary dealer status to firms frm countries that do not grant U.S. firms equal access to their government debt markets.
In a letter to House Banking Committee chairman Fernand St. Germain, Volcker warned that it could lead to retaliatin against U.S. firms already operating in other countries.
The committee approved the legislatin yesterday.
They said its impact would be felt only by Japanese firms designated as primary dealers in U.S. government securitie since other countries would meet the equal access rule.
"Even Japan, at which the proposal sems to be particularly aimed, has made a number of advances in opening its market to U.S. firms," Volcker said.

The legislation gives the administration six months to negotiate equal access for U.S. frms in the foreign government securities markets before the ban on foreign dealers in the U.S. would take effect.
Volcker said more progress could be mde by continuing negotiations without adopting the bill's more rigid approach.
An aide to Rep. Charles Schumer, he New York Democratic sponsor, said it is expected to pass in the House trade bill.

<Bank of Montreal> is cofident a solution will be found to Brazil's foreign debt problem and is not considering declaring its Brazilian loans non-performing, president Grant Reuber said.

Speaking to reporters after a speech to a Tronto business group, Reuber said: "I think at this stage it is really too early to say very much about (the Brazilian debt situation) but we're pretty confident that things will work out."
He declined to comment on when suc a settlement was likely.
Bank of Montreal had 1.98 billion dlrs in loans to Brazil as of las September 30, the most of any Canadian bank.
Brazil last month suspended interest payments o its 68 billion U.S. dlr foreign bank debt.
Asked if Bank of Montreal were considering declaring its Brazil loans non-performing, Reuber replied: "We haven't really got to that point because we don't think we wil have to face that issue."

Some bankers in the U.S. said earlier this week that slow progress in talks between Brazil and its major foreign lenders has increased the likeliood that U.S. banks will declare their Brazil loans non-performing at the end of the quarter.

Reuber told reporters the bank was still pondering its strategy regarding possible entry into the securities business after June 30 when baks and other financial institutions will be allowed full participation in the Ontario securities industry.
He said price would help determine if the bank formed its own securities unit or acquired an existing investment dealer, adding that asking prices for some dealers seem "fairly high.
Asked about plans for wholly owned Harris Bankcorp Inc, of Chicago, Reuber said Harris might consider acquiring more small community baks around Chicago.
"In addition, I think we are giving some consideration to the possibility of extension into other states," Reuber said of Harris, althogh he added that any such move was unlikely this year.

In his speech, focusing on current free trade talks between the U.S. and Canada, Reuber said failure to reach a deal would not represent a calamity for Canada but coud lower Canada's standard of living, raise unemployment and reduce the country's world trading influence.

USX Corp chairman David Roderick said the company had ended talks with British Petroleum Co Plc <BP> about the possible sale of some energy assets an said USX has no immediate restructuring plans for its oil businesses.
"We have terminated our discussions," Roderick told Reuters after a speech to th Petroleum Equipment Suppliers Association here.
He said US was not conducting talks with any other possible buyer of its energy assets.
Earlier today, P said it planned to offer 70 dlrs per share for the Standard Oil Co's <SRD> publicly held stock.

USX said in December th company had held formal discussions with BP about the potential sale of some of its overseas oil assets and USX had received expressions of interest from a half dozen other oil companies.
Roderick, in response to a question, said USX had no immediate plans to restructure its Marathon Oil Co, or Texas Oil and Gas orp.
He said US also did not plan to sell any of its 49 pct interest in the giant Yates Field in west Texas.
"W want to maintain our production in the Yates Field during these difficult times," Roderick added.
In response to a question, Roderick also said he did not know whether Australian investor Robert Holms a Court was accumulating USX stock.
In recent days, traders have suggested Holmes a Cour was buying additional shares.
Roderick said Carl Ichan, who terminated an eight billion dlr hostile takeover plan for USX in anuary, continued to hold a sizable interest in the company.
"Mr. Ichan still apparently ha 11.4 pct.
He hasn't bought any moe stock or sold any," Roderick said.
"He's a very satisfied shareholder right no.
I talk wih him monthly."
In his speech, Roderick predicted the fall in the value of the dollar would set the stge for the U.S. to solve its trade deficit problem which totaled 170 billion dlrs in 1986.
"I expect by the early 1990s the U.S. wil be running a net trade surplus," Roderick said.
"I think the worst is over and we cn look forward to stability and upward movement ahead."
However, he USX chairman warned that European trading partners may resist the turn in the U.S. trade deficit.
"Some conomic discomfort must be transferred from the United States to our friends, trading partners and allies."

The Federal Communications Commission voted at a meeting t ease a requirement that cable television firms must provide a signal-selector switch free of charge to all customers.

Moody's Investors Service Inc said it downgraded BanAmerica Corp and the unit BankAmerica Overseas Finance Corp but affirmed ratings of the units Bank of America N.T.
and S.A., Sefirst Corp and Seattle-First National Bank.

Moody's said the downgrade reflected its concern over prospects for material improement in the holding company's operating profitability in the medium term.
Cut were BankAmerica's senior debt to Ba-1 from Baa-3, subordinated debt t Ba-3 from Ba-1, preferred stock to B-1 from Ba-3 and commercial paper to Not-Prime from Prime-3.
BankAmerica is the second-largest bank holding company in the U.S. Moody's reuced the subsidiary BankAmerica Overseas Finance's senior debt to Ba-1 from Baa-3 and subordinated debt to Ba-3 from Ba-1.
That debt i guaranteed by the parent.

The rating agency also cited the holding company's continuing high level of problem assets, includig significant exposure to Latin American debtor countries, that will continue to pressure profitability.
However, Moody's noted that BankAmerica Corp remains liqid and owns considerable marketable assets.

Moody's said it affirmed the ratings of the Bank of America unit because of that bank's franchise value, significant core deposit base and an expectation of regulatory support if furher stresses develop.

The agency confirmed Bank of America's Baa-1 long-term rating and Prime-2 short-term rating, as well as Seafirst's Ba-1 senior debt and Seattle-First's short and long-term ratings of Baa-1 and Prime-2 respectvely.

Debt securities of major U.S. banks came under light selling pressure in secondary trading on the heels of Standard and Poor's Corp's downgrade of six money center banks late yesterday, analyst and traders said.
But they described market response as muted because the S and P action came a no surprise.
Besides, many participants had already shied away from bank issues following Brazil's suspension of interes payments last month, traders added.
"The downgrades were expecte for some time.
In fact, you can argue that S and P is lagging the market," commented oe trader.
On February 20, Brazil said it would suspend interest payments on about 68 billion dlr owed to foreign commercial banks.
o date was established for the renewal of payments.

In its action, Standard and Poor's cited he exposure to major Latin American debtor countries of Chase Manhattan Corp <CMB>, Chemical New York Corp <CHL>, Irving Bank Corp <V> and Manufacturers Hanover Corp <MHC>.

The rating agency lso downgraded Mellon Financial Corp <MEL> and Security Pacific Corp <SPC>, but said this reflected higher non-performing assets and weaker operating results rather than the international debt problem.
"The S and P downgrades were a non-evet," a trader said.
"Anyone who was caught unaware was not o top of the situation anyway."
Said another trader, "People talked about this before and after S and P's announcment.
There was not much reaction among bank issues today, though prices are still belw par."
Still, market watchers said the action further undermied sentiment for bank paper.
Because of Brazil's suspension of interest payments, U.S. bank paper has undererformed such other sectors as utilities, telephones and industrials, analysts pointed out.

Even though Standard and Poor's affirmed the debt ratings of Citicorp <CCI>, Bankers Trust New York <BT>, Bank of Boston Corp <BKB> ad J.P. Morgan and Co Inc <JPM>, few buyers can be found for securities issued by those banks, traders said.
"Let's fae it.
Investors believe these banks are alo exposed to Latin and other debtor countries.
And investors buy on perceptions," sad one broker.

About the only bright spots in an otherwise dull banking sector of the secondary corporate market are U.S. regional banks and Japanese banks because investors perceive them as less exposed to the debtor nations, analysts pointed ou.
