oyal Bank of Canada Chairman Allan Taylor said Ottawa and the provinces risk weakening the country's financial system if they do not agree on a harmonized regulatory regime for financial institutions.
aylor also said it was vital that the federal government retain its existing powers under Ottawa's major new proposals to revamp the country's financial system.
Unless great care is taken now, in the detailed drafting and implementation of regulatory change, we could actually end up weakening our financial system," Taylor told a business luncheon.
Also, we must avoid costly and inefficient duplication of regulation and supervision between federal and provincial authorities," Taylor continued.

Earlier this week Federal Minister of State for Finance, Tom Hockin, said progress was being made with his provncial counterparts on the proposals that involve removing the traditional barriers separating the banking, securities and insurance sectors.
The governments are attempting to resolve a jurisdictional dispute ovr who regulates what under the new system.
The provinces have traditionally had authority in the securities fild while Ottawa oversaw the banking sector.
But the Chairman of Canada's largest bank stressed that Otawa should retain its regulatory powers to "preserve an efficient, competitive, national financial system."
On the free trade talks under way with the U.S., Talor said Canadian negotiators must insure banks have as much access to the American market as U.S. institutions are granted here.
He told a new conference later he was "reasonably confident" te Canadian side was making reciprocity in financial services an issue at the negotiating table.
International Cocoa Organization's, ICCO, council chairman Denis Bra Kanon continued wok towards a compromise plan on how the ICCO buffer stock should buy cocoa, consumer delegates said.
Consumer delegates said Bra Kanon had not formally presented the comprmise plan to producers and consumers, and it was unlikely he would do so before Friday, they said.
There was widespread confidence a result on the outstanding items cold be reached by Friday, when the council session is due to end, consumers said.
Bra Kanon completed bilateral consultations with several delegations today on te main sticking points in the draft buffer stock rules package, they said.

Certain delegations wanted further discussion on the amount of non-member cocoa the buffer stock will be permitted to buy, differentials fr different origin cocoas and limits on buffer stock purchases of nearby, and forward material, the delegates said.
The buffer stock working group finalized the remaining buffer stock rues, with only minor modifications to the original draft buffer stock package produced last week, the delegates said.
The ICCO council is due to eect a new executive director when it reconvenes Friday, producer delegates said.
Producers intend to present a single candidate for the post, and this is most likely to be Edouard Kouame from Iory Coast, they said.
Earlier, the existing executive director, Kobena Erbynn from Ghana, was expected to re-nominated, but he is now likely to withdraw, th delegates said.
The executive committee is due to meet Friday at 1100 GMT, with the council unlikely to reconvene until late Fridy, consumers said.
Many London equity dealers doubt whether the much publicised flood of Japanese investment int the U.K. Equity market will be as large as some analysts have forecast.
There has recently been much speculation that the Japanese would look towards the U.K. Stock market for investment opportunities on a much larger scale when the nw fiscal year begins next month.
Last October's reorganisation of the stock market, known as 'Big Bang', paved the wy for greater participation by overseas investors.
Some analysts believe the Japanese have earmared massive sums for investment in Europe.
Both the London and Tokyo markets have moved ahead strongly since the start o this year.
But London has lagged behind in real terms and therefore is now beginning t look like giving a better return on any funds that are reserved for equity investment.
Sterling's frmness also means there are profits to be made from the currency turn.
However, many equity ealers polled by Reuters think that the Japanese will shy away from London and continue to invest in instruments such as U.S. Government securities.
Even if they o diversify from their old stamping grounds they will head for the U.S. Equity market before they come to the European stock markets, one dealer predicted.

"The Japanese, although very aggressive in markets hat they know, tend to be more conservative in those they don't...Even if they do come to London in a big way they would tend to go more for the fixed interest gilt edged market rather than the more volatile equities," he added.
He also cited the forthcoming U.K. General election as another factor in keeping Far Eastern money out of th London stock market.
"The Japanese do not like too much uncertainty and a general election creates just the kind that will kep them on the sidelines," one trader said.
There are also doubts whether the Japanese would find the track records of U.K. Companies strong enough to mae them willing to invest heavily.
"Our industrial and manufacturing output may be looking better, but it must still look pretty uninspiring to the Japanese, one broker said.
Some market participants, however, are a little more bullish and do expect more, although nt a massive amount, of Far Eastern funds to come to London in the short term.

They point out that capital gains on U.S. Bonds, a market in which the Japanese are traditionally heavy players, have been eroded because of the fall in the U.S Dollar and this could prompt them to move funds out of the U.S.

But even those who are mildly bullish concede that Japanese investors on the London exchange would almost certainly confine themselves to longer term investment in 10 or 15 leaing 'blue chip' issues, which may include industrial giants such as ICI, Hanson Trust, British Petroleum, Glaxo and Unilever.
One analyst said he believed if there was such investment in blue chip issues, recently privatised companies such as British Gas and British Telecom could be left out in the cod.
He aid that with an election coming up, overseas investors would be worried that a Labour victory would bring a policy of re-nationalisation of such companies.
he Labour party has in the past said it would do this.
Some f the recent rise in U.K. Equities has anticipated an increase in Japanese buying in the near future.

French Agricultural Minister Francois Guillaume warned that France would flatly reject proposed reforms of the Europea Community, EC, cereals, sugar and oilseeds sectors, which he said would disrupt these markets.

The EC Commission's roposals to shorten the intervention period and lower monthly premiums for cereals and increase the financial burden on the sugar producers will also result in lower real prices for producers, he told farmers here.

"I give you my word that France, while it will not reject technical adjustments or serious discussion, will simply reply in the negative to these bad reforms," Guillaume told the annual conference of the country's major farm union, FNSEA (Federation Nationale des Syndicats Dexploitans Agricoles).
Community agricultural ministers are due to meet again Monday to try and agree a package of reforms to curb spiralling EC outpu and fix farm prices for 1987/88.
Relations between the government and farmers have become strained in Franc in recent months.
There have been sporadic but frequent demonstrations by famers protesting over sharp falls in meat and pork prices and further cutbacks in Community milk output.
But Guillaume's warning that he would reject reorganisation of the EC cereal and sugar markets -- France beng a major producer of both crops -- won him warm applause from the FNSEA's farmers.

His pledge to fight the EC proposals and push for the complete dismantling of the system of crss border taxes designed to smooth out currency differences known as Monetary Compensatory Amounts, MCA's, however, are unlikely to avoid further protests by producers.
Farm leader Raymond Lacombe said the union planned to go ahead with a series of major protests boh in France and abroad against the EC Commission's proposals to overhaul the farm sector.
"The Minister's proposals back up our determination to organise union action i the coming weeks," he told reporters, adding that this could also act in Guillaume's favour on a ministerial level.
Guillaume was head of the FNSEA for many years before being appoited farm minister last spring.
Lacombe refused to say whether the farmers felt that Guillaume was dong a good job as farm minister.

There have been certain advances on cutting production costs, reducing fiscal costs and awarding drought aid, but there are still areas where more cold be done such as on farmers' indebtedness, he said.
Guillaume told the conference the government will make available 2.4 billion frncs (396 mln dlrs) to help producers reduce milk output and to encourage older farmers to retire.
The government has already announced financial aid for the milk sector and it was not clear how much of the packae announced today was new aid, Lacombe said.
billion-dlr package of budget deficit reductions, half through unspecificed new revenues, to cut the 1988 deficit with a goal of alancing the budget in 1991 under a new law's target.

The committee went over a package of deficit reductions proposed by its chairman, Democrat Lawton Chiles of Florida, which he said would reach the 108-billion-dlr deficit in 1988 under the Gramm-Rudman budget law -- using President Reagan's economic estimates
Using the Congressional Budget Office estimates, which Congress usually relies on, would produce a deficit of 134 billion dlrs, Chils said.
Under the Chiles plan, deficits would be cut from anticipated levels by nearly 110 billion dlrs over four years t produce a 1991 balanced budget--the target of the Gramm Rudman law.
For 1988, the Chiles formula would cut the deficit by 37 billion dlrs, half through defence and non defence savings, the rest through revenues.
Defence would be cut nearly 69 billion dlrs.
Reagan proposed hiking outlays by soe 8 billion dlrs.
His non defence budget savings, including health, welfare, agricultural, government servies and reduced interest payments, amount to 11.6 billion dlrs.

Japanese-owned Honda American Manufacturing Co has exported the first U.S.-built cars ever sold overseas by a foreign-owned uto company, a Honda spokesman said.
The subsidiary of Honda Motor Co Ltd <HMC.T> of Japan shipped 200 of its popular Accord cars o Taiwan earlier this month, the spokesman said.
The company might also eventually send U.S.-made cars o Japan, he said.
The automaker said it would not boost its U.S. imports of cars from Japan, but instead make up demand fo its cars in the U.S. by increasing U.S. production.
The shipment to Taiwan was part of planned shipments to San-Yan Industries of Taiwan of about 2,000 Accords a year
Honda said it does not make Accords in Taiwan, and is prevented by Taiwanese import restrictions from shipping them ther from Japan.
Those restrictions were loosened this year to allow imports fom the United States.
Previously no imports of foreign-built cars were allowed, the spoesman said.
The Accords were built at Honda's U.S. car and motorcycle production facility at Marsville, Ohio.
Honda in the past has sent motrcycles from Marysville to Europe and Australia, and has sent cars to Canada.
Honda's U.S. output would have to e adjusted to meet changing U.S. demand, the spokesman said.
He quoted American Honda president Tetsuo Chino as saying, "Honda will not increase U.S. imports beyond the current level even if voluntary export restrictions on Japanese crs are lifted."
Analysts say there re few signs Japan's restrictions will be lifted.
Honda might decide by the end of this yer whether to expand its U.S. production, the spokesman said.
Honda said it is considering building either of is two new luxury models--the "Legend" or "Integra"--in the United States.
The Legend and Integra, to models of the company's Acura line, were introduced last March.
If the cars prove popular enough, one of thm could be built at the Ohio plant, or at a new factory, the spokesman said.
The spokesman said it is possible Acuras built i the United States could be shipped back to Japan.
However, he said that decision has not yet been made, and would follow the decision to build th cars in the United States.
If demand for either one of the two cars reaches 100,000 vehicles a year, Honda could decide t build the cars in the U.S., the company said.

Sales of the Integra through February have outpaced the Legend--35,768 against 29,824--but the spokesman said Honda expects sales to "lean more heavily toward Legend" this year because a two-door Legend has been added to th line.
No negotiated solution is in sight to a three-day-old national strike by the majority of Brazil's 700,000 bankworkrs, a spokesman for the National Federation of Banks said.
The private bankers would rather wait until next Monday, when a labour court is due to judge th legality of the stoppage, the spokesman said.
The bankworkers are demanding a 100 pct pay rise
"The workers are breaking an agreement signed six monts ago.
If the banks agreed to grant them 100 pct now, soon workers would have to e laid off and in some cases even banks would run out of business," the spokesman told Reuters.
He said only the state-controlled Banco do Brasil was on the verge of negotiating an accord with it workers.

A huge five billion dlr credit facility being syndicated or two subsidiaries of British Petroleum Co Plc <BP.L> should be well received in the market, given the relatively generous terms it carries, banking sources said.

The sources said they believe the committed our year revolving credit - the largest of its kind in the euromarkets - carries a facility fee of 1/8 pct and that drawings will be at 1/8 pct over the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor).
Morgan Guaranty Trust o of New York, which is arranging the financing in conjunction with its London operation, was not available to commment on the terms.
BP announced it was arranging the financing earlier toay as part of its planned tender offer for the 45 pct of Standard Oil Co that it does not own already.
In addition to the revolving credit, BP also i arranging a U.S. commercial paper program for an as yet undetermined amount, which will be supported by the revolver.
Bankers noted that the terms on the new facility compare extremely favourably to those on other short-term facilities for which pricing ha turned extremely fine due to competition for the mandates.
It also contrasts with the 116 pct fee BP paid on a recent 1.5 billion dlr refinancing of some existing debt.

Earlier today a Morgan Guaranty official, while declining to reveal th pricing on the facility said that banks would be "compensated fairly" since this is a special purpose facility which must be completed quickly, with the signing expected in about 10 days.
The facility is only being sydicated among BP's relationship banks and therefore has large individual commitments from the banks.
Lead managers are being recruited t the 200 mln dlr level, co-lead managers at 125 mln and managers at 75 mln.
However, bankers said that dspite the size it is likely the financing will get done quickly since banks will want to be seen as supporting the relationship.
The financing s being arranged in the name of BP International and BP North America.
Bolivia's government, faced with a mounting social unrest, opened talks toay with the country's top union leaders on ways to settle a series of pay demands.
Foreign minister Guillermo Bedregal led a team of government officials t the talks, held with the mediation of the Roman Catholic church, sources said.
The secretary general of Bolivia's labour organization COB, Juan Lechin Oqueno, headed a group of four COB leaders to the meeting at the archbishopric of La Paz, they said.
Thousands of peasants, university students ann workers marched today through te streets of La Paz to protest against the government's economic policies.
A hunger strike to press for higher wages spread today t about 4,000 union leaders, workers, and university students in the country's major cities, said COB press secretary Gonzalo Vizcarra.

Simultaneonsly, about 9,000 miners employed by the state corpration COMIBOL continued their production strike begun last Friday to press for higher wages and more funds in the nationalised mining industry.

Extracts from a report by Italy's Budget Ministry on the country's economic development in 1986 showed gross dometic product (GDP) 2.7 pct higher in real terms than in 1985 but a rise in unemployment.
GDP calculated at 1980 prices rose to 434,682 billion lire last year from 423064 billion in 1985.
On a current prices basis, GDP was up 11 pct, totalling 894,362 billion lir in 1986 against 805,754 billion in 1985.
But growth was insufficient to prevent a rise in unemployment to 11.1 pct las year from 10.3 pct in 1985, the ministry said.
The report said falling oil prices and the depreciation of the dollar during 198 had favoured oil-importing countries such as Italy.
These factors helped Italy cut inflation to an average 6.3 pct in 1986, dow from 9.3 pct in 1985.
They also helped a major improvement i the trade balance.
On the basis of data recently recalculated by te national statistics institute Istat, Italy had a trade deficit in 1986 of 3,722 billion lire, the report said.
This slightly revises a previous deficit figure of 3,17 billion issued by Istat and compares with a negative balance of 23,085 billion for 1985.
Farm-state Senators indicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System recue package to include aid for borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks, as well as the farm credit system.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Agriculture subcommittee resposible for farm credit, said legislation to rescue the financially-troubled system should provide help to borrowers from all lenders to agriculture.
"We must provide some form of interest rate buydown, principal reducion relief for all eligible farmers and ranchers regardless of their lending institution," Boren said.
Boren's statement received bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, wo agreed that the aid package should cover all lenders to agriculture.

The comments by Senators of both parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, te American Farm Bureau Federation, and from the system itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focus of the rescue legislation for the farm credit system.
Until now, agriculture officials hd focused exclusively on how to resurrect the failing system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks and life insurance companies must be included in the ad package because "it would not be fair to address only the problems of Farm Credit System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents of an across-the-board interest rae or principal buydown did not say how much the broad approcah would cost.
But Neil Harl, professor of economics at Iowa State University told the hearing te cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion dlrs annually.

Sources close to Italy's <Gruppo Ferruzzi> said <European Sugar (France)>, a French company owned by Ferruzzi, would take over control of <CPC Industrial Division>, th corn wet milling business acquired by the Italian group earlier this week from CPC International Inc <CPC>.

The federal Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) proposed new rules that would require accounting firms that audit public companies to submit to a periodic outsid review of their operations.

The SEC voted unanimously to seek public comment on the plan, under which an accounting firm would have to hire another firm to conduct a so-called "peer review" every three years or lose the right to audit publc companies.
SEC officials conceded peer rview would not end all audit failures but said they hoped it would eliminate audits by clearly unqualified firms and individuals.
"Peer review will not sop all bad audits; we recognize that," SEC Chief Accountant Clarence Sampson told the five SEC commissioners.
"But we hope the rle will go far to eliminate audits performed by individuals without the necessary skills to conduct a proper audit," Sampson said.

The move is largely symbolic, since firms and individuals reponsible for auditing 84 pct of all public companies already voluntarily undergo peer review every three years, under an accounting industry self-regulatory plan.
But the SEC has been uder pressure for years from some federal lawmakers to make the accounting industry more open and accountable to the public.
Agency officials estimated that a per review would cost the average accounting firm between 1,500 and 2,500 dlrs, or 500 to 750 dlrs a year.
"I don't tink that (cost) is a dispositive issue," SEC Chairman John Shad said.
"It's wthin a reasonable range of cost."
The proposal would exempt foreign auitors of non-U.S. companies required to file financial reports with the SEC.

he rating agency said it would study B.P.
s strategy to restore financial flexibility after the acquisition.

British Petroleum o PLC may have to raise its planned 70 dlrs a share tender offer for the publicly traded shares of Standard Oil Co <SRD>, analysts said.
"There's a ot of speculation here that someway or other they would be forced to come up with another bid," said Rosario Ilaqua of L.F. Rothschild.
And despite P managing director David Simon's denial today that BP would raise the offer, the analysts said that remained a distinct possibility.
Analysts said hey base their thinking on Royal Dutch/Shell Group's <RD> <SC> bid to buy the outstanding stake of Shell Oil Co in 1984 and 1985.
Royal Dutch/Shell eventually raised its initial 55 dlrs a share offer to 60 dlrs a share, after lawuits by minority shareholders.
"I think they're going to have to go a little higher eventually, just as Royal Dutch/Shell had to go a little higher for the Shell Oil minority shares," Bruce Lazier of Prescott Ball and Turbn said.
He estimated a price of 75 dlrs a shar.
Royal Dutch/Shell offered 55 dlrs a share for the 30.5 pct of Shell Oil it did not already own in January of 194.
After objections from minority shareholders about the price, Royal Dutch/Shell raised its bid and began a 58 dlrs a share tender offer i April 1984.
But shareholders sued and a cort blocked completion of the offer.
After months of wrangling over the worth of Shell Oil, Royal DutchShell agreed to another two dlrs increase.
It ended up paying 5.67 billion dlrs for the outstanding Shell Oil stake, a significant premium to its original bid of about 5.2 billin dlrs.
The analysts made their comments befor Simon's remarks at a BP press conference in New York this afternoon.
Sanford Margoshes of Shearson Lehman Brthers Inc told clients this morning that a sweetened offer was possible.
The analyst said the bid could be raied by two dlrs a share.
Analysts do not expect regulatory hurdles because o the Royal Dutch/Shell group precedent.
But there may be shareholder lawsuits for te same reason, they said.
Goldman Sachs and Co, BP's investment advisor, advised the Shell Oil board in 1984 ad 1985.

Standard and Poor's Corp said it affirmed he ratings on 19 billion dlrs of debt of Chrysler Corp and related entities.
S nd P cited the acquisition of AMC as strongly negative.
It questioned the lng-term srategic value, as well as a high price of about two billion dlrs.

Affirmed were the BBB senior debt f Chrysler and its unit Chrysler Financial, Chrysler Financial's A-2 domestic and Eurocommercial paper, Chrysler Capital Realty Inc's A-2 commercial paper and Chrysler Financial's BBB-minus subordinated debt.
The BBB senior debt of two international units, Chrysler Credit Canada Ltd and Chryslr Overseas Capital Corp, was also affirmed.
Chrysler's debt issues were put on creditwatch on March nine after the automaker announed plans to acquire American Motors Corp <AMO>.
AMC's debt is still on creditwatch wit positive implications pending the deal's outcome.
The AMC purchase shows a strongly aggressive move on Chrysler's part to increase maret share at a time when industry competition is intensely competitive, S and P said.
This is a chang in the company's previous strategy.
Hawaiian Airlines Inc said it will continue to expand services to Pacific Islands tis year.

An Atlas Centaur rocket launching a miltary communications satellite went out of control a minute after launch and was destroyed, a NASA spokesman said.
The Atlas Centaur basted off in rainy and overcast conditions.
Within seconds controllers reported it was ut of control and the order to blow it up was given.
NASA spokesperson Lisa Mlone said the rocket may have been struck by lightening.
The failure is he first for NASA since May 1986, when a Delta rocket failed.

Standard il Co expects the sale of assets and federal tax refunds resulting from last year's loss to add about one billion dlrs to its normal cash flows from operations in 1987, its annual report said.
Last year, the report noted, the cash flow from operations dropped to .8 billion dlrs from 3.5 billion dlrs in 1985 and 3.2 billion dlrs in 1984 due principally to lower oil prices.

The report, prepared before British Petroleum Co Plc <BP> disclosed plans to sek the rest of Standard's stock, put 1987 capital spending at 1.6 billion dlrs, down from the 1.7 billion dlrs projected in January.
Standard's capital spending ttaled 1.77 billion dlrs in 1986.

The report showed a decline in proven oil reserves to 2.41 bllion barrels at the end of 1986 from 2.65 billion barrels a year earlier as discoveries and other additions dropped to 11.4 mln barrels last year from 23.2 mln in 1985.
But it said gas reeserves rose to 7.31 trillion cubic feet fom 7.22 trillion at the end of 1985 despite a 30.9 mln cubic feet downward revision in previous reserve estimates during 1986.
Discoveries and other additions totaled 20.5 billion cubic feet last year, up from 175.9 billion in 1985, it added.
Standard said both oil and gas production increased last year -- to 726,600 barrels per ay from 719,700 barrels the previous day and to 154.4 mln cubic feet daily from 10.1 mln in 1985.
But the average sales price of both dropped -- to 13.83 dlrs per barrel from 2.43 dlrs for oil in 1985 and to 1.49 dlrs per thousand cubic feet from 2.18 dlrs a year earlier.
Standard said its refined product sales also rose last year, to 644,500 barrels per dy from 604,200 barrels daily in 1985.
The former chief currency dealer of Herstatt Bank, which collapsed in 1974 o foreign exchange speculation in West Germany's biggest banking crash, can stand trial for damages, a court ruled.
The court overturned a claim by Danny Dattel that a case fr damages should not be allowed after such a long interval.
Herstatt creditors are seeking 12.5 mln marks from Dattel, whom they acuse of causing losses at the bank of over 500 mln marks by manipulating forward foreign exchange contracts.
The crash of the private Herstatt bank with losses of over oe billion marks stunned West Germany's business community, and led to a tightening of banking regulations.
The losses were even greater than the 480 mln marks announced recently b Volkswagen as a result of fraud in currency transactions.
Ivan Herstatt, managing director of the bank when it collapsed, was sentenced t four and a half years in prison in 1984 but appealed.
Six other people associated with the ban were jailed in 1983.
But Dattel was freed from prosecution after he produced medical evidence of paranoa caused by Nazi persecution during his childhood, which might have led him to take his own life.
Energy and Mines Minister Arturo Hernandez Grisanti today told a meeting of regional oi exporters the next few months will be critical to efforts to achieve price recovery and stabilize the market.
Hernandez said while OPEC and non-OPEC nations have already made some strides in their efforts to strengthen the market, the danger of a reversal is always resent.
"March an the next two or three months will be a really critical period," Hernandez said.
He said, "We will be able to define a movement, either towards market stability and price recovery or depending on the market, a reversal."
Earlier this week, Hernandez said Venezuela's il price has averaged just above 16 dlrs a barrel for the year to date.
If OPEC achieves its stated goal f an 18 dlrs a barrel average price, he said, Venezuela's should move up to 16.50 dlrs.
Hernandez spoke today at the opening f the fifth ministerial meeting of the informal group of Latin American and Caribbean oil exporters, formed in 1983.
Ministers from member states Ecuador, Mexico, Trinidad-Tobago and Venezuela are attending the to day conference, while Colombia is present for the first time as an observer.
Hernandez defined the meeting as an informl exchange of ideas about the oil market.
However, the members will also discuss ways to combat proposals for a tx on imported oil currently before the U.S. Congress.
Following the opening session, the group of ministers met with President Jaime Lusinci at Miraflores, the presidential palace.

The delegations to the conference are headed by Hernandez of Venezuela, Energy Minister Javier Espinosa of Ecuador, Energy Minister Kelvin Ramnath of Trinidad-Tobago, Jose Luis Alcudiai, assistant energy secretary of Mexico and Energy Minister Guilermn Perry Rubio of Colombia.
International Business Machines Corp said scentists at its Zurich research laboratory have taken a key step toward developing a method of testing computer chips with a laser.
The technique is important, IBM sid, because it could lead to the development of tools that can determine the quality of microscopic-sized computer chips without damaging them.
IBM said chip makers will need sch advanced testing methods to aid them in developing the next generation of semiconductors.
These chips will be smaller than today' chips but will be able to store vastly greater amounts of information.
IBM said its technique uses a laser light for "contactless" measuring of electrical signals on metal lines similar to the kind found in computer chip ciruitry.
It said that sing commercially available lasers, the method should permit measurements of circuits with a width of one micrometer or less.
A micrometer is about 80 times smaller than the thicknes of a sheet of paper.
Tround International Inc said it entered into a joint agreemet with <Lucas Aerospace Ltd>.

The company said the agreement calls for the selection of certain Tround products for use both with the Lucas 50 caliber gun turret on helicopters and other vehicles and to establish a sales effort for thes products.
The two companies are negotiating with the U.S. Navy to flight-qualify the joint system, which will be adaped to a helicopter provided by the Navy.
Tround said the system has the potential for revenues in excess of 300 mln dlrs over a six-to-eiht-year production time span, assuming the project is a success.
Farm-state senators idicated they may broaden a Farm Credit System rescue package to include aid for borrowers from private lenders such as commercial banks, as well as the farm credit system.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Snate Agriculture subcommittee responsible for farm credit, said legislation to rescue the financially-troubled system should provide help to borrowers from all lenders to agriculture.
"We must rovide some form of interest rate buydown, principal reduction relief for all eligible farmers and ranchers regardless of their lending institution," Boren said.
Boren's statement rceived bipartisan support from Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, who agreed that the aid package should cover all lenders to agriculture.

The comments by Senators of oth parties, plus endorsements for the across-the-board approach from the nation's largest farm organization, the American Farm Bureau Federation, and from the system itself, appeared to significantly broaden the focus of the rescue legislation for the farm credit system.
Until now, agriculture officials had focused exclusively on how to resurrect the failin system.

Boren said borrowers from private lenders such s commercial banks and life insurance companies must be included in the aid package because "it would not be fair to address only the problems of Farm Credit System borrowers."
However, Boren and other proponents of an across-the-board interest rate or principal buydown did not say how much the broad approach would ost.
But Neil Harl, professor of economics at Iowa State University told the hearing the cost could be in the range of 3.5 billion drs annually.

By trying to draw into the farm credit rescue package all farm borrowers, Boren and other Senators appeared to be reacting to pressure from private lenders and their borrowers, who fear they will be put at a competitive disadvantage by the government rescue of the farm credit syste and its borrowers.

The farm credit system is the nation's largest lender to agriculture with 39 pct of all farm real estate loans, but private lenders account for nealy a quarter of loans on farmland and 34 pct of farm operating loans, official figures show.
The American Bankers Association, in testimony to the hearing, warned the farm creit rescue should not be structured to favor the system over other lenders.

As one way to meet the concern of private lenders, several Senators, the farm credit system, and farm organizations endorsed creation of a secondary market o farm real estate loans, called "aggie mae", which is sought by private lenders.
"We are also exploring the possibility of including in the farm credit bill, th establishment of a secondary market for agricultural loans that would be available to all lenders," Sen. Boren said.

<Glenwood Inc> aid it is recalling lot number 54238 of its potaba tablet (aminobenzoate potassium), a prescription drug used mainly to treat scleroderma, a painful skin thickening condition.

The White House Economic Policy Council made a recommendation to President Reagan whether to retaliate aganst Japan for alleged unfair practices in semiconductor trade, U.S. officials said.

They would not disclose the council's recommendation, but the officials said earlier it was likely the council would call for retaliation and urge that curbs be imposed on Japanese exports to te United States.
The officials said it might be several days before Reagan would act and his moves mad public.
The Senate last week unanimously called on Reaan to impose penalities on Japanese exports.
Retaliation was also called for by the semiconductor industry and its chief trade union, both har hit by Japanese semiconductor trade.
In a pact last summer, Japan summer agreed to stop dumping its semiconductors at less than cost in the United States and other nations and to open its own market to the U.S. products
In return, th United States agreed to hold up imposing anti-dumping duties on Japanese semiconductor shipments.

U.S. officials say that while Japan has stopped dumping semiconductors on the American market, they have continued to dump them in third countries and that the Japanese market has remained all but closed o the U.S. semiconductors.

ritain's centrist Alliance has gained further ground and now stands second to the ruling Conservatives according to a new public opinion poll, leaving the main opposition Labour Party trailing in third place.

he Gallup survey to be published in tomorrow's Daily Telegraph newspaper shows the Conservatives with a popularity rating of 37.5 pct, followed by the Social Democrat/Liberal Alliance with 31.5 pct and Labour with 29.5 pct.
A Marplan poll published in this morning's eition of the Today newspaper gave the Conservatives 36 pct against a tied figure of 31 pct each for Labour and the Alliance.
Last month a Marplan poll gave the Tries 38 pct, the Alliance 21 pct and Labour 37 pct.
The latest poll findings would, if translated ito an election result, produce a hung parliament where no single party enjoyed an overall majority, analysts said.
That should dampen speulation of an early June election, they added.

Federal Reserve Governor Robert Heller said that there should b something approaching full nationwide banking in the U.S. by 1990 or 1991.

While much of the asic reform in anachronistic interstate banking laws may come on the state level, he told a financial analysts' meeting here that he also hoped for some concrete action on a federal level to address geographic and other issues.
"A crisis will bring it about very quickly...but that is not the way I would like to see it happen," he said, adding, "there needs to be contined pressure on Congress (to act)."
Heller said that it is very difficult to visualize the final version of plas to reform the U.S. financial services industry, which are currently being discussed on Capitol Hill.
"In the conference committee, anything can happen" he said.
He said that he hoped that his personal vision of banking reform, which h outlined earlier in a formal speech, would serve as a blueprint for Congressional debate.
In his speech, Heller called for a broad restructuing of the domestic financial servics industry, which would allow commercial banks to diversify along wider geographic and product lines.

Nance, president of Tenneco Oil Exploration and Poduction, told a meeting of the Petroleum Equipment Suppliers Association.
Nance predicted that y 1990, the Organization of Producing and Exporting Countries would be producing at the rate of 80 pct of capacity.
The ain will come largely through increased imports to the United States, he said.
"They will be ble to raise the price again but I do not think they will raise it as much as they did in 1979," Nance said.
He id not say how much of a price hike he expected.
Andrew Shoup, chairman of Dallas-based Sabine, predicted hat world oil prices would increase from a range of 15 to 20 dlrs a barrel in 1987 to a range of 17 to 22 dlrs a barrel in 1988.
Natural gas prices, houp said, should similarly climb from a range of 1.30 to 1.70 dlrs per mcf this year to between 1.50 and 1.90 dlrs per mcf in 1988.
"Fuel switching could elp us as much as five pct in increased demand," Shoup said, referring to the gas industry's outlook for 1987.
Repeal of the Fuel Use Act, a ederal law prohibiting the use of natural gas in new manufacturing plants and utilities, could increase demand for gas by as much as 15 pct, he said.
Tenneco's Nance also aid that some U.S. cities may experience peak day shortages in natural gas supplies next winter because of the industry's reduced deliverability.
Tenneco's as deliverability, for example, dropped by 20 pct during 1986, he said.
"This oes not mean the gas bubble is gone," Nance said.
We believe gas prices have bottomed out.
The real question s how broad the valley is -- is it one year, two years or three years before we start to climb out?"
J.C. Walter of Walter Oil and Gas Corp>, said the recent improvement in oil prices was not enough for independent producers to begin new onshore drilling projects.

"If crude oil stays below 20 dlrs a barrel and 1.50 dlr per mcf for natural gas prevails, the prospects for onshore exploration at deeper depths in the Texas Gulf Coast by independents i the 1990s are pretty dismal," Walter said.
He suggested that some independents may instead tur to exploration in shallow federal offshore leases.
Farm-out agreements, cheap rig rates and less competition have held finding costs in thoe areas to five or six dlrs a barrel, Walter said.
White House Budget Director James Mille said a budget plan drafted by Senate Budget Chairman Lawton Chiles (D-Fla.) was "seriously deficient."

In a statement, Miller called the senator's proposal for the government's fiscal 1988 budget would cut U.S. defense spening authority by more than 25 billion dlrs from President Reagan's request, resulting in a real reduction of military spending authority for the third year in a row.
While the plan would allow atual 1988 defense spending to rise by 5.6 billion dlrs, domestic spending would be increased by a disprportionate 42.7 billion dlrs, he said.

The Soviet economy has grown at an increased rate under Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership, but his goals may be too ambitious, according to a report from U.S. intelligene agencies.
The report was prepared jointly by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency for the Congressional Joint Economic committee, whch released it.
It said the Soviet economy grew by 4.2 pct in 1986, Gorbachev's first full year in power, twice the average rate of growth over the previous 1 years.

Gorbachev's policies to improve worker attitudes, remove incompetent officials, reduce corruption and alcoholism and modernize the country's industrial equipment accounted for some of the gains, the repor said.

"Although many of the specific policies Gorbachev has adopted are not new, the intensity Gorbachev has brought to his efforts and his apparent commitment to finding long-term solutins are attributes that his immediate predecessors lacked.
Nonetheless, Gorbachev's program appears too ambitious o a number of counts," the report said.
Earlier this week, two U.S. experts on the Soviet Union said Gorbachev was likly to be ousted in three to four years if he continues his reform policies.
"I don't think he can last four years," Marshall Goldman of Harvard University tol a Congressional hearing.
"He's moving so fast, he's stepping o so many toes."
A similar comment came from Peter Reddaway of the Smithsonian Institution's Kennan Institute fr Advanced Russian studies.

The economic report said meeting targets for commodity output would reuire unrealistic gains in productivity and industrial output targets appear too high to allow time to install more advanced equipment.
None of Gorbachev's proposals would change the system of economic incenives that has discouraged innovation and technological change, the report added.

"The first significant resistance to specific policies, although not overall goals, surfaced (in 1986) in both the massive government and paty bureaucracy, particularly among enterprise managers who complained that they were being asked to carry out conflicting goals -- such as to raise quality standards and output targets simultaneously," the report said.
The CIA-DIA report predicted two to three pct growth in te Soviet economy over the next several years.
It said the Soviet Union tailed the U.S. by seven to 12 years in advanced manufacturing technologies, such as computers and microprocessors.

Great American Corp said preliminary findings by reglatory examiners of its AMBANK subsidiary will result in a first quarter charge of 14.1 mln dlrs and a writedown of 1.4 mln dlrs.

Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) said Congress would consider limiting the use of generic commodity certificates as a mens of cutting government spending.

"I suspect that as we go into some of the budget debates we're going to have on the floor, this is going to be part of it," Leahy said, referring to proposals that the U.S. Agriculture Department save money by substituting cah outlays for payment-in-kind, or PIK, certificates in price and income support programs.

"I have a feeling that the PIK program, however the cost is defined, is going to be one of the top number of areas that people are going to be looking for savings," Leahy told a hearing of the Senate Agricultur Committee.

The Congressional Budget Office ha estimated that the government could save 1.4 billion dlrs during fiscal years 1988-92 if it curbed the use of generic certificates by banning so-called "PIK and roll" transactions.
Several Dmocratic senators had harsh comments for generic certificates.
"We're trying to take care of a bad situation -- surpluses-by depressing the price.
I on't see any benefits," said Sen. Tom Harkin (D-Iowa).
"I on't see any benefit in driving their prices lower, lower, lower all the time."
But en. Rudy Boschwitz said he supported use of certificates.
"By nd large I'm favorably impressed by PIK certificates.
I eel they have been helpful," said Boschwitz.
As expected, officials rom the General Accounting Office and the U.S. Agriculture Department indicated their estimates of the cost of PIK certificates compared to cash outlays were far apart.
The General Accounting Office, GAO, told the committee that PIK certificates increased total Commodity Credit Corp outlays through 1987 by between 107 mln an 653 mln dlrs.
GAO said that increase was offset by commodity storage cost savings of beween 169 mln and 253 ml dlrs.

Pressed by the committee, GAO Senior Associate Director Brian Crowley said government spending probably was about 450 mln dlrs above what it would have been had all program payments been made in cash, not counting storae savings.
Crowley also said he thought PIK certificates had lowered the price of corn and boosted domestic consumption o corn.
Agriculture Undersecretary Daniel Amstutz told the committee that the additional costs of using PIK certificates and storage, handling and transportation costs balance off very closely."
Amstutz said he estimated the net cost of using certificates was about one pct higher than using only cash to make progrm payments.

William Bailey, USDA deput administrator for program planning, said there were "one hundred issues I find either incorrect (in the GAO report), disagree with or where their (GAO) facts are inconsistent with what's going on."
Amstutz said GAO had not given USDA the option of "providing input" into the preparation of their report "as they frequently o."

The USDA undersecretary also conceded that certificates and marketing loans had the similar effect of "putting more goods into the market," but that while the department supported certificates, it would continue to oppose a marketing loan for wheat and feedgrains because t would cost too much.

Angola's U.S.-backed UNITA rebel group has offered to reopen the Benguela railroad that run through UNITA-held territory and links landlocked Zaire and Zambia to the Angolan port of Lobito.

UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, in a statement made in his Jamba headquarters in southern Angola and released by UNITA's Washington office, said he was prepared to guarantee saf passage for non-military freight as a gesture of "peace and reconciliation."
Savimbi challenged the Cuban-backed Angolan goernment, which controls the port, to match his offer and allow goods to pass through.
There was no immediate response from Luanda
UNITA has ben fighting the Cuban-backed Angolan government since 1976.
The offer of a rail rute to the Atlantic would help South Africa's black neighbors reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.
The U.S. Congress is currently considering a proposal to spend some 500 mln dlrs to build another railroad to help these states become less dependent n South Africa.
The eira corridor runs through Mozambique to Tanzania's Indian ocean ports but Savimbi suggested the Benguela route as an alternative.
The Benguela route can safely open immediately," he said.
"It ill provide the transportation our neighbors need, and it will not cost the Americans the money they say it will cost to open the Beira corridor."

arlier this month, the company's Occidental Fire and Casualty Co unit paid 26 mln dlrs to a unit of <Mutual of Omaha> under a commutation agreement.

Federal Reserve data released today indicate that there has been no policy change in recent weeks and that none is likely at next wek's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, economists said.

"The Fed continues to be accommodative in its provision of reserves, indicating that tere has been no policy shift since the beginning of this year," said Harold Nathan, economist at Wells Fargo Bank.
"These numbers and other things suggest he FOMC will not change policy," said Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. "The Fed is sitting fairly pretty now.

There's no real reason for it to change policy," said Joseph Liro of S.G. Warburg and Co Inc. Liro said the economy is showing moderate growth and does not require immediate policy easing and the money aggregates may well end March a the bottom of their target ranges.
All of the economists agreed that the Fed's major concern now is recent weakness in the dollar which early this wee was heavily supported by central banks.
They said fear of hurting the dollar wll cause the Fed to be cautious in lowering interest rates further.
Numbers released by the Fed today were al in line with expectations and similar to the data for most of this year.
The Fed said that banks' net free reserves averaged 603 mln dlrs in the two-week statement period that ended on Wednesday versus 749 ml dlrs in the previous period.
In the single week to Wednesday, banks' borrowings at the discount window, less extended credits, averaged 302 mln dlrs compared with 228 mln dlrs i the first week of the statement period.
Meanwhile the Federal funds rate average edgd up to 6.14 pct from 6.08 pct.
The Fed's failure to add reserves in the market on Tuesday and Wednesay surprised some, but economists said the data released today suggest it had no real need to add reserves.

The Fed's absence may be explained by the lack of any pressing need for it to supply reserves and by a desire to boost borrowings in the second week of the statement period to meet its borrowing target, said Liro of Warburg.
Liro said the Fed probably is shooting for a two-week borrowings average o 300-325 mln dlrs.
The borrowings actually averaged 265 mln dlrs in the latest statement period and that was up from 191 ml dlrs in the prior period.
Brusca of Nikko agreed that the Fed probably is aiming for two-week average discount window borrowigs of around 300 mln dlrs.
He said that would correspond to a Fedral funds rate of around 6.10 pct.
It is nearly impossible for the Fed to hit any borrowings target since the demand fr excess reserves is erratic, said Wells Fargo's Nathan.
He said the Fed is focusing instead on the funds rate and is trying to kee it roughly within a six to 6-1/4 pct band.
Upward funds rate pressure nd a big reserve-adding need are anticipated for the statement period that began today.
More Brusca believes the ed will have to add 3.5 to four billion dlrs a day in reserves in this statement period.
Liro puts he add need at around 3.9 billion dlrs.
To partly address this requirement, many expect the Fed to add permanent reserves with effect next Thursday by offering to buy all maturities of Treasury bills n Wednesday.
A similar coupon "pass" ma be required later.
There will be a greater demand for funds in this statement period because it includes the close o the quarter.
Further upward pressure on the Federal funds rate may come from window dressing demand as the Japanese fiscal year ends on March 31
Substantial difficulties faced by he U.S. farm credit system can be solved with a business-like approach to the problems, a Farm Credit Admimistration official said.
Marvin R. Duncan, a mmber of the administration board, said the farm credit system faces unprecedented difficulties in its 70-year history.
Addressing Chicago business and agicultural economists, Duncan outlined three basic problems of the farm credit system.
Those include the high cst of its debt, the quality of its assets, and the management of its credit delivery system.
He said some of he system's debt carries interest rates as high as 15.65 pct and will not mature until the year 2007.
Of its 54.6 mln dlrs in assets, 24.1 pct are non-accrual, high risk or aready forfeited property, which led to losses in 1986 of 1.9 billion dlrs and in 1985 of 2.7 billion dlrs.
Problems with credit delvery have been somewhat resolved, he said.

"The system is still plagued with duplication in layers of management and decision-making, inadequate taioring of credit services to fit the emerging market, a large investment in bricks and mortar, and a management and directorate more insular to the marketplace than that of its competitors," he said.
He said solutions to the problems should - - provide assurances to farmers on borrowers stock and the stability of the arm credit system.
- maintain confidence of investors who buy system securities
- address the high cost of the system's eisting debt.
- enable the Farm Credit System Capital Corporation to carry out its role as a workout bank

Frank Naylor, chairman of the Farm Credit Administration, said this week that the system may lose as much as 1.4 billion dlrs this year, and another board member, Jim Billington, said Congress should plan to spend at least 800 mln dlrs beginning late this year to bail out the system
Duncan noted that the system has about 70 billion dlrs in assets, serves about 800,000 individual borrowers and 3,000 cooperatives, and has 62.5 billion lrs in securities outstanding.
"With a business-like solution to its problems, it can continue that role for generations into the fture," he said.

The United States' emphasis on its foreign trade deficit is misplaced and the country's real probem lies in its large federal budget deficit, the General Agreeement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) said.
By stressing its record trade deficit of 169.8 billion dlrs last year, te U.S. Was fuelling protectionist pressure which threatens the world trading system, it said in an annual report.
The fundamental problem, the size of the U.S. Federal budget deficit, could b remedied only by cutting government spending or encouraging personal savings to finance the debt, it said.
GATT also predicted world trade would grow by only 2.5 pct in 198 -- a full percentage point lower than in each of the previous two years.

GATT experts urged Washington to resist protectionism and instead seek macroeconomic changes t reduce the current account payments deficit -- higher private savings, lower investment and a smaller federal budget deficit.
Raising U.S. Trade barriers "would result in little or no reduction in te current account deficit.
It would, however, increase inflation and reduce world trade," i said.
"The basic cause -- some combination of insufficient domestic savings and an excessive budget deficit -- would remain," th report said.

GATT economists said trade expansion would slow this year because of slower growth forecasts in Japan and some West European nations as they adjust production and workforces to a low dollar, risk of higher U.S. Inflation, concerns ove Third World debt management and looming protectionism.
The report also said imbalances in the current accounts of Japan, West Germany and the U.S. Had increased i 1986.
The most likely explanation was that exchange rate changes were not backed by changes in macroeconomic policies, it adde.
"Thus the prediction that these imbalances would be reduced as a result of the major realignment of exchange rates wa not borne out last year," the report said.
GATT warned there was a risk of a sizeable increase in the U.S. Inflation rate under the combined impact f a rapidly expanding money supply and low dollar.
"Such a development could worsen the business climate by increasing uncertainty and pushing up interest rates, which, in turn, would dversely affect world trade."
But the report noted a surprising rise in imports to the United States, despite the dollar's depreciation which makes foreign roducts more expensive.
It suggested that resources idle in the U.S., Both human and in underutilised factories, were not geared to produce the oods and services sought from abroad.
World rade in manufactures grew by only three pct in 1986, about half of the rate of the previous year.
Trade in agricultural goods expanded by just ne pct, continuing a stagnant pattern in that sector this decade, GATT said.
Developing countries' exports declined significantly, while their iports increased moderately, although full statistics are not available yet, GATT said.
The combined export earnings of 16 major indbted nations were sharply lower, and only five of them (Chile, Colombia, Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand) had higher exports.

Bolivian president Victor Paz Estenssoro will propose o Andean Pact countries a summit meeting with U.S. President Reagan to take place in Venezuela in May, foreign minister Guillermo Bedregal announced.

The Andean Pact, formed by Colombia, Venezuela, Peru and Ecuador, is a sub-regional economic group set up in 1969 to counteract economic progrss of other more developed South American countries, such as Argentina and Brazil.
New Zealand's budget deficit for fiscal 1986/87 eding March 31 is expected to be around the budget forecast of 2.45 billion N.Z.
Dlrs but below a Deceber forecast of 2.91 billion, Finance Minister Roger Douglas said.

Japan's consumer price index (base 185) was unchanged at 99.7 in February from a month earlier, the government's Management and Coodination Agency said.
The index sowed a 0.4 pct drop in January.
The February index was down one pct from a year earlier fr the third consecutive year-on-year drop.
In January, the index fell 1.1 pct from a year earlier, te first drop of over one pct since a 1.3 pct drop in September 1958.
In February petrol prices increased bt winter clothing prices stayed low and vegetable prices fell.
The February year on year fall was due to lower vegetable, fuel oil, petrol, electricity and gas prices, an despite higher housing, education, footwear and clothing costs.
The unadjusted consumer price index for the Tokyo area (base 1985) in mid-March rose 0.4 pct from a mont earlier to 100.6, reflecting higher vegetable prices.

The White House Economic Policy Council dcided to recommend trade sanctions against Japan for violations of the U.S.-Japanese semiconductor agreement, industry sources said.
They would give no details, noting tat the White House had not commented on the decision.
The administration has ben under pressure to retaliate.

There was no immediate announcement on the council's decision, but U.S. Officials said it was likely the senior policy groups move on curbs reflected growing American frustration over alleged unfair Japanese trade practices.
U.S. Officials said President Reagan would probably act on the recommendations in a day or so, after consulting with aides on the forein policy implications of retaliation.
The officials said Reagan might delay retaliation for a last try to persuade Japan to abide by the agreement reached last July govening trade in semiconductors.
Under a pact reached last July, Japan was to stop dumping semiconductors in world markets ad to open its own market to U.S.-made semiconductors.
In return, the U.S
Agreed to hold up imposing anti-dumping duties on Jpanese semiconductor shipments.
The United States aid that dumping has stopped in the U.S. Market but has continued in third countries, and that the Japanese market remains closed.
The pressure on eagan to retaliate included a unanimous call by the Senate last week to impose penalties on Japanese high technology products containing semiconductors.
A call for rtaliation also came from the semiconductor industry and from its chief trade union.
U.S. Officials said the most likely move against Japan would involve duties on semiconductor-based goods, such as televisions, video cassette recorders an computers.

anking sources in London had been quoted earlier as saying the British banks were balking at signing the package in an effort to get all participants to contribute equally to a new 7.7 billion dlr loan contained in the deal.

The bank issued 20 billion dlrs of similar bonds between February 1 and March 9.
India is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to hep it cut its trade deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and electronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, ae all on offer in return for crude oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the impetus behind countertrade, which began i 1984, comes from two state trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

"The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities to promote Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman sai, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
One trade source said India has targetted countries that depend on an Indan domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

However, countertrade deals still make up only a small part of India's total trading and are likely to account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.3 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
Countertrade accounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothig in 1984/85, official figures show.
However, the figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-convertible Indian rupees, te sources said.

Total trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms and crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87, aganst three billion in 1985/86.

Indian countertrade, which is being promoted mainly to help narrow the country's large trade deficit is still insignificant compared with agreements reached by Indonesia, Venezuela and Brazil, the trade sources said.
The trade deficit, which hit an estimated record 6.96 billion dlrs in 1985/86, is expected to decline t 5.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

But the push to include non-communist countries in countertrade is also due to other factors, including the slw growth of foreign reserves, a tight debt repayment schedule, shrinking aid and trade protectionism, businessmen said.
One source said India is showing more dynamism in promoting countertrade deals than in the past, when the deals were made discreetly because they break GAT rules.
As a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), India canot officially support bartering.
The MMTC's recent countertrade deals include iron ore exports to Yugoslavia for steel structres and rails.

"MMTC's recent global tenders now include a clause that prference will be given to parties who accept payment in kind for goods and services sold to India," a trade official said, adding that the policy remains flexible.
"We also take into acount other factors such as prices at which the goods and services are offered to India," the trade official said.

Early this year he commerce ministry quietly told foreign companies interested in selling aircraft, ships, drilling rigs and railway equipment to India that they stood a better chance if they bought Indian goods or services in return, the trade sources said.
Illustrating the point, the official said a South Korean firm recently agreed to sell a drilling platform worth 40 mln dlrs to the state-run Oil nd Natural Gas Commission.
In return, the South Koreans gave a verbal assurance to buy Indian goods worth 10 pct of the contract, against the 25 pct sought by ew Delhi, the trade official said.
"We selected the Korean firm beause its bid was the lowest," he added.
Countertrade is helping African countries shrt of foreign currency to import goods.
India has signed a trade protocol to buy up to 15000 tonnes of asbestos fibre from Zimbabwe in exchange for Indian goods, including jute bags and cars.
But despite India's new drve, countertrade has some inherent problems, they added.
"It is not always easy to meet the basic requrement that the trade should always be balanced," one trade source said.
"The other problem is it is often difficult to suply or buy commodities which the other party wants."
Another added, "Barter i also restrictive.
We look upon it as a temporary measure to get over the current balance o payments difficulty.
"This is why countertrade has not bee made a law in India.
It does not even figure in te country's foreign trade policy."

<Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Co> (NTT) is considering buying a Cray I supercomputer worth some three billion yen from Cray Research Inc <CYR>, and a decision is expected in early April, an NTT official said.
He told Reuters NTT was considering the Cray machine because of is superior operational speed and memory capacity, and not because of any pressure to buy foreign hardware.

Industry sources said foreign frustration was growing over lack of access t Japan's semiconductor and telecommunications markets, and Washington had criticised Japanese government agencies for not buying U.S.
The finance ministry appears ready to allow Japanese financial institutions to use overseas financial futures markets, a ministry offcial said.
He declined to say when, but banking sources expect approval as earl as April.
Banks, securities houses and insurance copanies are expected to become eligible to deal in deposit, interest rate, bond and stock index futures.
Ministry officials said they are wry of giving permission to individuals or corporations because of their relative inexperience.
Broking for Japanese residents by financial institutions would be prohibited as securities exchange laws br banks from doing this, the banking sources said.
verseas subsidiaries and branches of Japanese banks and securities houses have already been allowed to use the overseas futures markets on their own accounts.
he Finance Ministry Ordinance based on Foreign Exchange Administration Law will have to be revised to allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a ministry official said.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has told his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with a draft economic package in early April in time for his visit to Washington starting on April 29, government officials said

Nakasone also instructed the government's Economic Planning Agency (EPA) to work closer with the LDP to work out a full-fledged economic plan to boost domestic demand as pledged at last month's Paris curreny stability accord by six industrial countries, the officials told Reuters.

The date for the government to announce its package, based on the LDP's suggested measures, is not yet known but it may be before the fiscal 1987 budget passes the Parliament around lat May, the officials said.
The government has aid in the past the package should come after the passage of the budget.

But calls have grown at home nd abroad for the government to announce it earlier as budget debates have been stalled by an opposition boycott of parliamentary business in protest at a planned five pct sales tax.
EPA chief Tetsuo Kondo told a press conference he sees a need to work on the economic plan early although the government's stance o the date for the plan remains the same, an EPA spokesman said.
Projected measures include promoting house construction, infrastructure and urban development, h quoted Kondo as saying.
Under last month's Paris currency agreement, Japan promised to work out a comprehensive economic plan to stimulate domestic demand, increase impors and so help reduce its huge trade surplus.
The government announced today Nakasone will visit Washington on April 29 for a week to discuss bilateral issues, including the trae imbalance, with President Reagan and other officials.
The <British Petroleum Co of Australia Ltd> reported a 16.15 mln dlr net loss for 1986 agains a 73.38 mln dlr profit in 1985 after sales fell to 2.27 billion dlrs from 2.94 billion.
The British Petroleum Co Plc <BP.L> unit attributed the deficit to stock losses arising from the drp in crude prices in the first half, when it made a 119.93 mln dlr loss.

It said government compensation, in the form of subsidies to refiners to partially cover stock losses, together with improved crude prices in the second half, enabled th group's oil business to make a modest pre-tax profit.
BP Australia said it had not recommendd a dividend.
Commenting on the year's performance, the company said it suspended operations at the 60 pct-owned Agnew Nickel mine because o losses sustained from declining nickel prices.
The esults also included an 11.3 mln dlr extraordinary writedown on the value of the laid-up oil exploration drillship Regional Endeavour.

BP Australia said t had sold its 33-1/3 stake in chemical maker <CSBP and Farmers Ltd> yielding an extraordinary profit of 18.9 mln dlrs and expected to finalise the sale of the 80 pct-owned <Kwinana Nitrogen Co> in the first half of 1987.
Japan's Nissan Motor Co Ltd said it and <Lancer Boss Group Ltd> of te U.K. Have agreed to cooperate on the design and manufacture of forklift trucks.

Under the accord, Lancer will sart making jointly designed trucks at its plant in Moosburg, West Germany, from July with production reaching 300 three-wheeled and 100 four-wheeled trucks by end-March 1988.
Output will e doubled from April 1, 1988, a Nissan spokeswoman said.
Nissan will start selling the thee-wheelers under its brand-name later this year and the four-wheelers from the end of 1987, the company said.
The equipment manufacturing areement with Lancer is a precaution against the European Community's (EC) January 1987 restriction on forklift truck exports to the EC, industry sources said.
Nissan exports 70 ct of its annual output of 16,000 forklift trucks, shipping 2,548 units to the EC in 1986, the spokeswoman said.
The Finance Ministry is expected to introduce yen commercial paper, CP, from October 1 in response to growing calls from corporations, ministry sources sad.

Around 200 corporations satisfy financial standards set by securities houses for non-collateral straight bond issues, including electric power companies, <Nippon Telegaph and Telephone Corp> and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co Ltd, securities managers said.
Most eligible firms would have to set up special reserves fr CP issues called backup lines, or be guaranteed by financial institutions to protect investors, they said.
The legal status of yen CP would be the same a yen commercial bills and it would be placed by an intermediary bank or securities house, securities managers said.
The minimum issue unit will be 100 mln yen, and maturities will be from 30 days and six months, hey said.
Securities house, banks, insurance companies and consumer credit companies are barred from CP issues, they said.
Only banks may be commissioned to handle the clerical business of rinciple payments, they added.

Four major Japanese steelmakers plan to form a semless pipe export cartel for markets other than the U.S. And the European Community for a year from April to keep prices above output costs, company officials involved said.

The companies are Nippon steel orp <NSTC.T>, Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd <SMIT.T>, Nippon Kokan KK <NKKT.T> and Kawasaki Steel Corp <KAWS.T>, which together account for some 95 pct of Japan's total seamless pipe exports.
The firms will apply to form the cartel to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry today and approval is expected later this month, the oficials said.

Under the plan, the four companies will set floor prices for exports as prices have fallen sharply due to the yen's appreciation against the dollar, reduced world demnd caused by lower oil prices and excess domestic capacity which resulted in price-cutting competition, the officials said.
In calendar 1986, seamless pipe exports fell to 2.34 mln tonnes from 2.99 mn in 1985 and 3.12 mln in 1981.
The officials declined to give any idea of floor prices, saying it depends partly on volume, but industry sources estimate average export prices would rise by around 20 pct to some 80 dlrs a tonne.
The resident of Japan's biggest high technology firm, NEC Corp <NIPN.T>, is anything but worried, despite growing anti-Japanese protectionism, a soaring yen, and a stagnant world electronics market.
The company's structure was developed by looking ahead," Tadahiro Sekimoto told Reuters in an interview.
"We ssumed the era of a strong yen, trade friction and globalisation would arrive, and we moved ahead on that basis.
There's no ned to change our strategy now."
However, the world's largest manufacturer of microchips, the tiny silicon wafers which are the brains of most high technology products, knows it must keep looking ahead f it is to survive.
Hoping to build on existing strengths, NEC is now turning its focus on home electronics, an area of pst weakness, Sekimoto said.
NEC wants to follow its corporate slogan "C and C" (Computers and Communications) to create high level home electronis that go beyond mere televisions and video tape recorders, Sekimoto said.
Home electronics accounted for only eight pct of NEC's total 2,334.67 billion yen sales on a consolidated basis n the year ended March 31, 1986.
Industry analysts say NEC is wise to target what will be a major growth market in the future, bu some warn the company faces some stiff competition.

"This is where the market is going to be for a long time -- in products that combine personal computers, video display and telecommunications networs," said Salomon Brothers (Asia) Ltd analyst Carole Ryavec.
"But Matsushita (Electric Industrial Co Ltd) my be there first."
But Sekimoto argues that NEC's overall strengths will carry th day.
"Many companies are in the top 10 in computers or microchips or telecommunications, but none is in the to 10 in all three.
NEC is unique in that respect," h said.
To help its already high rankings, NEC will further increase the high level of offshore production which makes i one of the most multinational of Japan's electronics firms.
The company will increase offshore output of all goods it sels overseas to 50 pct from a current 25 pct over the next several years, Sekimoto said.

But the firm plans to go it alone in expanding overseas, despite moving last year to become joint owner, along wih France's Cie des Machines Bull <BULP.P>, of U.S. Firm Honeywell Inc's <HON> Information Systems unit.
"We hope to increase our share in the U.S. Markt through the Honeywell tie-up.
But our basic strategy is to take an independent an autonomous route," said Sekimoto.
The company also plans to maintain its independent line by continuing to make computers which are not compatible with thos of International Business Machines Corp <IBM>, he said.
"Among the Japanese competitors, only NEC hasn't been caught in software copyright disputs with IBM and our profits and market share have gradually expanded," Sekimoto said.
Once new ways of linking non-compatible computrs are perfected, IBM compatibility will be irrelevant.
"What will matter is the best hardware, the best software and the bes ability to meet customers needs," Sekimoto said.

In fact, NEC, which as over half of Japan's personal computer market, may go to court to stop competitors selling cheaper machines which can run NEC software but infringe copyright on its operating system, an NEC spokesman said.
While industry aalysts give NEC high marks for looking ahead, they note that it failed in forecasting microchip demand.
Like other Jpanese chipmakers, the firm was left with serious excess capacity when lean years followed the boom times.
But after two years of cutbacks in capital invetment in the sector, Sekimoto thinks the time has come to boost spending again, if only slightly.
"We're not gong to increase production.
But we are going to invest in new prduct development and upgrade existing plant," he said.
Despite NEC's admitted strengths, analysts note the company faces tough ties due to stagnant markets.
"NEC has excellent worldwide capacity and technology, but they are caught in a downturn which may last a long time," said Salamn's Ryavec.

The company forecasts such troubles will slash parent net profits to 30 billion yen in the year ending March 31, 1987, down 43 pc from the previous year, although sales are expected to rise eight pct to 2,130 billion yen.
Profits will improve nly slightly next year, rising to 38 billion yen on sales of 2,350 billion, it said.
The government dopted an 8,829 billion yen stop-gap budget for fiscal 1987 starting April 1 to compensate for the delay in the passage through the Parliament of the full 1987/88 budget.

The provisional budget includes 1,862 illion yen in public works spending to help stimulate the economy and meet overseas demand for Japan to import more and reduce its huge trade surplus, officials said.
They said the stop-gap bdget will be in effect for 50 days through May 20 and is the largest ever.
The budget inludes 1,580 billion yen in new government bond issues.
Officials said the spending n public works accounts for about two-sevenths of the 6,017 billion yen in public works outlay set aside in the pending formal 1987/88 budget.
The planned fll budget totals 54,101 billion yen.
The government had to work out the stop-gap budget because budget debates have bee delayed by an opposition boycott of Parliamentary business in protest against a planned five pct sales tax.
