Japan's industrial production index (base 1980) rose 0.3 pct to a seasonally adjusted 122.7 in February from the previous month, th Ministry of International Trade and Industry said.
Output fell 0.5 pct in January from a mont earlier.

The preliminary, unadjusted February index rose 0.6 pct from a year earlier after a 0.5 pct year-on-year rise in January The adjusted February producers' shipment index (base 1980) rose 0.7 pct to 118.5 from Janury when it fell 0.7 pct from December.
The unadjusted shipment index rose 1.4 pct from a year earlier after a 1.0 pct year-on-year January gain
The adjusted February idex of producers' finished goods (base 1980) fell 1.3 pct to 104.5 from January when it fell 0.3 pct from December.
The unadjusted index fell .5 pct from a year earlier after a 2.3 pct year-on-year drop in January.

A 2.7 pct rise by the electronics industry n higher output of facsimile machines and video tape recorders was a major contributor to the rise in February industrial output, though car production fell from January.

The official said industrial production is expected to rise 3.2 pct in Mrch on higher production by machinery, steel and chemical makers but will drop 3.4 pct in April on a downturn in the output of those industries.
He gve no further details.
A Tokyo Medical College group said it ad developed a five-minute method that may be the world's fastest way of screening people for the AIDS virus.

Lecturer Junko Renard told a meeting of the Japan Blood Transfusion Society new Latex Paricle Agglutination Test used a light meter to identify acquired immune deficiency syndrome in blood mixed with a reagent and a latex rubber compound.
State officials said Japan will step up its anti-AIDS campaign with 340,000 posters and a telephoe counselling service in 21 cities this month.
It will also hand out 90,000 books o AIDS diagnosis to hospitals and clinics.
Orders received in February by 50 major Japanese construction firms rose 2.7 pct to 841.68 billion yen from a year earlier for th third successive year-on-year gain, the construction ministry said.
Orders rose 1.7 pct from an upward revised 827.25 billion yen n January.
Orders in February from the private sector rose 17.0 pct from a year earlier to 614.26 billion yen, for the fourth consecutive year-on-yea rise.
This comes after a 37.3 pct rise in January from a year earlier, to a downwar revised 598.09 billion.
The February increase over a year earlier reflected a 23.9 pct rise in orders from non-manufacturing industries, absorbing a 10.8 pct drop in those from manufacturer.
Public sector orders fell 17.8 pct from a year earlier to 183.54 billio yen.
There was an 11.4 pct year-on-year rise t 160.74 billion in January.
Foreign orders were 20.08 billion yen, down 47.7 pct from a year before, after a 69.9 pct drop o an upward revised 43.61 billion in January.
Orders below 10 mln yen fll 27.7 pct from a year earlier to 23.80 billion yen.
This was after a 5.9 pct decline to an upwad revised 24.81 billion in January.
The ustralian government telecommunications authority, Telecom Australia, said it will offer two bond maturities totalling 40 mln Australian dlrs for tender next week.
Telecom aid in a statement that it will offer 12.5 pct March 1990 bonds and 13.0 pct February 1993 stock.
ids close mid-morning local time on Monday.
Telecom said 52 mln dlrs of 1990 bonds and 10 mln dlrs of 1993 bonds are already o issue.
South Korea plans to increase the size of its budget in 1988 by 11 to 12 pct fro this year's 15,596 billion won, Economic Planning Board officials said.

The proposed boost is based on a government forecast that gross national product (gnp) will grow by more than 7.5 pct and the gnp deflator by 3.5 pct in 1988, against tarets of 8.0 pct and 3.5 pct respectively this year, they said.
Details of the 1988 budget, in which spending will match revenue, have yet to be wored out, the officials said.
The balanced budget in 1986 totalled 13,800.5 billion wo.
Australia's ruling Labour Party is seiously considering a snap poll in May with the opposition in disarray after a leadership crisis, party officials said.
The election was discussed at a meeting of senior government advisers and leaders in Canberra last night, but a final decision is pending, the offcials said.

Prime Minister Bob Hawke has said he prefers to wait until his term eds in early 1988, but the officials said he might be persuaded to call a poll as early as May 9, a week before a promised tough mini-budget.
Public opinion polls give Labour a clear edge over the opposition Liberal-National coaition.
Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd <JARD.HKG> said it planned a bonus issue of four new "B" shares of 20 .K.
Cents each for every ordinary share of par value tw dlrs.
A company statement said the firm expects to pay a total 1987 dividend of four cents per "B" share, while the "A" share dividend will be maintained at last year's levl of 40 cents a share.
Jardine Matheson announced earlier a 205 pct jump in 1986 net profits to 479 mln dlr from 157 mln in 1985.
Shareholders' funds increased to 5.02 billion dlrs fro 4.77 billion in 1985, the statement said.

It quoted chairman Simon Keswick as saying Jardine Matheson achieved the good performance through satisfactory results in most sections, espeially Hong Kong Land Co Ltd <HKLD.HKG>, Jardine Fleming Co Ltd, and its business in Japan.

He said the group's stake of about 35 pct in Hong Kong Land, which will be lowered to 26 pt after the completion of a reorganisation, is "a long term investment and now stands at a level which causes us no financial strain or problems of asset imbalance."

Keswick said the issue f new "B" shares will give the group "the flexibility in the future to issue ordinary shares for expansion without jeopardising the shareholding stability which has been brought about through the group's recent restructuring."
He said he new issue is pending approval from both the firm's shareholders and warrant holders, adding an appropriate adjustment will be made to the warrant exercise price.
The Jardine group has nearly completed its reorganisation, with Jardine Matheson transferring its control of Hk Land to the new unit <Jadine Strategic Holdings Ltd>.

Jardine Strategic will also hold majority stakes in the two companies spun off fom Hk Land -- <Mandarin Oriental International Ltd> and <Dairy Farm International Holdings Ltd> -- plus cross holdings with Jardine Matheson.
Jardine Matheson, which had debts of about 2.7 billion dlrs last year, will become debt fre after the restructuring.
"A positive cash flow from operations and disposals, continuing into 1987, has transformed our balance sheet" Keswick said.
He noted the firm last year sold interests in airfreight operations, Australian properties and trucking business, and its remaining U.S. Oil an gas activities.
Jardine Matheson decided to make a provision against its general trading business in the Middle East in view of the continuing weakness of oil prices, Keswick aid.
But e said the operations would be profitable in the longer term.
He said the irm's function "has evolved into one primarily of strategy, structure and financial and personnel policy."
He said Jardine Matheson will reduce the size of the board o directors but will simultaneously create a new Pacific regional board.
He gave no further details o the change.
Jardine Matheson shares rose 20 cents to 24.90 dlrs at midday o the Hong Kong stock market.
In early trading it had fallen to 24.30 dlrs because of rumours yesterday that the firm planed a rights issue.

The Broken Hill ty Co Ltd <BRKN.S> said it expects a strong full year result, helped by sigificant investment allowance credits in the fourth quarter, but net will fall short of the record 988.2 mln dlrs earned in 1985/86 ended May 31.
The group earlier reported its net earnings dropped to 603.0 mln dlrs in the first three quartrs ended February 28 from 813.0 mln a year earlier.
hird quarter net fell to 206.0 mln dlrs from 238.6 mln a year earlier and 220.3 mln in the second quarter ended November 31, BHP said in a statement.
arnings in the first nine months were at the lower end of share analysts' forecasts yesterday of a range of 600 mln to 620 mln dlrs.
BHP held ts annual dividend unchanged at 37.5 cents after declaring a steady final dividend of 20 cents and announced a one-for-five bonus issue to shareholders registered May 1.
The bonus s being made from reserves which will not qualify for tax-free distribution after the introduction of dividend imputation next July 1.
The onus shares will not rank for the final dividend, BHP said.
BHP said t should not be expected that the present rate of dividend will be maintained on the increased capital.
he level of future dividends will be influenced by the implications of the proposed dividend imputation legislation, it said.
As previously reported, dividends will become tax-free in shareholders' hands provided they are paid out of profits that have borne the full 49 pct compan tax rate.
BHP, which confined comment to the third quarter, said peroleum net earnings dropped to 98.8 mln dlrs from 139.6 mln a year earlier, and steel profit to 27.0 mln from 48.8 mln.

BHP said the petroleum division earnings fall reflected generally lwer oil prices and sales volumes from Bass Strait while the steel decline was due to a five pct fall in domestic sales and higher costs associated with the commissioning of new plant and some operational difficulties.
The rise in third quarter minerals net to 95.7 mln dlrs from 81.5 mln a yar earlier largely reflected the increase in ownership of the Mt Newman iron ore project, it said.
The 60.7 mln dlr extraordinary gain, all in the third term, reflected a 240.7 mln proft on the sale of <Blue Circle Southern Cement Ltd> offset by a U.S. Oil acreage writedown.
The Reserve Bank said it will not offr any treasury notes for tender next week.
Last week the Bank offered 400 mln dlrs of 13-week notes and 100 mln dlrs o 26-week notes.
Analysts said the Bank's decision not to offer stock next week reflects the higher demand fr funds at the start of the system of provisional tax payments.
Japan's current account surplus rose to 7.38 billion dlrs in February from 3.89 billion a year ag and from 4.95 billion in January, the Finance Ministry said.
The trade surplus rose to 8.14 billion dlrs in February from 4.77 billion a year earlier an 5.70 billion in January.
The long-term capital account deficit widened to 11.40 billion dlrs from 8.06 billion a year ago, bu it narrowed from 12.32 billion in January, the Ministry said.
Japan's February exports rose to 16.74 billion dlrs from 14.89 billion in February 1986 and from 14.65 billion in January, the inistry said.
Impors fell to 8.61 billion from 10.12 billion a year earlier and 8.94 billion in January.
The invisible trade deficit fell to 617 mln dlrs i February from 693 mln a year earlier, but was up from a 527 mln deficit in January.
Figures do not tally exctly because of rounding.
Transfer payments narrowed to a 140 mln dlr deficit lat month from a 185 mln deficit a year earlier and a 225 mln deficit in January.
The basic balance of payments deficit in February fell t 4.02 billion dlrs from 4.17 billion in February 1986 and 7.37 billion in January.
Short-term capital account pyments swung to a 1.28 billion dlr deficit in February from a 1.60 billion surplus a year earlier and a 1.44 billion dlr surplus in January.
Errors and omissions ere 2.65 billion dlrs in surplus, compared with a 1.27 billion surplus a year earlier and a 1.10 billion deficit in January.
The overall balance of payments deficit rose to 2.65 billion dls from 1.30 billion a year earlier but was down from 7.04 billion in January.
The seasonally adjusted trade surplus fell to 9.16 billion dlrs i February from the record 9.58 billion in January, the Ministry said.
The seasonally adjusted current account surplus also dropped to 8.4 bilion dlrs in February from the record 8.83 billion set in January.

Department store and supermarket sales in February rose 3.7 pct from a year earlier to 1,080 billion yen, after a 2.6 pct year-on-year gain in January, boosted by higher sales of clothes and food t department stores, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said.
The unadjusted total included department store sales of 559 billion yen, up 5.1 pct from a year earlier, and supermarket sales of 521 billion, up 2. pct.
The seasonally adjusted store sales index (base 1985) fell 1.5 pt to a preliminary 106.7 in February from 108.3 in January compared with 102.9 a year earlier.

The Philippines will ask the U.S. Agriculture Department (USDA) to increase it 1987 sugar import quota following market reports that Taiwan will not be able to fulfil its quota, Sugar Regulation Administration (SRA) chairman Arsenim Yulo said.
Yulo told Reuters the SRA woul also protest a USDA move to award Taiwan's shortfall to the Dominican Republic.
The Dminican Republic already has a larger sugar quota, Yulo said.
"Any Taiwanese shortfall hould be awarded to the Philippines or at the least we should share a hike with the Dominican Republic."
The USDA last Dcember listed 1987 sugar import quota allocations for the Dominican Republic at 160,160 short tons and for Taiwan at 10,920 short tons.
The Philippines has said t was badly hit by a cut in its quota to 143,780 short tons from 231,660 in 1986.

India's castor oil exports are provisionally estimated at 30,000 tnnes in fiscal 1986/87, ending March 31, against 54,000 tonnes in 1985/86 due to a shortfall in the domestic castorseed crop, private traders said.
Drought in parts of the country is expected to reduce the castorseed cro to a provisionally estimated 350,000 tonnes in 1986/87 from 550,000 tonnes in 1985/86, they told Reuters.
The U.S. Has approved the sale of a U.S.-made supercomputer to India while rejecting is request for a more powerful model, the New York Times reported.

India wanted to buy a powerful supercomputer, such as the Cray X-MP with two processors running in tandem, but the Times said U.S. Officials offered a choice of machines wit a single processor, several generations behind the Cray X-MP.
The paper, citing unnamed U.S. Officials, said the Indian government was told of the decision last week, but has so far given no formal indication that it i interested in the type offered.
India had asked the U.S. For an modern supercomputer which it indicated would be used for scientific purposes, notably sophisticated weathr forecasting.
However, India's close ties with the Soviet Union remains the main reason why the U.S. Has restricted the sale f its state-of-the-art computer technology to India, the Times said.
U.S. Defence officials are particulalry concerned the Soviet Union could gain access to the supercomputer and use it to ecipher high-level U.S.
Codes, while others say the computer could be very useful i designing nuclear weapons.
<United States Lines Inc> has laid off 260 employees, almost is entire Far East staff, its Hong Kong office general manager Elliott Burnside told Reuters.

Fisons Plc <FISN.L> aid it planned to raise about 110 mln stg through an international placing of up to 18 mln new shares, mainly in Europe and the Far East.

Outgoing United States Ambassador Stephen Bosworth told a news conference he did not think the Philippines would follow Brazil's example an suspend interest payments on foreign loans from commercial banks.
"I see no evidence that the Philippine government even contemplates oing that.
It has said at the outset that it accepts te legitimacy of these debts and it is determined over time to meet its obligations fully," he said.
Philippine officials and a 12-bank committee have been meeting fr the past four weeks in New York in a bid to reschedule 9.4 billion dlrs of foreign debt.
Bosworth said the United States strongly supports Manila's bid t put its international financial situation in order and that the private bank creditors were aware of that.
"I think there is no question that the private banks are aware of the views of the U.. Government ...
I am confident they will take those views into account when they make their own decisions," Bosworth said
He added: "These are privte banks.
They are responsible o their shareholders and they have to make their decisions on their own.
But I am cnfident they understand the views of the United States and our strong support."

Sri ankan Food Department officials said the U.S. Department of Agriculture rejected a U.S. Firm's offer of 80 U.S. Dlrs per tonne CAF to supply 52,500 tonnes of soft wheat to Colombo from the Pacific Northwest.
hey said Sri Lanka's Food Department subsequently made a counter-offer to five U.S. Firms to buy wheat at 85 U.S. Dlrs CAF for April 8-16 delivery.
he company which obtains USDA approval for the proposed price must inform the Department before 1330 gmt, they said.

Philippine sugar production in the 1987/88 rop year ending August has been set at 1.6 mln tonnes, up from a provisional 1.3 mln tonnes this year, Sugar Regulatory Administration (SRA) chairman Arsenio Yulo said.
Yulo told Reuters a survey during the current milling season, which ends next month, showed the 1986/87 estimate would almost certinly be met.
He said at least 1.2 mln tonnes of th 1987/88 crop would be earmarked for domestic consumption.
Yulo said about 130,000 tonnes would be set aside for the U.S. Sugar quota, 150,000 tones for strategic reserves and 50,000 tonnes would be sold on the world market.
He said if the government approved a long-standing SRA recommendation to manufacture ethanol, the project woud take up another 150,000 tonnes, slightly raising the target.
"The government, for its own reasons, has been delaying approval of the project, but we expct it to come through by July," Yulo said.
Ethanol could make up five pct of gasoline, cutting the oil imort bill by about 300 mln pesos.
Yulo said three major Philippine distilleries were ready to start manufacturing etanol if the project was approved.
The ethanol project would result in employment for about 100,000 people, shrply reducing those thrown out of work by depressed world sugar prices and a moribund domestic industry.
Production quotas, set for the first time n 1987/88, had been submitted to President Corazon Aquino.
"I think the President would rather wait tll the new Congress convenes after the May elections," he said.
"But there is rally no need for such quotas.
We are right ow producing just slightly over our own consumption level."
"The producers have never enjoyed such hgh prices," Yulo said, adding sugar was currently selling locally for 320 pesos per picul, up from 190 pesos last August.
Yulo said prices were driven up bcause of speculation following the SRA's bid to control production.

"We are no longer concerned so much with the world market," he said, adding producers in the Negros region had learned from their mistaes and diversified into corn and prawn farming and cloth production.
He said diversification into products other than ethanol was also possible within the sugar indusry.
"The Brazilians long ago learnt thir lessons," Yulo said.
"They have 300 sugar mills, compared with our 41, but they relocted many of them and diversified production.
We want o call this a 'sugarcane industry' instead of the sugar industry."
He said sugarcane could be ed to pigs and livestock, used for thatching roofs, or used in room panelling.
"When you ut sugarcane you don't even have to produce sugar," he said.
Yulo aid the Philippines was lobbying for a renewal of the International Sugar Agreement, which expired in 1984.
"As a major sugar producer we are urging them t write a new agreement which would revive world prices," Yulo said.
"If there is no agreement world prices will always b depressed, particularly because the European Community is subsidising its producers and dumping sugar on the markets."
He said current world prices, holding steady at about 7.0 cents per pound, were uneconomical for the Philippines, where production costs ranged from 12 to 14 cents a pound.
If the price holds steady for a while at 7.60 cents I expect the level to rise to about 11 cents a pound by the end of this year," he said.
ulo said economists forecast a bullish sugar market by 1990, with world consumption outstripping production.
e said sugar markets were holding up despite encroachments from artificial sweeteners and high-fructose corn syrup.
"But we are not hapy with the Reagan Administration," he said.
"Since 1935 we have ben regular suppliers of sugar to the U.S.
In 1982, when they restored the quota system, they ct ours in half without any justification."
Manila was keenly watching Washington's moves to cut domestic support prices to 12 cens a pound from 18 cents.
The U.S. Agriculture Department last December slashed its 12 month 1987 sugar import quota from the Philippines to 143,780 short tons from 231,660 short tons in 1986
Yulo aid despite next year's increased production target, some Philippine mills were expected to shut down.
"At least four of the 41 mills were not working durin the 1986/87 season," he said.
"We expect two or three more to follow suit during the next seaso."

ll figures are subject to rounding.

Mitsubishi Corp <MITT.TOK> aid it has taken a 25 pct stake worth five mln krone in <Danish Dairy Farms Ltd> and will jointly market its produce from April.

apan has sought to assure the U.S.
It is not rying to keep foreign equity in a new Japanese international telecommunications company below the legal limit of 33 pct, a Post and Telecommunications ministry official said.

In a letter sent yesterday, Postal Minister Shunjiro Karasawa told U.S. Comerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige that the ministry does not object to foreign participation by those U.S. Firms that have expressed interest.
But it does oppose any foreign international telecommunications carrier having a maagement role, he said.

The move appears to be an effort to dampen U.S. Opposition to the planned merger of two rival firms seeking to compete with the current monopoly <Kokusai Denwa Denshin Co Ltd>, and to reduce the share hed in any KDD rival by U.K.'s Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L>, industry analysts and diplomats said.

One of the rival firms, <International Telecom Japan Inc> (ITJ) has offered a stake in the company to eight U.S. Firms including General Electric Co <GE>, Ford Motor Co <F> and Citibank NA <CCI), and two Euroean companies, ITJ president Nobuo Ito said yesterday.
Cable and Wireless holds a 20 pct share in a second potential KDD rival, <International Digital Communications Planing Inc>, along with <C Itoh and Co>.
Merrill Lynch and Co Inc <MER> and Pacific Telesis International Inc <PAC>, both of the U.S., Hold thre and 10 pct shares respectively.
The Post and Telecommunications Ministry has urged the merger of the two firms because it says the market can only suppot a single KDD competitor.
It has also rejected management participation by an international common carrier, such as Cable and Wireless, arguing no international precedent fo such a stake exists.

Cable and Wireless Director of Corporate Strategy, Jonathan Solomon, yesterday again told ministry officials he opposes a merger proposal that would limit Cable and Wireless' share to less than three pct and total foreign participation to about 20 pct, the miistry official said.
Channeling the U.S. Firms into a single merge competitor would most probably result in diluting Cable and Wireless' share, industry analysts said.
"Eventually the ministry will get what it wnts -- one combined competitor," Bache Securities (Japan) Ltd analyst Darrell Whitten said.
Leverage may get the total foreign share up t a certain amount, but you won't find any one company with an extraordinarily large holding," Whitten said.
Western diplomatic sorces were more blunt.
"They (the ministry) don't want to see Cable ad Wireless with a reasonable share and they think of all sorts of strategies to reduce that share," one said.

Fumio Watanabe, a senior Keidanren (a leading business organization) official who has been trying to arrange the merger, will present a ne outline of his proposal on Thursday, the ministry official said.

Botswana has stopped importing almost all meat proucts from Zimbabwe after reports of a suspected outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the neighbouring country.

imbabwean officials were not immediately available for comment.
he ban will affect products such as uncanned meat, milk, ham, butter and bacon, BOPA reported.

Italy's budget ministry said yesterday that GDP rose 2.7 pct in eal terms in 1986.
DRI forecast that inflation, which was an average 6.3 pct in 1986, will be under five pct this year and that interest ates should drop two pct.
Girardin said the lira is exected to appreciate 14 pct against the dollar this year following last year's 22 pct appreciation.
An expected German mark appreciation aainst the dollar means that the lira should lose about six pct of its value relative to the German currency, he said.
DRI estimates that foreign demand or Italian products should grow by a 3.2 pct this year following last year's 6.2 pct increase.
Japan today announced nother mammoth monthly trade surplus that economists said would be sure to intensify already mounting pressure on the country for action.
"The world has every reason to e furious with Japan for not moving more quickly," Jardine Fleming (Securities) Ltd economist Eric Rasmussen said.
The Finance Ministry said today that he trade surplus soared to 8.14 billion dlrs in February from 5.7 billion in January and 4.77 billion a year ago.
he current account surplus, which includes trade in services as well as goods, climbed to 7.38 billion dlrs last month from 4.95 billion in January and 3.89 billion a year ago.
fter being adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, the figures look a bit better, but not much.
n that basis, the trade surplus declined slightly in February to 9.16 billion dlrs from a record 9.58 billion in January.

"In the medium term we expect this modest improvement to continue but the pace of progress may be too slow to ward of further protectionism or further yen strength," said William Stirling, economist at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. A strong yen would make Japanese goods more expensive on world markets while making imports into the country cheaper.
"On a seasonally adjusted basis, we appear to be making some progress on gettig exports down," Jardine's Rasmussen said.
But imports do not seem to be picking up much because the Japanese econoy remains sluggish, he said.
Finance Ministry officials blamed last month's slower import growth on a decline in oil imports as refiners worked off stocks they ha built up in January.
The officials ook comfort from a decline in the volume of exports last month, after an unexpected year-on-year increase in January.
This means the effects f the two-year rise of the yen against the U.S. Dollar are finally beginning to have an impact on exports, they said.
But economists wrned that may not be soon enough for Japan's trading partners.
Thyssen AG <THYH.F> said it expects to post a good profit i 1987 despite anticipated losses in its mass steel-making operations this year.
Managing board chairman Dieter Spethmann told he annual meeting the group was satisfied with profit developments in the first half of the 1986/87 financial year to September 30.
The group's other three divisions -- speialty steel, capital goods and trading -- had made a profit so far in 1986/87, he added.
Spethmann said income fom associate companies had also been good in early 1986/87.
In 1985/86 Thyssen's world group profit fell to 370.1 mln marks from 472.4 mn in 1984/85, reflecting costs linked to its steel operations.
The company's dividend was an unchanged fiv marks.
A Thyssen spokesman told Reuters that planned job cuts at subsidiary Thyssen Stahl A would be higher than announced earlier.
Total job losses by 1989 were ow expected to total up to 7,800 against original projections of 5,900.
Thyssen Sahl employs some 40,000 people.
The amount of a eurobond issued yeserday by Walt Disney Co Ltd has been raised to 75 mln Australian dlrs from an original 60 mln, lead manager Warburg Securities said.
The issue, which matures n May 7, 1990, has a 14-1/2 pct coupon and is priced at 101-3/8 pct.

Recent slackness on Dutch capital markets has led some bankers to question the Central Bank's policy of pegging the guilder firmly to the West German mark and t ask for more flexiblility in exchange rate policy.

While agreeing with th Bank's commitment to defend the guilder strongly, some bankers want the Bank to make more use of the range within which the guilder and the mark can fluctuate against each other in the European Monetary System (EMS).
Roelof Nelissen, chairman of Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank NV (Amro) said the Central Bank' policy was overcautious.
I would like to suggest that the Bank use more freely the range given to the guilder in the EMS," Nelissen said at the presentation of Amro's 1986 annual report last week.
ithin the EMS, the mark is allowed to fluctuate against the guilder between 110.1675 and 115.235 guilders per 100.
he Central Bank maintains a stricter policy and tries to keep the mark below the 113.00 guilders per 100.
It regards a stable exchange rate as its man target, using interest rate policies to influence the exchange rate.
The reference of exchange rate goals above interest rate aims goes almost undisputed in the Netherlands.
ritics say the Bank keeps the reins unnecessarily short.
Rabobank ederland said in its latest economic bulletin: "By maintaining the 113.00 limit, the Central Bank raises the expectation it will always intervene above that level.
If it suddenly needs more flexibility it wil find it very hard to obtain."
Amro's Nelissen said relatively small changes in interest rates and exchange rates could cause substanial flows of securities business and sharp fluctuations on the Dutch capital market.
Large nterest rate changes were often needed to bring about small changes in the guilder/mark exchange rate, he added.
Unlike mro, Algemene Bank Nederland NV (ABN) says this is a price the Dutch have to pay.

It fully agrees ith the Central Bank's policy, director-general Julien Geertsema told Reuters, noting a 1983 decision not to revalue the guilder fully with the mark in the EMS hurt confidence in the Dutch currency.
"It is a pity we need such a wide interest rate difference between West Germany t maintain the exchange rate," he added.

Interest rate differentials between West Germany and the Netherlands are the main factors that trigger capital flows between the two countries, as the economic performance of the two does not difer much, economists said.

Data on 1986 capital flows between West Germany and the Netherlands have not yet been released, but in 1985 they accounted for only 10 pct of total trade flows between the two countries, pu at 110 billion guilders for 1986 by the Dutch-German Chamber of Commerce earlier this month.
Economists say capital flows are more sensitive to intrest and exchange rates.
West Germany is the Netherlands' largest single trading partner, taking 28 pct of Dutch exports an providing 26 pct of imports in the last quarter of 1986, Central Bureau of Statistics figures show.
At the moment, the rates for three month euromark deposits trade around 4.0 pct while the same deposits in guilders have a rate of aroun 5-7/16 pct.
Amro bank argues that the Dutch real interest rate will even rise further because of expectations of deflation here in 1987, contrasting with slight inlation in West Germany.
In the Netherlands, he cost of living is expected to decrease by 1.5 pct at a GNP growth rate of two pct, the Dutch Central Planning Agency said in its 1987 forecast last month.
German NP is seen rising by two to 2.5 pct, but with inflation between zero and 1.0 pct, according to most German forecasts.
But espite this upward push on real Dutch rates, money dealers do not expect the Central Bank to cut official rates independently without prior moves by the Bundesbank.
Following the West German interest rate cuts on Jnuary 22, the Dutch Central Bank did not lower its rates but set a 0.5 pct lower tariff for special advances and abandoned its credit surcharge.
Most traders were surprised y this move as they had expected the Bank to follow suit unconditionally, they said.
The Bank said it lwered the rate with the largest impact on the money market as far as the exchange rate permitted.
While not entirely unsympathetic to critics of its policies, th Central Bank keeps its grip firm and the range narrow.
"The European Monetary System is not only a relationship between the guildr and the mark.
Many times widening of the margin between the two would implicate we have to buy or sell large amounts of a third currency," Centrl Bank vice-director Jan-Hendrik Du Marchie Sarvaas said.
"If we allowed the guilder to become a little cheaper, the markets would start t believe it was weak.
We don't want tha.
We want to make clear that the guilder is just as strong as the mark, he said.

The German auction system of shares tading, retaining the business floor, can develop in parallel to off-floor computer trading introduced in London in the "Big Bang," Frankfurt stock exchange president Michael Hauck said.
Hauck told a conference that it was unclear if th Frankfurt floor would become superfluous.
The Frankfurt exchange did 55 ct of all German securities trading and was investing 86 mln marks in renovating its building.
A screen-delivered inhouse quotation system would soon be in place too.
The nature of the auction sstem limited how far trading hours could be extended from the present two-hour session.
Other practical problems inhibited the German ability to follow Londn's moves.
Official brokers, who set the prices, were under the control of the Financ Ministry.
This meant transfer of securities control to an independent body if desired, would need legislative changes, Hauck said.
"Shorting" stocks in Germany was also prohibited by the rules for pension an insurance funds.
They could thus not be lent out for te kind of speculative positions taken by London market makers.
But Hauck said the system in London could b criticised for being too distant from those it should serve.
Spain's air and rail transport was at a virtual standstill as airline ground staff and raiway workers joined university students and health workers in strikes against the Socialist government.
Railway workers and staff at the state airlines Iberia and Aviaco want pay rises of seven to eight pct but the government has imposed a ceiling of five pct to conrol inflation.
Under a government decree ordering the strikers to maintain minimum services Iberia was due to opeate 32 of its 330 flights and Aviaco 10 out of 82.
Flights to and from Spain by othr airlines were not affected.
Student demonstrations in several cities last night led to clashes with riot polce in Madrid, Cadiz and Saragossa.

The state railway network operated some commuter services but passengers who tried to use the few sleeper trains running last night were met by angy pickets and found compartments without light or heating.
World Bank President Barber Conable called on Japan to boost investment in develoing nations, for its own sake as well as that of the world economy.
"Japan has the means to make a major contribution to development in the Thid World," he told about 500 Japanese businessmen and academics.
"I would be plesed with additional support."
With 25 pct of the world's total banking assets, Japan could do more t help assist indebted Third World countries develop roads, bridges and other infrastructure, he said.
Conable aid additional commercial bank investment would also be to Japan's advantage.

It would profit from rchannelling its huge trade surplus into Third World economies -- notably those in South America, China and India -- that are likely to expand faster than those in the developed world, he said.
Japan is ow the second largest shareholder in the Bank's concessionary lending affiliate, the International Development Association (IDA).
It has also agreed recently to expand its contribution to another affiliate, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), Conabe noted.
Conable said the World Bank was expanding its structural adjustment loans, designed to encourage developing countries to open their economies moe to free competition and trade.
"Adjustment loans could rise to 30 pct (of total World Bank loans) in the near future, though maybe not this year, Conable told Reuters after his speech.
Such loans currently account for slightly over 2 pct.
Applied chemicals group Henkel KGaA <HNKG.F> said it is selling its Hamburg vegetable oil and fats subsidiary Noblee und Thoerl GbH to Oelmuehle Hamburg AG.
A company spokesman declined to give the purchas price.
Noblee, a supplier of specialised refined oils and fats to the food processing industry, had turnove of 161 mln marks last year.
A Henkel statement said the divestment was part of the company's strategy of concentrating on is core businesses.
For Oelmuehle, the acquisition of Noblee means access to new markets, the statemet added.

Soviet officials said foreign businessmen are expressing strong interest in establishing joint enterprises in the Soviet Union an already 30 preliminary agreements had been signed with Western firms.
But Western economic experts described foreign business interest as cautious and noted that no final contracts had been sealed to set up joint entures on Soviet territory.
Moscow last year invited companies in socialist, developing and capitalist countries to start joint ventures as part of a programme to open up th Soviet Union's foreign trade ties.
At the same time, a number of Soviet ministries and enterprises received the right to deal directly on world arkets.
Previously the Ministry of Foreign Trade monopolised all import and export business
Explaining the changes at a news conference today, Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Kamentsev said they had received a mixed reaction in the foreign press bu a warm response from businessmen.
Over 200 proposals for establishing joint ventures had been received from foreign firms, 121 of which had been judged of mutual interest, h said.
Thirty protocols had been signed and 12 projects were "practically impleented," including ventures with Finnish, Japanese, West German and American firms, he added.
But Western diplomats specialising in Soviet economic affairs said the protools were not legally binding and not a single contract had been finalised.

"The Soviet Union is selling the joint venture idea very hard because it wants to obtain new technology cheaply, but I wold say business reaction in the West has been cool so far," commented one diplomat.
Asked why this was so, he said the rules for running joint ventures were still unclear and no Western firm wanted to be the first t take a major financial risk.

Kamentsev, flanked by Foreign Trade Minister Boris Aristov, Foreign Trade Bank Chairman Yuri Ivanov and other officials, repeated terms for th establishment of joint ventures, including the ground-rule that the Soviet side must have a stake of at least 51 pct in any enterprise.
He said some businessmen had the mistaken impression that foeign partners could only take profits from the products which their enterprises exported.
"I would like to stress that the foreign partner can take profits from all the products which his ventre produces according to his share of the capital," Kamentsev said.
He added that the Soviet Union was interested in "long-term and stable contacts" with foreign firms and was ofering a number of tax breaks to companies which invested here.
Speaking about the reform giving individual Soviet trading organisations more autonmy, Kamentsev said 21 ministries and 75 enterprises now had the right to deal for themselves on world markets.
Organisations enjoying this right handled 25 pct of total Soviet trde including 40 pct of trade in machines and tools, he said.
The Ministry of Foreign Trade continued to conduct business for te remaining ministries and state enterprises and supervised trade in essential products such as food.
IBM Australia Credit Ltd is issuing a 75 mln Australian lr eurobond due April 24, 1990 with a 14-1/8 pct coupon and priced at 101-1/4, Salomon Brothers International Ltd said as lead manager.
The non-callable bonds will be isued in denominations of 1,000 and 10,000 dlrs and will be listed in Luxembourg.
Gross fees of 1-1/2 pct comprise 1/2 pct for management and underriting combined and one pct for selling.
There will b co-leads.
The borrower is wholly owned b International Business Machines Corp <IBM.N>.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will make an official week-long visit to the United States from April 29 and hold talks in Washington with Presiden Reagan, Chief Cabinet Secretary Masaharu Gotoda told reporters.
Government sources said Nakasone would try to resolve growing bilateral trade friction and discuss the June Venice summt of Western industrial democracies.
Foreign Minister Tadashi Kuranari will accompany Nakasone, ministry official said.
U.S. Industry sources in Washington said the White House Economic Policy Council was recommending trade sanctions against Japan fo violating the two countries' agreement on semiconductor trade.
Under the pact, Japan pledged to stop dumping microchips in the U.S. And Asia and open its domestic markt to U.S. Semiconductors.
Mexico denied reports that British bnks are resisting signing a 76 billion dlr new loan and rescheduling package.
In a statement, the Finance Miistry said the process for formalizing the package was going as planned.

Banking sources in London had been quoted earlier as saying th British banks were balking at signing the package in an effort to get all participants to contribute equally to a new 7.7 billion dlr loan contained in the deal.
However, the Finance Ministry statement sid all the British banks had promised their participation in the loan.
"The contribution of each one f them corresponds exactly to the request of the Mexican government," the statememt said.
The inistry said Citibank, which chairs Mexico's bank advisory committee, has received cables from the British banks "confirming said commitment."
The inistry said the books on the package would be closed by mid-April and the first 3.5 billion dlrs of the new money should arrive by the end of the month.
It lso said French, Swiss and "some" Canadian banks had subscribed to the package and that the remaining Canadian banks would sign the accord in the next few days.

The Bank of Spain suspended its daily money market assistance obliging borrowers to take funds from the second window, where on Wednesday rates were raised to 16 pct compared with 14 pct for norml overnight funds.
Money market sources said in view of high borower demand the suspension was likely to remain in effect until April 3, the start of the next 10-day accounting period for reserve requirements.
The suspension comes after the Bank yesterday gave 1,145 billion pesetas assistance, a record high for tis year.
It said 90 billion pesetas was provided at th second window.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will visit Washington next mnth in a bid to defuse mounting U.S. Anger over Japanese trade policies, but Western diplomats said they believed his chances of success were slim.

Boxed in by powerful political pessure groups and widespread opposition to his tax reform plans, Nakasone will be hard-pressed to come up with anything new to tell U.S. President Ronald Reagan and key U.S.
Cngressmen, they said.
News of he week-long visit starting April 29 coincided with news that Japan recorded a 8.14 billion dlr trade surplus last month, more than 70 pct higher than a year earlier.

It also came one day after the Reagan Administration's Economic Policy Council decided to take retaliatory action against Japan for its alleged failue to live up to a joint trade agreement on computer microchips.

Nakasone wants to go armed with two separate packages - one designed to pep up Japan's sagging economy and imports in the shortterm, the other to redirect the country in the medium term away from its over-dependence on exports for growth.
But government officials said political infighting could rob both packages of much of their punch and might even prevent one from seeing the liht of day.

Nakasone has insisted that the government would not draw up a package of short-term economic measures until after its 1987/88 budget passed parliment because he feared that would amount to a tacit admission that the budget was inadequate.
ut his hopes for quick passage of the budget in time for his trip have been shattered by a parliamentary boycott by opposition parties protesting over the sales tax plan.
aced with the possibility that he might have to go to the U.S.
irtually empty-handed, Nakasone today ordered his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with its own measures.
e can then tell Reagan the LDP package will form the basis of the government's plans, without losing face in parliament over the budget, political analysts said.

Officials working on the government's short-term economic package said t would probably include interest rate cuts on loans by government corporations, deregulation, measures to pass on some of the benefits of the strong yen to consumers in the form of lower prices, and accelerated public investment.
They said a record prtion of state investment planned for the entire 1987/88 fiscal year will take place in the first half, probably over 80 pct.
Diplomats said that was unikely to be enough to satisfy Reagan, who is under pressure from the Democrat-controlled U.S. Congress to take greater action to cut the huge American trade deficit.
To complement the short-term mesures, Nakasone is also likely to present Reagan with details of Japan's longer-term economic plans.

A high-ranking advisory body headed by former Bank of Japan goernor Haruo Maekawa is expected to come up with a final report outlining concrete steps to redirect the economy days before Nakasone is scheduled to leave for Washington.

Its recommendations are designed as a follow-up to Maekawa's report lst year on economic restructuring and are likely to cover such potentially politically explosive areas as agricultural reform and land policy, officials said.
While wanting to make the rport as explicit and detailed as possible, they said the political realities might force them to water down some of the committee's recommendations.
A subcommittee is considering what he Japanese economy might look like in the medium to longer term after it undergoes massive restructuring, officials said.
The subcommittee projects that the current account surplus will fall to les than two pct of Japan's total output, or gross national product, around 1993 or 1995.
Last year the surplus, which measures trade in goods and services, amouned to over four pct of gnp.
The subcommittee also projects annual economic growth for Japan of nearly four pct over that period and a very gradual appreciation of te yen, to about 130 to the dollar by around 1993, from 150 now.
The Bank of England said it provided the money maket with 265 mln stg in assistance this morning.
This compares with the bank's estimate of the shortage i the system of 750 mln stg, earlier revised up from 700 mln.
The central bank purchased bank bills outright comprising 119 mln stg in band one at 9-7/8 pct, 144 mn stg in band two at 9-13/16 pct and two mln stg in band three at 9-3/4 pct.
The Bank of Japan intervened in the market to keep the dollar above 149 yen but the unit was under strong selling pressure by an investmnt trust, dealers said.

The central bank stepped into the market when the dollar fell towards 149.00 yen, but a trust bank aggressively sold dollars to hedge currency risks, and the Bank interveed again at 149.00, they said.
The trust bank apparently changed its earlier view that the dollar would rise and started selling relatively large amounts of dollars, pushing the unit down to 148.80 at oe point, brokers said.
One dealer estimated that the Bank bought 400 mln to 500 mln dlrs as i tried to keep the U.S. Currency above 149 yen.
The Bank of France intervened in the Paris foreign exchange market ths morning for the third successive day, banking sources said.
Like yesterday, it bought dollars and sold yen in small amounts, thy said.
One dealer said it was seen in the market twice in ealy dealing, buying five mln dlrs each time.
Other dealers also reported small-scale intervention to stabilise the dollar after aggressive selling overnight in Tokyo, where the Bank of Japan also intervened again
The dollar steadied at aroun 6.0650/0700 francs after easing in early trading to 6.0615/35 from an opening 6.0700/50.
It close yesterday at 6.0800/30.

One major french bank said it bought 10 ml dlrs for the central bank, selling yen, within a trading range of 148.20/30 yen to the dollar, compared with yesterday's 149.28 rate at which intervention was carried out here.
The yen later firmed to around 147.90/148.0.
The Bundesbank entered the open market in the late morning to buy dollars against yen in concert with th Bank of France, dealers said.
The Bundesbank came into the market when the dollar was around 148.10 yen just after it had fallen belo 148 to touch 147.80 at 1027 GMT.
Th move had little effect, with the dollar still testing 148 yen ahead of the official fixing.
Dealers said the intervention was for fairly small amounts, in contrast to the Bundesbank's activity on Wednesday when dealers reported it bought about 10 mln dlrs.
The Bundesbank had no omment.
The finance ministry appears ready to allow Japanese finacial institutions to use overseas financial futures markets, a ministry official said.
He declined to say whn, but banking sources expect approval as early as April.
Banks, securities houses and insurance companies are expected t become eligible to deal in deposit, interest rate, bond and stock index futures.
Ministry officials said they are wary of giving permssion to individuals or corporations because of their relative inexperience.
Broking for Japanese residents by financial institutions would b prohibited as securities exchange laws bar banks from doing this, the banking sources said.
Overseas subsidiaries and branches of Jaanese banks and securities houses have already been allowed to use the overseas futures markets on their own accounts.
The Finance Ministry Ordinance based n Foreign Exchange Administration Law will have to be revised to allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a ministry official said.
<Brierley Investments Ltd> (BIL) launched a full takeover bid fr the supermarket group <Progressive Enterprises Ltd> at 4.35 dlrs a share.
BIL said in a statement the offer is conditional on minimum acceptances totalling 30 mln shares, just under 25 pct of the 120.4 mln Progressive shares on isue.
Progressive is curently involved in a proposed merger with <Rainbow Corp Ltd>.
Rainbow earlier tis week raised its stake in Progressive to 52 pct.
BIL opposes the Rainbow merger and analysts say BIL needs a 25 pct stake in Progressive to prevent t occurring.
The merger involves shareholders in Progressive and Rainbow both receiving shares in a new company <Astral Pacific Corp td> on a one-for-one exchange basis.
The BIL bid is higher than the 4.20 dlrs BIL said it would offer when it first announced on Monday it would make a full bid for Progressive, and it follows much public debate between BIL an Rainbow.
BIL Chief Executive Paul Collins said lst week that he opposes the Rainbow/Progressive merger because BIL sees Progressive shares as being worth twice as much as Rainbow's.
BIL has not dislosed how many Progressive shares it holds.
Rainbow has said he merger is soundly based.
Chairman Allan Hawkins said last week that BIL's actions were aimed only at dirsrupting the merer and were not in the interests of Progressive shareholders.
Both Rainbow's and Progressive's boards have approved te merger proposal.
It has also been approved by the Commerce Commission, but BIL's bid is still subject t the Commission's scrutiny.
Progressive shares ended at 4.35 dlrs, Rainbow at 3.42 and BIL at 4.17 at the close of New Zealand Stock Exchange tradig today.

<Helikopter Service A/S>, Norway's biggest helicopter operator, will assemble 18 Bell 412 SP helicopters for Norwegian Defence under license from <Bell Helicopters Textron> o the U.S., The company said.
The 18 medium-range helicopters, worth 540 mln crowns, will be assembled at the company's facilites at Sola airport in Stavanger.
Helikopter Service technical director Tygve Eidem said the 25-mln crown assembly contract will help the company diversify its operations.
Helikopter Service's main income s from chartered flights between Norway's North Sea oil fields and mainland heliports.

The 50-day provisional 1987/88 budget, adopted today by te government, allows the Finance Ministry to issue up to 14,600 billion yen worth of foreign exchange fund financing bills, government sources said.
Foreign exchange dealers said the yen funds would b used to buy dollars, to prevent a further dollar fall.
The government sources said the amount, covering the first 50 days of the year starting April 1, accounts for more than 90 pct of the 16,000 billion yen in bills incorporated in the full budgt.
The amount of a eurobond issued yesterday by Walt Disney Co Ltd has been raised to 75 mln Australian lrs from an original 60 mln, lead manager Warburg Securities said.
The issue, which matures on May 7, 1990, has a 14-1/2 pct coupon and is priced at 101-3/8 pt.
<Fletcher Challenge Ltd> (FCL) chairman Ron Trotter will step aside as chief executive in October on reaching 60 and will be replaced by grup managing director Hugh Fletcher, FCL said in a statement.
Fletcher, 39, whose grandfather James Fletcher was the founder of <Fletcher Indusries> from which FCL partly takes its name, joined the group in 1969.
He holds master of commerce, bachelor of science and MBA degrees from Harvard University and is also chairman of Ai New Zealand.
No new managing director has been named yet to replce him.

Reports the Soviet Union has lately extended its recent buying programme by taking five to eight raws cargoes from the free market at around 30/40 points under New York May futures highlight recent worldwide demand for sugar for a variety of destinations, traders aid.
The Soviet buying follows recent whites buying by India, Turkey and Libya, as well as possible raws offtake y China.
Some 300,000 to 400,000 tonnes could have changed hands in current activity, which is encouraging for a sugar trade which previousl saw little worthwhile end-buyer enquiry, they added.
Dealers said a large proportion of the sales to the Soviet Union in the past few days involved Jpanese operators selling Thai origin sugar.

Prices for nearby shipment Thai sugars have tghtened considerably recently due to good Far Eastern demand, possibly for sales to the Soviet Union or to pre-empt any large block enquiries by China, they said.
Thai prices for March/May 15 shipments have hardened to around 13/14 points under May New Yor from larger discounts previously, they added.
Traders said the Soviet Union might be looking to buy more sugar in the near term, possibly towards an overall requirement this year of around tw mln tonnes.
It is probable that some 1.8 mln tonnes have already been taken up they said.

Turkey was reported this week to have bought around 100,000 tonnes of whites while India had further whites purchases of two to thee cargoes for Mar/Apr at near 227 dlrs a tonne cost and freight and could be seeking more.
Libya was also a buyer this week, taking two cargoes of whtes which, for an undisclosed shipment period, were reported priced around 229/230 dlrs a tonne cost and freight, they added.
utures prices reacted upwards to the news of end-buyer physicals offtake, although much of the enquiry emerged recently when prices took an interim technical dip, traders said.
akistan is lined up shortly to buy 100,000 tonnes of whites although traders said the tender, originally scheduled for tomorrow, might not take place until a week later.

Egypt will be seeking 20,000 tonnes of May arrival white sugar next week, while Greece has called an internal EC tender for 40,000 tonnes of whites to be held in early April, for arrival in four equal parts in May, Jun, July and August.

Three Dutch computer leasing firms are charging the Dutch unit of International Business Machines Cor <IBM.N> with unfair trading practices, saying its prices undercut the leasing market, a court spokesman said.
He said the three firms started summary proceedings in the Amsterdam district court yesterday aganst IBM Nederland NV and its leasing finance subsidiary IBM Nederland Financieringen BV.
A verdict is expecte on April 16.
The three firms suing IBM here are IB Holland BV, ICA Europe BV and Econocom Nederland BV.
An IBM Nederland spokesman said the firm denied the charges but decined further comment.
<Union Miniere A> said in a statement that it has acquired an eight pct interest in Pancontinental Mining Ltd <PANA.S> for a sum equivalent to 1.2 billion Belgian francs.
Pancontinental operates old and coal mines in Australia and natural gas and oil fields in Canada.
Union Miniere said the location of its interest within the Pancontinental group wil be decided later.
It did not elaborte.
Union Miniere is a wholly owned subsidary of Societe Generale de Belgique <BELB.BR>.
outh Africa's trade surplus rose to 1.62 billion rand in February after falling to 906.2 mln in January, Customs and Excise figures show.
his compares with a year earlier surplus of 958.9 mln rand.
Exports rose slightly to 3.36 billion rand in February from 3.31 billion in January but imports fell to 1.74 billion from 2.41 bilion.
This brought total exports for the first two months f 1987 to 6.67 billion rand and imports to 4.15 billion for a total surplus of 2.52 billion rand against 1.71 billion a year earlier.

A scheme to distribute surplus food free to the poor in the European Community (EC), which was due to expire next Tuesday, will be partialy extended for a further month, an EC Commission spokesman said.
e added the executive Commission has not yet decided whether the scheme should become a permanent feature of the EC's struggle to find a use for its massive stocks of farm produce.

Almos 60,000 tonnes of cereals, sugar, beef, butter and other food have been authorised for distribution under an operation sanctioned by EC farm ministers on January 20 in which charities act as executive Commission agents.
The original iea was to help the needy survive this year's unusually cold European winter.
The spokesman said the Comission was extending the scheme fully in Greece, which has recently been hit by unseasonal snowstorms, for the month of April.
Other EC countries would b authorised to use stocks of food for which they have already applied under the scheme up to April 30.
The spokesman said this would enable distribution of flour, semolina, sugar and olive oil at a relativey high rate next month.
He said the Commission, which has powers to continue most aspects of the scheme without consulting minister further, will be considering soon whether it should be made permanent.
Cost, which has already reached around 65 mln European currency units, would be a major consideation.
End-January stocks included 1.28 mln tonnes of butter, 520,000 tonnes of beef and over 10 mn tonnes of cereals.
Veteran politician Giulio Andreotti abandoned his attempts to fom a government, putting Italy on course for early elections, political sources said.
Christian Democrat Andreotti told President Francesco Cossiga he ws unable to reconstruct the five-party coalition after two weeks of negotiations, they said.
India is searching for non-communist countertrade partners to help it cut is trade deficit and conserve foreign exchange.

Wheat, tobacco, tea, coffee, jute, engineering and eectronic goods, as well as minerals including iron ore, are all on offer in return for crude oil, petroleum products, chemicals, steel and machinery, trade sources told Reuters.
Most of the mpetus behind countertrade, which began in 1984, comes from two state trading firms -- the State Trading Corp (STC) and the Minerals and Metals Trading Corp (MMTC).

The two state trading corporations are free to use their buying power in respect to bulk commodities to promote Indian exports," a commerce ministry spokeswoman said, adding that private firms are excluded from countertrading.
ne trade source said India has targetted countries that depend on an Indian domestic market recently opened to foreign imports.

However, countertrade deals still ake up only a small part of India's total trading and are likely to account for less than eight pct of the estimated 18.53 billion dlrs in trade during the nine months ended December, the sources said.
ountertrade accounted for just five pct of India's 25.65 billion dlrs in trade during fiscal 1985/86 ended March, against almost nothing in 1984/85, official figures show.
owever, the figures exclude exchanges with the Eastern Bloc paid in non-convertible Indian rupees, the sources said.

Total trade with the Soviet Union, involving swaps of agricultural produce and textiles for Soviet arms and crude oil, is estimated at 3.04 billion dlrs in fiscal 1986/87, against three billon in 1985/86.

Indian countertrade, which is being promoted mainly to help narrow the country's large trade deficit, is still insignificant compare with agreements reached by Indonesia, Venezuela and Brazil, the trade sources said.
The trade deficit, which hit an estimated record 6.96 billion dlrs in 1985/8, is expected to decline to 5.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

But the push to include non-communist countries in countertrade is also due to other factors, including the slow growth of foreign reserves, a tight debt repaymnt schedule, shrinking aid and trade protectionism, businessmen said.
One source said India is showing more dynamism in promting countertrade deals than in the past, when the deals were made discreetly because they break GATT rules.
As a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs ad Trade (GATT), India cannot officially support bartering.
The MMTC's recent countertrade deals include iron ore exports t Yugoslavia for steel structures and rails.

"MMTC's recent global tenders now include a clause that preference will be given to parties who accept payment in kind for goods and services sold to India," a trade official said, adding that the policy remains flexble.
"We also take into account other factors such as prices at which the goods and services are offered to India," the trade offiial said.

Early this year the commerce ministry quietly told foreign companies interested in slling aircraft, ships, drilling rigs and railway equipment to India that they stood a better chance if they bought Indian goods or services in return, the trade sources said.
Illustrating the point, the official said a South Korean firm recently agreed to sell a drilling platform worth 40 mln dlrs to the state-run Oil and Natural Gas Comission.
Japan's current account surplus rose o 7.38 billion dlrs in February from 3.89 billion a year ago and from 4.95 billion in January, the Finance Ministry said.
The trade surplus rose to 814 billion dlrs in February from 4.77 billion a year earlier and 5.70 billion in January.
he long-term capital account deficit widened to 11.40 billion dlrs from 8.06 billion a year ago, but it narrowed from 12.32 billion in January, the Ministry said.
apan's February exports rose to 16.74 billion dlrs from 14.89 billion in February 1986 and from 14.65 billion in January, the Ministry said.
mports fell to 8.61 billion from 10.12 billion a year earlier and 8.94 billion in January.
The invisible trade deficit fell to 617 ln dlrs in February from 693 mln a year earlier, but was up from a 527 mln deficit in January.
Figures do not tlly exactly because of rounding.
Transfer payments narrowed to a 140 mln lr deficit last month from a 185 mln deficit a year earlier and a 225 mln deficit in January.
The basic balance of payments deficit in February fell to 4.02 billion dlrs from 4.17 billion in February 1986 and 7.37 billio in January.
Short-term capital account payments swung to a 1.28 billion dlr deficit in February from a 1.60 billion surplus a year earlier and a 1.44 billion dl surplus in January.
Errors and omissions were 2.65 billion dlrs n surplus, compared with a 1.27 billion surplus a year earlier and a 1.10 billion deficit in January.
The overall balance of payments deficit rose o 2.65 billion dlrs from 1.30 billion a year earlier but was down from 7.04 billion in January.
Japan's consumer price index (base 1985) was unchanged at 99.7 in February from a month earlier, the government's Management and Coodination Agenc said.
The ndex showed a 0.4 pct drop in January.
The February index wa down one pct from a year earlier for the third consecutive year-on-year drop.
In January, the index fell 1.1 pct from a year earlier, te first drop of over one pct since a 1.3 pct drop in September 1958.
South Africa's inflation rate, currently at 16.3 pct, should decline further during 1987, the Reserve Bank said i its latest quarterly review.
Although the recent fall in inflation was "largely attributable to purely statistical factors," the decline had clearly ben aided by a recovery in the rand's exchange rate, the Bank said.
"The inflation rate stands o benefit further from the more recent advances in the exchange rate in the third quarter of 1986 and in the first few months of 1987," it said.

Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone ha told his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to come up with a draft economic package in early April in time for his visit to Washington starting on April 29, government officials said.

Nakasone also instructed the government's Economic Planning Agency (EPA) to work closer with the DP to work out a full-fledged economic plan to boost domestic demand as pledged at last month's Paris currency stability accord by six industrial countries, the officials told Reuters.
Indian officials responded coolly to a reported U.S. Offer to sell India a supercomputer less powerful than it sought, saying it showed Washington's lack of sensitivity to Indin concerns.

Asked about a New York Times report that the United States had offered New Delhi a supercomputer generations behind the type it requested, an official told Reuters, "If the U.S. i doing that they have not been sensitive to Indian concerns."
He declined to confirm the report directly but said India had received an offer of a supercomuter from the United States "and we are considering it."
Sounding disappointed and dismayed he added, "We do not wish at this stage to say whether i is the computer we were looking for, or a more or less powerful model."
The official, who asked to remain anonymous, added: "An announcement will be made in 10 days t two weeks time."
India has sought for more than two years to buy an advanced supercomputer primarily for monoon forecasting.
But the sale has been held up by U.S. Security concerns prompted by India's closeness t the Soviet Union, its chief arms supplier.

The Swiss National Bank bought dollars against yn today, a spokesman for the bank said.
He declined to say how many dollars te bank bought or when precisely it intervened.
Swiss foreign exchange dealers described the National Bank's purchases as modest, perhaps amounting to n more than 20 or 30 mln dlrs.
The Bank of France, wich was reported buying dollars against the yen in Paris, had made inquiries with Swiss banks as well, and the Bundesbank had also intervened.
Bank of Jpan dollar purchases today were perhaps 1.2 to 1.5 billion dlrs.

Dealers said this tended to confirm the market's impression tat major industrial countries had agreed at the Paris meeting on an effective floor for the dollar of 148 yen, and the market seemed ready to test it.
Commercial clients were also selling dllars against the yen as the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31 drew closer.
Today's dealings n spot currencies are booked for March 31.

One dealer said he had the feeling Japanese companies had ben asked by the Bank of Japan not to sell dollars at this point, but some, while sticking to the letter of that request, were offering dollars forward today, rather than lose out if the dollar fell further.
The run on the dollar against the yen came in a market thinned by the absence of many dealers fo a Forex Club meeting in Hamburg.
Trading was, in fact, rather light against currencies other than the yen, the dollar holding little changed through the day
The market now expected the U.S. Federal Reserve to intervee in support of the dollar.
"But they will probably do it only half-heartedly, so I don't thnk it will matter too much on rates," one dealer said.
The government welcomed a wage settlement for public sector workers which was agreed late last night as a fair compromise for both sides, government spokesman Fridhelm Ost told reporters.
The wage settlement gives 2.3 mln wrkers in federal, state and local governments a 3.4 pct wage increase for 1987, retroactive from January 1.
The public sector union OeTV had oriinally sought a six pct increase, while the government's initial offer was 2.7 pct.
U.S. consumer prices, as measured by the Consumer Price Idex for all urban consumers (CPI-U), rose a seasonally adjusted 0.4 pct in February after a 0.7 pct January gain, the Labor Department said.
The CPI for urban wge earners and clerical workers (CPI-W) rose to 329.0 in February, the department said.
Prices for petroleum-based nergy rose sharply for a second consecutive month during February but by less than in January, the department said.
Energy prices rose .9 pct last month after a 3.0 pct rise in January, accounting for one-third of the overall CPI rise.
For he 12 months ended in February, the CPI rose an unadjusted 2.1 pct.
Transportation rices rose 0.5 pct in February after a 1.5 pct increase in January.
Smaller price rises for motor fuels and decines in new car prices and finance charges were responsible for the moderation.
Gasoline prices rose 4.2 pct last month ater increasing 6.6 pct in January, but were still 18 pct below levels of a year ago, the department said.
Housing prices rose 0.4 pct in February ater a 0.5 pct January increase, largely due to a rise in fuel oil prices.
Fuel oil prices were up .4 pct in February after increasing 9.8 pct in January, but were still 15 pct below price levels of February 1986.
Food prices rse 0.2 pct last month after a 0.5 pct January increase.
Grocery store food prices were p 0.4 pct, the same as in January, but meat, poultry, fish and eggs cost less for a third consecutive month, the department said.
Medical care rose 0.3 pct in February to a level 7.1 pct above one year ago, because of higher costs for prescription and non-prescription drugs and medical upplies, the department said.
he index for apparel and upkeep rose 0.7 pct in February after a 0.4 pct increase in January.
he department said the introduction of higher priced spring merchandise, particularly men's clothing, was responsible for the advance.
Prices for other goods and services rose 0.7 pc in February following a 1.1 pct increase in January.
Tobacco prices, up 0.9 pct after a 2.0 pct January increase, accounted for 30 pct of the index rise, th department said.
A federal judge has denied motions by several banks for summary dismissal of lawsuits challenging the loans they made to the Hnt brothers' two energy companies.

Nelson Bunker, W. Herbert and Lamar Hunt sued the 2 banks last year for 13.8 billion dlrs in damages after halting payment to the banks on 1.5 billon dlrs in overdue loans to <Placid Oil Co> and <Penrod Drilling Co>.

The ruling announced Thursday by Judge Barefoot Sanders clears the way for the Hunts to examine documents and interview officers at the banks seking evidence to support their charges of fraud, breach of fiduciary duty and interfering with the companies ability to pay back the loans.
Judge Sanders also rejected parts of the Unts' suit, including allegations te banks were trying to monopolize the drilling-rig business.
He reserved judgment on other Placi and Penrod complaints, including charges the banks acted in bad faith on the loans.
MacMillan Bloedel Ltd said shareholders auhorized a previously announced three-for-one stock split, applicable to holders of record April nine.
The company said its stock will begin trading o a split basis on April 3, subject to regulatory approvals.
Very stormy weather is likely in the North Sea through Saturday, disruptig shipping in the region, private forecaster Accu-Weather Inc said.
Rain will accompany the strong winds that are expected over the Noth Sea today into tonight.
Saturday will also be very widy and cooler with frequent showers.
Winds today will be southwest at 30 o 60 mph, but will become west to northwest tonight and Saturday at 25 to 50 mph.
Waves will build o 20 to 30 feet today and tonight and continue Saturday.
Wind and waves wll not diminish until late in the weekend.
The Finance Ministry is expected to introduce yen commercial paper, CP, frm October 1 in response to growing calls from corporations, ministry sources said.

Around 200 corporations satisfy financial standards set by securities houses for non-collateral straight bond issues, including electric power companies, <Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co Ltd, securities managers said.
Most eligible firms would have to set up special reserves for CP issues called backup lines, or b guaranteed by financial institutions to protect investors, they said.
The legal status of yen CP would be the same as yen commercial bills and it would b placed by an intermediary bank or securities house, securities managers said.
The minimum issue nit will be 100 mln yen, and maturities will be from 30 days and six months, they said.
Securities houses, banks, isurance companies and consumer credit companies are barred from CP issues, they said.
Only banks may be commissioned to handle the clerical business of principle payments, hey added.

A Liberian motor bulk carrier, the 72,203 dw tonnes Nikitas Roussos, which was grounded in the Suez canal yesterday has been refloated and is now proceeding through the the canal, Lloyds Shipping Intelligence said.
The finance ministry appears ready to allow Japanese financial institutions to use overses financial futures markets, a ministry official said.
He declined to say when, but baning sources expect approval as early as April.
Banks, securities ouses and insurance companies are expected to become eligible to deal in deposit, interest rate, bond and stock index futures.
Ministry officials aid they are wary of giving permission to individuals or corporations because of their relative inexperience.
Broking for Jpanese residents by financial institutions would be prohibited as securities exchange laws bar banks from doing this, the banking sources said.
Overseas subsidiaries and branches of Japanese banks and securities houses have already been allowed to use the overeas futures markets on their own accounts.
The Finance Ministry Ordinance based on Foreign Exchange Administration Law will have to be revised to allow local institutions to join the overseas markets, a minitry official said.
