The tonnage of oods passing through Ivory Coast's main port of Abidjan rose 2.3 pct last year, according to the Ivorian Chamber of Commerce.
Its monthly report aid 9.47 mln tonnes of goods passed through the port last year compared with 9.26 mln the year before.
Exports fell to .75 mln from 3.89 mln tonnes while imports rose to 5.72 mln from 5.37 mln.

Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that the Greek armed froces were ready to tackle any aggressors following the sailing of a Turkish research vessel and warships towards disputed waters i the Aegean Sea.
Papandreou told an emergency cabinet meeting in Athens "the military readiness of our country is able now to give a very hard lesson if our neighbours (Turkey) were to carry out militar actions."
He said the activities of the researh vessel could be aimed at partitioning the Aegean.
"The air force, navy and army are in a state of alert," Genral Guven Ergenc, Secretary General of the Turkish General Staff, told a news conference.
He said the Turkish research ship Sismik 1, escorted by an unspecified numer of warships, would sail into disputed waters in the Aegean Sea tomorrow morning.
Ergenc told Reuters later that all leave had been cancelled for members o the armed forces in the Aegean coast area.
The Turkish government said yesterday it had licensed the state-owned Turkish Petroleum Cor to explore for oil in international waters around three Greek islands off Turkey.
Greece and Turkey have long-standing disputes over areas of the Aegean and the presence of Turkish troops in Cyprs.

The latest row erupted when the Greek government said last month that it was taking control of a Canadian-led consortium which was already producing oil off the Greek island of Thassos and would drill in the sam area after the takeover.

Ergenc told the news conference the alert followed a government decision that Turkey should protect its interests "because of measures Greece has been taking in the Aegean in violation o international agreements."
Asked how Turkey would react if Greece attacked any of the vessels, he said "If there is an attak, it is clear what has to be done.
An attac on a warship is a cause for war."
But he added "We are not in a state of ar.
The measures taken by the military are directed towards protecting ou rights."
Greece said yesterday it would defend its national rights in the Aegean and urged Turkey to accept reference of the dispue to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
Turkish Foreign Mnistry spokesman Yalim Eralp told reporters today this was unacceptable because of preconditions Athens had attached.
In Athens, Greek Prime Minister Papandreou said that if the Turkish vessel Ssmik 1 began research operations "we will hinder it, of course not with words, as it cannot be stopped with words."
Greek newspapers said the armed forces wre on alert and navy ships had gone to the Aegean.
But government spokesman Yannis Roubatis did ot confirm the move, saying only "The Greek fleet is not at its naval base."
Papandreou said that a map issued n Turkey showed 95 pct of the areas proposed for research were on the Greek continental shelf.
Papandreou told the U.S. And NATO that if they had a part in orchestrating the present crisis in order to force Greece to negotate with Turkey, the Greek government would not accept it.
Papandreou has maintained in the past that he will not negotiate with Ankara until Turkey recognises Greek rights in the Aegean and withdraws its trops from Cyprus.
He said that in the case of war with Turkey it would not be possible for Greece to discuss the future of American military baes here.
Asked by reporters if he wold close the U.S.
Bases in Greece in the event of war, Papandreou replied "Obviously, ad perhaps even before the war."
Electricite de France is issuing 100 mln Swiss francs of 3-3/8 pct notes with warrants issed by Credit Suisse attached to buy gold, lead manager Credit Suisse said.
Each eight-year note of a 50,000-franc face value has 15 warrants, two of which entitle te holder to acquire 100 grams of gold at a price of 2,350 francs.
The strike price represents a premium of about 15 pct over the current market price o gold.
The warrants may be exercised from April 3, 1987, to April 30, 1990.
The notes, callable starting 1992 at 101.50, have a fina maturity on April 30, 1995.

Porsche AG <PSHG.F> aid it expects to post a satisfactory profit in 1986/87, with domestic volume sales seen lower but U.S.
Managing board chairman eter Schutz said domestic sales were expected to fall to 9,000 in the year ending July 31 from 11,340 in 1985/86.
Sales hould rise to more than 30,000 from 28,670 last year.
Schutz ade no specific profit or sales forecasts.
Last month the ompany said it expected net profit to fall below 70 mln marks this year from 75.3 mln marks in 1985/86.
For ales, Porsche expects its overall world volume this year to be above 50,000.
Sales ast year stood at 53,254, Schutz said.
His expectations of a satisfactory profit wre based on a combination of price rises and cost-cutting, he added.
The expected drop in West German sales this year would be the result of the so-called "grey market" for Porsche cars, e said.

When the dollar was strong against the mark, many Porsches had been bought locally in West Germany for illegal export to the U.S. Porsche has previously said domestic sales in the 1986/87 first half fell to 3,267 from 5,387 in the same 1985/6 period.
The fct that U.S.
Sales will account for a larger percentage of overall sales this year than before does not pose problems for profit, the Porsce board said.
In the last 12 months it has raised U.S. Prices by around 20 pct without sufferig any decline in sales.
At the same time Porsche has hedged its dollar-denominated business for the 1986/87 business year, finane director Heinz Branitzki.
Branitzki put Porsche's hedging costs in 1985/86 a 28 mln marks.
In a speech to the annual meeting, Schutz said third-party orders placed with Porsche's engineering research centre in Weissach were rising and should top 100 mln marks this year for the firt time.
Porsche's net profit dropped sharply to 75.3 mln marks in 1985/86 from 120.4 mln marks i 1984/85.
FCS Laboratories Inc said George D. Fowle Jr has resigned as president o the company and Garu Griffin resigned as treasurer, both effective March 31.
The company said directors elected Chairman Nicholas A. Gallo III to the additinal title of president and Chief Financial Officer Richard D. Mayo was elected treasurer.

A final compromise proposal on cocoa buffer stock rules presented by International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, coucil chairman Denis Bra Kanon is swiftly gaining acceptance by consumer and producer members, delegates said.
"We are close, nearer than ever to accepting it, but we still have some work t do," producer spokesman Mama Mohammed of Ghana told Reuters after a producers' meeting.
European Community, EC, delegates said EC consumers accepted the package in a morning meeting and predicted "no problems" n getting full consumer acceptance.
Delegates on both sides are keen to come to some agreement today, the last day of the fortnight-long counil meeting, they said.
The compromise requires that buffer stock purchases from non-ICCO member countries cannot exceed 15 pct of total buffer stoc purchases, delegates said.
The non-member cocoa issue has been among the most contentios in the rules negotiations.
The 15 pct figure, up fve percentage points from earlier proposals, represents a concession to consumers, delegates said.
They have demanded a larger alowance for non-member cocoa in the buffer stock than producers have wanted.

Another problem area, delegates said, was the question of price differentials or different origins of cocoa bought into the buffer stock, by which the buffer stock manager could fairly compare relative prices of different cocoas offered to him.
The compromise narrowed the range f differentials between the origins from what previous proposals had detailed -- a move some delegates described as "just fiddling."
But the adjustments may prove sinificant enough to appease some countries that were not satisfied with the original proposed differentials assigned to them, delegates said.
The compromise lso stated buffer stock purchases on any day would be limited to 40 pct each in nearby, intermediate or forward positions, delegates said.
If the cmpromise is accepted by the council, most consumers and producers want buffer stock rules to take effect next week, or as soon as practically possible.
The full ouncil is scheduled to meet around 1500 GMT to discuss the compromise, and could agree on it then if all parties are satisfied, they said.
Consumers re due to meet before the council.
<Dixons Group Plc> said it bought about 2,445,000 Cyclops Corp common shares, boosting its holdings of the company's stock to about 83 pct of those now outstanding and 79 pct on a fully diluted basi.
Dixons aid the stock was purchased in a single block transaction at 95 dlrs per share.

The co-leaders in the new Danish eurobond deal are Copenhage Handelsbank, Den Danske Bank and Kredietbank Luxembourg, Thuesen added.

<Elders Resources td> said its two-for-seven convertible unsecured notes issue will raise 161.32 mln dlrs for group expansion and development.

Venezuela will shortly send creditor banks a term sheet specifying the changes agreed last month in the country's 20.3 billion dl public sector debt rescheduling, finance minister Manuel Azpurua said.
Azpurua told reporters yesterday the document is in its "final phase' of preparation, and will be soon be sent to baks for approval.
"We expect that once the term sheet is received and analysed by the banks, it will be approved in a relatvely short time,' Azpurua said.

Under the new rescheduling agreement reached February 27, payments on Venezuela's public debt were extended from 12 to 1 years and the interest rate dropped from 1 and 1/8 to 7/8 of a pct above LIBOR.
In addition, payments for the 1987-1989 period were lowered frm 3.82 billion dlrs to 1.350 billion dlrs.
Venezuelan officials said this amounted to an effective grace perid, something the banks had refused to grant.
The agreement replaced a February, 1986 rescheduling accord which Venezuela asked banks to revise, citing a 40 pct drp in oil revenues last year.

hey will be underwriting six mln dlrs each instead of 10 mln dlrs.

hey will be underwriting three mln dlrs each instead of five mln dlrs.

estpac launched the facility early this month at 200 mln dlrs but soon reduced it to 100 mln dlrs and amended the terms due to the market's cool response.
he underwriting margin was raised to 10 basis points over the Australian dlr bank bill rate.

<Country Wide Transport Services Inc> said it is holding an initial offering of 2.2 mln shaes of common stock at 15 dlrs per share.

Commercial Union Assurance <CUAC.L>, a composite insurance company in the U.K., Said it is arranging a financing facility totalling 750 mln European Currency Units (ECUs) which will now incude a medium term note program.
Barry Cameron-Smail, Commercial Union's treasurer, said he new financing will not increase its debt outstanding but rather act as an umbrella for all its financing needs.
Commercial Union has had a Euro-commercial pper program since the autumn of 1985 and a guilder commercial paper program since January 1986.

Cameron-Smail said Commercial Union decided on having the financing denominated in ECUs bcause it is more stable than most major currencies, and because it would give greater flexibility in its financings as it expands operations abroad.
Although banks are anxious to develop a market for medium term noes, only a few companies such as Electrolux AB and Pepsico Inc have gone so far as to arrange one.
Commercial Union is the first U.. Company to set up such a program.
Cameron-Smail said the company seeks to help the development of such a market as it would provide a new funding base for its medium trm assets.
Cameron-Smail said that aside from traditional lines of business, Commercial Union would like to move into other areas where it may not be able o fund the assets itself.
"This (the medium term note program) will e the platform for developing those assets," he said.
He said Commercial Union will work closely wth dealers for the note program to find the right pricing level to satisfy investor demands.
The program will be investor driven, he noted, adding that the company wants the notes placed with end investors and not traded in the secndary market.
Commercial Union will be abe to issue medium term notes in U.S.
Dollars or sterling, with the dollar notes listed i Luxembourg, while the sterling notes will be listed in London.
Bankers expect that the matuities will be concentrated in the one to five year area.
The dealers for the program are Barclays de Zote Wedd, Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd, Goldman Sachs International, Swiss Bank Corporation International Ltd and S.G. Warburg and Co Ltd. REUTER 

Westinghouse Electric Corp said earnings per sare growth will exceed sales growth and will be in the double digit range through 1989.
In 1986, the cmpany earned 4.42 dlrs a share on revenues of 10.7 billion dlrs.

Speaking at a meeting for securities analysts, Douglas Danforth, Westinghouse's chairman, said the company's sales growth target is about 8.5 pct a year for 1988 and 1989, "given an economic environment that remains o a moderate growth course."
He also said the company will make acquisitions, bu he did not specify particular targets.
Paul E. Lego, senior executive vice president told te analysts "our plans do not call for a multibillion dlr acquisition, even though our balance sheet can handle one.
Despite this disclaimer, if we identify a major acqusition that has significnt value-creating for Westinghouse...we will consider it."
He said the company would consider an acquisition canddate that is in an area compatable with Westinghouse's primiary businesses.

Danforth said the corportation was focused in several ky areas including defense electronics, financial services, broadcasting, electrical products and services for construction and industrial and utility markets.
Danforth added that he expects Westinghouse's sales to grw faster than the markets the corportation serves and "surely faster than GNP."
He said earnings per share growth is expected to consistently exceed the Standard and Poor's 500 index and return on equity will remain in th 18 to 21 pct range.
Leo W. Yochum, senior executive vice president for finance, told the analysts "we will consider buying back stock" but there are no current plans fo such a buyback.
Yochum said that at the company's current level of earnings it could comfortably maintain higher debt levels and that Westinghouse will use its debt apacity to improve shareholder value.
Last year, Westinghouse established a 790 mln dlrs restructuring reserve to be used for plant consolodation, assett writedowns and othe items.
Yochum said, the company spent 306 mln dlrs of that reserve in 1986 and will spend 344 mln dlr of the reserves in 1987.
The balance will be use in 1988.
He also said, capital expenditures should be about 400 ml dlrs in 1987.

onsumer members of the International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, accepted a final buffer stock rules compromise, "on the condition that producers also agree," consumer spokesman Peter Baron said.

A new Rbobank mortgage bond, whose terms dealers considered extremely generous, was in heavy demand on the Amsterdam bourse today, bond dealers said.

Later, the bank proposed to allot only 30 pct of subscriptions, causing a general outcry amog traders.

Homac Inc said the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan issued a preliminary injunction against Tangent Inc of Dallas from appointing directors to Homac's board without written consent of a majority o shareholders.
It said the court also prohibited Tangent from acquiring or attempting to acquire any additional Homac shares pending filing of an amendment t Tangent's Schedule 13D.
Homac said the court declined to issue a prelminary injunction to prohibit transfer of approximately 800,000 shares of common stock by DSA Financial Corp to Tangent.
Homac claims it had te first right to purchase.

NATO ambassadors met in emergency session today to discuss tnsion between members Greece and Turkey over a disputed area of the Aegean Sea on the Western Alliance's southern flank, Greek diplomatic sources said.
They said no information ad yet emerged from the meeting, called after statements from both countries that they were prepared to back rival oil exploration teams with warships.

General Guven Ergenc, Secretary General of the Turkish General Saff, said today the Turkish research ship Sismik 1, escorted by an unspecified number of warships, would sail into disputed waters in the Aegean Sea tomorrow morning.
Greek Prime Mnister Andreas Papandreou said "The military readiness of our country is able now to give a very hard lesson if our neighbours (Turkey) were to carry out military actions."

The row erupted when the reek government said last month that it was taking control of a Canadian-led consortium which was already producing oil off the Greek island of Thassos and would drill in the same area after the takeover.
Hanson Trust Plc <HNSN.L> said its U.S. Subsidiary, Hanson Industries Inc, is to sell PCR Inc, a speciality chemicals unit, for 6.25 ml dlrs cash to <Chemical Partners Inc>.

The British government may revoke the licences of selected Japanese banks and securities companies operating in London's financial City when thy come up for renewal next summer if progress is not made towards opening up Japan's markets to foreign competition, government sources said.
"We can't say "yes, we are going to do it (revoke licences)" but this is definitely being considered," n official said.
His comments came after the government was formally urged today by a cross-section of influential MPs to take join retaliatory action with the United States against Japan.
Britain has grow increasingly impatient with Japanese trade practices.
"There's a sense of urgency here now, but the emphasis is on securing - not undermining - our inerests in Japan," another government official told Reuters.

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said on Tursday that Britain would not hesitate to use new powers contained in the Financial Services Act 1986 and the Banking Bill to retaliate against countries that do not offer reciprocal market access.
She learly had Japan in mind, government sources said.
The U.K. Last ear showed a trade defict with Japan of 3.7 billion stg, official figures show.

A parliamentary motion, signed by 98 MPs, today urged the U.K. Government to "coordinate action with the President of the United States, and through the Department of Trade and Industry, to suspend all further applications from Japanese communications companies for equipment approval by the British Approvals Board for Telecommunications, and al further applications from Japanese financial institutions for licences" until authorities in Japan stopped imposing what the MPs called "restrictive conditions" on the bid by (Cable and Wireless PLC) (cawl.L) and its U.S. And Japanese partners for a stake in Japan's international telecommunications market.
The motion for retaliatory steps came from a cross-section of MPs, reflecting te strength of feeling inside Parliament.
Parliamentarians said their action would increase pressure on the Conservative government to take firm action
fficials said another option now being considered by the U.K. Is to refuse issuing new banking licences to Japanese institutions.
That could be done under the government's proposed Banking Bill now moving through arliament.
58 Japanese financial institutions are authorised to deal in London, of which 29 re banks.
n Tokyo, 14 London-based firms are authorised to do financial business, officials said.
he new financial services and banking acts offer Britain an alternative for retaliation which would be otherwise denied under legally-binding international trade agreements.
"The Financial Services Act gives (Trade and Industry Secretary Paul) Channon power to stop firms from engaing in investment, banking and insurance," one official said.
"This point has been made to the Japanese at official level a number times," the official adde.
Britain and France are now working together to urge that the European Community take collective action agaist Japan, but by working within EC treaties, another official said.

British Trade Minister Alan Clark said this week in a radio interview that the European Community should build barriers against Japanese imports through certification procedures similar to those facing European exporters i Japan.
"There comes a point where you cannot resist any longer," he said, adding "(such barriers) cant be put in place overnight."

Clark said the issue of reciprocity regarding visible trade "strikes at the basis of whether British industry is to have a fair access t an extremely large market (Japan) which is itself in a very dominant position (in) certain aspects of our own domestic market ...
It is relly a question of fairness."

The situation is only likely to worsen following news that Japan's trade surplus with the rest o the world rose by more than 70 pct in February, year-on-year, to 8.14 billion dlrs from 5.7 billion in January, political sources said.
But Clark said in his interview that the isues of visible trade and access to financial markets should be kept separate.

Should Britain decide to act against Japanese financial institutions, it would most likely focus on the smaler, rather than larger ones, to minimise any risks to its role as a global business centre, government sources said.
Japan's four largest securities houses are members of the London Stock Exchange
In Washington, White House officials said President Reagan was ready to impose retaliatory trade action against Japan for breaking its semiconductor agreement with th United States.

There was no immediate indication when Reagan might act on the recommendations of his Economic Policy Council to curb Japanese exports to the United States but officials said the mov could come today or early next week.
Trade sources said the actions being weighed by Reagan included tariffs on a wide varety of Japanese exports which use semiconductors.

Negotiators for eneral Motors Corp and the United Auto Workers union, which yesterday shut down the automaker's Pontiac, Mich., truck plant, resumed talks in search of a local contract for the facility.
Ron iller, vice president for UAW local 594, said negotiations resumed at 1000 EST, as expected.
Miller said the two sides seemed to be getting closer to an agreement when te union's noon deadline yesterday was reached.
He said he hoped an accord could b reached by Monday.

Miller said negotiators for the union, which represents 9,000 workers at Pontiac, and General Motors have still not been able to agree on the main issue--the company's use of nonUAW labor for some jobs.
Workers on the picket line were determined to stay on strike fr as long as necessary to reach a new agreement.
"We'll stay out here as log as it takes," said one.
Picketing was peceful and friendly, with no signs of violence.

ome prices advanced by as much as 1-1/2 points yesterday as the rest of the market eased back further.
owever, one or two traders expressed surprise that the authorities had issued further bonds of any kind in the light of the nervous conditions prevailing in the market.
n such relatively small amounts, the new issues were unlikely to have a significantly harmful effect on Government bond prices in general, dealers said.

Galactic Resources Ltd, earlier reporting a 1986 loss of 25.6 mln U.S. dlrs, said i adopted a more conservative accounting policy, similar to other gold producers' accounting for exploration costs.
As a result, the company retroactively charged all past exploration ad related administration costs incurred on its properties against expenses in 1986, 1985 and 1984.
Under the new policy, all future exploration and related administration cots will be written off to expenses rather than capitalized as an intangible asset, it said.
Galactic said the accounting change reulted in a 22.8 mln U.S. dlr charge against 1986 earnings.
It did not immediately disclose the affect of the change on prio years' results.
The new accounting policy is not expected to adversely affect working capital position, future cash flows or the company's ability to conduct ongoig business operations, it said.
Galactic said the charge includes 9.9 mln U.S. dlrs of costs concerning its Summitville Mine leac pad and 8.9 mln U.S. dlrs in waste removal costs, dyke construction and other mine developments.
Galactic said under the prior accounting policy, the Summitville mine expenses would have been amortized over the life of the min and charged against future earnings.

The change will also result in lower depreciation and amortization charges against income of about 52 U.S. dlrs an ounce of gold produced in future periods, based on total estimated reserve of 617,000 ounces.
Galactic said March leaching production at Summitville is expected to exceed 2,500 ounces, raising gold equivalnt production since the June 5, 1986 start of leaching to 65,000 ounces.
Mars Store Inc said it expects to report a loss of about 800,000 dlrs for te fourth quarter and about 1.1 mln dlrs for the fiscal year ended January 31.

As a result of the loss, the company said it has decided to discontinue the operations of its Big Value Outlet division, which will result in a yet undisclosed one time charge against earnings for the year.
The estimated 1.1 mln dlrs year loss or about 50 cs a share, compares with earnings of 871,000 dlrs or 42 cts a share recorded last year.

"The fourth quarter loss was affected by an abnormally high inventory shrinkage, lower than planned sales and higher markdowns related t increased promotional activity, all of which reduced fourth quarter gross margins," the company said.
In order to concentrate on the company's core business, the operation of discount and promotional department stores, Mars said, it has decided to close the Big Value divison.

Honeywell Inc said it has completed the sale of 57.5 pct of its Honeywell Information Systems <HIS> computer business to <Compagnie des Machines Bul> of France and <NEC Corp> of Japan for 527 mln dlrs in cash.
Honeywell said it will use much of the money to reduce shortterm debt incurred last December when the company purchased the Sperry Aerospace Group.
Honeywell said the sale of HIS has created a new dedicated computer comany jointly owned by Bull, NEC and Honeywell.
The new privately held company, named Honeywell Bull, is 42.5 pct owned b Honeywell Inc, 42.5 pct by Bull and 15 pct by NEC, the new company said.

Honeywell added that terms of the agreement with NEC and Bull allow it to reduce its current 42.5 pct stake in the new company t 19.9 pct at the end of 1988 by selling just over half its shares to Bull.
Book value at the time will determne the move's pricing, Honeywell said.
Honeywell chairman and chief executive officer, Edson Specer, said the move is the last major step in Honeywell's restructuring.

"As the leading worldwide supplier of of automation and controls for buildings, industry, aerospace an defense, Honeywell is now focusing its management, technical and financial resources on high market share business," Spencer said.

Honeywell said it expects to be Honeywell Bull's largest customer, purchasin computers for its own internal data processing, for integration into Honeywell buidling and industrial automation systems and for resale to the U.S. governement.

Honeywell said HIS's Federal Systems Division is now a wholly owned unit of Honeywell Inc, and has been named Honeywell Federal Systems Inc. Honeywell said it accounted for HIS as a discontinued operation in 1986, and will account for it future interest on a cost basis, recording any dividends as received.
Honeywell Bull said it will continue to develop its product line and build its business in integrated systems for networkin, database management and transaction processing.
The new company said its board will have nine members, incluing the chairman and chief executive officer.
Bull will have four members, Honeywell two and NEC one, th new company, which began worldwide operations today, said.

It added that Jacques Stern, Bull's chairman and chief executive officer, will serve as Honeywell Bull's chairman of the board, whle Jerome Meyer, formerly executive vice president of Honeywell Information Systems, was named president and chief executive officer.

The Amsterdam Stock Exchange will start an official inquiry into dealings in shares and share certificates of Dutch construction company <Bredero Vast Goed N.V.> earlier this week, amid suspicion of insider trading, a bourse spokesman said.
Bredero shares fell 14.50 guilders to close at 58.00 guilders during the official bourse sesson last Tuesday.
Bredero announced several hours after Tuesday's close it would postpone the publication of its 1986 figures, scheduled for the followig day.
"The price trend indicates not all investors shared the sam information," the spokesman said.
He said the bourse would publish the results of its inquest but declined to say when this could be expecte.
The bourse said earlier today trading in Bredero shares, suspended on Wednesday, will b resumed on Monday.
The bourse has cancelled all dealings i Bredero paper done on Tuesday when prices crashed.
Bredero shares, quoted on the domestic section of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, where traing starts 1-1/2 hours after the main market, closed at 72.50 guilders on Monday.
Certificates closed at 68.0 guilders.
Insider trading is not a criminal offnce here.

he dollar subsequently hovered at 147.55/65 yen.
Dealers said hey were uncertain about the size of the intervention, but some said it was only for a small amount.

President Reagan vetoed an 87.5 billion dlrs highway an mass transit bill calling it a budget buster.
The bill, which also contains a provision allowing states to raise highway speed limits, now goes back to Congress where the White House faces a uphill battle to sustain the veto.
Reagan in a message to Congress said he had an alternative proposal that would authorize 66 billio dlrs over five years, the same levels as in the Senate-passed version of the bill.
He said he recognized the states were rapidly running out of highway funds and the legislation needed to make funds available for the 1987 constructon season.
He said was no reason why Congress could nt send a new bill that he could sign before the spring construction season was any further along.
Reagan supports raising the speed limit to 65 mh from 55 mph on rural interstate highways.

Pegasus Gold nc said milling operations have started at its Montana Tunnels open-pit gold, silver, zinc and lead mine near Helena.

New Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, faced with a debt-ridde economy, will have to produce a harsh budget next week to impress financial markets, appease political opponents and maintain his tenuous hold on power, analysts said.

For Haughey, who failed to win an overall majority in last month's election, only scraped back into power when the speaker in parliament stepped in with his casting vote to decide a tied vote on who would be the next Pime Minister.
Heading a minority government an faced with a stagnant economy weighed down by debt, he has little room for manoeuvre.
The national debt has now reached 24.3 billion punts -- 10,000 dlrs for every man, woman and child on the island and pe capita three times the size of Mexico's.
Its 19 pct unemployment rate is on of the highest in the European Community and 30,000 youngsters emigrate every year.
The 58 pct income tax level could hardly be raised again

Haughey, declining to be tied down on specifics, promised on the election trail o get Ireland out of the debt trap with an annual growth rate of 2.5 pct, compared to central bank predictions of 1.5 pct.
Jobs were his top priority, e said.
or his crucial first budget, Haughey has ruled out any increase in the level of government borrowing and forecast "widespread cutbacks with severe restrictions right across the board."
inance Minister Ray MacSharry also stressed that some of the 187,000 civil service jobs must go to trim Ireland's annual public wages bill of 2.84 billion punts.
The big question now is to what extent he will grasp the nettle and cut in next Tuesday's budget," said Kevin Barry, economist with National and City Brokers.
You have to cut the Exchequer Borrowing Recquirement (EBR) substantially and swiftly.
e has to do it now," Barry said.
oting that last year's EBR was 2.145 billion punts, he said "Two billion would be good news.
The markets are already taking the view i is going to be tough."
"He has absolutely n room to maneouvre.
He cannot spend t stimulate the economy.
I don't see any good news in te short-term."
But he, like other analysts, rules out a debt-servicing crisis that would mean calling in te International Monetary Fund (IMF).
"It's too easy to borrow aboard," he addd.

The steady rise of sterling, the currency of one of Ireland's main trading partners, has been a boost to Irish exporters with te country recording a 31 mln punt trade surplus in February, the 10th surplus in a row.
Political uncertainty is not a major factor for the punt because te main political parties are all essentially conservative with no major economic policy switches expected.
New Fine Gael leader Alan Dukes, who replaced ousted Prime Minister Garret Fitzgerald at the head of the main opposition party, has pldged to back Haughey's budget if, as expected, he gets tough.
Haughey is four short of an overall majority and would have t rely on the support of independent deputies if all four opposition parties united to vote against him.

But in today's climate of economic austerity, few politicians would risk returning to the polls so soon and Haughey could cling to poer for at least another two years if he brings in a belt-tightening budget next week, political commentators say.
The debt-laden economy is the great national preoccupation, pushing firmly into the background for nw Haughey's ultimate dream of a united Ireland with the British out of the north.

Heinz chairman Tony O'Reilly, one of the most successful Irishmen in international business, stressed the need for a frontal attack on the national debt, arguing "many of our children hav lost faith in the future."

"Were there to be an uptick in world interest rates or a precipitous decline in our parities, the effect on our economy and on the provision of services by or government would be catastrophic," he said.
This island of 3.5 mln people has been living beyond its means with a stae spending spree on welfare benefits that could not be financed by economic growth.
The Agriculture Department's widening of Louisiana gulf differentials will affect county posted prices for number two yellow crn in ten states, a USDA official said.

All counties in Iowa will be affected, as will counties which use the gulf to price corn in Illinois, Indiana, Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, Mississippi, Arkansas, Alabama and Louisiana, said Ron Burgess, Deputy Director of Commodity Operatios Division for the USDA.

USDA last night notified the grain industry that effective immediately, all gulf differentials used to price interior corn would be widened on a sliding scale basis of four to eight cts, depending on what the differenial is.
USDA's action was taken to lower excessively high posted conty prices for corn caused by high gulf prices.
"We've been following this Louisiana gulf situation for a moth, and we don't think it's going to get back in line in any nearby time," Burgess said.
Burgess said USDA will probably narrow back the gulf diffrentials when and if Gulf prices recede.
"If we're off the mark now because we're too hih, wouldn't we be as much off the mark if we're too low?"
While forecasting more adjustments if Gulf prices fall, Burgess sad no other changes in USDA's price system are being planned right now.
"We do't tinker.
e don't make changes lightly, and we don't make changes often," he said.

Sen. Phil Gramm, a coauthor of the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law, said he will insist Congress pass a 1988 budget abiding by the law's 1988 deficit target.
The Texas Republican told a news conference he will bock Senate action on any budget bill failing to hit the 108 billion target by raising a parliamentary point of order against it.
He doubte there were 60 votes needed to overrule him.
Senate and House udget committees are working on budget plans which will fall short of the 108 billion dlr goal using Congressional Budget Office estimates.
Gramm avors a spending freeze to reach the law's goal.

Drought has resulted in a reduction in China's estimated wheat crop this year to 87.0 mln tonnes, 2.0 mln below last yer's harvest, the U.S. Agriculture Department's officer in Peking said in a field report.
The report, dated March 25, said imports in the 1987/88 seson are projected at 8.0 mln tonnes, 1.0 mln tonnes above the the current season's estimate.
Imports from the United States are estimated at 1.5 mln tones compared to only 150,000 tonnes estimated for the 1986/87 year, it said.
After travelling to major wheat producing areas and obtaining more inforation on the planted area, the total planted area was estimated down 290,000 hectares due to the dry fall, it said.
The report aid to compensate for the below normal precipitation irrigation has increased as has the use of fertilizer.
While there are pockets here irrigation is not possible, most of the wheat crop has access to some water and therefore has emerged from dormancy and is doing well, the report said.
It said scattered rain in many parts of China in the past 10 days has improved the situation but information on hail damage in Anhui is icomplete.

The United States told India t could purchase a supercomputer because U.S. concerns over a possible security breach had been removed.
U.S. officials said the United Sates did not specify which supercomputer it was willing to sell but had offered India a choice.
They declined to comment on a newspaper report that the United States wanted to sell India a computer less powerful than the Indians had sought
They said he United States was awaiting a response from New Delhi.
The New York Times, quoting unnamd government and industry officials, said the United States wanted to sell a weaker-model supercomputer to India.
.S. and Indian negotiatiors reached a tentative agreement in December on security precautions for the sale of the computer, which has a wide variety of military applications.
We have told the Indians that we ratify the tentative agreement reached in December," a U.S. official said.
ndia proposed to use the supercomputer to analyze weather patterns to forecast monsoons.
he sale of a U.S. supercomputer to a non-Western nation is rare.
his transaction was seen as a test of a technology-sharing agreement signed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and President Reagan in 1985.
he American concern was that the advanced technology might fall into the hands of the Soviet Union, which is India's main weapons supplier.
One condition calls for U.S. personnel to service the computer in Inia for three years, a Pentagon spokesman said.
The spokesman predicted the negotiations, whch also involved the State Department, could be quickly resolved.
The only countries which make te supercomputer are the United States and Japan.
In New Delhi, Indian officials tod Reuters that a U.S. offer had been made.
"An announcement will be made i 10 days to two weeks time," an official said.
Deere and Co said t agreed with General Motors Corp to discontinue negotiations on the formation of a joint venture company to design, manufacture and market diesel engines.

A manager with steel producer Krupp Stahl AG <KRPG.F> was arrested yesterday for fraud and falsifying documents, the state prosecutor's offic said today.
wo executives of steel trading companies in North Rhine Westphalia and Hanover were also arrested for aiding the Krupp manager, a spokesman for the office said.
he office identified the manager only as Alex I.
e said the manager is charged with faking signatures on forms ordering large shipments of heavy steel plate from one of the trading companies for which Krupp AG paid.
he spokesman said the manager ordered the shipments, which on paper were for Krupp Stahl AG in Bochum but were delivered to the trade house near Hanover.
he three men are also accused of pocketing profits from the sale of the steel plates, but both Krupp and the prosecutor's office declined comment on how much money was involved.
he Hanover daily Hannoversche Allgemeine said in an article today the shipments' order value totalled 100 million marks, while another local daily, the Neue Presse, put the value at 50 million marks.
The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) Council reached agreement on rules to govern its buffer stock, the device it uses to keep cooa off the market to stabilise prices, ICCO delegates said.

The date on which the new rules will take effect has not been decided but delegates said they expected them to come ino force early next week, after which the buffer stock manager can begin buying or selling cocoa.
Since prices are below the "may-buy" level of 1,655 Special Drawing Rights a tonne set in the cocoa pact, the manager is likel to buy cocoa sooon to support the market, they said.
Delegates and traders said they expected the manager, Juergen Plambeck, to intervene in the market within three weeks of the pact comin into force.
The rules permit him to buy and sell cocoa from origins or the second hand market on an offer system, not by means of a posted price a in the previous cocoa accord.
The cocoa will be priced according to a fixed set of differentials, ranging from 137 stg for most expensive Ghana coco to zero for Malaysian cocoa.
Purchases from non-members, such as Malaysia, will be limited to 15 pct of the total stock and those on any one day should be limited to 40 pc each in nearby, intermediate and forward positions.
The council meeting, which is expected to conclude two weeks of sessions involving various working groups and the council itself, wa continuing, the delegates said.
The current cocoa agreement came into force on January 20 during a previous meeting of the council which was unable t agree on the rules to implement buffer stock operations.
he cocoa buffer stock rules just decided by the International Cocoa Organization, ICCO, council will take effect immediately, delegates said.
hat means the buffer stock manager is likely to begin buying cocoa within two or three weeks, after organizing communication systems and assessing the market, they said.

Marine Midland Banks Inc said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it may reclassify as "nonperfoming" 359 mln dlrs of medium- and long-term loans to Brazil.

Hungary's economy and hard currency trade have filed so far this year to reverse a two-year unfavourable trend, the official Hungarian news agency MTI said.

Hungary's hard currency trade fell into a deficit o 539.4 mln dlrs last year from a surplus of 295.3 mln in 1985 and 1.2 billion in 1984.
MTI quoted a government spokesman saying last December's wae freeze decree would expire on April 1 as envisaged.
Gross domestic product grew a sluggish one pct i 1986 after stagnating in 1985 and growing 2.6 pct in 1984.

Cyprus has protested to the Unite Nations over alleged airspace violations by the Turkish air force, an official statement said.

"On behalf of my government I wish to protest strongly the above aggressio and provocative actions of Turkey ..." Cyprus' permanent representative at U.N. Headquarters said in a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar.
The protest came as NATO ambassadors met in emergency session in Brussels to discuss rising tensions between Greece and Turky over a disputed area of the Aegean sea.
The protest said Turkish jets flew oer Cyprus yesterday during an exercise of Turkish forces occupying north Cyprus.
There was no immediate indication whether the alleged overflight wa connected with the Aegean crisis.

Nigeria nd France have signed a bilateral agreement to reschedule Nigeria's official debt to France, government sources said.
The ccord was signed here yesterday by Nigerian Finance Minister Chu Okongwu and senior French Treasury officials after talks with CoFACE, the French export credit agency, they said.

The agreement ame after a similar agreement with Britain this week and follows an accord between Nigeria and the Paris Club of western creditor governments in December to reschedule some 7.5 billion dlrs of official debt.
The Paris Club multilateral agreement concerned medium and long-term debt due between September 1986 and end-1987 over 1 years with five years grace.
As with all Paris Club rescheduling accords, specific interest rates and other details have to be negotiated o a bilateral basis with the creditor countries involved.
No details of the discussions here were immediately availabl.
The agreement signed on Tuesday with Britain's Export Credits Guarantee Department was the first in Nigeria's tour o creditor nations.
Okongwu left Paris today for London and is due back in Nigeria on Monday, diplomatic soures said.
Nigeria is hoping that further bilateral accords can be concluded soon a this could encourage official export credit agencies to renew insurance cover for exports to Nigeria.

CoFACE suspended its cover for medium and long-term export contracts with Nigeria in 1983, but maintained its cover for current trade deals involing consumer goods with six-month credit periods, CoFACE sources said.
"We have an open position regarding Nigeria," the sources said, adding tht it was for French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur to decide whether to renew full insurance cover.

Nigeria is due to receive 900 mln dlrs in fresh export credits this year from official agencies under a structural adjustment program drwn up by Nigeria and the World Bank to reschedule part of the country's 19 billion dlr foreign debt.
But these credits cannot be approved until the export credit agencies agee to resume insuring the credits.
French exports to Nigeria were 3.42 illion francs in 1986, down from 4.94 billion in 1985, while Nigeria's exports to France were 5.63 billion francs in 1986, down from 15.33 billion in 1985.
Details f Nigeria's official debts to France were not immediately available.

President Reagan as ready to impose retaliatory trade action against Japan for breaking its semiconductor agreement with the United States, White House officials said.

There was no immediate indication hen Reagan might act on the recommendations of his Economic Policy Council to curb Japanese exports to the United States, but officials said the move could come today or early next week.
Trade sources aid the actions being weighed by Reagan include tariffs on a wide variety of Japanese exports which use semiconductors.

The sources said the tariffs could be slapped on pesonal computers, television receivers and laser-printers, with the aim of penalizing Japan's major electronic firms, including NEC Corp, Hitachi Ltd, Toshiba Corp and Fujitsu Ltd.

They said eaan could also delay invoking sanctions for a week or two, giving Japan a final opportunity to end the dumping practice, but added that negotiators had already held extensive talks with the Japanese to no avail.

The South frican Reserve Bank, confirming previous estimates, said real gross domestic product in the 1986 fourth quarter grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.7 pct versus 4.6 pct in the third quarter and 1.3 pct in the 1985 final quarter.
The bank, in its ltest quarterly review, said the nominal growth rate for the year did not quite reach one pct after a 1.5 pct contraction in 1985.
But it said when the strengthening of the trms of trade is taken into account, the real GNP in 1986 advanced by 1.5 pct compared with a decrease of 0.5 pct in 1985.
GDP is the total vlue of goods and services produced by an economy but omits income from abroad.
GNP inludes such payments or outflows.
The bank also said tere were indications the country's economic recovery was becoming more broadly based.
With the exception of comerce all major sectors of the economy contributed to the fourth quarter rise in domestic production.
The bank said ajor increases in foreign reserves were recorded in January, February and the first half of March 1987.
Reserves ose by 1.70 billion rand during January and February.
Total reserves in 986 declined by 189 mln rand to 5.70 billion rand and were equivalent to about 14.5 pct of the total annual value of import payments.
The current account urplus amounted to 7.20 billion rand in 1986 versus 5.90 mln the previous year.
The bank said cntinuing strength of the current account has allowed foreign reserves to be "rebuilt to more comfortable levels."
"This has strengthened the authorities' hands in lending support to the exchange rat of the rand if such action were to be called for," the bank said.

U.S. cotton farmers are likely to plant about 10.6 mln acres in the coming season, based on an average of estimates offered b cotton market analysts gearing up for the U.S. Agriculture Department's 1987 planting intentions report next Tuesday.
The annual report gives cotton traders their first glimpse of what U.. production might be in the 1987/88 season, which begins August 1.
Trade and commission house forecasts raged from 10.2 to 10.9 mln acres.
On March 18 of last year, the USDA reported that cotton famers in 1986 intended to plant 9.71 mln acres.
Four months later, the USDA estimated that 9.67 mln acres had ben planted as of June 1.
By January, its estimate of 196 planted acreage nationwide was 10.06 mln.
Analysts said their forecasts for even greater acreage in 1987 were spurred in part by belief that this year's good demand an firm prices will be repeated next year.
Analysts said those factors mae cotton a profitable crop.
"With cotton more attractive price-wise, I think there i going to be a switch in acreage from soybeans to cotton.
Soybeans are dirt cheap," said Lisbeth Keefe of Cargil Investor Services, whose comments were echoed by other cotton market specialists.
Changes in the US. cotton program also could lead to increased acreage, analysts said.

They recalled that under the 1986 program, cotton farmers who used part of teir crop as collateral for government loans were not responsible for the cost of storing that cotton in government warehouses.
But under the 187 plan, the government will not pick up the tab for storage.
Analysts said the change will discourage sme farmers from participating in the program, which could result in more cotton.
"The cotton program stipulates a mandatory setaside of 25 pct of a farmer's base acreage," noted Judy Weissman of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
But farmers who elect not to participate in the prgram are free to plant all the acreage they have.
Some analysts said cotton farmers in the high-yielding Western sttes would be most likely to steer clear of the program.

"Western acreage should be up at least 20 pct," said one commission house analyst, whose estimate was based in pat on forecasts made by the National Cotton Council during its annual meeting in late January.
"I think some Western growers have decided they should b in the program for security reasons.
There's a lot of comfort in knowing you'll be guarnteed the government's loan price of 52.25 cents a lb.
Anyone outside the program is subject to the wiles of the marke," said Walter Brown, market analyst for a major California cotton producer.
Some cotton specialists said their expectations for increased acreage might not be verified in Tuesday's planting intentions repot.
"Anything the USDA is announcing now is based on information they gathered before their cotton program was announce (on March 20)," one analyst cautioned.
She said traders will get a better idea of next year's cotton output when the USDA's planted acrege report is released on July 9.
Brown took that opinion a step furher.
"I don't think planted acreage is imprtant.
What counts is the abandonment rate," the difference between acreage planted and acreag harvested.
Brown said the abandonment rate this year was "pretty high" at 15.5 pct because of weather problems in key producing states
"More normal would e about six pct," he said.

Greece and Turkey's NATO allies today called on both countries to avid any action that could aggravate an explosive situation in the Aegean and "avoid recourse to force at all costs."
After an emergency meeting of NATO ambassadors, a statement was issued saing "the present situation damages the interests of Greece and Turkey, and of the Alliance as a whole."
Secretary-General Lord Crrington also offered himself as a mediator in the dispute on the Western Alliance's southern flank.
The meeting as called after reports that warships of both countries were sailing towards a disputed oil exploration zone of the Aegean.
The statement aid the tensions in the area had reached a serious level and called on both countries to begin immediate discussions.
"Any intensification would make things worse," i added.
No attempt was made at the meeting to resolve the complex dispute whih was aimed at damage-limitation.
Carrington said, "I am of course anxious o help in any way I can, provided that both Greece and Turkey, and the other allies, wish me to do so."

Central Bank president Francisco Gros denied rumours that foreign creditors had filed court actions against Brazil to seek paymnt of its 109-billion dlr debt.
"There is no court action against Brazil," Gros said i a television interview.
Brazil last month suspended interest payments on its 68 billion dlr debt to commercial banks and yesterday suggested a extension of short-term credit lines for 60 days until May 31.
Media reports said some banks rated as small among Brazil's 700 creditors had filed lawsuits against the decision t suspend interest payments.

Gros said negotiations with the commercial creditors would start within two weeks, when he and Finance Minister Dilson Funao attend council meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Washington.
Brazil is facing the issue very carefully.
We are seeking a neotiation that will give the country space to grow, because only with growth will we be able to meet our commitments," Gros said.
The price of gold bullion and share prices of North American gold stocks are benefiting from continued weakness in th U.S. dollar, analysts said.

"There's been a tug of war between the (currency) speculators and the central banks over th U.S. dollar and it looks like the game has gone to the speculators," said John Ing at Maison Placements Canada Inc.
The dollar remained close to post-World War II lows today against the Japanese yen despite buying by several central bank, including the Federal Reserve, dealers said.
A drop in the dollar means uncertainty an gold is the traditional hedge against uncertainty, Ing noted.
Another analyst, Richard Cohen at Brown Baldwin Nisker Ltd, noted that "a lot of foreign investors are holding U.S. ollars.
If they see they are losing money, they move ack into gold."
A dollar decline also has inflationary implications, Ing said, adding that Maison Placements sees inflation rising to a four pc annual rate from the current level of about three pct.
Ing predicts gold will peak at 510 dlrs this year from its current level of about 416 dlrs per ounc.
Cohen sees an average price of 425 dlrs, and another analyst, Michael Pickens, at Yorkton Securities, puts the average t 450 dlrs, with a possible spike above 500 dlrs.
owever, gold stocks in the U.S. and Canada have risen far faster in recent months than the price of the metal itself, causing concern among analysts that a correction lies somewhere in the future.
ut for now, all analysts say there is no sign the buying pressure is slowing down.
The stocks have run an incredible way," Cohen said.
n U.S. markets today, ASA Ltd <ASA> rose 4-1/8 to 61-1/2, Campbell Red Lake Mines <CRK> was up 1-3/8 and Newmont Gold <NGC> increased 1-1/2 to 31-1/4.
he Toronto Stock Exchange gold index today was up 268 points at 8067.90.
Hemlo Gold gained 1-1/4 at 26-3/4, LAC Minerals was up 1-5/8 a 41, Placer Development rose 1-1/4 at 43-3/8 and Lacana Mining gained 1 at 18.
Ing pointed out that the TSE gold index has gained 51 pt since December 31, 1986, while the price of bullion has increased six pct.
"Canadian golds have been the tp performing index this year," he noted.
In the U.S., there is "to much money chasing too few stocks," Pickens said.
And many investing institutions such as pension funds and insurance companies stll have excess cash, he added.

Cohen also noted that today's silver price break through six dlrs an ounce indcates small investors are entering the precious metals market and he expects the ratio between gold and silver prices to narrow.

Honeywell Bull Inc, owned by Honeywell Inc <HON>, <Cie des Machines Bull> and <NEC Corp>, said it expects its 1987 revenues to increse 15 to 20 pct over its current level of about 1.9 billion dlrs.
Honeywell Bull president Jerome Meyer also told the press conference the company was profitable, addng the company aimed to improve profits over time.
Honeywell Inc earlier today received 527 mln dlrs in cash for the sale of 57. pct of its computer business to Bull and NEC.
Honeywell will retain a 42.5 pct interest in Honeywell Bull and Bull will own a equal amount.
NEC owns 15 pct of the company

Meyer, who had been executive vice president of Honeywell Information Systems, said Honeywell Bull would work closely with NEC and Bull in both developing new products and marketing computers t multi-national companies.
"We haven't been growing as fast as we'd like, but we are going to turn that around," Meye said.
He said business was soft i the U.S.
He said the company was reorganizing its distribution progams and its staff, reassigning and laying off selected employees.
He also said the copany was hiring new workers.

Honeywell Bull chairman Jacques Stern, who is also chairman of Bull, said he believed the computer industry cold be a fast growing market for companies that provide the type of computers customers want.
"I don't believe in te slump of the market," he said.

The computer company would offer open systems so that customers would not be tied to a specific vedor or architecture, and it will also focus on tying computers together through communications networks.

French state computer group Cie des Machines Bull <BULP.PA> will issue 800 mln French francs worth of stock option bonds, th Finance Ministry said.
Each bond of 1,000 francs nominal and six pct interest, will cary three "A" warrants and three "B" warrants giving the right to subscribe to Bull shares.
Bull is on the government's list of companies scheduled to be privaised over the next five years but no date has been set.
This operation will reinforce Bull's capital and reduce the state's stake, pror to privatisation, the Ministry said in a press release.

The three "A" warrants will give the right to subscribe to five Bull shares at a price of 46 francs until November 30, 198 and the three "B" warrants the right to subscribe to five shares at a price of 52 francs until November 30, 1989.

Bull shares were quoted at a close of 55.45 francs o the Paris stock exchange today.
The privatisation commission values Bull at a minimum of six bilion francs, the press release said.
Latest consumer price data indicate US. inflation will be moderate in 1987 even though it will be above last year's pace, economists said.

"Inflation is not such a constructive factor as this time last yar, but it's not building up a large head of steam," said Allan Leslie of Discount Corp. U.S. consumer prices, as measured by the consumer price index for all urban consumers, rose a seasonally adjusted 0.4 pct in February after a 0.7 pct January gain.
Energy prices, which fired January's dta with a three pct rise, advanced a more moderate 1.9 pct last month.
The CPI came within the range of economists' expectations and had little direct impat on U.S. financial markets.

Among the key components of the report, transportation prices rose 0.5 pct in February after a 1.5 pct January gain reflecting smaller price appreciation for motor fuel and declines in new car prices and finance charges.

"There are no pronounced pressures at the retail level," said William Sullivan of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Economists said the latest CPI supports existing expectations for a inflation rate of 3.5 to four pct in 1987.
The CPI rose 1.1 pct from December 1985 to Decembr 1986.
Without last year's energy price drop, it ros 3.8 pct.

Economists said that upward pressure on import prices as a result of the dollar's drop as well as the volatile energy component warrant attention in case gains in these areas become factore into the wider economic picture.

"As long as those price rises do not become entrenched in cost of living adjustments contained in labor contracts, thus reducing international competitiveness, then the Federal Reserve would probably be willing t tolerate four pct inflation," said Larry Leuzzi of S.G. Warburg and Co Inc. Reuter 

The federal Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is expected to anounce soon that it will require an additional review of Genentech Inc's TPA heart drug, a move that likely will delay the company's plans to market the drug this spring, government and Wall Street sources said.

TPA, a bio-engineered blood-clot dissolving drug which Genentech hopes to mrket under the name Activase, will be reviewed by the FDA's cardiorenal advisory committee during the panel's May 28-29 meeting, the sources said.
Neither Genentech nor the FDA wuld confirm that a second review of the drug had been set.
"It's under consideration for the May 28-9 meeting," an FDA official said.
"It's on a drat agenda."
Similarly, a Genentech spokeswoman said the FDA had not yet notified it o the second advisory committee review.
"We know it's a possibility, but as of this minute, we can't conirm that we are on the agenda," she said.
The spokeswoman said a second review hd "always been a possibility."
But she declined to say how the review would affect marketing plans bfore receiving official FDA word.
The spokeswoman acknowledged that rumors of a second FDA commttee review had buffeted Genentech's stock yesterday on Wall Street.
The stock fell 2.75 dls a share to clsoe at 61.75 dlrs.
TPA stands for tissue plasminogen activator, and would be usd on heart attack victims to clear blockage in a vein or artery.
Though other blood clot dissolvers are on the market, TA is said to be more effective and with fewer side effects.
Analysts have projected the worldwide market for the drug a as high as 1.5 billion dlrs a year.
Stuart Weisbrod, a biotechnology analyst with Prudential Bache Securities In., told Reuters the additional FDA review likely would keep TPA off the market until at least November.
Approval had been expected this sprin.
He said the FDA action prompted him to cut his estimate of Genentech's 1987 earnings to about 40 cents a sare from his earlier projection of 67 cents a share.
He said the delay would lower Genentech's 1987 revenues from TP to about five to six mln dlrs compared to an earlier projection of 50 to 60 mln dlrs of 1987 revenues.
Westinghouse Electric Corp WX> said it is still open to a merger of its radio operations with General Electrics Co's <GE> NBC radio operations.
"We have left he door open and GE is reassessing the merger and so are we," Westinghouse chairman Douglas Danforth told Reuters at the conclusion of a meeting before analysts.
Danforth said he cntinues to see value in a merger between Westinghouse's radio operation and those of NBC.
Discussions with NBC n the merger of the two companies' radio units were suspended in December.
Danforth reaffirmed that Westinghouse is interested in acquisitions, saying the company is leaning toward acquisitions in th 300 mln to 500 mln dlr range.
He said, however, that larger acquisitions are possible i they are the right fit.
Danforth, who earlier today said he expects earnings growth in the double-digit range through 1989, said he is comfortable with analysts' predictions of 4.0 dlrs to 5.30 dlrs a share this year.
In 1986 the company earned 4.42 dlrs a shar.
He said the company has targeted waste energy systems and hazardous waste removal, as some of th emerging growth areas for the company.

Consumer energy costs rose 1.9 pct in February following a sharp rie last month, the Labor Department said.
The February increase in the overall energy costs, including petroleum, coal and natural gas followed a 0.2 pct drop in December and a 3.0 pct rise in January, it said.
Energy prices were 12.2 pct below year-ao levels.
The department's Consumer Price Index showed that the cost of gasoline rose in Februay by 4.2 pct, after a 6.6 pct rise in January.
Gasoline prices were nonetheless 18.0 pct belw their levels as of February 1986.
Also, the category including fuel oil, coal and bottled gas rose in February b 3.8 pct, putting it 14.9 pct under the year-ago figure.
The index also showed that natural gas and electricity were unchanged last month, but dow 3.5 pct from the February 1986 figure, the department said.
The index has been updated o reflect 1982-84 consumption patterns; previously, the index was basd on 1972-73 patterns.
The Philippines has reached agreement with its bank advisory committee on a debt-rescheduling agreement aftr four weeks of talks, a source close to the Philippine delegation said.
No details were available and bankers were not avaiable to comment because meetings with the Philippine negotiators were still in progress.

But a spokesman for Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co, which chairs the 12-bank Philippine advisory committee, said a prss conference with finance minister Jaime Ongpin will begin at the bank's headquarters at 1430 EST/1930 GMT.
"There is an agreement," the source close to te Philippine delegation said, adding that details would be announced at the press conference.
Manila wants to reschedule about 3.6 billion dlrs of debt that falls due between 1987 and 1992 and to obtain easier terms on 5.8 billion dlrs of prevously restructured debt.

The talks have dragged on because of the banks' reluctance to accept interest payments partly in Philippine Investment Notes, PINs, instead of cash and because of Manila's insistence on an interest rate margin close to the 5/8 pct spread oer Eurocurrency rates that it initially demanded.

A cold air mass working its way south from Canada may pose a threat to developin hard red winter wheat in Oklahoma, according to Eugene Krenzler, wheat specialist for the Oklahoma Cooperative Extension.
"There is soe threat.
Some of the crop is far enough along so tht it's probably vulnerable," Krenzler said.

Accu Weather meteorologist Dale Mohler said cold air moving from the north could put temperatures in the middle 20's fahrenheit as early as tonight, depending on development of a low pressure area over southeast Colorado which could stal the system.
If impeded by the low-pressure area, the cold air could hit Oklahoma and Texas as late as Monday mornng.
Temperatures could stay in the mid-20's for up to eigh hours, Mohler said.
Krenzler said less than 10 pct of the Oklahoma what crop has advanced to boot stage.
The closer to that stage the more vulnerable the hed of the wheat is to cold weather, he said.
"We can handle probably an hour or so down to 25 or 26 degrees (fahrenheit)," Krenzler said, "as log as we don't have a lot of wind."
"If we do get six hours down below 25 degrees I'd say we have a good chance of significat damage to the heads," he said.
Krenzler said early planted stands in the north-central and southwestern part of the state are probably most vulnerable.
Crops in the panhandle of Oklahoma and Texas are less developed and have some snow cover protection from th cold, he noted.

McLean Industries Inc said its two shipping subsidiaries -- UNITED States Lines Inc and United States Lines (S.A.) Inc -- have agreed in principl to dispose of substantially all their remaining operating shipping assets.
The units have been operating under protection of Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code since last November
McLean said U.S. Lines has a letter of intent with CSX Corp's <CSX> Sea-Land Corp subsidiary to transfer assets of its Transpacific/Hawaii/Guam Servie to Sea-Land.

McLean said Sea-Land has tentatively agreed to pay 125 mln dlrs for six vessels, certain port facilities, and various other equipment used in U.S. Lines' Transpacific service and theee Lancer class vessels and subsidy rights owned by the two McLean subsidiaries.

As previously announced, U.S. Lines (S.A.) will transfer its South American Service to <Crowley Maritime Corp>'s American Transport Lines Inc subsidiary in return for a fixed lease payment fr the four Lancer class vessels and a participation based on American Transport's South American revenues.

McLean said the agreement also calls for Crowley to release U.S. Lines (S.A.) for any damages and unpaid charter hire for three vessels leased to U.S. Lines (S.A.) b Crowley which have been returned to Crowley.
McLean said the inimum lease payments will be seven mln dlrs and estimated revenue participation during the first four years at about 16 mln dlrs.
In addition, U.S. ines (S.A.) subsidiaries in Brazil and Argentina will be sold to American Transport.
The company said oth agreements in principle have been approved by directors of the companies involved, but still need court, regulatory and lender approval.

McLean said it is requesting the bankruptcy ourt to schedule a hearing on its motion to approve the agreements, adding that the court has granted the company's request to extend for 90 days the period for the shipping companies to file a proposed plan of reorganization.
It said the planned transactions will leave McLean with no significant shipping assets except 12 New York class vessels, whic are not in operation and are expected to be sold.
McLean said its shipping units are returning the vessels operating in foreign commerce to United States ports to permit th planned transfer to purchasers.
The company said U.S. Lines will maintain its weekly service from the U.S. West Coast to Hawaii and Guam unti the vessels are transferred and the transaction is completed.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) has proposed stringent limits on the portion f futures trading that can be conducted between "trading rings," or affiliated groups of floor brokers, according to a CME spokesman.
Violators would be subject to fines of as much as 50,000 dlrs, the exchange said in a letter distributed o its members earlier this week.
The proposal is one of the reforms the exchange's Board of Goverors suggested to curb practices that have come under fire for unfairly limiting competition on the floor.
Local traders claim that trading among broker "rings" violates the open-outcry sytem prevailing in the futures markets.
Limits on ring trading would be applied floor-wde under the proposal.
The other reforms, which address dual trading, would apply only to the Standard and Poor's 50 stock index futures pit.

A debate over dual trading, the practice of trading for one's own account and filling customer orders, has arisen because many traders believe it can create a climate for trading abuses, especialy in the extremely volatile stock index futures pit.

Adoption of the Board of Governors' reforms hinges on an Aril 13 vote of CME members on a membership petition, signed by several hundred members in February, that would bar all dual trading at the exchange.
Defeat of the petition is lkely, according to a floor broker contacted by Reuters, who also said he welcomed the limits on the "ring" traders.
If members reject the petition, tat would open up the way for the Board of Governors' reforms.
CME President William Brodsky said he need to curb broker group trading has grown "as the groups have gotten larger."
"A lot of the individuals wre losing business because they were faced with a large-scale competition.
The Board began studying the problem abot six months ago.

Under the proposed reforms, members of a broker rings -- defined as brokers who share brokerage fees, revenues, expenses, a deck of customer orders o employee salary expenses -- would be barred from trading more than 15 pct of their personal trades with each other.
Those found in violation would be subect to fines of up to 50,000 dlrs.
Broker ring members would also be prohibited from trading more than 25 pt of customer orders with each other.
Fines of up to 10,000 dlrs woud be levied on violators.
More stringent limits were proposed on individual trading than customer orders because "we don't want to negatively impat customer orders," Brodsky said.
"On the other hand, the need to do a personal order s very different."
Broker associations ould also be limited to having no more than one member serving on an exchange disciplinary or pit committee.

The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) council agreed standard price differentials for different origin cocoas to form prt of the buffer stock buying and selling procedure, consumer delegates said.
The buffer stock manager will accept offers for differen origin cocoas according to a sliding scale of price differentials, under which Ghana cocoa will be pegged at a 137 stg premium to Malaysian.
Thus, if the buffer stock manager was buying cocoa based on a Malaysian price of 1,200 st a tonne, he would accept Ghana offers up to 1,337 stg.
Differentials were fixed as follows, Country Differential stg/tonne Malaysia 0 Brazil 55 Ivory Coast 67 Cameroun 7 Nigeria 120 Togo 130 Ghana 137 Nigeria's differential is on "landed weight" terms.
Shipping weight terms will be accepted at a 5 stg discount to this rate.
The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) council adjourned after agreeing buffer stock rules for te 1986 International Cocoa Agreement, an ICCO spokesman said.
The buffer stock will begin operations immeditely, he said.
He confirmed delegate reports that the buffer stock manager will trade cocoa by meas of an offer system, and according to fixed differentials for cocoa from different origins.

Purchases from non-members will be limited to 15 pct of the total and buying or selling operations in any one dy will be restricted to a maximum of 40 pct each for nearby, intermediate and forward positions, he said.
The United States said it was doing what it could to ease tension in the Aegean as Greek and Turkish warshps headed for a possible clash over oil drilling rights on the sea's continental shelf.
State Department spokesman Charles Redman told reporters, "We have urged boh sides to exercise restraint and avoid any actions which might exacerbate the situation."
"In the light of the mst recent developments, we are consulting with the parties and with other interested allies on means to reduce tensions," he added.
Redman declined to elaborate on wat Washington was doing, but he said an emergency meeting of NATO ambassadors in Brussels on the subject was only one path it was pursuing.

He also refused to say which side was to blame for he renewed confrontation, saying Washington was still trying to ascertain all the facts, as Prime minister Andreas Papanderou said Greece was prepared to tackle any aggressor.
"The crucial pint here is that these are two friends and allies.
We don't want to see tnsion rise and we are doing what we can to see if we can help here," Redman said.

A U.K. Financial services company, <Quadrex Scurities Ltd>, is planning a joint venture with the American Stock Exchange for a new U.S. Dealer market in non-U.S. Securities, Quadrex chairman Gary Klesch said.
He said the ew exchange is aimed at facilitating U.S. Institutions' trade in foreign debt and equity securities.
It is planned to provide a central depositary for stocks and bonds, the lack of whih has hitherto inhibited such trading, he said.
Klesh said the new market would come under SEC jurisdiction, and that while the SEC i considering the plans, he could not estimate when it might get an official go ahead.
However, Klesch added that he hoped the exchang could open in the autumn.

He said Quadrex is a five-year-old securities business, based in London and backed by about 40 mln dlrs capital, which owns companies operating in a range of financial markets, including forign exchanges and Eurobonds.
Klesch said further details would be available neaer to the planned opening.
