South Africa's Environmental Affairs Mnister John Wiley has been injured in a shooting incident at his home, police said A police spokesman said the matter was still being investigated and refused to give further details.
The outh African Press Association said no crime was suspected.
he minister's condition was not known.
South Africa's Evironmental Affairs Minister John Wiley died today in an apparent suicide attempt, police said.
His wife ound him lying on his bed at home this morning with a bullet wound in his head, police said.
A pistol ly by his side.
The police said no crime was suspected and they were treatng it as an apparent suicide.
The spokesman said Wiley's wife returned to the family home ner Cape Town to find the door locked.
She found help to break ino the house and found her husband dead.
Wiley, 60, had been member of parliament for Simonstown, near Cae Town, since 1966, representing several parties.
Local reporters said he had been fighting a very active campaign to retain the seat for the National Part (NP) in the May 6 whites-only general election.
They said he won the seat comfortably for the NP in the 1981 poll, but was facing a strog challenge this year from John Scott, candidate for the centrist Progressive Federal Party.
Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz was quoted as saying Iran has attacked several ships with land-based missiles sited a the Strait of Hormuz.
Announced recently Iran had emplaced Chinese-made "Silkworm" anti-ship missles with the range to cover the entire width of the 24-mile-wide strait at the Gulf's mouth.
Aziz said in an interview with al-Thawra newspaper that leaders of Gulf Arab states had told hm of the existence of the missiles, which he said had been in place for many months.
"They briefed me with their details and we know that the Iranians used them several times t attack ships belonging to Arab states in the Gulf, sailing in the waterway," he said.
This is the first time any person of authrity has said Iran, Iraq's enemy in the 6-1/2-year-old Gulf war, had fired the missiles in anger.
A British naval source in the Glf said last week Iran had fired one test missile against a hulk in the strait.
About 120 ships have been attacked in he Gulf by both belligerents since January last year.
Aziz said the U.S. Had announced the existence of the missiles so late after teir arrival as part of its efforts to neutralise the effects of the secret U.S. Arms sale to Iran.
"The missiles existed n the Gulf for many months ...

But they became a serious topic for America and the West only after the failure of the Iranian invasion plan (against the south Iraqi city of Basra) and as a balloon to cover up the Iranate story," Aziz said.

Bank fuer Gemeinwirtschaft AG <BKFG.F>, BfG, partial operating profits fell to 182.6 mln marks in 1986 rom 313.7 mln in 1985, new majority shareholder Aachener und Muenchener Beteiligungs-AG <AMVG.F>, AMB, said.

But total operating and extraordinary profits, including earnings from currency and securities trading on the bank's own account and earnings from the sale of holdings in other firms, were more than double the pevious year's level, AMB said.
BfG's 1986 accounts were included in a prospectus for AMB's capital increase, which is to finance th insurance company's acquisition of 50 pct plus one share of BfG.

Despite the fall in partial operating profits, BfG paid an unchanged 20 mln marks into open reserves and transferred an unchanged 80 mln marks to its trade union holding company, <Beteiligungsgesellschaft fuer Gemeinwirtschaft G>, from which AMB has acquired the majority stake.
The bank has aid its business last year suffered from the turbulence around the troubled trade-union-owned housing concern Neue Heimat.
MB said the 500 mln mark drop in BfG's business volume to 50.1 billion marks affected the interest surplus.
he interest surplus, which fell to 897.9 mln marks from 981.1 mln, was also depressed by the 0.1 point fall in the interest margin to 1.9 pct.
A rise n the surplus on commission to 208.8 mln marks from 188.1 mln was not enough to compensate for this.
The rise n total operating profits enabled BfG to step up risk provisions, with country risks particularly emphasised because of the continuing difficulties of some countries.
Disclosed risk povisions, which under West German accounting rules do not necessarily reflect the full amount, rose to 736.3 mln marks from 224.0 mln.
BfG's arent credit volume eased to 32.63 billion marks in 1986 from 33.51 billion.
Foreign debtors acounted for 24 pct of this credit volume, and Latin American debtors accounted for 14.7 pct of total lending to foreigners.

BfG posted extraordinary earnings from the sale of 25.01 pct of <Volksfuersorge Deusche Lebensversicherung AG>, 74.9 pct of <BSV Bank fuer Sparanlagen und Vermoegensbildung AG> and five pct of <Allgemeine Hypothekenbank AG>.
The sale was lnked to AMB's acquisition of a majority of BfG.
These sales show up as 494.2 ln marks from profit transfer agreements and 326.5 mln from writing back risk provisions.
The Jeddah-based Islamic Development Bank (IDB) said in an annual reort its loans during the last Islamic year fell 24 pct due to world economic recession.
Total financing approved by the bank for projects, trade, and technical and special assistance fell to 756.9 mln Islamic dinars in the yer ended September 4, 1986, from 1,001.4 mln the previous year.

"Due to a general recession in the world economy, the demand for development funds was low and there was a scarcity of processabl projects in most member countries during 1406 (September 1985-86)," the report said.
It said a steep decline in oil prices had led to a major transfr of resources from oil-producing countries to industrial nations.

"The oil exporting member nations of the IDB faced a major adjustment problem arising from a sizable decline in oil prices and loss of export earnings, affectng their position as potential suppliers of capital," the report said.
Project financing and technical assistance loans fell to 175.7 mln Islamic dinars in te year ended last September from 269.4 mln the previous year.

The report said although there was a reduction in foreign trade financing loans in the past year due to a sharp decline in the price of ol and various primary commodities, the quantity financed in physical terms of imports was higher.
Foreign Trade financing declined to 572.8 mln dinars from 668.2 million dinars te previous year.
Disbursements of loans, incuding previously-approved loans, fell to 557.2 mln dinars from 783.9 mln.
The Bank in 1986 decided to estblish a fund under the name "IDB Unit Trust" to introduce and market financial instruments in line with the principles of Islam, the report said.
"This experience will provide a foundation or the floating of other financial instruments in the near future through which the bank expects to mobilise even larger resources," the report said.
The IDB was estblished by the 46-member Islamic Conference Organisation and opened in October 1975.
The Bank of Japan has already purchased more than one billion dls in intervention since the opening and continues to buy the U.S. Currency, dealers said.

The central bank was supporting the dollar against the yen amid heavy selling pressure from investment trusts and securities houses which had puhed the dollar as low as 144.75 yen earlier this morning, they said.
The dollar recovered slightly from te intervention and was trading around 145.00, they added.
It had opened in Tokyo a 145.80 yen.
New Zealand's Reserve Bank said it has cancelled the regular weekly Treasury bil tender scheduled for tomorrow.
The bank said in a statement that it forecasts a small net cas injection into the system over the settlement week.
However, it said it will conduct ope market operations during the week.
After these the cash balance should fluctute around 30 mln N.Z.
Bank of Japan governor Satoshi Sumita said he does not expect the dollar t remain unstable and fall further.
He told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that the Bank of Japn would continue to cooperate closely with other major nations to stabilize exchange rates.
The central bank has been keeping extremely careful watch on exchange rate movements sine last week, he said.
He said the dollar would not continue to fal because of underlying market concern about the rapid rise of the yen.
Sumita said the currency market has been reacting t overseas statements and to trade tension between Japan and the U.S. Over semiconductors.
The yen's tendency to rise will prevent Japan frm expanding domestic demand and undertaking necessary economic restructuring, he said.

Finance Minister iichi Miyazawa said that the dollar's drop today to 145 yen is partly attributable to the perception inside and outside Japan that the country has failed to fulfill its promise to expand domestic demand.
He told a ower House budget committee in Parliament that it was natural for other nations to think that Japan is not doing enough because of the delay in the passage of the 1987/88 budget.
The udget has been delayed by opposition boycotts of Parliament to protest government plans for a new sales tax.
Bank of Japan governor Satoshi Sumita said the central bank will carefully consider its monetary policy in light of the recent sharp fall of he dollar.
Asked if the Bank of Japan will consider a further cut in its discount rate, he said he now thinks the bank will have o carefully consider its future money policy.
He told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that credit conditions have been eased by the five discount rate cuts by Japan since he beginning of last year.
Japan ust now be especially careful about a flare-up in inflation, with money supply growth accelerating, he said.
Sumita said the central bank would continue to make a judgement on monetary policies while watching consumer prices, exchange rates and economic and financial condition both in and outside Japan.

Asked if the September 1985 Plaza agreement was a failure because the dollar had fallen too far, Sumita said he still thought the pact was a good one in the sense that it had corrected the overvaluation of th dollar.
But the Plaza accord did not set any target fo the dollar's fall, he said.
The dollar's steep fall stems from the maret's belief that the trade imbalance will continue to expand, he said.
President Alan Garcia said Peru has found gold deposits worth an estimated 1.3 billion dlrs i a jungle region near the Ecuadorean border about 1,000 km north of here.
He told reporters the deposits, located at four sites near the town of San Ignasio, containd the equivalent of 100 tonnes of gold.
Garcia said the government would soon install a two mln dl treatment plant at Tomaque.
It will extract enough ore to provide an estimated 25 mln dlr profit by the end of this year, he added
Garci said the other gold-bearing deposits are located at Tamborapa, Pachapidiana and a zone between the Cenepa and Santiago rivers.
Iran's non-oil exports were worth at least 750 mln dlrs in the year ended March 20, a 35 pct increase rom the previous year, the national Iranian news agency IRNA reported.
IRNA, monitored n London, quoted a senior Industry Ministry official as saying non-oil exports included carpets, animal skins, pistachios, fruit and industrial goods.
The USSR will hold local ouncil elections on June 21 at which voters in some districts will have a choice of candidates as part of an experiment in electoral reform, the Tass News Agency said.

The official agency said yesterday he selected districts, still to be chosen, would have a slate of several candidates, not all of whom could be elected, and voters would strike out the names of those they did not support.
Tass said candidates would hve to win support from more than 50 pct of registered constituents to win seats.
Voting s compulsory in the Soviet Union.
In the past, official rturns for elections at most levels in the Soviet government system have recorded 99 to 100 pct support for all candidates.
Voters simply dopped the official ballot paper with the single candidate's name into an urn.
Tass said districts chosen or the experiment would return several deputies rather than a single representative to local council bodies.

The announcement followed pledges on electoral reform by Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, campaigning to revitalise confidence in th communist system after what he has described as a period of stagnation.
The United States and Japan will soon settle their trade dispute over semiconductors, U.S. Commerce secretary Malcolm Baldrie said on television.
Baldrige, referring to the U.S.-Japan trade agreement on semiconductors, said: "Their government wants to live u to it.
Their industries haven't been doing it, and I think we'll have a good settlement to spae both sides."
"I think the Japanese understand full well that they haven't lived up to this commitment," h said.
He added: "I do not think there wil be a trade war at all."
On Friday, Washington announced plans to put as much as 300 mln dlrs in tariffs o Japanese electronic goods from April 17, because of Tokyo's failure to observe the agreement.
The officials said the tariffs would be ended as soon as Japan started adhering to the agreemen.
But they said there as little chance Japan could react quickly enough to avert the higher tariffs.
Baldrige said the Reagan adinistration hoped the strong U.S. Action against Japan would convince Congress to tone down protectionist trade legislation now being drafted.
He denied he action had been taken for that reason.
A top level political reshuffle following the January removal of Communist Paty chief Hu Yaobang will take place at a party conference later this year, Vice-Premier Yao Yilin said Saturday.
Yao told a news conference Zhao Ziyang would go on holding te jobs of Premier and acting Communist Party chief until the 13th party congress, due to be held by October.
Yao gave the news conference in the Great Hall of the Peope along with Vice-Premiers Li Peng and Tian Jiyun, the two main contenders to succeed Zhao as Premier.
Western diplomats say Li, a technocrat who studied in the Soviet Union, is the most likely successo.
Li appeared to go out of his way to deny any special sympathy with Moscw.

In answer to questions, he said he had never met Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev when both studied in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and had since met him on only two occasion, both of which had been reported in the news media.
Asked what China could learn fromn the Soviet economic system, Li said the main lesson was o avoid excessive centralism and rigid control over economic activities.
"We do not totally reject the planned economy, but we ae opposed to rigid control in the planned economy which hampers initiative and enthusiasm of the grassroots enterprise," Li said.

On Taiwan, Yao repeated Chinese policy of not ruling out force to regain the nationalist-ruled island, but did not repeat an offical statement earlier this week that the goal was to achieve reunification by the year 2000.
"As for reunification, it is our hope that it will be achieved through peaceful means, but we have not eliminated the possiility of taking non-peaceful means to achieve that process," he said.

China as set up a new nationwide financial institution which will handle foreign exchange and renminbi deposits and loans, leasing, investment, guarantees and bond issues, the People's Daily overseas edition said.

The new institution, Everbright Financial Co>, is a unit of state-owned <Everbright Holding Co> of Peking, which has had a turnover of 500 mln dlrs since it was set up three years ago under the chairmanship of Wang Guangying, the paper said.
A estern banker said the creation of the new firm is a further step in making China's banking more competitive and breaking down the monopolies that existed previously.

He said the scope of the ne firm will be similar to that of state-owned <China International Trust and Investment Corp> (CITIC), which has been active in raising foreign funds and bringing foreign investment and technology to China.
CITIC is better known inside China, because most of Everbright's activities up to now have been abroad, the banker said
"The heads of both enjoy excellent relations with China's to leaders," he added.
The paper said Chen Muhua, president of the People's Bank of China, and Vice Premier Yao Yilin attended the firms founding ceremony, an indication of highest-level approval.

The paper quoted Chen as saying at the ceremony that in 1987 China will continue to deepen its economic reforms by such means as further reforming its financial system, enlivening currency markets and speeding up the circulation of unds.
State-owned AT-Jugoslav Airlines has signed a contract to buy five McDonnell Douglas Corp <MD.N> MD-11 wide-bodied airliners for its longhaul routes, Tanjug news agency reported.
AT will take delivery of the aircraft between 1991 and 1994, the agency said.
The irline will also add two turboprop aircraft to its fleet in June and lease two McDonnell Douglas DC-10s by the beginning of the summer tourist season, it said.
Poland's communist government raised food, fuel and energy prices but said it had taken an economic risk by reducing the scale of the increses under pressure from the country's official trade unions.
A communique broadcast on Saturday evening said food prices would rise o average by 9.3 pct, petrol, gas and electricity by 25 pct and coal by 50 pct.
The immediate increases will be followed by a rise of 10 pct in the cost of mea from April 1.
Some postal charges will go up 100 pct next month and rail and bus fares by 3 pct in October.
The government said its annual plan for the economy had specified a 13 pct increase in foo prices this year.
"Economic reasoning calls for greater price rises than thos which have been announced ...
The government has taken an economic risk in accepting a portion of the trades unions' demands," th communique said.
The National rade Union Alliance (OPZZ), which claims seven million members, warned earlier this month it would fight efforts to impose the original range of price rises.
It said the rises would badly affect the lower pad and the old, despite government pledges to protect their purchasing power.

Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, whose banned organisation has been replaced by the OPZZ, condemned the increases in front of a crowd of 1,500 cheering supporters at St Brygida's Roman Catholic Church in the Baltic port of Gdans.
"For the first time i six years (since Solidarity was banned), I say enough.
For the first time, I am decidedly against
I am against price rises as being the only sign o reform," Walesa said.
"I am for reforms
I favour the reforms which (Soviet leader Mikhail) Gorbachev is carryin out ...
But I am not in favour of make-believe reforms," he sai.

ormer National Security Adviser John Poindexter told President Reagan on two occasions in 1986 that profits from arms sales to Iran were being diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, according to a Time magazine report.

oindexter resigned as head of the National Security Council (NSC) last November when the Reagan administration disclosed he was aware part of the profits from the arms sales were diverted to contra rebels in Nicaragua.
he report in Time quoted unnamed friends of Poindexter's as saying he felt he was following Reagan's orders and that he kept the president adequately informed.

"Indee, he is likely to testify that on at least two occasions in 1986, he told Reagan in general terms that the contras were being helped as an ancillary or side benefit of the arms deal with Iran," Time said.
Reagan has repeatedly denied he knew anything about the diversion of arms sales profits to the contra.
In his nationally televised March 19 news conference Reagan told reporters Poindexter and fired NSC aide Oliver North "just didn't tel me what was going on."
Poindexter has been granted limited immunity so he can testify in congressional hearings o the affair.

Japan's video tape recorder (VTR) production fell 10.4 pct from a year earlier to 2.18 mln sets in February for the third successive year-on-year dro, reflecting slow exports, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said.
But February output was up 27.2 pt from a month earlier.
Colour television production rose 5.7 pct from a year earlier to 1.20 mn sets in February after 15 consecutive year-on-year drops.
The February increase over a year ao reflected higher domestic sales.
The production was up 38.5 pct fro a month earlier.
U.S. machine tool orders fell 1.1 pct in February to 145.1 mln dlrs from a revsed 146.7 mln dlrs in January, the National Machine Tool Builders Association said.
Last month the association reported the January totl tool orders at 147.8 mln dlrs.
In its monthly statistical report, the tool industry trade association also said that February orders wer off 31.0 pct from orders of 210.4 mln dlrs in February last year.
The association said metal-forming tool orders fell 13.3 pct last month to 41.4 mln dlrs from a revised 47.7 mln dlrs in January, and were off 1.1 pct from 41.8 mln dlr in February 1986.
Metal-cutting tool orders totaled 103.8 mln dlrs in February, up 4.9 pct from a revised 99.0 mln dlrs in January and 38.5 pct below the 168.6 mln dlrs in new orders fr February 1986.
The association said the backlog of orders in February was 1,210.7 mln dlrs, up 0.6 pct from the revised January backlog of 1,203.3 and 29.2 pct below the backlog in February las year.

The association said total shipments of machine tools fell 6.8 pct last month to 137.7 mln dlrs from a revised 147.7 mln dlrs in January and were off 32.1 pct from te 202.7 mln dlrs in orders in February last year.
Last month the association reported the January total shipments of machine tools at 148.3 mln dlr.

BTR Nylex Ltd> said it will increase its takeover offer for Borg-Warner Corp's <BOR> listed unit, <Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd> (BWA) to five dlrs each from four dlrs for all issued ordinary and preference shares.
he new offer values the diversified auto parts manufacturer's 27.22 mln ordinary shares and 13.22 mln first participating preference shares at 202.2 mln dlrs.
Formal documents will be sent to shareholders s soon as possible, it said in a brief statement.
BTR Nylex, which manufactures rubber and plastic product, first bid for BWA in late January.
As previously reported, Borg-Warner Corp, which owns 65 pct of BWA's ordinary shares and 10 pct of the preferences, advised a month ago that it would not accept the offer.
This meant BTR Nylex's 50.1 pct acceptance condition could not be met, BWA said i a statement reporting its parent's decision.
BWA advised shareholders to ignore the offer and said other parties had expressed interest i bidding for it.
But no other bd has yet emerged.
BTR Nylex is a 59.5 pct-owned listed subsidiary of Britain's BT Plc <BTRX.LON>.
The dollar's tumble to a record low of 144.70 yen in Tokyo today motivated some major Japanese investors to lighten thir U.S.
Bond inventory further and is expected to spur diversification into investment assets including foreign ad domestic shares, dealers said.
The key U.S. 7-1/2 pct Treasury bond due 2016 fell to a low of 96.08-12 in early Tokyo trade against the 98.05-06 New York finish, the recovered to 96.20-22.

Some trust bank pension fund acccounts and investment trusts were seen selling several hundred million dollars on the foreign exchange market here today, accentuating the uni's tumble, securities house dealers said.

They seem undecided on what to do with the fresh yen cash positions resulting from their dollar sales today, and are sidelined until the currency market stabilises and the interes rates outlook clarifies, a Nikko Securities Co Ltd currency trader said.

Th dollar's plunge and low yields on U.S. Bonds will further promote diversification into other foreign investments, as well as call back funds into the domestic bond and stock markets from overseas bond markets, securities bond managers said.
hey said major Japanese investors in the past two years are estimated to have held 50 to 80 pct of their foreign portfolios in U.S. Bonds but many have lightened their U.S.
ond inventory to as low as 40 pct.
An investor group trying to acquire GenCorp Inc said t would move to unseat the board of directors and take other action if GenCorp refuses to discuss a 2.3 billion dlr takeover bid.

General Acquisition Co, a partnership of Wagner and Brown nd AFG Industries Inc <AFG>, reiterated in a statement sent to GenCorp on Friday that it was willing to negotiate its earlier offer of 100 dlrs a share for the tire, broadcasting, plastics and aerospace conglomerate.
Analysts have speculated GenCorp culd fetch at least 110 to 120 dlrs per share if broken up.
GenCorp officials declined to comment on the statement, but a spokesman reiterated a request to shareholders to wait until th board renders an opinion before making a decision on the offer.
GenCorp has said a statement would be made on o before the company's annual meeting on Tuesday.
General Acquisition said the board could not carry out its duties to shareholders and make an informed decision until i has, "...
Explored with us the ways in which our offer ca be revised to provide greater value to your shareholders."
General Acquisition added it was aware the board may be reviewing alternative transactions, which might provide GenCorp shareholers with a payment other than cash.

"If that is the case, you should recognise that our additional equity capital may very well enable us to offer cash and securities having greater value than GenCorp could provide in any similarly structured transacton," it said.
It added GenCorp's board had an obligation to present any alternative proposal to shareholders in a way tha allowed competing offers.
General Acquisition requested it be given a chance to bid on a competitive and fair basis before an final decision was made on any other buyout proposal.
The statement repeated the request GenCorp remove a "poison pill" preferred share purchase rights to shareholders, making an takeover more expensive.
It said it might take legal action, or seek the support of shareholders in calling a special meeting to replace th board and consider other proposals.
GenCorp should not accept any other proposal containing defensive features, i said.

The Finance Ministry is trying to eliminate technical obstacles so as to encourage purchases of Japanese Treasury bills b foreign governments and central banks, in order to increase overseas holdings of yen assets, a senior Finance Ministry official said.
The official declined o give details but securities sources said they expect the 16 pct withholding tax on T-bills to be repaid immediately when governments and central banks buy bills.
The urrent practice of filing tax redemption claims is time consuming, they said.

Securities houses here have had difficulty elling six-month debt-financing paper, called tankoku, to overseas governments and central banks because of the tax system and the Bank of Japan's book entry system, which demands the accounts be kept with the houses rather than by the Bank.
Tankoku, introduced n February 1986, were designed as a key short-term instrument to promote internationalization of the yen.
But since the introduction of a complicated book-entry system for bill purchases in January 1986, foreign governments and central banks have shied away from buying he bills, the sources said.
Foreign governments nd central banks are therefore expected to be allowed to hold their accounts at the Bank of Japan, the securities sources said.
Relevant measures are likely to be announced at the next U.S.-Japan yen-dollar committee meeting on the deregulation of Tokyo's financial market, expected in May, they aid.
Sumitomo Metal Mining Co said it will raise its monthly nickel output to around 1,750 tonnes from April 1 from 1,650 nw because of increased domestic demand, mainly from stainless steel makers.
Sumitomo produced 1,800 tonnes of a nickel a month until end-186, but cut output in January because of stagnant demand, a company official said.
Calendar 1987 production is likely to fall to around 20,000 tones from 22,000 in 1986 as a result of the first quarter reduction, he said.
Sumitomo is Japan' only nickel producer.
Japanese vehicle exports fell 8.2 pct in February from January to 530,066, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Associaton said.
February exports ell 6.8 pct from a year earlier after a 6.8 pct year-on-year rise in January, the first growth since June 1986, when they rose 4.4 pct from a year earlier.
February exports included 361,285 cars, down 6.3 pct from a year earlier, 165,770 trucks, down 8.6 ct, and 3,011 buses, up 51.4 pct.
Exports to the U.S. Fell to 226,942 in February from 259,272 a year earlier, while those to the European Community roe to 141,095 from 121,050.
The EC figure included 63,387 vehicles to West Germany, up from 41,821, but exports to Britain fell to 20,554 from 28,53.
Shipments to South-east Asia fell to 33,957 from 41,960 an those to the Middle East fell to 15,828 from 25,278.
Japan's motorcycle exports rose 18 pct from January to 177,115 in February, but fell 25.9 pct from a year earlier, th 12th consecutive year-on-year drop.

U.S. roastings of green coffee in the week ended March 21 were about 250,000 (60-kilo) bags, including that used for soluble production, compared with 195,000 bags in the corresponding week of last yer and about 300,000 bags in the week ended March 14, George Gordon Paton and Co Inc reported.
It said cumulative roastings for calendar 1987 now total 3,845,000 bags, compared with 4,070,000 bags by ths time last year.
Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said that Japan and other industrialized nations committed themselves in Pars last month to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen.
He told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that the six nations have takn measures, including market intervention, to support the dollar above that level.
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa told the same committee that the six - Britain, Canada, France, Japan, the U.S. And West Germany - had intervened aggressively since the dollar fel below 150 yen.
Miyazawa said major nations are trying hard t stabilize exchange rates.
Asked if there had been any change n the fundamentals of each nation since the February 22 Paris accord, he said he did not think the fundamentals themselves had changed substantially.
But he said he market is sensitively looking at what is happening in major nations.
He id not elaborate.
Miyazawa added that it was difficult to ay why there has been such speculative dollar selling in the market.

Stocks plunged sharply just before the close of trade as the yen's continued rise against the dollar and Friday's order by President Reagan to impose weighty duties on key Japanese export sector prompted investors to evacuate their stock holdings, brokers said.
At 1456 local time the index had slumped 502.98 to 21,675.04, the day's low
On Saturday the index rose 151.36 to a record high f 22,178.02.

Dry areas of the Australian sugar cane belt along the Queensland coast have been receiving just enough rain to sustain the 1987 crop, an Australian Sgar Producers Association spokesman said.

The industry is not as worried as it was two weeks ago, but rainfall is still below normal and good soaking rans are needed in some areas, notably in the Burdekin and Mackay regions, he said from Brisbane.
Elsewhere, in the far north and the far south of the state and in northern New South Wales, the cane crop i looking very good after heavy falls this month, he said.
The spokesman said it is still too early to tell wht effect the dry weather will have on the size of the crop, which is harvested from around June to December.

He said frequent but light falls in the areas that are short of moisture, such as Mackay, mean they really only ned about three days of the region's heavy tropical rains to restore normal moisture to the cane.
But rainfall in the next two or three weeks will b crucial to the size of the crop in the dry areas, he said.
"It's certainly not a diastrous crop at this stage but it might be in a month without some good falls," he said.

apan is becoming dangerously isolated again as the U.S. And Europe feel they have been cheated by Japanese promises to switch from export to domestic-led growth, officials and businessmen from around the world said.

s the dollar today slipped to a record low below 145 yen, making Japanese exporters and holders of dollar investments grit their teeth harder, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said there was a perception Japan had reneged on its promise.
he problem goes deep and centres on misunderstandings by both sides over the key Maekawa report of April, last year.
The document was prepared by a private comittee formed by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and led by former Bank of Japan head Haruo Maekawa.
It recommended that to stop friction due o its large trade surpluses, Japan must "make a historical transformation in its traditional policies on economic management and the nation's lifestyle.
There can be o further development for Japan without this transformation."
Americans and Europeans took the report to hart and have looked in vain for clear signs of this historic change.
But the Japanese remain doubtful about the sort, or even medium term prospects of totally transforming their economic habits.
The bubble of frustration against what appears as Japanese prevaricaion burst last week.
The U.S. Said it intended to raise tariffs of as much as 300 mln dlrs on Japanese exports to th U.S. On the grounds Japan had abrogated a bilateral semiconductor pact.

British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher threatened to block Japanese financial firms from London after the Japanese placed what the British say are restrictive conditions on a bid by British firm Cable and Wireless to join a domestic telecommunications join venture.
On Friday, European currency dealers said European central banks, annoyed at restrictive Japanese trade practises, might leave Japan alone t intervene to staunch the rise of the yen.
Eishiro Saito, head of top Japanese business group Keidanren, spotted te dangers inherent in such contradictory views last November when he visited the European Community.

"Related to this matter of (trade) imbalance, the point that I found to be of great cause for alarm during this trp to Europe was the excessive degree of hope placed by the Europeans in the results of the Maekawa report," he said.
"We explained that the process of restructuring the economy away frm its dependence on exports toward a balance between domestic and external demand...Would take time," Saito said.
Saito's words wee ignored.

In February, C Industrial Policy Director Heinrich von Moltke came to Japan and said "I only know that your government, under the leadership of Maekawa, points to restructuring your economy into a less outward looking, more inward looking one.
t is the Maekawa report which has attracted the most attention in Europe."
nd Europeans and Americans want quick action.
"A ar better answer than protectionism would be structural change within the Japanese economy, the kind suggested by the Maekawa report.
And e hope to see changes occur in the near future," visiting Chairman of General Motors Roger Smith said in March.
Such expectations are now ingrained, which was partly the fault of Nakasone, who heralded Maekawa's report as a sea of change in Jaanese affairs, said U.S. Officials.
Months before the report wa issued, U.S. And EC business leaders met their Japanese colleagues to discuss the trade problem.
"We are more anxious than ever that the new approach of the Maekawa committee does lead to speedy and effective action," said C Industrial Union leader Lord Ray Pennock.

"The important implication of the Maekawa report is that t is finally looking to let Japanese enjoy the fruits of their labour," said Philip Caldwell, Senior Managing Director of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Contents of th report were leaded well ahead of issuance.
Japanese fficials say they are implementing the report as fast as they can, said a European ambassador who has travelled the country asking about this issue.
He aid People mentioned many things in line with the spirit of the report, including restructuring of the coal and steel industries.
A major misunderstanding is that the private report wa government policy.
Europeans are confused about this, underlined by von Moltke's refeence to the "leadership" of the Maekawa report.
Even so, Japanese officials pont to last September's government programme of new economic measures.
"Without endorsing the report as policy, officials point out that the government has put its signature to a programme designed to implement the report," the ambassador said

The Finance Ministry said it proposed to the unerwriting syndicate a record low 4.7 pct coupon on the 10-year government bond to be issued in April, down from the previous record low five pct March issue.
The bond would be priced at 99.75 to yeld 4.736 pct compared with 99.50 and 5.075 pct in March, and proposed issue volume is 1,400 billion yen against 475 billion, it said.
The syndicate s expected to accept the terms immediately, underwriters said.
<Ssangyong Construction Co Ltd> of South Korea has signed a 48.3 mln U.S. Dlr financing package to fund the construction of a hotel and commercial complex in Jakarta, the aget, Wardley Ltd, said.

The package, guaranteed by the parent firm, <Ssangyong Cement Industrial Co Ltd>, includes a 25 mln dlr medium term loan, a five mln dlr revolving letter of credit facility ad an 18.3 mln dlr bonding facility.
The three year loan carries interest at 1/2 point over three or six month Singapoe interbank offered rate (Sibor).
The LC facility costs 10 basis points over Sibor and the bonding facility 50 bass points.

The facility is being lead managed by Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. Managers are Arab Banking Corp, Bak of Nova Scotia, Gulf International Bank, Istituto Bancario San Paolo di Torino, National Bank of Kuwait, Standard Chartered Asia Ltd and Sumitomo Finance (Asia) Ltd. Co-managers are Australian European Finance Corp Ltd and Cho Heung Bank.
A Wardley spokesman said the loan was well receved by international banks which have a keen appetite for increasingly scarce Korean assets.
The loan was approved by the Korean Finance Minitry because it is for use outside Korea and will not raise the country's indebtedness, he said.
Indonesia has minimised the economic impact of falling oil prices, kept inflation within limits ad boosted exports, Finance Minister Radius Prawiro said.
Indonesia was badly hit by last year's steep plunge in crude prices, which cut revnue from oil exports by half.
But Prawiro was quoted by Indonesian newspapers as telling President Suharto that inflation was kept to around nine pct in the financial year ending tomorrow, against around 4.3 pct the previou year.
Exports were estimated to have risen by seven pct, he said, although he did not giv complete figures.
The depressed economy forms the main backdrop to general elections next month in Indonesia, a major producer of rubbr, palm oil, tin, timber and coffee.
Prawiro said 1986/87 had also been difficult because of the appreciation of currencies like the yen and the mar against the dollar, which increased Indonesia's debt repayments.
He said the economy would have suffered more from the world economic recession if the government had not devalue the rupiah by 31 pct last September.
In an editorial on the economic outlook, the Jakarta Post said the government must pres ahead with measures to deregulate the economy to help boost non-oil exports.
The English-language daily said bigger export earnings were needed to finance not only imports bt also the country's growing foreign debt, estimated at around 37 billion dlrs.
"About 50 pct of our foreign debt obligations fall due within the next three t five years and will steadily increase the debt servicing burden," the paper said.
However, end-investors were seen bargain hunting in expectation of a further yen interest rate decline dealers said.
Most dealers were cautious in the face of the dollar's nosedive today and the possibility of a U.S. Interest rate rebound t halt further dollar depreciation.
A 4.7 pct coupon and volume of 1,400 billion yen for the April 10-year bond proposed by the Finance Ministry this afternoo were taken favourably by the market.
Woolworth Holdings Plc <WLUK.L> said it would make a 244 mn stg agreed bid for <Superdrug Stores Plc> valuing the company's shares at about 696p each.
The offer would be made on the basis of 17 nw Woolworth ordinary shares for every 20 in Superdrug.
Woolworth said it had received acceptances from the holders of 61 pct of Superrug shares.
The bid is Woolworth's second attempt in recent months to acquire a retail chemis chain.
Earlier this year it negotiated a possible bid for <Underwoods Pl> buit the talks were broken off two weeks ago.
ull acceptance of the offer would involve the issue of about 29.8 mln new Woolworth shares, or 14 pct of the enlarged share capital.
A cash alternative would offer 646p for each share in Superdug.
Members of the Goldstein fmily have accepted the offer for 11.7 mln shares, which have not been underwritten.
Another major shareholder, Rite id Corp's Rite Investments Corp unit, had accepted the offer for 9.9 mln shares, and would take the cash alternative for 9.0 mln of these.
In the year to en-January, Woolworth reported pretax profits sharply higher at 115.3 mln stg after 81.3 mln previously.
In the year to en-February, Superdrug reported pretax profits of 12.26 mln after 10.36 mln previously on turnover that rose to 202.9 mln from 164.3 mln.
Superdrug hares firmed to 670p from 480p on Friday.
Wolworth eased to 813p from 830p.
The Japanese government appears to have little new t offer to settle a dispute with the U.S. Over computer chips, trade analysts and government officials said.

The U.S. Has threatened to impose tariffs worth up to 300 mln dlrs on Japanese electronics exports t the U.S., In retaliation for Japan's alleged failure to keep a pact on the microchip trade signed last September.
A Foreign Ministry official told Reuters "Japan has doe what it can, and now we must persuade the United States to wait for those steps to take effect."
The U.S. Alleges that, in defiance of the Septmber agreement, Japan is still selling microchips at below cost in non-U.S. Markets and refusing to open Japan further to U.S. Chip sales.
U.S. Tariffs are due t take effect on April 17.

Analysts noted Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) has already ordered chipmakers to cut prodction in order to dry up the source of cheap chips sold in third countries at non-regulated prices.
"I'm not sure MITI can do much more thn it has," said Jardine Fleming (Securities) Ltd analyst Nick Edwards.
A MITI official said the Ministry was not planning to call for production cuts beyond those already sought, athough it would continue to press chip users to buy more foreign goods.
Spokesmen for some Japanese electronics firms said they would cnsider buying more U.S. Chips.
But a Matsushit Electric Industrial Co spokesman said a rapid increase in imports was not likely.
Most analysts said Japanese exporters would be hard hit if the United States did implement the tariffs, which woul be levied on consumer electronics products rather than on microchips themselves.

"If the tariffs remain in place for any length of time, tere will be complete erosion of exports to the United States," said Tom Murtha, analyst at James Capel and Co. "The Japanese electronics industry is too powerful to be stopped altogether, but recovery for the industry will be delayed for another year," he said.
Some analysts said tariffs would aso harm U.S. Industry by stepping up offshore production and by reducing demand in Japan for semiconductors U.S. Firms are trying to sell here.
"The American aproach is full of contradictions," Jardine Fleming's Edwards said.
"If they want to expand (.S.) exports, the last thing they want to do is hit the makers of the final products because that hurts the final market," Edwards said.
But other analysts said the dispute reflects not just U.S. Concern over what it sees as a strategi industry, but also frustration with Japan's vast trade surplus.
Some analysts argued that to solve the semiconductor problem Japan may have to take action beyond that pleded in the semiconductor pact.
Carole Ryavec, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd, said "The major overall issue is to stimulate th domestic economy and move away from an export-dependent economy."
Remarks by Japan's Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that last moth's G-6 meeting agreed to stabilize the dollar above 150 yen have come too late to influence currency trading, dealers said.
After Nakasone's statement the dollar rose to 146.40/50 yen frm an initial low of 144.20/40 and New York's Friday finish of 147.15/25.
But the rebound was lagely on short-covering, they said.
"I think (Nakasone's desperate," said a U.S. Bank foreign exchange manager.
Nakasone told a Lower House Budget Committee in Parliament that Japan and other industrialized nations committed themselves in Paris last month to stbilize the dollar above 150 yen.
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa told the same committee that th six - Britain, Canada, France, Japan, the U.S. And West Germany - had intervened aggressively since the dollar fell below 150 yen.
"His (Nakasone) remarks should have been made and should have had a bigger influence when the dollar was still above 150 yen," sid P.S.
Tam o Morgan Guaranty Trust.
Tam said the dollar has hit short-term chart targets and is likely t rebound.
But he warned of another dip to belw 145 yen.
Dealers said the worsening trade relations between the U.S. And Japan will continue to depres the dollar.
The trade issue has now become a political issue since the Reagan Administration is facing uproar in Congress over th3pYgks in cutting the country's 169.8 billio dlr trade deficit, they said.

Japanese securities houses and banks are eager to enter the market for lead-management of mark eurobonds when the ban on Japanese institutions is lifted, but the entry may b difficult, Japanese bankers said.
Most Japanese securities houses and banks established here said they have concrete plans to entr lead-management business, as soon as terms are cleared, probably this year.
Japan's largest bank, The Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd, is also considering expanding its business her, bankers said.

Japanese banks were excluded from lead management of mark eurobonds when the Bundesbank opened that market to foreign banks in May 1985, due to the lack of reciprocity fr German banks in the Japanese market.
Last year, the Japanese began a slow opeing by granting West German banks investment licences.

Pressure on Tokyo stepped up last week when U.K. Government sources said Britain ay revoke the licences of some Japanese banks and securities firms operating in London when they come up for renewal if progress is not made towards opening Japan's markets to foreign competition.
A spokesman for the Dai-Ichi Kangyo repesentative office here said the bank was naturally considering options such as expanding its mark securities trading operations to Frankfurt.
Sources at the bank's London banch said the bank was already seriously planning such a move.
Expanding secondary operations would also iprove the placement capacity of Japanese houses intending to move into lead management of mark eurobonds.
But even Japanese banks already esablished in secondary markets here face a host of problems in lead management.
One s finding borrowers.
One banker at Nikko Securities o Ltd's The Nikko Securities Co (Deutschland) GmbH said the cost of mark issues may be too high for some Japanese firms.
"For he moment, for Japanese borrowers, marks are expensive," he said.
any prefer Swiss francs or eurodollars.
A Japanese borrower ith a five-year equity warrant eurodollar bond issued at 2-1/2 pct can now swap into domestic yen rates of one pct.
ut mark swap opportunities are limited.
In adition, many Japanese companies are committed already to large German banks.
To avoid souring rlations with German banks they now cooperate with, Japanese houses may prefer finding borrowers so far not seen in the mark sector.

Names may include Sanyo Electric Co Ltd and Nishimatsu Construction Co Ltd, which both count Yamaichi Securities Co Ltd as their house bank, or Hokkaido Electrc Power Co Inc, which recently gave a presentation here with the Industrial Bank of Japan's unit here.
Japanese banks are also faced with fining local personnel, which is not easy.
"They are definitely going t have a manpower problem," one Swiss banker said.
Swiss and American banks hd no trouble attracting top German managers.
But Japanese cultural differences wil be harder for Germans to overcome.
Success may depend on whther Japanese parents allow German subsidiaries independence to operate without interference.
Once established, more problems ae expected if extra competition shaves margins.
Extra competition could cut manaement fees in the mark sector.
Separate management and underwriting fees common here may also be eroded, whch now make German underwriting business profitable compared with other centres.
A few banks are unsure if they really want to get involved in te business.
"I don't think Sumitomo has 100-pct concrete plans at this moment unless there is a new development," a banker at the West Geman commercial branch of Sumito Bank Ltd in Duesseldorf said.
Apart from the commercial branch in Duesseldorf Sumitomo has a rep ofice in Frankfurt, but both are primarily engaged in commercial banking.
If Sumitomo were to set up a securities operation, it would hae to set up a full subsidiary, he said.

Japanese feed and starch makers actively bought U.S. Corn last week, C and F basis, for July/September shipment in view of bullish freight rates following active inquiries by the Soviet Union, trade sources said
Some said the makers were seen buying some 30 pct of their requirements, estimated at about three mln tonnes for th three-month shipment period.

"Belief is growing that freight rates will not decline sharply from current high levels even in the usually sluggish summer season because the Soviet Union's chartering is seen continuing five to seven months rom April," one source said.
The sources said Japanese trading houses were seen covering a total of 500,000 tonnes of Chinese corn for shipment in Ma to October.
But they are believed to have not yet sold most of the corn to end-users in anticipation of further corn price rises in th world market.

But the sources forecast supplies from Argentina may fall to 400,000 o 500,000 tonnes from an anticipated 800,000 in calendar 1987 and from South Africa to 700,000 to 800,000 tonnes from an estimated one mln in light of tighter export availability.
The recent deterioration in the steel market makes it impotant for Arbed SA <ARBB.BR> to maintain efforts to reduce costs, the company said in a statement.
It reported that its competitive position had weakened considerably in the second half of 1986, leading to a seven pt cut in steel output over the whole of the year to 3.74 mln tonnes.
Arbed had managed to make a 890 mln franc net profit, slightly down from the 1.12 billion profit in 195, thanks to lower raw material costs and prudent management, the company said.

Arbed said the early months of 1987 had seen the market deteriorate further, but the decision of the European Community to maintain anti-crisis measures, a least provisionally, should under normal circumstances have a beneficial effect.
EC ministers have agreed to extend a quota production system while discussions contine on an industry plan for capacity reductions.
Arbed said in current conditions, cost cutting efforts remain necessary to avoid ay weakening of resources which have been built up over the last three years.

BASF AG said the volatile currency situation last year, particularly the fall of the dollar, led to sharp drops in turnover denominated in marks and to price reductions for exports from domestic productin.
But in a statement accompanying year-end figures, the group said it expected satisfactory business development over th next months.
"At the moment we do not expect any extraordinary influences such as there were last year," t said.
Orders in hand and incoming orders were steady t a high level.
BASF reported 13.6 pct lwer 1986 world group pre-tax profit at 2.63 billion marks compared to 1985.
The unusual situation on he crude oil market last year also produced a clear sales slide in the oil and gas sector and forced price declines for petrochemical products, BASF said.
The fall in pre-tax pofit corresponded to the losses on stocks in the oil and gas sector at the beginning of 1986.
In the parent company, he positive earnings development continued, it said, where pre-tax profit rose by 3.2 pct to 1.97 billion marks.
The decline in parent cmpany turnover was balanced out by increased capacity use and price declines in raw materials.
In 1986, world roup turnover was off 8.8 pct at 40.47 billion marks compared to 1985, BASF said.
Parent trnover fell 8.5 pct to 18.72 billion.
Turnover increases, with he exceptions of the sectors fine chemicals and informations systems, had only been achieved in those areas widened last year through acquisition in 1985.
Results from these ad been taken only partly into the fourth quarter of that year but fully included in 1986 data.
So far in he current year, the investment volume of the parent company and the world group is exceeding that in 1986, BASF said, without giving concrete figures.
Bahrain is introducing a new domestic money market regime to provide dinar liquidity aid centred on the island's newly launched treasury bill prgramme.

The Bahrain Monetary Agency has issued a circular to all commercal banks outlining a new policy from April 1 which gives liquidity aid through sale and repurchase agreements in treasury bills, or through discounting them.
The circular, released officially to Reuters, said current arrangements for providing liquidity aid will n longer be valid except "in quite exceptional circumstances."
Under the current system, the agency provides the island's 20 commercial banks with dinar liquidiy by means of short-term swaps against U.S.
Dollars and, less frequently, by short-term loans secred against government development bonds.
"The agency considers that it is now appropriate to replace these operations with short-term assistace based on Government of Bahrain treasury bills," the circular to banks states.
The agency said t will repurchase treasury bills with a simultaneous agreement to resell them to the same bank at a higher price which will reflect an interest charge.
The agency said t envisages the repurchase agreements will normally be for a period of seven days.
Bahrain launched a eekly tender for two mln dinars of 91-day treasury bills in mid-December last year and has since raised a total of 26 mln dinars through the programme.
Bahrain's commercial banks re currently liquid and have been making little use of the traditional dollar swaps offered by the agency.
But anking sources said the new regime from April 1 will mean banks cannot afford not to hold treasury bills in case they need funds from the central bank.
Banking sources said ore than half of the 20 banks hold treasury bills, although the need by others to take up paper could increase demand at weekly tenders and push down allotted yields slightly.
Last eek's yield was six pct, although the programme had started at the end of last year with rates as low as 5.60 pct.
Banking ources said the cost of liquidity through repurchase accords will not differ much from that on dollar swaps.
But a bank sing dollars to obtain liquidity would foresake interest on the U.S. Currency while the underlying treasury bill investment is unaffected in a repurchase accord.

Japanese crushers have bought some 214,000 tonnes f Brazilian soybeans for late April/early July shipment and may buy up to 140,000 to 190,000 tonnes more for June to August shipment, trade sources said.
Japan imported 128,089 tonnes of Brazilian beans in calendar 1986, Finance Ministry customs-cleared satistics show.
The sources said Brazilian beans were cheaper tha U.S.
Origin which may account or the heavy purchases, but added there were concerns about deliveries from Brazil in the near term due to labour problems there.

The Japanese purchases comprise 30,000 tonnes for April 2/May 10 shipment, 102,000 for May, 15,000 for late May/early June, 36,000 for June, and 31,000 for late June/early July shipment, the sources said.
As a result of he large volumes of Brazilian beans purchased, Japanese crushers will buy a total of only 150,000 tonnes of U.S.
Beans or May shipment.
Some 100,000 of this shipment has already been purchased, the sourcs added.

Beans for Apil shipment.

A maximum budget deficit of 2.5 billion dlrs for fiscal 1987/88 ending June 30 is needed if financial markets are to be impressed wih the government's resolve to tackle Australia's economic problems, Westpac Banking Corp <WSTP.S> said.
This compares with the budgeted deficit of 3.5 billion dlrs for te current 1986/87 year although the market expects the actual shortfall to be some 500 mln dlrs higher.
In its latest Economic Review, Westpac said powerful arguments could be advaned for eliminating the deficit altogether next year or even budgeting for a modest surplus.
Westpac said such a policy would deliver the message the government ws determined to face deep-seated economic problems.
But it said it would be a great deal to expect o a government in what was probably an election year.

t said even a relatively minor cut in the deficit would require some unpleasant decisions, noting a repeat of the 1986/87 budget's zero real growth in spending would only bring the deficit to about 4.3 billion dlrs.
A cut of greater than two pct in real terms was needed if a 2.5 billion dlr deficit was to be achieved and ths required some radical surgery to existing programs, the bank said.

Westpac said the government's mid-May mini-budget provided an opportunity for bold measures, both in relation to the size of the government's role in te economy and the principles governing that activity, notably indexation of outlays.
It said official figures show 93 pct of outlays in some wy indexed, hard to justify when living standards outside the public sector were being eroded.

In current circumstances, the alternative to fiscal discipline is the sure rod to bigger external debts, further currency depreciation, a boost to inflation and, ultimately, capital flight, the bank said.

he figure was 2.6 pct higher than in December 1985.

The Bank of England said it forecast a liquidity surplus of around 100 mln stg in th money market today.

Among the main factors affecting liquidity, exchequer transactions will add some 985 mln stg to the system today while a fall in note circulation and bankers' balances above target will add around 36 mln stg and 110 mln stg respectively.
Partly offsetting these inflows, bills for repurchase by the market will drain some 785 ml stg while bills maturing in official hands and the treasury bill take-up will remove about 546 mln stg.

The Bank of Japan will sell 500 billion yen of financing bills via a 32-da repurchase agreement to help mop up a money market surplus of around 1,750 billion yen tomorrow, short-term money houses said.
The bill, to mature on May 2, will produce a 3.8995 pct yield on th sales, made by the Bank of Japan to banks and seucurities houses through money houses, they said.
The repurchase agreement yield compares with the 3.9375 pct one-month commercial bill discount rate today and the 4.40 pct rae on one-month certificates of deposit.
The surplus is due largely to government tax allocations to local governments and public entities at the end of fiscl 1986/87 tomorrow.
The operation will put outstanding bill supplies at about 2,50 billion yen.

Finance and Planning Minister Ronnie De Mel has left for Washington to discss Sri Lanka's request for an International Monetary Fund (IMF) loan facility of up to 6.5 billion rupees, ministry officials told Reuters.
They said De Mel will propose to IMF officials that Sri Lanka tim its budget deficit and control its balance of payments by cutting back on development projects and other government spending.
He hopes to get approval for a structural adjustment facility and compensatory financing facility starting i June.
De el will also attend a Washington meeting of the Group of 24 from April 5 to 8.
Japan's ailing shipyards ave won approval from the Fair Trade Commission to form a cartel to slash production to about half of total capacity for one year, effective April 1, industry sources said.
The pproval follows an act of parliament passed last week designed to help the industry regroup and shed 20 pct of capacity by March 31, 1988, Transport Ministry officials said.

The cartel, comprising 33 yards capable of constructing ships of more than 10,000 gross tonnes, will limit newbuilding output to a maximum of three mln compensated gross registered tonnes in 1987/88, the Shipbuilders Association o Japan said.
Industry sources said the 33 will seek to renew the cartel in 1988/89 in the belief demand will remain sluggish

Last week's temporary act of parliament also allows shipbuilders to receive favourable taxation terms plus up t 50 billion yen in compensation for liabilities incurred through job losses and the sale of excess capacity.
Up to 30 billion yen has been allocated fo purchasing redundant land and equipment from shipbuilders.
The Ministry will start drawing up its restructuring guidelines from April 1 and the yards will implement the guidelines fom September, industry sources said.

The Indonesian rupiah has held steady since its 31 pct devaluation against the dollar six months ago, but has slipped against th mark and to a lesser extent against the yen, according to central bank figures.
In the past month, the rupiah has fallen five pct against the ye.
Today's middle rate per 10 yen was 1,129.78 against 1,075.20 at end-February and 1,058.6 at devaluation in September.
Bank Indonesia's quoted rate for the dollar, the main currency for Indonesia's oil and gas exports, was 1,644.0 today, the same rate fixed at the time of devalation.
The rate for the West German mark was 913.28 today, a shrp drop from September when it was 786.06.
The British pound has risen t 2,657.93 against 2,429.83.
The value of the rupiah is set daily against a basket o currencies by the central bank.
The rise in the value of the mark and the yen hs hit Indonesia by increasing its debt servicing levels.
Its total disbursed foreign debt is estimated by the World Bank at 37 billio dlrs.
apan is one of Indonesia's key trading partners, taking half its oil exports.
Gillette Canada Inc s launching a 500 mln French franc bond, due April 30, 1992, paying nine pct and priced at 101-5/8, Banque Paribas said on behalf of Banque Paribas Paris, the lead manager.
Morgan Guaranty Ltd will co-lead manage he issue, which will be sole in denominations of 10,000 francs and be listed in Luxembourg.
Fees are 1-1/4 ct for selling and 5/8 pct for management and underwriting combined.
The bonds are noncallable and payment is April 29.

Philippine coconut oil exports to Europe wuld be virtually wiped out if the European Community (EC) implements a new tax on vegetable oils, Philippine Coconut Authority (PCA) chairman Jose Romero said.

But he told reporters he did not think the EC would impose the tax because f objections from the U.S. "There's just so much flak coming from many countries, spearheaded by the United States, whose soybean exports would be adversely affected.
This would sark a trade war," he said.
The tax, to be impose from July, would add about 375 dlrs a tonne to vegetable oils entering the EC.
The Philippines exported 43,540 tnnes of coconut oil worth 11.7 mln dlrs to Europe in January, against total exports of 86,959 tonnes worth 23.8 mln.
It also exports copra and copra mal.
Agriculture Secretary Crlos Dominguez has also raised objections to the proposed EC tax.
He said it could cuse the collapse of world demand and prices and destroy the domestic industry.
weden's Wallenberg group said it raised its holding in telecommunications maker Telefon AB L.M.
ricsson <eric.St.> to 37.5 of the voting rights from 28.9 pct.

The move by he Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation, one of the institutions at the core of the group of companies formed by the late industrialist Marcus Wallenberg, further consolidated group control over one of its key firms, analysts said.
The foundation now controls 14.1 pct of Ericsson's voting rights with 22.3 pct held by the group's investment companies <AB Investor> an <Forvaltnings AB Providentia>.

The move comes after the Wallenberg group fought off a hostile takeover bid earlier this month for match and packaging conglomerate Swedish Match AB <smbs.St> from arms and chemical concern Nobel Industrier AB <NOBL.ST> by increasing its stake in Swedish Match to 8 pct from 33 pct.
<GKN Plc> said it and <Zahnradfabrik Friedrichshafen AG> would reorganise the ownership structure o their <Viscodrive GmbH> joint venture.
Under the agreement, GKN's Uni-Cardan AG unit would increase its stake in Viscodrive to 75 pct from 50 pct, whil ZF's stake would drop to 25 pct.
At the same time ZF would take an 80 pt stake in a new company, <Steertec Lenkungen GmbH> leaving Uni-Cardan with 20 pct.
Viscodrive manufactures viscous control unts while Steertec will develop power steering systems.
Yugoslavia said it has been asked to participat in the production of a new Soviet airliner -- the Ilyushin 114.
The official Tanjug news agency said this was decided at a meeting in Havana of officials of the Soviet-led trade group Comcon.
Yugoslavia is a communist nonaligned state, belonging neither to the Warsaw Pact or the Western alliance, Nato, but it enjoys preferential tradig status in Comecon.
Under the deal, Yugoslavia will produce several major parts, including the landing gear, for the new medium-range 80-passenger Ilyushin airliner, Tanjug sid.
No finncial details were disclosed.
French retail prices rose a confirmed 0.2 pct in February, in line with provisional figures released two weeks ago showing a rise of between 0.1 and 0.2 pct the National Statistics Institute said.
The rise compared with a 0.9 pc rise in January.
Year-on-year retail price inflation was confirmed t 3.4 pct for February compared with a three pct rise year-on-year in January.

The Philippines' restructuring of 13.2 billion dlrs of foreign debt will provide a welcome boost for the economy, but last Friday's accord with the country's 12-bank advisory committee does not imply an overnight boom, bankers and businessmen polled y Reuters said.
"The successful negotiations form an important piece in the mosaic," Christian Roeher, Secretary-General of the European Chamber of Commerce, said
"Now is really the time for the government to star implementing its ideas.
There has been a lot of talking and loud thinking.

Business leaders aid the 17-year rescheduling of commercial bank debt would give President Corazon Aquino some badly-needed breathing space, but warned her government was still in the midst of political consolidation.

"There is a lot of iterest among foreign investors in the country, but now they are waiting to see what happens in the congressional and local elections later this year," said American Chamber of Commerce president George Drysdale.
The government s serious about getting down to work, but there are many individual agendas for growth and no consensus.
But ach step brings a unanimity of opinion closer, he said.

Aurelio Periquet, President of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, told Reuters the debt accord had positively translated th international banking community's confidence in the country's economy and Aquino's government.
"This government needs less pressure and more time and happily our creditors seem to see it that way," he said
"This accord may not result in an immediate boom, but at least it enhances the image of the country fo foreign investors."
But Periquet said domestic and foreign investments fell short f targets in 1986.
"The accord does not solve all our problems," he adde.
Periquet said the question of political stability no longer worried Filipino businssmen, who had already started expanding existing businesses or investing in new areas.
"A number of us have already put in new money and thre are plans for the export market," he said.
"President Aquino has shown her ability to pull the nation out o one crisis after another."
Roeher said foreign investment would probably be held back until after te congressional polls in May and the local elections in August.
"The two elections will probably have a more decisive effect on te way business reacts," he said.
"Some foreign companies are not waiting, but they are moe the exception than the rule," Roeher said.
He said it was important the government ensure the creaion of more jobs was not just a transitory development.
"The absorption of enormous ad given to the Philippines is also poor.
A lot of it hs not been put to use.
The government should act without further delay to absorb te 1.7 billion dlrs of development aid it will receive in 1987," he said.
A foreign banker close to the debt negotiations said h did not foresee any real boom until 1989.
The problem is that Aquino has inherited her political system from (former President Ferdinand) Marcos," the banker said.
"Ther is still a clamour for the sharing of benefits, different sectors claiming their rights and duties.
If they go too fast there could be another bust two years own the road."
usinessman Raul Concepcion, whose brother Jose is the country's trade and industry minister, said everyone could heave a sigh of relief.
"Now that the debt agreement is out of the way, our economic and financial officials can concentrate on their work, like increasing government revenue and efficiency, he said.
Toray Industries Inc <TORT.T>, Japa's top synthetic fibre maker, named managing director Katsunosuke Maeda as president, effective April 16.
Current president Yoshikazu Ito wll become chairman.
Yields on certificates of deposit offered by the United Arab Emirates central bank were higher than last Monday's offering, th bank said.
One-month maturity rose 1/16 pint to 6-3/16 pct, two-month 1/8 point to the same level, and three- and six-month issues 3/16 point to 6-1/4 pct each.

Credit Agricole announced an offer to swap the 1,889,000 fancs of bonds outstanding on its original 4.25 mln franc, 10-year, 14 pct July 1980 issue for its new four billion franc, two tranche, 8.30 pct, 1987 issue.
The swap will be n the basis of two 2,000 franc nominal 1980 bonds for one 5,000 franc nominal bond of the 1987 issue.
Sri Lanka will uproot rubber trees that are more than two years old and affected by the lef disease corynespora, the head of the government's Rubber Research Institute told Reuters.

Rodney De Mel said affected trees less than two years old would undergo base-budding -- attaching a clone as close as possible to th trunk's base and cutting off the top of the tree once the bud has taken.
Uprooted or base-budded trees mature later, causing an output loss estimated at 350 kilos per hectare from the sixth year whn they begin producing.
About 7,000 acres are planted with the high yielding RIC 103 variey, the clone afflicted by corynespora.
Only about 2,000 acres are affected by the disease, which causes leave to fall off, De Mel said.
Sri Lanka has 508,000 acres plantd with rubber trees.
De Mel said the disease was detected in nurseries as early as in middle 1985, but it was only in August-September 1986 that it beame widespread.
The Institute is conducting a survey to determine how many trees wil be uprooted or base-budded.
Healthy trees will be sprayed ad remain under observation.

Lilaratne, head of the government's Rubber Controller Department, which monitors the industry, told Reuters replanting and base-budding would have to be undertaken before late My when the monsoon rains begin.
De Mel said clones in the nurseries which are susceptible to corynespora, identified as RIC 103, RIC 52, RIC 104, RIC 106, RIC 17 and RIC 118, will be uprooted and burned.
The same procedures will be undertaken for the foreign clones indentified as NAB 12, RRIM 725, FX25, PPN 2444, PPN 2447, KRS 1 and PPN 2058.
Lilaratne said th susceptible clones would be replaced by PB 86, RRIM 600, RRIC 110, RRIC 121, RIC 100 and RIC 102.
These six vrieties would also be used to replace trees uprooted or base-budded, De Mel said.
Lilaratne said planters would receive 10,000 rupees per hetare for replanting and plants would be free of charge.
"But no compensation is contmplated at the moment," he added.
De Mel aid a drought in Sri Lanka has helped control the spread of the disease.
"The drought has not stopped the disease, but probably helped in some way because trees have not been affected in areas that are ry," he said.
Brokers said th disease had not affected prices because it has not caused a drop in production.
Prices for the best latex crepe at the Colombo auction last week firmed to 20.19 rupees per kilo from 20.05 rupees at the pevious sale.
Finland's <Kansallis-Osake-Pankki> said in a statement it is issuing 100 mln dlrs subordinated bonds due 1994 with equity warrants in international markets ith maximum interest rate of 4-5/8 pct.
Pricing ill probably be April 7, the statement said.
The new ssue could raise the bank's share capital by 200 mln Finnish marks from the present 2.26 billion, it said.
The statement said the issue followed up the 1986 tender issuance involving the first non-restricted or free shares, which can be held y aliens.
The warrants entitle holders to subscribe for a maximum of 10 ml free shares.
Eight mln of the Bank's current 113 mln shares are free shares, a spokewoman said.

The float follows the signing by Finnish President Mauno Koivisto last Friday of legislation entitling aliens with effect from next Jue 1 to own up to two fifths of the shares in Finnish companies, with consent of the Council of State, as against one fifth although voting rights will be restricted.

Quebecor Inc <PQB.A>, the Canadian publishing concern, is issuing a 60 mln dlr convertible bond due May 14, 1997 bearing a indicated coupon of 5-3/4 to six pct, said Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as lead manager.
The issue will be priced to have a conversion premium o 22 to 25 pct, with final terms to be set on Monday, April 6.
The company's stock last traded o the Toronto Stock Exchange at 19-3/8.
