Yugoslav government plans to stop subsidising loss-making firms will anger hundrds of thousands of workers, Western diplomats said.
The law, proposed by Prime Miister Branko Mikulic, goes into effect on July 1 and aims to end a long-standing practice of supporting unprofitable companies.
Under the law, wage cuts will be imposed on losing enterprises, while those failing t recover within a six-month grace period will face liquidation.
The diplomats said Mikulic's attempt to create a market economy is inevitable, but has stil come as a shock to those accustomed to government subsidies.
"It was a bitter pill which had to be swallowed, but if an overdose is taken too abruptly, it may have advere effects on the system," a Western diplomat said.
He said if the law was applied too strictly it would probably provoke a new wav of strikes and unrest.

Yugoslavia was swept by strikes last month following the introduction of a wage-freeze law, later amended to allow more flexibility and some exemptions i what some political analysts saw as a retreat by Mikulic.
But with inflation moving towards 100 pct, trade union leaders have ased how much more deprivation workers can take.

The union leaders said workers thoughout the country are already receiving salaries below limits set under existing law, while others have received no waes at all this year because their employers are unable to pay them.
Workers also complain much of thir income is taken in local, state and federal taxes.
Many others are losing their motivation to work and confidence in goverment as they feel their decision-making powers are being eroded, trade union officials said.
Meanwhile, the oficial Tanjug news agency reported a paper and cellulose factory at Ivangrad in the Montenegro republic closed yesterday and 2,000 of its workers were given "temporary leave."
Tanjug said he plant had been running at a loss for the 24 years it had been in operation, and its closure was the result of "economic necessity" rather than bankruptcy.
The French gvernment won, as expected, a vote of parliamentary confidence sought by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac on his general policies.
Votes from Chirac's Gaullist RPR party and its junior partner in the ruling coalition, the centre-right UDF, gave Chirac's cabinet a slim majority in the National Assembl.
A total of 294 deputies in the 577-member assembly voted to support Chirac, with 22 voting against.
One member was absent
The Socialists, Communists and the extreme-right National Front voted against the prime minister's cal.
Mounting trade friction between the US. And Japan has raised fears among many of Asia's exporting nations that the row could inflict far-reaching economic damage, businessmen and officials said.
They told Reuter correspondents in Aian capitals a U.S. Move against Japan might boost protectionist sentiment in the U.S. And lead to curbs on American imports of their products.
But some exporters said that wile the conflict would hurt them in the long-run, in the short-term Tokyo's loss might be their gain.

The U.S. Has said it will impose 300 mln dlrs f tariffs on imports of Japanese electronics goods on April 17, in retaliation for Japan's alleged failure to stick to a pact not to sell semiconductors on world markets at below cost.
Unofficial Japanese stimates put the impact of the tariffs at 10 billion dlrs and spokesmen for major electronics firms said they would virtually halt exports of products hit by the new taxes.
"We ouldn't be able to do business," said a spokesman for leading Japanese electronics firm Matsushita Electric Industrial Co Ltd <MC.T>.

"If the ariffs remain in place for any length of time beyond a few months it will mean the complete erosion of exports (of goods subject to tariffs) to the U.S.," said Tom Murtha, a stock analyst at the Tokyo office of broker <James Capel and Co>.
n Taiwan, businessmen and officials are also worried.
We are aware of the seriousness of the U.S.
Threat against Japan because it serves as a warning t us," said a senior Taiwanese trade official who asked not to be named.
Taiwan had a trade trade surplus of 15.6 billion dlrs last year, 9 pct of it with the U.S.
The surplus helped swell Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves to 53 billion dlrs, amog the world's largest.
"We must quickly open our markets, remove trade barriers and cut import tariffs to allow imports of U.S. Products, if w want to defuse problems from possible U.S.
Retaliation," said Paul Sheen, chairman of textile exporters <Taiwan Safe Group.

A senior official of outh Korea's trade promotion association said the trade dispute between the U.S. And Japan might also lead to pressure on South Korea, whose chief exports are similar to those of Japan.
Last year South Korea had a trade surplus of 7.1 billion dlrs with the U.S., Up from 4.9 billion dlrs n 1985.
In Malaysia, trade officers and businessmen said tough curbs against Japan might allow hard-hit producers of semiconductors in third countries o expand their sales to the U.S.
In Hong ong, where newspapers have alleged Japan has been selling below-cost semiconductors, some electronics manufacturers share that view.
But other businessme said such a short-term commercial advantage would be outweighed by further U.S. Pressure to block imports.
"That is a very short-term view," said Lawrence Mills, director-general o the Federation of Hong Kong Industry.
"If the whole purpose is to prevent imports, one day i will be extended to other sources.
Much more serious for Hong Kog is the disadvantage of action restraining trade," he said.
The U.S. Last year was Hong Kong's biggest export market, accouting for over 30 pct of domestically produced exports.
The Australian government is awaiting the outcome of trade talks beween the U.S. And Japan with interest and concern, Industry Minister John Button said in Canberra last Friday.
"This kind of deterioration in trade relations between two countries which are major trading partners of ours is a very serios matter," Button said.
He said Australia's concerns centred on coal and beef, Australia's two largest exports to Japan and also significant U.S. Exports o that country.
Meanwhile U.S.-Japanese diplomatic manoeuvres to solve the trade stand-off cotinue.
Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Part yesterday outlined a package of economic measures to boost the Japanese economy.
The measures proposed include a large supplementary budget and record public works spending in the first half of the fiancial year.
They also call for stepped-up spending as an emergency measure to stimulate the economy despite Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's avowd fiscal reform program.

Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Michael Smith and Makoto Kuroda, Japan's depuy minister of International Trade and Industry (MITI), are due to meet in Washington this week in an effort to end the dispute.
The union representing 7,000 pilots at United Airlines is proposing wage cuts of up to 25 pct to help finance a 4.5 billion dlr employee buyout of the nation's second larget air carrier.

In a television link-up of 10,000 employees at 11 sites nationwide, the Air Line Pilots Association unveiled details of a planned employee stock ownership plan for United, a wholly-owned subsidiary o UAL Inc.
The proposed wage cuts would affect senior pilots the most, although the other 53,000 workers employed by United would also be asked t accept less pay.
In addition, the union is asking its pilots to invest one-third of the union pension fund's 1.1 billion dlrs in the proposed employee-owed company.

In an effort to get the rank and file to contribute five pct of their earnings, United's 21-mmber master executive council donated 150,000 dlrs in cash and committed 2.1 mln dlrs in pension fund assets for acquisition of new preferred shares.
A survey of 19 provinces and seven cities shwed vermin consume between seven and 12 pct of China's grain stocks, the China Daily said.
It also said that each year 1.575 mln tonnes, or 25 pct, of China's fruit output are let to rot, and 2.1 mln tonnes, or up to 30 pct, of its vegetables.
The paper blamed the wate on inadequate storage and bad preservation methods.
It said the government had launched a national programme to reduce waste, calling fr improved technology in storage and preservation, and greater production of additives.
The paper gave n further details.

The Ministry of International Tade and Industry (MITI) will revise its long-term energy supply/demand outlook by August to meet a forecast downtrend in Japanese energy demand, ministry officials said.
MITI is expected to lwer the projection for primary energy supplies in the year 2000 to 550 mln kilolitres (kl) from 600 mln, they said.
The decision follows the emrgence of structural changes in Japanese industry following the rise in the value of the yen and a decline in domestic electric power demand.
MITI is planning to wrk out a revised energy supply/demand outlook through deliberations of committee meetings of the Agency of Natural Resources and Energy, the officials said.
They said MITI will aso review the breakdown of energy supply sources, including oil, nuclear, coal and natural gas.

Nuclear energy provided the bulk of Japan's electric power in the fiscal year ended March 31, supplying an estimated 27 pct on a kilowatt/hour basis, followed b oil (23 pct) and liquefied natural gas (21 pct), they noted.
Nissan Motor Co Ltd <NSAN.T> is negotiating the supply of car components to Mexcan units of Ford Motor Co <F> and Chrysler Corp <C>, a Nissan spokeswoman said.
<Nissan Mexicana SA de CV> is owned 96.4 pct by Nissan and 3.6 pt by Marubeni Corp <MART.T>.
It expects to win orders for precision casting parts for engines, and aluminium cass for automatic transmissions.
These will supply output of 70,000 mid-size cars a year at Chrysler's Mexican uni, the spokeswoman said.
Nissan is negotiating a similar deal to supply Ford's Mexican unit with precision casing parts for car engines, the spokeswoman said, without providing further details.
The company is expected t reach agreements with both U.S.
Car makers someime this year, she said.
Nissan Mexicana will invest about 400 mln yen to imrove production facilities after the agreements are signed, she said.
Foreigners will be able t invest up to two mln N.Z.
Dlrs in New Zealand assets without getting approval from te Overseas Investment Commission, the Commission said.
The decision, effective tomorrow raises the threshold from its prevous level of 500,000 dlrs, it said in a statement.
"The new level is felt to be more appropriate to objectives given the present cost structure involved in operating a business in New Zealand," the commssion said.
The increase does not aply to the acquisition of shares.
Thailand's trade deficit widened to 4.5 billion baht in te first quarter of 1987 from 2.1 billion a year ago, the Business Economics Department said.
It said Janunary/March imports roe to 65.1 billion baht from 58.7 billion.
Thailand's improved business climate this year resulted in a 2 pct increase in imports of raw materials and semi-finished products.
The country's oil import bill, however, fell 23 pct i the first quarter due to lower oil prices.
The department said first qurter exports expanded to 60.6 billion baht from 56.6 billion.

Export growth was smaller than expected due to lower earnings from many key commodities including rice whose earnings declined 18 pct, maze 66 pct, sugar 45 pct, tin 26 pct and canned pineapples seven pct.
Products registering high export growth were jewellery up 64 pct, clothng 57 pct and rubber 35 pct.

Indonesia expects crude palm oil (CPO) prices to rise sharply to between 450 and 550 dlrs a tonne FOB sometime this yer because of better European demand and a fall in Malaysian output, Hasrul Harahap, junior minister for tree crops, told Indonesian reporters.
Prices of Malaysian and Sumatran CPO are now around 332 dlrs a tonne CIF for delivery i Rotterdam, traders said.
Harahap said Indonesia would maintain its exports, despite making recent palm oil purchases from Malaysia, so tha it could possibly increase its international market share.
Indonesia, the world's second largest producer of palm oil after Malaysia, has been forced to import pal oil to ensure supplies during the Moslem fasting month of Ramadan.
Harahap said it was better to import to cover a temporary shortage than to lose export market.
Indonesian exports of CPO in calendar 1986 were 530,500 tonnes, against 468,500 in 1985, according to cental bank figures.

<Nissho Iwai Corp> and Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd <KAWH.T> have jointly won an order to build 200 subway cars worth about 200 mn dlrs for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York, a Nissho spokesman said.
The cars, to be produced wih 51 pct U.S.
Content, will be delivered between ealy 1988 and August 1989, he said.
Ten will be built in Japan, but the others will be mae at a Yonkers, New York, plant equally owned by Nissho and Kawasaki.
The House Armed Services Committee last night proposed cutting President Reagan's funding request for the Strategic Defence Initiative program b 1.7 billion dlrs to 3.5 billion.
The committee also cut by more than half the amount the president requested for a rail system for strategic missils.
It approved 250 mln dlrs for the project during its consideration of the 198 defence authorisation bill.
The committee's proposals must be adopted by the full Hose and Senate before becoming law.
The administration's total request for 198 defence spending was 312 billion dlrs.
NEC Corp <NESI.T> filed suit in Tokyo District Court to temporarily hat the manufacture and marketing of <Seiko Epson Corp>'s NEC-compatible personal computer series, an NEC spokesman said.
He said Seiko Epson's PC 286 computer and HDD-20 interface board infringe on software copyrights of th Basic In Out System program of NEC's best-selling 9801 computer series.
A spokesman for Seiko Epson, which is part of the Hattori Seiko Co Ltd <HATT.T> group, sid its computer does not infringe on any copyrights and will be marketed this month.
The HDD-20 interface board went on sale last December

NEC's request for an injunction against Seiko Epson and its marketing subsidiary is the first entirely doestic lawsuit charging infringement of computer software copyrights, the Seiko Epson spokesman said.
Share market analysts said that NEC controls about 0 pct of Japan's personal computer market.

Introduction of NEC-compatible machines could spark a price war and cut NEC's profits, as happened to International Business Machines orp <IBM> following the introduction of IBM-compatible machines, they added.

Tu crews in New South Wales (NSW), Victoria and Western Australia yesterday lifted their ban on foreign-flag ships carrying containers but NSW ports are still being disrupted by a separate dispute, shipping sources said.
The ban, imposed a week ago over a pay claim, had prevented the movement in or out of port f nearly 20 vessels, they said.
The pay dispute went before a hearing of the Arbitratin Commission today.
Meanwhile, disruption began today o cargo handling in the ports of Sydney, Newcastle and Port Kembla, they said.
The industrial action at the NSW ports is part of the week of action called by the NSW Trades an Labour Council to protest changes to the state's workers' compensation laws.
The shipping sources said the various port unions appear o be taking it in turn to work for a short time at the start of each shift and then to walk off.
Cargo handling in the ports has been disrupted, with container movements most affected, but has not stopped altogether, they said
They said they could not say how long te disruption will go on and what effect it will have on shipping movements.
The Indonesian Cmmodity Exchange is likely to start trading in at least one new commodity, and possibly two, during calendar 1987, exchange chairman Paian Nainggolan said.
He told euters in a telephone interview that trading in palm oil, sawn timber, pepper or tobacco was being considered.
Trading n either crude palm oil (CPO) or refined palm oil may also be introduced.
But he aid the question was still being considered by Trade Minister Rachmat Saleh and no decision on when to go ahead had been made.
The fledgling exchange currently trades coffee and rubber physcals on an open outcry system four days a week.
"Several factors make us moe cautiously," Nainggolan said.
"We want to move slowly and safely so tht we do not make a mistake and undermine confidence in the exchange."
Physical rubber trading was launhed in 1985, with coffee added in January 1986.
Rubber contracts are traded FO, up to five months forward.
Robusta coffee grades four and five are traded fo prompt delivery and up to five months forward, exchange officials said.
The trade ministry and exchange board are considering the introduction of futures trading later for rubber, but one offiial said a feasibility study was needed first.
No decisions are likely until after Indonesia's elections on Apri 23, traders said.

Trade Minister Saleh said on Monday that Indonesia, as the world's second largest producer of natural rubbr, should expand its rubber marketing effort and he hoped development of the exchange would help this.
Nainggolan said that the exchange was trying to boos overseas interest by building up contacts with end-users.

He said teams had already been to South Korea and Taiwan to encourage direct use of the exchange, while a delegation would also visit Europe, Mexico and some Latin American staes to encourage participation.
Officials say the infant exchange has made a good start although trading in coffee has bee disappointing.

Transactions in rubber between the start of trading in April 1985 and December 1986 totalled 9,595 tonnes, worth 6.9 mln dlrs FOB, plus 184.3 mln rupiah for rubber delivered locally, te latest exchange report said.
Trading in coffee in calendar 1986 amounted to only 1,905 tonnes in 381 lots, valued a 6.87 billion rupiah.
Total membership of the exchange is now nin brokers and 44 traders.

Food Department officials said the U.S. Department of Agriculture approved the Continental Grain Co sale of 52,50 tonnes of soft wheat at 89 U.S. Dlrs a tonne C and F from Pacific Northwest to Colombo.
They said the shipment wa for April 8 to 20 delivery.
Western Mining Corp Holdings Ltd <WNG.S> (WMC) said it will establish a new joint venture gold mine in the Northern Territory at a cost of about 21 mln dlrs.
The mine, to be known s the Goodall project, will be owned 60 pct by WMC and 40 pct by a local W.R. Grace and Co <GRA> unit.
It is lcated 30 kms east of the Adelaide River at Mt.
Bundey, WMC said in a statement It said the open-pit mne, with a conventional leach treatment plant, is expected to produce about 50,000 ounces of gold in its first year of production from mid-1988.
Annual ore caacity will be about 750,000 tonnes.
Sumitomo Bank Ltd <SUMI.T> is certain to lose its status as Japan's most profitable bank as a result of its merger with the eiwa Sogo Bank, financial analysts said.
Osaka-based Sumitomo, with desposits of around 23.9 trillion yen, merged with Heiwa Sogo, a small, struggling bank with an estimated 1.29 billion dlrs n unrecoverable loans, in October.
But despite the lnk-up, Sumitomo President Koh Komatsu told Reuters he is confident his bank can quickly regain its position.
"We'll be back n position in first place within three years," Komatsu said in an interview.

He said that while the merger wll initially reduce Sumitomo's profitability and efficiency, it will vastly expand Sumitomo's branch network in the Tokyo metropolitan area where it has been relatively weak.
But financial analysts re divided on whether and how quickly the gamble will pay off.
Some said Sumitomo may have paid oo much for Heiwa Sogo in view of the smaller bank's large debts.
Others argue the merger was more cst effective than creating a comparable branch network from scratch.
The anaysts agreed the bank was aggressive.
It has expanded overseas, entered the lucative securities business and geared up for domestic competition, but they questioned the wisdom of some of those moves.
"They've made bold moves to put everything i place.
Now it's largely out of their hands," sai Kleinwort Benson Ltd financial analyst Simon Smithson.

Among Sumitomo's problems are limits placed on its move to enter U.S. Securities business by taking a share in American investment bank Goldman, Sachs and Co. Sumitomo last August agreed to pay 500 mln dlrs for a 12.5 pct limited partnership in the bank, but for the time being at least, the Federal Reserve Board has forbidden them t exchange personnel, or increase the business they do with each other.
"The tie-up is widely looked on as a lame duck because the Fed was stricte than Sumitomo expected," said one analyst.
But Komatsu said the move will py off in time.
Regulations will change in the near futre and if so, we can do various things.
We only have to wait two or three years, not until the 21st centur," Komatsu said.
Komatsu is also willing to be patient about possible routes into the securities busines at home.
Article 65 of the Securities and Exchange Act, Japan's version of the U.S. Glass-teagall Act, separates commercial from investment banking.
But the walls between the two are crumbling and Komatsu said h hopes further deregulation will create new opportunities.
"We need to find new businss chances," Komatsu said.
"In some cases these will b securities related, in some cases trust bank related.
That's the kid of deregulation we want."

Until such changes occur, Sumitomo will focus on such domestic securities business as profitable government bond dealing and strengthening relations with Meiko Securities C Ltd, in which it holds a five pct share, Komatsu said.
He said Sumitomo is cautiously optimistic about entering the securities businss here through its Swiss universal bank subsidiary, Banca del Gottardo.

The Finance Ministry is expected to grant licences to securities subsidiaries of U.S. Commercial banks soon, following a similar decision fr subsidiaries of European universal banks in which the parent holds a less than 50 pct.
But Komatsu is reluctant to puh hard for a similar decision on a Gottardo subsidiary.
"We don't wat to make waves.
We expect this will be alowed in two or three years," he said.
Like other city banks, Sumitomo is also pushing to expand leding to individuals and small and medium businesses to replace disappearing demand from big business, he added.
The analysts said Sumitomo will have to devote a lot o time to digesting its most recent initiatives, including the merger with ailing Heiwa Sogo.
"It's (Sumitomo) been bold in is strategies," said Kleinwort's Smithson.
After that, it's a question of absorbing and juggling around.
It ill be the next decade before we see if the strategy is right or wrong."
Mines and Energy Minister Subroto confirmed Indonesian support for an extension of the sixth International Tin Agreement (ITA), but sai a new pact was not necessary.
Asked by Reuters to clarify his statement on Monday in which he said the pact should be allowed to lapse, Subroto said Indonesia was ready to back extension of th ITA.
"We can support extension of the sixth agreement," he said
"But a seventh accord we believe t be unnecessary."
The sixth ITA will expire at the end of June unless a two-thirds majority of members vote for an extension
egotiations between mining companies and the National Union of Mineworkers are foundering and mines could face a May Day work stoppage, the Chamber of Mines said.
t said the union had called off talks on a specific issue, the introduction of a Labour Day on May 1.
The nion refused a request to give advance notification of the names of workers who would be working on May 1 rather than taking the option of a paid holiday, the Chamber said.
t said mining companies wanted advance notice in order to plan their operations.
"The union is adamant only employees who wsh to work on Labour Day should notify management," the Chamber said.
"This raises the prospect that the mines will once again face stay-away action on May 1 and that the employees who o not work will once again forfeit pay."
It said the union accepted all the proposals except giving advane notification for May 1.
It said miners had been offered a full paid holiday on May 1 or a premium of six pct of their bsic monthly pay for working that day.
The coupon on the 75 mln dlr, 15-year, convertible eurobond for Atari Corp has been set at 5-1/4 pct compared with indicated range o five to 5-1/4 pct, lead manager Paine Webber International said.
The conversion price was set at 32-5/8 dlrs, representing a premium o 20.38 pct over yesterday's Atari share close of 27 dlrs.
Bangladesh is expected to draw up a 47 billion taka development plan for the 1987/88 fiscal year beginning July 1, Finance Ministry officals said.
This is a rise of si pct over the current year.
They said 86.5 pct of the funs would come from foreign sources.
Bangladesh will seek nearly two billion dlrs to be used for development projecs and imports in 1987/88 at a donors' meeting in Paris later this month, the officials said.
The Bundesbank accepted bids for 6.1 billion marks at today's tender for a 28-day securities repurchase pact at a fixed rate of 3.80 pct, a centra bank spokesman said.
Banks, which bid for a total 12.2 billion marks liquidity, will be credited with the funds allocated today and must buy back securities pledged on ay 6.
Some 14.9 billion marks will rain from the market today as an earlier pact expires, so the Bundesbank is effectively withdrawing a net 8.1 billion marks from the market with today's allocation.

A Bundesbank spokesman said in nswer to enquiries that the withdrawal of funds did not reflect a tightening of credit policy, but was to be seen in the context of plentiful liquidity in the banking system.
Banks held an average 59.3 billion marks at the Bundesbank over the firt six days of the month, well clear of the likely April minimum reserve requirement of 51 billion marks.
The Bundesbank spokesman noted that by bidding only 12.2 billion marks, below te outgoing 14.9 billion, banks themselves had shown they felt they had plenty of liquidity.

Dealers said the Bundesbank is keen to prevent too much liquidity accruing in the market, as that would blunt the effectiveness of the security repurchase agreemnt, its main open-market instrument for steering market interest rates.
Two further pacts are likely this monh over the next two weeks.
The Bundesbank is currently steering call money between 3.6 and 3.8 pct, althouh short-term fluctuations outside that range are possible, dealers said.
The U.N. Development program (UNDP will give Bangladesh a 6.79 mln dlr grant to undertake a detailed study on the building of a bridge over the River Jamuna, the official BSS news agency said.
It aid an agreement was signed here yesterday.
Communication Ministry officials said the bridge would be to link Dhaka with the northern areas of Bangladesh and was expected to cost bout 836 mln dlrs.
They said offer of help had been received from Saudi Arabia and the World Bank, but they gave no details.
he issue price of the European Investment Bank's 300 mln guilder 6.25 pct bullet bond due 1995, announced on April 1, has been set at par, lead manager Amro bank said.
ubscriptions remain open until 1300 gmt tomorrow, April 9.
ayment is due May 14 and coupon date is May 15.
Bond Corp Holdings Ltd <BNA.S> and Atlas Consolidated Mining and Development Corp <ATLC.MN> are still holding talks on a bail-out package for the troubled mining firm, an Atlas statement said.
Atlas, the Philippines' biggest cpper producer, said it had been hit by depressed world copper prices.
It reported a net loss of 976.38 mln pesos in the year ending December 1986, compared with a ne loss of 1.53 billion in 1985.
The company said it had been able to cut its losses because its scaled-down copper operations in the cental island of Cebu started in the second half of 1986.
Atlas said negotiations were continuing on the acquisition by Bond of the company's existing bank loans and their restructuing into a gold loan.
A memorandum of understanding signed by the two sides in October last year said Bond would acquire Atlas' total loans of 275 mln dlrs, to be repad by the mining company in gold.

Atlas said the two sides were also discussing equity infusion into Atlas and the creation of a development fund for further exploration and development of the compan's gold properties in the central province of Masbate.
ilson Banks, general manager of <Bond Corp International Ltd> in Hong Kong, told Reuters the Atlas statement on the negotiations was "reasonably accurate."
anks said Bond Corp was seriously considering several investments in the Philippines but did not give details.

n its statement, Atlas said development of the pre-World War Two underground mines in Masbate had been accelerated and the ore tonnage had increased, extending the operation's life at least until 1993.
Thailand's improving economy may have helped its trade and finance position but it has also created major problems for local banks, Thi and foreign bankers said.
They said a 900 mln dlr saving from cheaper imported oil and 19.7 pct export growth last year contributed to the country's first curret account surplus in 20 years.

But the bright picture, together with a government program to help farmers cope with depressed commodity prices, coinides with sluggish investment by a private sector still feeling the lingering effects of the 1984-86 recession.
Thai banks have had growing surplus funds and difficulties finding borrowers since the third quartr of 1986.
Kunthon Narkprom, head of the budget and planning division of Thai Farmers Bank Ltd, estimated excess liquidity in banks peaked last month at 60 billion baht, three times wha he considered normal.
Bank of Thailand figures show total deposits in 1986 grew 12.7 pct to 627.7 billion baht, while lending rose only 3.4 pct t 548.6 billion.
The lending/deposit ratio, which measures bank loans as a percentage of deposits, fel to 86.6 pct last month, the lowest since the 1970s, after averaging 96.6 pct in 1985.

Thai banks have cut lending and deposit rates a record six times since January 1986, during which time the average minimum loan rate fell t 11.5 pct from 15.5 and the gross one-year fixed deposit rate to 7.25 pct from 11.
Five banks announced last week they would cut their maximum lending rates t small borrowers by one percentage point to 14 pct.

Kunthon of Thai Farmers estimated banks now have a combined 80 billion baht unused overdraft line as many small and medium-size companies delay borrowing i anticipation of more cuts in interest rates.
The record liquidity has seriously hrt the profits of banks, which have been forced to invest idle funds in low-yield government securities.
Kunthon said the banks hold fur to 10 billion baht in short-term government bonds bought through the Bank of Thailand's bond repurchase facility, double the normal amount.
Thailand's 16 local commercial banks reistered one of their worst years in 1986, with overall profits falling over 30 pct after a 14 pct decline in 1985.
Kunthon said profits should increase 0 pct this year as the banks adjust to the new interest rate structure.

Olarn Chaipravat, senior executive vice president of Siam Commercial Bank Ltd, tld reporters last week the liquidity problem stems partly from the fact most loan demands come from businesses seeking funds for small, labour-intensive projects.
e said there are few large, capital-intensive projects and many borrowers go offshore to meet their requirements.

omboon Chinsavananond, Thai Farmers' fund management executive, said liquidity has been aggravated by the central bank's policy of fixing a stable baht-dollar exchange rate which permits Thai companies to import dollar-denominated funds with a minimal risk of currency exchange losses.
e said underlying bearishness towards the U.S. Dollar has encouraged foreign borrowers who hope to pay less on loan principal when their loans mature.

hai bankers said central bank governor Kamchorn Sathirakul last month rejected a request to increase a 10 pct withholding tax on interest on foreign loans, a measure they said would reduce foreign borrowings.
he governor replied the bankers should extend more loans to rural areas instead.
Bankers aid some Thai banks have offered credit-worthy clients loans at near money market rates of seven to eight pct in a bid to compete with foreign funds.
A arket analyst at Siam Commercial Bank said bank lending at such rates amount to about 15 pct of all loans extended by the industry.

A foreign anker, who requested anonymity, said the "segmented market approach" used by Thai banks for setting different lending rates has caused dislocation of funds in the financial sector, eroded bank profits and prevented banks from taking a more logical move of further cutting interest rates.
He aid the liquidity problem gives the Bank of Thailand a perfect opportunity to assert more control on the Thai money market.

The Bank of Thailand is taking "a step n the right direction" by planning to float three billion baht in bonds to mop up part of the surplus, he said, but he added the bank has been lax in using its bond repurchase window as a tool to absorb or inject liquidity into the market.
William Wu, head of he Treasury Unit of Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., Said the money market lacks the instruments to absorb liquidity and avoid sharp interest rate fluctuations.
He said the liquidity as fuelled the stock market's strongest rally in seven years and Thailand should seize the opportunity to develop the corporate bond market.
China's industrial output rose 14.1 pct in the first quarter of 197 against the same 1986 period, the People's Daily said.
Its overseas edition said the growth rate, which compares with a target of seven pct for the whole of 1987, was "rather high" bt the base in the first quarter of 1986 was on the low side.
Industrial output grew 4.4 pct i the first quarter of 1986.
It said China's industrial production this year has been normal but prduct quality and efficiency need further improvement.
It gave no further details
The Saitama Bank Ltd is issuing a 100 mln dlr convertible eurobond due March 31, 2002 paying an indicated two pct and priced at par, the bank's London offic said.

The non-callable bond is available in denominations of 1,00 and 10,000 Australian dlrs and will be listed in Luxembourg.

Major Japanese automakers are gearing up o equip sporty models with four-wheel steering, a feature that could become standard on high-grade cars in the future, automotive industry sources said.
Two companies are rady to market such cars soon, they said.
Honda Motor Co Ltd will sell ts Prelude with four-wheel steering from this Friday, and Mazda Motor Corp officials say a model with the new steering will be out by mid-year.
Mazda aims to ship the cars overseas before year-end but the decision will depend on initial conumer reaction.
Nissan Motor Co Ltd has offered a less sophisticated four-wheel steering system on its Skylie since August 1985.
Toyota Motor Corp has exhibited its developments in the field at a recent motor show and Mitsubishi Motors Corp said i will use the system in the near future.

Though major U.S. And European automakers have also researched and tested the four-wheel system, they say they are waiting to see consumer response to the Japanese cars and fo further improvements in safety and costs.
Four-wheel steering allows drivers to easily manoeuvre into parking spaces and gives more control o sharp turns.
Mazda officials believe the new steering will improe safety.
"At extremes, four-wheel stering gives a driver more control," said one official.
"On slippery surfaces r at high speeds, the system reduces unnecessary movement of the vehicle."
While acknowledging the added vehicle stability, a Hnda engineer said: "This invention is not intended to improve safety, but is aimed at allowing everyone to drive easily."
Mazda's electronic steering system tells the back weels to turn in the opposite direction from the front wheels at slow speeds but in the same direction at high speeds.
Honda's system, which is mechanical, is similar ut the direction of the rear wheels is determined by the angle of the front wheels.
With Nissan's system the rear wheels mov only parallel to the front.
Automakers say professional drivers who have tesed the four-wheel steering say it greatly improves handling.
An official with oe U.S.
Vehicle manufacturer said four-wheel steering is a technical improvement, but it is uncertain wheher it will translate into higher sales or profits.
"All automakers are interested in something new" he said.
"If it becomes a predominant factor, everyoe will want to follow."
The official said four-wheel steering i partly a gimmick to sell cars.
"It's a benefit of a seondary nature compared with devices for fuel economy or emission control."
General Motors Corp has developed a four-wheel steering system, but s unlikely to market it within the next five years, Y. Hojoh, engineer with the Japan branch of General Motors Overseas Corp, said.
GM must consider the costs t the consumer, he added.
The industry sources said the additional cost of the system in Japan would probably make little difference to the consumer as it would be aded to already high-priced models.
apan's Agriculture Ministry, angered by U.S.

Demands that Japan open its farm products arket, will tell U.S. Officials at talks later this month that liberalisation would harm existing U.S. Farm exports to Japan, a senior ministry official said.
"Imports from the .S. Would drop due to active sales drives by other suppliers," the official, who declined to be named, said.
"Japan is the largest customer for U.S. Farm products and it is not reasonable for the U.S. o demand Japan liberalise its farm import market," he said.
Agriculture Minister Mutsuki Kato has said if the US.
Insists Japan open its protected rice market it will also open its wheat market, where volume and orign are regulated to protect local farmers.
Australia and Canada could then increase their wheat exports as they are more competitive than the U.S., e said.
End-users would also buy other origins, grain traders said
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng, who is due to visit Japan for talks between Apri 16-27, has said he will ask Japan to offer a share of its rice market to U.S.
Suppliers and reove quotas on U.S.
Beef and cirus imports.
Other countries are already cuting into the U.S. Market share here.
Australia, the largest beef supplier to Japan, has ben trying to boost exports prior to the expiry of a four-year beef accord next March 31.

Imports of U.S. Corn have fallen due to increased sales from China and South America, while Japanese sobean imports from Brazil are expected to rise sharply this year, although the U.S. Will remain the largest supplier.
U.S. Feedgrain sales ill also drop if Japan opens up its beef imports, since Japan depends almost entirely on feedgrain imports, mainly from the U.S., Japanese officials said.
n indication of the U.S.
Position came last Dcember when Under Secretary of Agriculture Daniel Amstutz said Japan has the potential to provide one of the largest boosts to U.S.
Agricultural eports, with the beef market alone representing some one billion dlrs in new business.

The U.S. Has also asked the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to investigate the legality of Japanese import controls on 12 other farm products, including fruit juices, purees and pulp, tomato juice, ketchup and sauce, peanuts, prepared beef products an miscellaneous beans.
To help calm heated trade relations with the U.S., Japan's top business group Keidanren has urged the government to remove resiual import restrictions on agricultural products.
But Agriculture Minister Kato has ruled out any emotional reaction, and the senior ministry official said the farm issue should no become a scapegoat for trade pressure in the industrial sector.
"Japan is the largest buyer of U.S. Farm products, and these issues should not be discussed on the same table," th official said.

The Bank of England said it forecast a shortage of around 250 mln stg in te money market today.

Among the main factors affecting liquidity, bills maturing in official hands and the take-up of treasury bills will drain some 505 mln stg, while bills for repurchase by the market will remve around 194 mln.

South Korea's trade surplus is growing too fast and te government has started taking steps to slow it down, Deputy Prime Minister Kim Mahn-je said.

He told a press conference the government planned to increase investment, speed up the opening of the local market t foreign imports and gradually adjust its currency to hold the surplus "at a proper level."
But he said the government would not allow te won to appreciate too much in a short period of time.
South Korea has been uner pressure from Washington to revalue the won.
Wants South Korea to cut its trade surplus wih the U.S., Which rose to 7.4 billion dlrs in 1986 from 4.3 billion dlrs in 1985.

Kim, who is also economic planning minister, said prospects were bright for the South Korean economy, but te government would try to hold the current account surplus to around five billion dlrs a year for the next five years.
"Our government projections of eight pct GNP growth, five billion dlrs of (current account) surplus and 12 pct growth n exports all seemed to be reasonable early this year.
But ow the surplus is growing faster than we expected," he said.
Trade ministry officials said South Korea's exports ose 35 pct to 9.34 billion dlrs in the first three months of this year, while imports rose only 8.5 pct to 8.2 billion dlrs.
Kim said the swing of South Korea's current account to a surplus of 4.65 billion dlrs in 1986 from an 890 mln dlr deficit n 1985 was very significant.
The surplus enabled he country to reduce its foreign debt last year for the first time.
South Korea's foreign ebt, which fell to 44.5 billion dlrs in 1986 from 46.8 billion in 1985, is still among the largest in Asia.
This huge amount of our foreign debt has been one of the major constraints on our development... Last year was a major turning point for the Korean economy," Kim said.
im said his government plannned to reduce the ratio of foreign debt to the country's GNP to about 20 pct in 1991, from about 50 pct in 1986.
The government, however, does not want to accelerate reducing the debt by making an excessive trade surplus," he said.
im said a sudden rise in the surplus would cause inflation and lead to trade friction with Seoul's major trading partners, particularly the United States.
"We need a surplus because we have to reduce our debt, but we are taking measures to hold th size of the surplus at a proper level," Kim said.

Finland's national oil company Neste Oy <NEOY.HE> said in a sttement it had agreed with Canadian firms to study the feasibility of building a plant in Edmonton, Canada, to produce a replacement for lead in petrol.
The prospective plant would cost n estimated 270 mln Canadian dlrs and would produce methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) from raw materials available locally, it said.
The partners in the study re Neste Oy, Celanese Canada Inc, Hoechst Celanese Corporation and Trade Mountain Pipe Line Company Ltd, of Vancouver, B.C.

The Edmonton site was suitable because of the raw materials availability, the proximity to pipeline transportation and the important capital and operating advantages gained by locating on an existing Celanese Canada site, th statement said.
The partners would look into the feasibility of a plant producing 500,000 tonnes per annum of MTBE an octane enhancer that can replace tetra ethyl lead.
Most of the MTBE would be targeted for the United States where lead levels in gasoline ar being lowered because of health concerns, the statement added.
Canadian lead limits are currently 11 times as high as the U.S. Limit but lead is scheduled for virtual elimination in Canada by 1993, which should create a Canadian demand for MTBE, t said.
Finland's Neste Oy, whose turnover last yar was over five billion dlrs, has extensive experience with MTBE.
It has a mjor investment in an MTBE plant in Saudi Arabia.
The Edmonton, Alberta plant would be schduled to go on stream in late 1989, the statement said.
alks between employers and unions in the West German engineering industry over pay and working hours broke down without result late last night, an official from the IG-Metall union said.
G-Metall, Western Europe's largest union, is reviving its campaign for a 35-hour working week and is demanding a five pct pay increase.
trikes for a 35-hour week in 1984 brought West Germany's automobile industry virtually to a standstill.
he result of the 1984 campaign was a compromise reduction in working hours to 38.5 from 40.
The talks which broke down yesterday were n the key North Wuerttemberg/North Baden area, which generally sets the trend for the rest of the country.
IG-Metall official Ernst Eisenmann, speaking last night, bamed the failure of the negotiations on the employers.
He said they ad been uncompromising on the question of the shorter week.
Hans-Peter Stihl, negotiating for the employers, said ny plan to reduce working hours gradually to 35 hours was unacceptable.

The employers have not made an official offer on cutting the working week, but sources invlved in the negotiations say that they are working on the basis of a possible half-hour reduction from next year and a pay increase of 2.7 pct in 1987 and of 1.5 pct in 1988.
The Union will propose that the negotiations be officially declared a failure and the a process of arbitration is likely.
IG-Metall has said that cutting the working week will create jobs in West Gerany where more than two mln people are unemployed.
IG-Metall itself has abot 2.5 mln members.
IG-Metall has already been staging a series of "warning strikes" to press home demnds for the 35-hour week.
Yesterday, 23,000 engineering workers struck at 90 plants for one to two hours, accordng to an IG-Metall statement.
Among he strikers were 4,000 at a Daimler-Benz AG <DAIG.F> plant in Bremen, and 3,100 at Ford Motor Co's <F> Ford-Werke AG plant in Saarlouis.

ew orders for manufacturing industry goods have mostly fallen or stagnated in recent months, but data for February finally showed a reversal of the trend, with a 1.9 pct rise.

The South Korean tock market seems to be consolidating following government measures to cool its rapid rise this year, domestic and foreign analysts said.
The composite index hit a record 05.13 early last week, nearly 50 pct up from the New Year when it stood at 264.82, but plunged to a 383.48 close on April 3, the day after the government intervened.
Under the measures, industrial firms with bank loans worth 50 billion won or more must either offer new shares or issue convertible bonds t repay the loans.
Securities houses will have to sell shares they are holding if the volume excees 40 pct of their paid-in capital.
The ceiling for investment trust firms wa fixed at 50 pct.

South Korean firms have traditionally preferred obtaining low interest bank loans -- the current rate is 10 pct -- to issuing bonds at a higher rate o floating share issues with the attendant dividend pressures and launch expenses.
The Seoul Stock Exchange, with 355 listed stocks, grew explosively in the first three months of the year, building on an already impressive 68. pct gain in 1986.
Analysts now expect the market to pause temporarily and then resume its upwrd movement, despite the indirect government regulation.
They said the continuous growth of the nation's gross national product (GNP) ad trade surplus, improved exports and good performances by industrial firms all fuelled the boom.
The trade surplus widened to 460 mln dlrs in March from 110 mn in February, while government economists expect GNP to grow nine pct this year.
Analysts said the deep slump in the real estate market also increased liquidty in the stock market.
"Many investors are still confident the maret will not lose its strength.
It seems likely to pause for a while and then rebound again," said Park Sin-bom, a director of Lucky Securities Co. "There are more positve factors than negative.
The market is still buoyed by ample liquidity thanks to the economy's strog performance."
The stock market began to recover during Saturday's half-day session with the index closing at 397.24 in active trading on Monday, bu closed lower on Tuesday at 390.24 on turnover of 76 billion won.
"I would say the market is flat for th time being....
It is very prone to profit-taking after the sharp gains in the first three months and the variou government measures," a foreign analyst said.
"But the market will head up again after a rest because the fundamentals are expected to rise and investors will be a bullish as ever at the slightest sign of a market recovery."

He added that the newly launched 30 mln dlr Korea Europe Fund would have an impact on the South Korean stock market, despite its small volume compared with the 5.72 trillion won of listed capital on the Seoul exchage.

Citibank A/S <CCI.N>, the Norwegian subsidiary of the U.S.-based bank, said it made a net loss of just over six mln crowns in 1986 -- although foreign bankers said the expect it to show 1987 profits after two lean years.

Citibank's Oslo treasury head Bjoern Sejerstad told Reuters, Citibank, one of seven foreign bank subsidiaries operating in Norway, lost money because of restructuring for investment banking away from commercial baning and an economic slump in Norway following last year's plunge in oil prices.

The economic package unveiled yesterday by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) marks the start of a major shift away from the policies of the past, private economsts and government officials said.
"A big step forward has ben taken," said Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd senior economist Susumu Taketomi.

The package, seen as a response to mounting overseas pressure o boost the sagging Japanese economy, calls for a supplementary budget of more than 5,000 billion yen later this year, plus increased imports.

Although the measures must still gain the approval of the Fnance Ministry, economists said the government will find it too difficult to alter the measures significantly once they have gained domestic and overseas backing.
"At last, the LDP and he Ministry of Finance are turning a corner," said Sumitomo Bank Ltd's chief economist Masahiko Koido.
For the past five years the govrnment has adhered to a tight fiscal policy in its drive to stop issuing deficit financing bonds in 1990.
To meet that goal, spending departments re required to submit annual budgets for current expenditure 10 pct below the previous year and investment five pct below.

Masayoshi Ito, chairman of the LDP's policy affairs council, said yesterday the govrnment must stick to its 1990 fiscal reform target, but should review the ceiling it places on public works spending.
Even some Finance Ministry officials privately ackowledge that policy changes might be needed, including easing the government's iron grip on spending.

Economists said the government could meet ts 1990 target and also increase spending by using money it got from the sale of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp shares and by taking advantage of lower than expected interest rates on its debt.
Officially, the Finance Mnistry is adhering to its tight stance but some signs of change have appeared.
"We do not ave any intention of abandoning our objective to restore fiscal balance," a Finance Ministry spokesman said.
He aid so far the ministry had tried to achieve two goals simultaneously.
These ere reforming the government's fiscal position and stimulating domestic demand.

But the Finance Ministry spokesman added, In looking at the current situation of the economy and the relationship between Japan and the United States, we feel we have to place more emphasis on stimulating demand."
Economists predict battles within the government over the coming months as the Finance Ministry fights to ensure the cracks in its policy do not lead to a complete breakdown of fisca discipline.
"The Ministry is afraid that once there is a small hole in the dike, it will lead to a flood," Industrial Bank's Taketom said.
But Taketomi said the ministry, provided it has a device in place to check excess spending for political reasons, is likely to giv the go-ahead to a shift in policy.
"This seems to mark the first step toward a more active fiscal policy in response to requests from the international community," he said

Sumitomo's Koido said if the government quickly implements the LDP's 5,000 billion yen package, economic growth in the 1987/88 year ending next March 31 could be around three pct, Hs current forecast of 2.2 pct growth assumes a supplementary budget of around 1,000 billion yen.

The five-nation <International Aero Engine> (IAE) consortium has decided not to go ahed with the proposed launch of its Superfan engine, a spokesman for consortium member <Rolls-Royce Plc> said.

Japan and Britain ave signed a memorandum on exchange of securities market information to protect investors and promote the integrity of securities markets, Finance Ministry officials said.

As interaction between Japanese and U.K. Securities market grows, it is desirable for both countries to exchange supervisory and investigatory information to assist each other in securing compliance with their statutes, rules and requirements, the memorandum said.

Deputy prime minister Kim Mhn-je said South Korea is studying various measures to reform what he described as its underdeveloped bank and financial sector.
Kim, ho is also economic planning minister, told a news conference the country's banks and finance houses had not developed to keep pace with their industrial counterparts.
He aid two major factors had hampered the development of the financial sector -- high inflation and heavy government intervention in bank decision-making.
He aid in the past the government had pressed banks to give soft loans to industry to boost economic growth.
im said the government would now give top priority to interest rate liberalisation.
his could be achieved within several years, though not within one year.
e said liberalisation was possible because South Korea's current account had turned from a deficit to a surplus, which had brought in foreign funds and increased domestic savings.
he current account recorded a surplus of 4.65 billion dlrs in 1986 after a deficit of 890 mln dlrs in 1985.
ut Kim said the government needed to reorganise much of the financial sector.
im said mergers of some financial companies and the upgrading of others to merchant banks or full banks were being considered by the financial development committee of the finance ministry.
e did not elaborate but said he expected no drastic measures to be announced this year.

On liberalisation of the country's stock market, Kim said despite Seoul's determination to open it up, free investments there by foreigners would not be allowed in the near futre because the market was currently "over-heated."
He said this was due to ample liquidity created partly by the country's current accunt surplus.
Kim said the market was extremely vulnerable to a sudden influx of foreign funds becuse it was still very small in terms of size and numbers of shareholders.
"Opening up the capital market must wait until the vulnerability to such an influx i removed," he said.
He said only about one mln South Koreans, out of a population of 40 mln, invest i the Seoul market.
A top U.S. Official said Japan has little chance of convincing the U.S. To drop threatened trad sanctions, despite the efforts of a Japanese team that left for Washington today.

Michael Armacost, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, was asked at a press conference whether Japan's moves to boost its domestic economy and open its markets could persuade the U.S. Not to imose tariffs on Japanese imports said, and replied: "...It is probably too early for the figures to demonstrate that the situation has turned around and to permit the result you have described."
Armacost said the U.S. Hopes Japan will take stps to lift its domestic economy and reduce dependence on exports, remove barriers to imports and settle outstanding trade issues.

"There are obvious problems at the moment in the trade area, but we do not wish thse problems to divert attention from important areas of cooperation that continue to exist on security and political issues," he said.

"The question is whether through cooperative actions between or governments we can reduce the (trade) imbalance or whether Congress takes action to reduce it through protectionist legislation," he said.

The ministries of Finance and Justice said they have presented parliment with a new law to make insider trading in shares a criminal offence.

A year ago, the Amsterdam Bourse announced its own rules, effective from January 1, 1987, aimed at preventing unfair use of inide information in the trading shares listed on the exchange, but said back-up legislation was essential.

The proposed law calls for up to two years imprisonment, fines of up to 100,000 guilders for an individual and one million guilders for a company, and repayment to the state of profits made fro insider dealing.
The proposed fines are higher than any currently in force in Dutch law, a joint statement from th two ministries said.
The draft law sets no limit to the illegal profits to be repaid
The amount would be determined b a court.
A Finance Ministry spokesman said the time-frame for the introduction of the new legislation depended entirely on it reception in Parliament.

In the meantime the Bourse's Share Trading Association monitors business closely, frequently suspending or even rescinding dealings in a stock whn price movements suggest that foreknowledge of a pending announcement is being exploited.

He did not disclose the offerd price.

Diaz said New York investment bank Allen and Co Inc had earlier said it was interested in buying all 38.1 mln sequestere shares.
He told Reuters last month Elders IXL Ltd <ELXA.S>, the Melbourne-based brewing company, had also bi for the "B" shares.

The Hong Kong Economic Journal last month quoted a spokesman of Australian stock broker Jacksons Ltd as saying that <Barwon Farmlands Ltd>, an Australian firm owned 30 pct by <Ariadne Australia Ltd>, was planning a Filipino branch in order to buy the entire blok of 38.1 mln shares.
Anheuser-Busch last year made a 150 mln dlr bid to buy <San Mguel Brewery Ltd>, a Hong Kong listed company which is 69.65 pct owned by <Neptunia Corp Ltd>, a San Miguel Corp subsidiary.
The talks broke down last June ater the two sides said they could not agree on the terms of the sale.
he People's Construction Bank of China is launching its first international borrowing by mandating four foreign banks for a 150 mln U.S. Dlr loan, one of the lead managers Banque Indosuez said.
he other three lead managers are Bank of Tokyo, Citicorp International Ltd and the Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd.
he 10 year loan has a 4-1/2 year grace period.
nterest is set at 1/8 percentage point over London interbank offered rate for the first eight years, rising to 1/4 pct for the remaining two years.
There is a 3/16 pct management fee and an unspecified, but very small, commitment ee.
Syndication f the loan is expected to start soon and it should be signed in Shanghai next month.
The onstruction Bank, which is one of four specialist banks in China, focuses on infrastructure and heavy industrial projects.
he funds raised will partly finance two ethylene factories near Shanghai.
Construction f the plants, which are a major item in the current five year plan, will begin soon.
he plants will cost more than 300 mln dlrs.
he remainder of the funds will come from export credits and domestic borrowings.
Australian markets are booming as foreign fund managers redirect capital away from the United States and other traditional markets, anaysts said.

High short-term interest rates, a bullish stock market and an increasingly stable currency reflect a massiv inflow of fresh funds in the last two months, largely from Japanese and U.S. Investors, analysts polled by Reuters said.
Fund managers want quality markets to park their cash in and have settled on Australia, Britain and Canada as they diversify from volatile U.S. Dollar instruments, tey said.
A one percentage point fall in key 10-year bonds rates in the past month, record share prices and a 10-month high for the currency of 0.71 U.S Dlrs all illustrated the inflow.
Official figure on the latest inflow of investment capital are not available, but brokers said they received almost daily inquiries from Japan and the United States.
"These eople have got trillions of dollars sloshing about and they don't know what to do with it.
Some f that is ending up here with the attraction of high interest rates and reasonable currency stability," National Australia Bank Ltd economist Brian Hamley said.
There is a 'flight to quality'," Hamley said.
"Australia ay not be in the best (economic) position, but there aren't too many other countries where you'd want to put your money."
The stronger Australian dollar was also attracting investors taking advantage of an appreciating currency against the volatility of th U.S. Unit, analysts said.
"We're looking a more favoured market than perhaps th U.S. Where some people would be concerned about the value of the U.S. Dollar," Lloyds Bank NZA Ltd chief economist Will Buttrose said.
"Why not put the mone in Australia where entry is cheap and the currency looks stable?"
But turning that capital ito more permanent productive investment depends on government economic policy, he said.

"It will only disappear if people lose confidence in th direction in the economy," Buttrose said, adding that offshore investors would carefully watch the government's promised tough economic statement on May 14.

While happy to invest in bonds and other vehicles yielding interest unobtainable elsewhere, fund managers could just as easily reverse the flow -- particularly the Japanese, who were badly hurt in the past by rapid falls in the Australian dollar and hfty jumps in bond rates, analysts said.
"It will remain very edgy money
If something was not to be delivered, if the statement wasn't considered tough enough, one might see a substantial outflow," Butrose said.
Offshore investors are eager to see Australia take tough economic decisions to curb its 100 billion dlr foreign debt and stubborn current account deficit, analysts said
"They are giving us the benefit of the doubt and I think they would like to leav the money here," Buttrose said.
Reserve Bank policy has also reflected the increased interest in investment in Australia and the need o shield Japanese investors from rapid currency fluctuations.

Reserve Governor Bob Johnston last week acknowledged an element of targeting the rate against the yen in currency policy when he said authorities could not take their "eyes off the yen" because of th crucial role of Japanese investors.
Analysts said they believed the Reserve Bank had worked successfully in recent months to keep the Australian dollar within the range f 100 to 103 yen.
Apart from its recovery against a weak U.S. Dollar, the Australian dollar has also risen almost three pct on a trade-weighted basis in the last three weeks
Offshore buying has also played a role in the booming Astralian share market.
It has followed Wall Street an other markets, but is also setting its own trend in response to the weight of both domestic and offshore funds pouring into equities, particularly in the gold sector.
The key all ordinaries index ose to a record 1,758.3 today, nearly 20 pct above its level at the end of 1986, while the gold index has nearly doubled to a record 3,081.0 in the same period.

The property sector is also sought after, with Japanese companies that have invsted heavily in the United States in recent years turning their attention to undervalued real estate, particularly in the tourism field.
Analysts pointed to the recent sale of Sydney's five-star Regent Hotel to Japanese interests for more than 145 mln drs as indicative of the type of property being sought.
"They think they find good value real estate here which, with long term and fixed capital investment, is the knd of investment Australia needs," Buttrose added.
Kuwait's il-reliant and debt-ridden economy has started to pull out of a nosedive but oil prices will determine the pace of recovery, bankers and economists say.
Crucial will be the ability of the 13-member OPEC to hold oil prices around a new benchmark of 18 dlrs a barrel in the northern hemisphere summer hen demand usually slackens.
Bankers stimate the economy, measured in terms of gross domestic product (gdp), shrank 19 pct in real terms last year after contracting 8.1 pct the year before.
This as after taking into account inflation in consumer prices of 1.5 pct in 1985, slowing to 1.0 pct in 1986.

Factors depressing economic activity include the 6-1/2-year-old Iran-Iraq war o Kuwait's doorstep, which threatens the emirate's vital oil export lifeline through the Gulf and has sapped business confidence.

But sentiment received a much-needed boost in September when, after a series of piecemeal steps to combat a det crisis caused by the 1982 crash of local stock market, a comprehensive new debt settlement program was introduced.
The share crash, result of a speculative spree in foward trading, left 95 billion dlrs of post-dated cheques in default.
The cheques were also used as collateral for consumer spening, thus generating an informal credit system.
Much of the debt has been watered down but big sums are still owe by individuals and companies.
There was some 4.4 billion dinars (about 15.7 billion dlrs) in outstanding bank credit at the end of 1986, of which one-quarter to one-third was estimated b bankers to rank as bad or doubtful debt.
But the government has repeatedly said i will not allow any banks to go under.
The new debt settlement scheme entails a rescheduling of problem credit over 10 t 15 years, depending on whether debtors have regular cash flows or not.

Banks' shareholders and depositors will have their rights guaranteed by the government -- an edict of vital significance in a country of only 1.7 mln people whee the financial sector is the biggest after oil.
Kuwait is better placed than any other OPEC country to ride out the ol glut, bankers and economists say.
Kuwait has an OPEC quota of 948,000 barrels per day (bpd) compared with production capacity of 4.0 mln bpd mentioned last yar by Oil Minister Sheikh Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah.

But strategic diversification into downstream operations in Europe several years ago an a hefty refining investment at home gives it guaranteed markets abroad and enables it to sell over one-half of its output as high-grade refined oil products.
Oil industry sources say Kuwait is able to get an average 200 dlrs a barrel more by selling oil in the form of processed product such as gas oil, kerosene and naphtha, rather than as crude.
Bankers say the rebound in oil prices is the major reaso for cautious optimism.
Other reasons are low domestic inflation, a bottoming out of the fall in imports in recent years and signs government spending on productive sectors ill remain steady.
External accounts are in good shape, with an estimated 1.8 billion dinar current account surplus in 1986, 16 pct below that for 1985, but still an achievement n the recession-hit Gulf.
Kuwait's petrodollar reserves in mid-1986 were put offcially at over 80 billion dlrs, earning investment income of the equivalent of about 3.65 billion dlrs a year.
But for the first time since the end of the oil boom, these reserves ay not be enough to prevent a "real" budget deficit for the 1986/87 fiscal year ending June 30, bankers say.
In a budget portrayed by bankers as mldly contractionary, revenues for 1986/87 were cut 38.6 pct and spending 11 pct, doubling the nominal deficit to 1.33 billion dinars.
This left out income from state reserves, uually excluded in official budget accounting, which are forecast by bankers at up to 1.0 billion dinars in 1986/87, resulting in some shortfall.
Bankers say it is too early to vnture a forecast for economic growth this year or next.
"It depends on oil rices," one said.
"Thi summer is important."
Cabinet Affairs Minister Rashid al-Rashid said last Sunday the cabinet has ratified recommendations to rationalise state spending in favor of productive sectors and reactivate the economy.
He gave no details but bankers say these are expected to be spelled out in the 1987/88 budget, ossibly in June.
Malaysia is unlikely to meet its targeted output of five mln tonnes of oil pal in calendar 1987, oil palm growers told Reuters.
Output in 1987 is expected to reach around 4.5 mln tonnes, unchanged from 1986, becuse of drought, low use of fertiliser and overstressed palms, they said.
The growers were asked for their reaction to an Oil World newsletter report that Malaysi's oil palm output is likely to drop sharply this year.

Palm oil now sells at around 700 ringgit a tonne, or about 115 ringgit less than soybean oil, but Malaysia must sell more palm oil to prevent a stock buidup that could damage the industry, a leading grower told Reuters.
The country's palm oil stocks no total some 500,000 tonnes against about 800,000 last March, the growers said.
The growers expect palm oil price to ease later this year due to pressure from South American and U.S.
The current South American oilseed harvest, mainly soybean, is likely to be around 25.7 mln tonnes against the previous 21.7 ml tonne crop, they said.
In adition, new U.S.
Soybean plantings are also expected o enter the market around November when Malaysian palm oil output peaks.

They said new planting of palms is also likely to slow, with some 50,000 hectares expected to be planted with new trees against 100,000 in 198, although the effects of this reduction will not be felt for about another three years.

Elders IXL Ltd <ELXA.S> plans to float off the around 5,000 public houses belonging to its U.K. Subsidiary Courage Ltd to raise about one billion tg, Elders strategy executive director Stuart Kelso said.
he scheme, subject of speculation in a Scottish newspaper yesterday, was fairly well advanced, but not certain to go ahead.
"There could be road blocks," he dded.
The earliest flotation date would be June, though the sale will probably e later.
Elders would retain a one-third interest in the property interests under the curren plan.
o immediate use has been earmarked for the funds raised.

Elders bought Courage from Hanson Trust Plc <HNSN.L> last year for 1.4 mln sg.
The deal followed Elders unsuccessful efforts to expand into the U.K.
Drinks industry by acquiring Allied-Lyons Plc <ALD.L>.
Hanson acquired Courage wen it took over Imperial Group Plc early last year.
The Elders plan to raise funds from Courage is a variant of the ts earlier scheme to sell off 50 pct stakes in the Allied-Lyons pubs to their publicans, market sources added.

Freeport McMoran Inc <FTX.N>, a New York listed New Orleans-based natural resource, oil and gas company, is planning to build and run a surface sulphur mine in the central Philippnes, a company statement said.
It said Freeport officials were in the Philippines to discuss contractual arrangements with joint venure partner <International Consultex (Philippines) Inc>.

The statement quoted Robert Foster, president of Freeport Sulphur Co, as saying the company was optimistic about the proposed mine at Pamplona in Negros Oriental province, as well as te country's investment climate.

"We anticipate that the project may employ as many as 1,000 workers in Negros Orental."

The statement said Freeport, which anticipates 1987 sales of 1.5 billion dlrs, is a major producer of sulphur, phosphate and nitrogen fertilisers, uranium oxide and eo-thermal energy.
A Bank of Japan spokesman declined to comment on a press report that the central bank had decided to conduct closer scrutiny of the operations of financial institutions i the bond market.

JIJI quoted the sources as saying that current bond market yields are similar to short-trm interest rates due to excessive speculative operations.

This was attributable to heavy redemptions of government bonds and unclear prospects for the dollar, which has sent many foreign bond market participants to the domestic market, the souces were quoted as saying.

Diversified building materials group Monier Ltd <MNRA.S> said talks are taking place which may lead to Britain's Redland Plc <RDLD.L> making an offer for the Monier shares it does not already hold, chairman Bill Lock said.
Redland already holds about 49 pct of Monier's 156.28 mln issued shares, he said in a brief notice to the Australian Stock Exchange

Monier shares were trading at a 1987 high of 3.10 dlrs today, up from the previous peak of 2.80 at yesterday's close, and well above the 1987 lo of 2.18 dlrs.

Isuzu Motor Ltd <ISUM.T> will pay no dividend for the first half year ending April 30, 1987, as the company is expected to mark a 12 billion yen parent company current loss in the first half du to slow exports caused by the yen's appreciation, a company spokesman said.
