he sources said it would aim to carry a large part of Kenya's coffee and tea exports and oil and fertiliser imports.

U.S. and U.K. bank regulators are asking banks to set aside more reserves than is necessary to cushion them against the risks posed by the interest rate and currency swap transacions they carry, swap dealers said.

After viewing proposed guidelines released jointly today by the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve Board, dealers said that in effect, regulators are asking them to set aside reserves twie for the same risk.
Market participants will have 60 days to resond to the proposals.

Adoption of stiffer capital requirements is especially significant in the eurobond markets, which saw new isse volume of about 183 billion dlrs in 1986 according to figures compiled by Euromoney magazine.
While no firm figures exist, dealers n eurobonds estimate that 80 pct of all new issues are involved in some swap arrangement.
Separately, the ISDA estmates that about 300 billion dlrs worth of swap transactions are outstanding.

Kenneth McCormick, co-chairman of the International Sap Dealers Association (ISDA) and President of Kleinwort Benson Cross Financing Inc, said that the Association has no comment and will study the proposals.
"What they are proposing is really duble counting," Patrick de Saint-Aignan, managing director of swaps for Morgan Stanley and Co, said.

Instead, he argues, banks should either be required to hold a percentage of he face value -- say one pct per year to maturity -- or to hold a percentage of the cost of replacing the contract in the event of a counterparty default.
"The potential risk factors are very large relative to wht we had expected," said a director at one U.K. merchant bank.
"What they are really doing is asking you to capialize now -- to borrow money now -- to cushion you against risk you might have 10 years from now," he added.
(Adds title fist paragraph).
Dealers also said they believe that banks not covered by the agreement, such as those based in Japan, will ave a competitive advantage because they will not have to pass the costs on to customers.
Indeed, regulators re apparently also concerned about the exclusion of other countries from the new requirements.

Federal Reserve Board Governor artha Seger, following approval of the proposed guidelines by the Fed, said she is concerned that Japan was not involved in the U.K.-U.S. effort to draft new capital rules.

Dealers said they were smewhat relieved to see that bank regulators recognized the concept of netting, that is, offsetting the amounts receiveable from and payable to a single counterparty against each other.
The paper aid that regulatory authorities "recognize that such arrangements (netting) may in certain circumstances reduce credit risk."
Furthermore, the paper said, if a netting agreement could be reached that would withstand legal tests, it might be willing to reduce capital requirements acordingly.
But dealers aid they fear regulators may insist on an airtight netting agreement that is impossible to design.
"One problem is that there has never been a major default in he swaps market.
So we on't know if any of the swap arrangements will really stand up in court," said one bank official.
Former White House spokesman Larry Speakes said he and President Reagan misled the public unintentionally on the Iran arms scanal because they themselves were misled by others.

In a televise interview, Speakes was contrasting the defensive, much-criticized efforts Reagan made in early attempts to cool the scandal with the dynamic speech he expected when the president addressed the nation tonight.
"When we went into those press conferences and that nationwide address in November right after the (Iran) story broke, th president did not have the proper information," Speakes said.
"And tat's why we were misled.
And consequently, the preident and I misled the public, to a certain extent."
"We were badly served by the pople that were involved in the Iranian crisis and running the show."
Asked whom he meant, Speakes said frmer National Security Adviser Robert McFarlane; McFarlane successor John Poindexter; and then-National Security Council aide Oliver North.

Speakes said those three had prepared a false chronology of events "that misled us ito thinking that we had all the facts ..." McFarlane has said that he, North and Poindexter had doctored a White House chronology to obscure and minimize Reagan's role in the arms sales.
He said they did tat as part of an effort to prepare the president for a November 19 news conference.

The Canadian government's reduced borrowing needs enabled the Bank f Canada to make "aggressive use" of short term debt instruments and pare the cost of financing in 1986, the central bank said in its annual report.

The report, authored by retired governor Gerald Bouey, also noted advances to Canadian banks fell to under one billion dlrs at the ed of the year from more than four billion dlrs in January, 1986, and that the country's economy performed unevenly while inflation remained a major concern.

Bouey said the bank was able to reduce the number of new bond issues with maturities of 10 years of more, lessen te reliance on Canada Savings Bonds while raising substantailly more through short term treasury bill financings.

"The aggressive use of the treasury bill program has meant that the government is now able to maintain lower cash balances and loer financing costs," said Bouey who was replaced by deputy governor John Crow last month.
The amount of treasury bills outstanding at year end was 69.7 billion dlrs, an increase of 10.3 billion dlrs over the yer and 20 billion dlrs since 1984.

The reduction in borrrowing needs was brought about by an eight billion dlr decline in the government's financing requiremens, a run down in Ottawa's cash balances, and generation of 2.3 billion dlrs from foreign exchange transactions.
Also in pursuit of shorter term financing, the bank made greater use of bond auctions to market new issues with two t five year maturities, Bouey said.

Bouey said payments to chartered banks, which are made to banks that are facing liquidity problems, dropped to a average of 832.3 mln dlrs at end of December from a peak of 5.2 billion dlrs in March, 1986.
The advances were made largely to four banks, Canadian Commercial Bank, Northland Bank, Continental Bank of Canaa and the Bank of British Columbia.
The first two banks have been liquidated, which enabled partial repayment of advances, and the remaining tw banks were sold and the new owners repaid the advances.

Chicago Mercantile Exchange, CME, directors have postponed action on a membership petition calling for a ban on dual trading, CME Chairman Jack Sandner tod Reuters.

Consideration of the petition was scheduled for a regular board meeting today, but directors first wanted the opinions of a special committee that ha been studying trading conditions in the Standard and Poor's 500 futures pit for the last six months.
"We didn't want to preempt th committee," Sandner said.
Instead, Sandner said the board will wait for the findings of the special S and P committee, which is considering some type o restriction on dual trading in S and P 500 futures.
Dual trading is the legal practice in which an exchange member can execute customer orders as well as trade for hi own account.
Critics maintain the practice provides an opportunity for traders to "front-run" or trade their own accounts at more favorable prices befor customer orders are executed.
Sandner said he expects the special committee to report its findings late next week and the board to act when thse findings are presented.

In response to reports that the CME board is opposed to a ban on dual trading, Sandner pointed out tht the board already unanimously approved a partial ban on dual trading in S and P 500 futures at a prior meeting.
The change was withheld, however, at the request o the special committee after a study was released and the committee felt the issue should be addressed more comprehensively, Sandner said.
Sandner said that he personally had no aversion t a ban on dual trading and "the leadership (of the CME) is not opposed to a ban on dual trading."
Last week, CME special counsel Leo Melamed said te special study committee is considering changes only for S and P 500 futures and options on futures.

In addition to the dual trading issue, the comittee is also expected to make recommendations on the possibility for electronic order entry and execution for S and P 500 futures and rule changes to alleviate crowded conditions in the S and P trading pit, Melamed said.
Melamed said at the tme that in matters where a special committee is appointed, recommendations from the committee are usually approved by the exchange board of directors.
Prospects for renewal of the fie-year U.S./USSR grains agreement are uncertain at this point, a Soviet trade official told Reuters.

The current trade imbalance between the United States and the Soviet Uion, high U.S. commodity prices, and increased world grain production make a renewal of the supply agreement next year less certain, Albert Melnikov, deputy trade representative of the Soviet Union, said in an interview.
The current agreement epires on Sept 30, 1988.
Melnikov said that world grain markets are diferent than when the first agreement was signed in 1975.
Statements from oth U.S. and Soviet officials have indicate that a long term grains agreement might not be as attractive for both sides as it once was.
We have had one agreement.
We have ad a second agreement, but with the second agreement we've had difficulties with prices," Melnikov said.
"I annot give you any forecasts in response to the future about the agreement....
I do ot want to speculate on what will happen after Sept 30, 1988," he said.
Melnikov noted hat he has seen no indications from Soviet government officials that they would be pushing for a renewal of the agreement.
"The situation is different in comparison to tree, five or ten years ago ... We can produce more," he said.

Chrysler will also help retrain the plant's workfore.

When the plant reopens in July, Chrysler workers will have completed more than five mln classrom and on-the-job hours in retraining, th company said.
The July restart will be on a single-shift basi.
Second-shift production will start ths fall.

President Reagan, fighting to recover politically from the Iran-contra scandal, plans to acknowledge in a critical speech to the nation tonight he needs to change his ways, administratio officials said.
"It will be a forward-looking speech in wich he will say he accepts the need for change," said an official who asked not to be identified.
"I think the president wants to give his side of th story."
The official said Reagan would tell the public what he is doing to set things right in the wake of lat week's scorching Tower commission report on the origins of the scandal.
It is not clear whether Reagan will heed the advice of many of his political allies and acknowledge that his Iran polic was wrong and he personally made some mistakes.

Asked at his daily news briefing if the president would say he erred, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters, "His views are intensely personal and I won't give you any advance on what he intends to sa in that area."
He said the speech would be 12 or 13 minutes in lengh and that Reagan would "look beyond the horizon to a revitalized White House that will pursue an active foreign policy."
"The president will discuss the Tower board report an its recommendations.
He'll focus on changes he's making in the structure of the NSC (National Security Council) and hi goals for the next two years," the spokesman said.
To date, Reagan has defended his decision to sell arms to Iran and conceded only there wre errors in implementation.
Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said tonight's speech might be Reagan's last chance to repair his presideny.
"It's about the ninth ining ... he has to try and set us on another course.
It's hard to do tat, he probably won't be able to do it," Dole told reporters.

The former chairman of Peoples National Bank of Rockand County, N.Y., pleaded guilty to charges of bribery and income tax evasion.

Congressmen from eef producing states and representatives of the U.S. livestock industry urged the Reagan administration to press Japan and South Korea to open up their markets to imports of beef.
Testifying at a House subcommittee hearing o livestock issues, Rep. Hal Daub (R-Nebr.
), said the administration should push hard for greater beef imports by Japan ad South Korea.
Daub was joined b several other lawmakers.
U.S. assistant trade representative Suzanne Earley, replied "we're not going to let Japan off the hook, or Kore."

She noted trade representative Clayton Yeutter met with a senior Korean official last week on the beef issue, and that Yeutter and Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng will visit Tokyo in April for discussions on farm trad issues.
Japan maintains a quota on beef imports, set at 58,400 tonns high quality beef in fiscal 1987.
South Korea has banned beef imports but there are indications Seoul may bow to U.S. pressure and allo some imports soon, industry officials said.

In testimony today, Tom Cook, director of industry affairs for the National Cattlemens Association said "the Congress, administration and the industry must take a strong, tough and united stand to impress the Japanese that we mean business and that we expect them o open their markets."

Under the 1985 farm bill, the Agriculture Secretary can lower the U.S. milk price support to 10.60 dlrs per cwt frm the current 11.35 dlrs if government purchases of dairy products are forecast to exceed five billion lbs in 1988.

Whether the Soviet Union will fulfill its buying obligations under the U.S./USSR grains agreement depends entirely on th United States, a Soviet trade official told Reuters.
"How can I tell that we are ready to fulfill the agreement if the United States does no want to offer us grain at competitive prices?"
said Albert Melnikov, dputy trade representative of the Soviet Union to the United States.
"We are in the market for grains, ut it is up to the United States to be the seller ... to offer Soviets competitive prices," he said in an interview.
Melnikov said that the United States has ot lived up the agreement by failing to make available to Moscow U.S. grain at prevailing market prices.
"We are being acused of not implementing this agreement.
We do not conider we are at fault," Melnikov said.

Article I in he agreement states that "purchases/sales of commodities under this Agreement will be made at the market price prevailing for these products at the time of purchase/sale and in accordance with normal commercial terms."
"The United States should supply to the Soviet Union definite quantities o grain at competitive prices ... Is the United States ready to supply this?"

The Soviet official said that near-term corn demand has been met by the recent Soviet purchases of U.S. corn, which he confirmed at 15 mln tonnes, but said that if U.S. corn prices remain competitive, the Soviets will buy more if they need it.
Wheat buying, however, is a diffeent story, Melnikov said.
"If the United States is interested in selling its wheat, then they must offer competitive prices, and it's up to te United States to decide how these competitive prices will be offered," he said.
Last year's U.S. offer of subsidized wheat to the Soviets ws rejected because of an insufficient subsidy, Melnikov said.
He said that at the time of the 13 dlr pr tonne subsidy offer, U.S. wheat prices were 26 dlrs over world levels.

Key tax and budget lawmakers Wednesday expressed reservations about the suggested new securiies tax, which has has aroused concern on Wall Street and put pressure on brokerage stocks.

Grappling with the need to either raise taxes or cut federal spending to meet the fiscal 1988 budget deficit target of 108 billion dlrs, House Speker Jim Wright suggested the tax be studied as one way to raise more federal revenues.
The Texas Democrat's idea as first presented to House Ways and Means Commitee chairman Dan Rostenkowski this week would tax sales and purchases of securities.
A tax of 0.25 to 0.5 percent would raise from 8.5 t 17 billion dlrs a year.

Rostenkowski, the chief taxwriter, considers it too early to back any tax increase idea but agreed to add the securities transfer tax t a long list of tax alternatives under review by congressional tax analysts, a spokesman said.
The Illinois Democrat has repeatedly stressed this year he is reluctant t back a tax increase so long as President Reagan maintains his staunch opposition.
"First we've got to decide whther to raise additional revenues.
Only then ca we consider the specific options.
At this point nothing is on or off the tabl.
It's just to early," Rostenkowski said in a statement.
He made no commitment to Wright in a private meeting Tuesdy, and in fact was not asked for one, a House source said.
The idea was presented only as something that might or miht not be valuable, he said.
House Budget Committee chairman William Gray agreed it was another opion to be looked at, if Congress decided it needed to raise revenues to reduce the deficit, an aide said.
The Pennsylvania Democrat does not inend to recommend specific tax proposals, the aide said.
The Budget Committee will recommend a certain amount of revenue t be raised in 1988, but will leave to the taxwriting committee the decision on how the taxes will be raised.
The securities transfer tax would raise a hefty amount of revenue to ease Congress's difficult task of trimming the deficit by 61 billion dlrs this year to met the target.
But some in Congress feared that such a tax could drive securities business offshore and hurt U.S. investment, and there were uncertainties about the details of the ta.
Democrats have not united beind any budget alternatives so far this year.
This week they are scheduled to discuss the budget ad possible spending cuts or tax increases but no decisions are anticipated, congressional sources said.
At the same time, without President Reagan's assent to a general tax increase, they are left with piecemeal taxes that are guaranteed to anger those who must pa.
"We could just do all of them," one congressional sorce said of the various tax ideas -- excise taxes, securities taxes, oil import fee and others.

The directors of the American Farm Bureau, the nation's largest farm organization, voted Tuesday to urge Congess to leave the 1985 farm bill in place without alterations.
"We are solidly opposed to opening up the 195 farm bill," said Dean Kleckner, president.
"The current farm bill has been in place for just a little over a year and in our judgment there is moe to be gained at the present time from maintaining the legislation.
"Several independent studies ... indicate the 1985 farm bill is beter on balance than any of the alternatives being advanced," Kleckner said.

The Farm Bureau also urged Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng to adjust the loan rate for 1987 crop soybeans as much as h deems possible under the farm bill to keep soybeans competitive in the world market.
A Farm Bureau proposal suggests that producers should be eligible for supplemental payments in the form of PIK certificates for the diffeence between 5.02 dlrs a bushel and the new loan rate.
The organization also urged Lyng to authorize deficiency payments to farmers who were unable to plant 198 winter wheat because of adverse weather.

Sporck said the group hopes to have an operational plan read by June 1.
Then it will search for a site for th manufacturing facility and an executive to head up the consortium.
The consortium could be operating by the end of the year, and the facility working in 18 months, he said
International Business Machines Corp hopes to participate in th effort, Paul Low, an IBM executive, said.
He said the project suppliers of raw materials and others vital to the semiconductor industry, such as toolmakers, would be invited t participate.
Sporck said no decision was made on wat product would be produced, stressing that the emphasis was on developing technology and sharing that with firms which belonged to SEMATECH.

President Reagan will visit Rome and West Berlin during a trip to Europe in June to attend the Venice summit meeting o the major industrialized countries, the White House said.

Sumner Redstone, president of National Amsements, Inc, predicted he can win regulatory approvals to wrap up the 3.4 billion dlr acquisition of Viacom International Inc in 60 to 90 days.
Redstone, 63, catapulted himself into he big leagues of entertainment early today when a group of Viacom managers and their financial backers decided not to top National's bid.
"We've had counsel working for sme time in every region where Viacom has cable televison systems" Redstone told Reuters in a telephone interview.
Redstone also sid "Viacom is committed to working very closely with us to obtain approvals."
Viacom has been seeking aprovals for transfer of its broadcast licenses and cable systems since September when its management group first advanced a buyout plan.

But Redstone turned the situation into a spirited biddin contest which was capped by the announcement this morning that Viacom's independent directors on behalf of Viacom entered into a defintive merger agreement with National.
National is a family business which operates a chain f movie theaters.
It is dwarfed by Viacm.
Redstone said he was weary after talks dragged on through the night but also excited at the prospect of runnng a leading electronic media company.
He noted that the number of motion pictre admissions in the U.S. has shown no growth in 15 years.
Of nine satellite television channels operated by Viacom, four ar motion-picture oriented pay channels.
Redstone said exclusive contracts with pay television networks are th emerging trend.
"Up until recently you could see any motion picture on any pay chnnel," Redstone said.
He noted Viacom has exclusive ageements with two studios and plans to sign a deal with a third company next month.
Redstone said the management group's inestment bankers will be paid what is due for termination of its merger agreement.
Such fees culd total about 30 mln dlrs.
"That will e a company expense," Redstone said.
He said BankAmerica <BAC> Corp as had numerous inquiries from lenders who want to participate in a 2.25 billion dlr financing for the deal.
BankAmerica wll provide 592 mln dlrs.
After the merger, Viacom will e a subsidiary of National but 17 pct of the company will be in public hands.
A senior British official said that protectionist bills being considered by Congress could trigger retaliation by the European Community (EEC and threaten the global trading system.

Paul Channon, secretary for trade and industry, said if Congress passed legislatin to curb textile imports, which would hit EC shipments as well as shipments from major Asian textile producers, "the community would have to retaliate."
His comments echoed those made yesterday by Belgian Trade Minister Herman De Croo, who said if the bill passed, the community would retaliate b imposing taxes on U.S. exports.
Channon made his remarks at a news conference after two days of talks with Reagan Administration officials an members of Congress.
De Croo was also in Washington for trade talks

Channon said there was a greater protectionism sentiment in Congress since his visit here last year as Congress and the Administration tried to find ways to reduce the U.S. trade deficit, which last year hi a record 169.8 billion dlrs.
Channon also called for greater EC-U.S. cooperation to force Japan t open its markets to foreign goods.
Channon said Japan's trade surplus is causing everyone problems - its surplus with the United States last year was 51.5 billion dlrs and with EC nations, 16.7 billion drs.
"The more united presure there could be, the better," he said.
Channon also called or increased U.S.-EC cooperation to avoid trade disputes.

He said the two ides narrowly avoided a confrontation earlier this year over lost grains sales when Spain and Portugal joined the community and its liberal imports regulations were tightened to conform to EC standards.
"But if oth sides drew back from the brink that time," he said, ""it does not mean that they would do so on another occasion."
Channon added hat "There is increasing reesentment in Europe over the U.S. tactic of negotiating under the pressure of unilaterally imposed deadlines."

He said other otential conflicts are already in sight - alleged European government subsidies of Airbus aircraft and taxes on fats and oils - and "the commuity and the United States must therefore learn to manage their relations better."

He said another bill o let the United States retaliate against a nation if that nation's market was not open to U.S. goods would bypass the trade pact GATT (General Agreeeement on Tariffs and Trade) as an arbiter of trade practices.

He said foreign trade aw should be judged by GATT and not by the United States, adding "if the (trade) law is to be interpreted by the United States and not by the GATT, what is to happen to the rest of us?"

U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said he hoped the U.S. dollar would continue to decline in relation to the currencies of Taiwan and South Korea as a way to improve the U.S. trade pcture.

China's 1986/87 sugar crop has been revised to 5.26 mln tonnes (raw value), down four pct from te previous forecast and five pct below the previous season, the U.S. Agriculture Department said.
In its World Production and Trade Report, the depatment attributed the decline to relatively poor profitability of sugar, causing harvested area of cane and beets to decline seven pct from 1985/86.

Beet sugar production for 1986/87 is now estimated at 837,000 tonnes, five pct less than earlier forecast ad down five pct from the previous season, while cane output is projected at 4.423 mln tonnes, down four pct from previously forecast and five pct below the previous season, it said.

The United Auto Workers and Amrican Motors Corp agreed to resume talks on a new labor contract for the company's threatened Kenosha, Wisc.
assembly plant dspite a breakdown in talks last weekend, UAW vice-president Marc Stepp said.
Stepp told reporters that issues which caused the talks to beak off are being discussed between the two sides and that a main table bargaining session has been scheduled Friday in Milwaukee.
France's Regie Naionale des Usines Renault has a controlling stake in American Motors.

Stepp said the union intends "to exert full efforts" to rach an agreement that would keep the plant in operation past 1989, when AMC has said production will end unless the UAW grants concessions on labor costs.

The UAW leader said the company and the union agreed in principle in 185 to pattern a future contract covering some 6,000 Kenosha workers after lower-cost UAW contracts covering Mazda Motor Corp's new U.S. plant in Michigan and the New United Motor plant in California operated by Toyota.
Stepp said there is such deep hosility between the company and union locals in Milwaukee and Kenosha that communication between them is very difficult.
But he said it is possible o reach agreement on a new contract to save the jobs of UAW members at AMC's Wisconsin operations despite the impasse.
AMC has said it will resume tlks, but only for 24 hours to ascertain whether the union was willing to agree to the concessions it wants.
The Kenosha lant builds AMC's Renault cars and a line of Chrysler Corp <C> vehicles under a contract assembly deal.

Dome Petroleum Ltd's plan to reschedule debt of more than 6.1 billion Canadian dlrs will likely be detailed to a group of 56 maor creditors on Monday or Tuesday next week, a company spokesman said.

Circulation of the complex plan to reschedule the company's debt was delayed to incorporate late changes resulting from discussions with Dome's lenders, spokesman Daid Annesley told Reuters in response to an inquiry.
Annesley said Dome expects its debt will total between 6.3 billion ad 6.5 billion dlrs by June 30, 1987, when it hopes to implement the debt plan now under negotiation.
Annesley said Dome Petroleum would issue a statement outlining the company's det rescheduling proposal following release of the plan to lenders.
Dome Petroleum previously said it hoped to submit the det plan by mid-February in order to win agreement in principle from creditors prior to June 30.

The group of major lenders have agreed to defer a substantial amount of debt payments until June 30 under a interim agreement that links payments to secured lenders with cash flow generated by assets backing the loans.
Annesley also said there was no change in the sttus of legal actions initiated by six Swiss noteholders who are seeking interest and principal payment on their unsecured debt.
Together, the noteholders are owed about 520,000 Swiss francs, ad their legal action places a total of 300 mln Swiss franc denominated debt in default.
Annesley said the company's next scheduled appearance in a Swss court to defend against the actions is set for March 16.
Dome Petroleum's 1986 fourth quarter nd year earnings will likely be reported at the end of March, he also said.

Confessed spy Jonathan Pollard was sentenced today to life in prison for passing thousands of pages of top-secret U.S. military docuents to Israel.

U.S. purchases of Soviet products must increase before the Soviet Union wil buy more U.S. goods, a Soviet trade official told Reuters.
"American exports (to the Soviet Union) depend on Soviet exports to te United States," said Albert Melknikov, deputy trade representative of the Soviet Union to the United States.
"One should not forget that i is impossible only to buy from the United States.
We must be able to sell our products to the United Sttes as well," he said in an interview.

New York investor Julian Robertson and several investment partnerships e controls said they raised their stake in Capital Wire and Cable Corp to 481,800 shares, or 12.2 pct of the total, from 430,200, or 10.9 pct.

Trans World Airlines Inc complicated the bidding for Piedmont Aviation Inc by offering either to buy Piedmont suitor USAir Group or, alternatively, to merge with Piedmont nd USAir.
Piedmont's oard was meeting today, and Wall Street speculated the board was discussing opposing bids from Norfolk Southern Corp and USAir.
The TWA offer was announced shortly after the Piedmont board meeting was scheduled o begin.
TWA offered to buy USAir for 52 dlr cash per share.
It also said it was the largest shareholder of USAir and threatened to go directl to USAir shareholders with an offer for 51 pct of the stock at a lower price.
TWA also said it believed its offer was a better deal for USAir shareholders than an acquisition of Piedmont, but it said it alternatively would discuss a three-way combinaion of the airlines.
Market sources and analysts speculated that TWA chairman Carl Icahn made the offer in ordr to put his own airline into the takeover arena.
"We're just wondering if he's not just tryng to get TWA into play.
There's speculation on the street he just wants to move onto somthing else," said one arbitraer.
"We think TWA might just be putting u a trial balloon."
Analysts said the offer must be taken seriously by USAir, but that the airline will probabl reject it because the price is relatively low compared to other airline deals.
They also said Icahn must prove his offr credible by revealing financing arrangements.
"They need to show their commitment and ther ability to finance.
I think it's a credble offer," said Timothy Pettee, a Bear Stearns analyst.
"I think it's certainly on the low end of relaive values of airline deals," said Pettee.
Pettee estimated 58 dlrs would be in a more reasnable range based on other airline mergers.
USAir stock soared after TA made public its offer.
A spokesman for USAir declined comment, and said USAir hd not changed its offer for Piedmont.
USAir offered of buy 50 pct of that airline's stck for 71 dlrs cash per share and the balance for 73 dlrs per share in USAir stock.
USAir closed up 5-3/8 at 49-1/8 on volume of 1.9 mln share.
Piedmont, which slipped 1/2 to close at 69-5/8, also remained silent n the TWA action.
Piedmont has an outstanding 65 dlr cash per share offer from Norfolk Southern Corp. Norfolk Southern declined comment, but said it stuck with it offer for Piedmont.
Norfolk owns about 0 pct of Piedmont and opened the bidding when it said it would propose a takeover of Piedmont.
Some analysts said cahn may be trying to acquire USAir to make his own airline a more attractive takeover target.
"Icahn I think had wanted t sell his airline and there were no takers.
I think the strategy might hae called for making his investment more attractive.
One way to accomplish that specific objective is to go out ad acquire other airlines," said Andrew Kim of Eberstadt Fleming.
"I don't know whose going to buy them, but at least ths way it becomes a much more viable package," said Kim.
But Icahn's financing ability for such a transaction remains in doubt, i part because of TWA's heavy debt load.
Wall street sources said TWA hs some cash with which to do the offer.
The sources said Icahn has ot lined up outside financial advisers and plans to make his own arrangements.
Icahn earlier this year abandoned pans to buy USX Corp <X> and still retains 11 pct of that company's stock.
Some Wall street sources said he financier's USX plan was impacted by the cloud hanging over his adviser, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc, because of Wall Street's insider trading scandal.
Industry sources aso predicted USAir might reject the TWA offer on price and financing concerns.
"It's littered with contingencies and t doesn't even have a financing arrangement," said one executive at another major airline.
But the executive conceded a merged TWA-USAir would be a strong contender with USAir's east coast rout system and planned west coast presence from PSA.
USAir could feed the intenrational flights of TWA, which has a midwest presence in its St. Loui hub.
Adding Piedmont, dominant in the southeast, to the mi would develop an even stronger force.
The combined entity would also have TWA's pars reservaton system.
Such a merger would be complex and analysts said it would result in an airline iwth a 18 pct market share.

The Reagan administration officially submitted to Congress its proposals to cut back US. farmers' income deficiency payments, decouple planting decisions from income support levels and accelerate reductions in loan rates, Senate staff said.
The recommendations, first outlined last January in President Reagan's fiscal 1988 budget blueprint, were transmitted to both houses of Congress s legislative proposals.
It was not clear which lawmakers might introduce the easures.
The most controversial proposal in the package would make 10 pct annual reductions in target prices for major commoditie.
A number of legislators have predicted the target price proposal ill not move in Congress.
The package also would offer the so-called 0/92 option to producers of 1987-90 crops and raise the annual permissible reduction n loan rates to 10 pct from 5 pct.
Under 0/92, a producer is guaranteed t least 92 pct of his deficiency payment regardless of how much he plants.
U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said e plans a July trip to China to discuss trade issues including China's admission to the General Agreements on Tariffs and Trade.
Yeutter told a congressional hearing it was possible China could be a member o GATT before the end of the year.
"They are making major moves to becoming a full scale member of the word economy," he told the House Appropriations subcommittee which oversees his agency's budget.
Depending on how the negotiations go on the terms of China's GATT membership, Yeuter said he could put the final touches on the U.S. part of the agreement during his trip.

The admission of China to GATT, which is the multinational group of nations which negotiates international rules on trade, would offer both potential export markets and potental competition for U.S. industries, he said.
That has a lot of potential as well as risks for U.S. business," Yeutter said.
I think China will develop into a fine market for us," he added.
Pan m Corp said its Pan American World Airways unit will reduce management costs by 20 pct, or about 80 mln dlrs, through job cuts, salary freezes and other measures.
Pan Am also said it has asked its labor unions to help lower coss by an additional 180 mln dlrs.
The airline said it will eliminate 464 managment positions and freeze all management salaris, a move that will save 30 mln dlrs a year.
An additional 50 mln dlrs of expenses under management's control will also be cut it said without offering details.
Pan Am sid it is seeking a 20 pct pay cut from its unions.

Pan Am vice chairman Martin R. Shugrue said n a statement, "Management is leading the way, but with 40 pct of our operating expenses represented by labor costs, we must have the cooperation of our labor unions if we are to make additional improvements to our 1987 operating plan."
Shugrue asked an Am's unions to begin negotiations on the pay cuts immediately.

The failure of talks to introduce new coffee export quotas within the Intrnational Coffee Agreement, ICA, was preferable to the alternative of Brazil having a sharply reduced quota, as had been proposed, President of the Rio de Janeiro Coffee Trade Association Carlos Calmon said.
He told Reuters proposals to reduce Brazil's quota to 25 pct of he world share from 30 pct at present were unacceptable as the country has large stocks and a good harvest is expected.
"Brazil has the capcity to export 20 mln bags this year," Calmon added.

Calmon said, assuming a 58 mln bag global ICA quota, Brazil's share under the proposals wuld have been 14.5 mln bags, of which soluble would have accounted for 2.0 mln, leaving just 12.5 mln bags of green coffee for export.
"It's a pity the talks broke down, ut for Brazil this was better than such a quota reduction," he added.
In 1985 Brazil exported 19.6 mln bags f soluble and green coffee, including about two mln bags to non-members.
A severe drought nd marketing problems cut exports last year to under 10 mln bags.
Calmon estimated stocks as of January 1 at 18 mln bags, of which 5.0 mln hav already been sold for export.
The harvest this year should be around 3 mln bags, he added.
The latest Brazilian Coffee Institute estimate for last year's harvest is 11.2 mln bags, although man traders believe it was higher than this.
Israel will tender overnight for 33,000 long tons of U.S. sorghum and/or 22,000 long tons o U.S. corn for April shipment, private export sources said.

Sales of new cars by the U.S. auto industry rose 6.7 pct in late February from the weak levels of a year ago, but industry giant General Motors Corp <GM> was an exceptio with an eight pct drop.
The figures represented a slight rcovery for the industry from weak mid-February sales, but the eight domestic-based car manufacturers still saw sales fall 9.1 pct for the full month from last year.

GM, whose sales have been weakening for several months, took only 48.1 pct of domestic car sales in the February 21-28 period compared with 55.7 pct a year ago, when sales for the entire industry were depressed from the ending of major marketing incentiv campaigns.
At the same time, rival Ford Motor Co <F> said its car sales in the period rose 29.3 pct and Chrysler orp <C> was up 11.3 pct.
The industry leader's slide was even more marked for the full month as GM took only 37 pct of all car sales in February, including import, compared with 43.5 pct a year ago.

Industry analysts said the 198,818 domestic-make cars sold in the seven selling days of late February represented a seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 7.0 mln unis while the 556,953 sold in the month were at a 7.4 mln annual rate.
Last year, the industry sold a record 11.44 mln new cars, including 82 mln domestic makes.

But consumers have taken a breather since ten and car sales sales have been weaker in 1987 due to tax-induced heavy buying in December, a lack of widespread sales incentives and intermitent bad weather, analysts said.
GM sles vice-president C.N.
"Bud" Moore said in a sttement that his company's sales "began their recovery from the low point reached in January, and we expect the improvement to continue in coming months."
Anne Knight, automotive analyst for Pine Webber and Co, told Reuters that GM's sales were weak, but added: "I think sales will get better in the spring."
"GM may make more production cuts in view of the weak sales, but this may b a strike year so they might try to build inventories," she said.

In a further effort to revive sales, GM said its Oldsmobile, Pontiac and Buick divisions would offer many of their new car lines through April 30 with discount loan packages at rats ranging from 3.9 pct for 24-month contracts to 9.9 pct for 60-month deals as an alternative to cash rebates.
Among the smaller U.S.-based manufacturers, Japanese-owned American Honda <HMC> said its late February car sales ros 96.2 pct from last year while Japanese-owned Nissan <NSANY> was up 35.9 pct.

German-owned Volkswagen of America fell 42.5 pct, American Motors Corp <AMO> plunged 62.5 pct and Japan's Toyota <TOYOY> sold 1,082 domesic makes compared with none a year ago before it started domestic production.
Detroit's late February truck sales were generally positive with GM u 10.9 pct, Ford up 48 pct, Chrysler gaining 46 pct and AMC's jeep sales off 4.0 pct.
Imported cars sales, released monthly, were estimated at 219,300 in Februry, a 0.4 pct rise from last year and 28.3 pct of the overall car market.
That was lower than January's 31.4 pct share but above te 26.3 pct share a year ago.
Distillate fuel stocks held in primary storage fell by 3.4 mln barrels in the week ended Feb 27 to 128.4 mln barres, the Energy Information Administration (EIA) said.

In its weekly petroleum status report, the Department of Energy agency said gasoline stocks were off 100,000 barrels in the week to 251.5 ml barrels and refinery crude oil stocks were up 3.2 mln barrels to 333.0 mln.
The EIA said residual fuel stocks fell 2.2 mln barrels to 37.9 mln barrels and crude oil stocks in the Strategic Petroeum Reserve (SPR) were up 700,000 barrels to 516.5 mln.
The total of all crude, refined product and SPR stocks were unchaged at 1,575.1 mln barrels, it said.
Rep. Jack Kemp, a New York Republican, urged President Reagan to oppose any legisltion to impose a tax on stock transactions.
In a statement Kemp called the tax "a money grab to permit Democrats t begin another government spending spree."
"I call upon President Reagan to signal immediately that he will veto any tx increase on stock transfers," Kemp said.
He added that the tax would punsh the 50 million stockholders.

House Speaker James Wright, a Texas Democrat, has asked congressional tax analysts to look at a 0.25 to 0.5 pct tax on stock trades along with othr tax proposals to help reduce the federal budget deficit.
ank of Canada Governor John Crow said he expects the Canadian economy will grow moderately in the coming year, despite the near flat growth in the final quarter of 1986.
We see moderate growth," Crow told a news conference following presentation of the central bank's annual report in the House of Commons today.
e said there were positive signs of growth in the economy, particularly the drawdown of business inventories in the fourth quarter.
Yesterday, Statistics Canada reported gross domesic product expanded a slight 0.2 pct in the quarter.
Crow reiterated the bank's previous statements that inflation remains a maor priority in setting monetary policy and said only zero inflation would be acceptable.
Canada's inflation rate is currently hoverng around the four pct mark.
The governor said Canada's banking system remains sound despite recent cocern about exposure by the country's banks in debt plagued countries such as Brazil.
"It (the debt problem) is not a hppy development but I think it can be overplayed in terms of its impact," Crow told reporters.
Argentina's Idustry and Foreign Trade Secretary announced he lifting until December 1989 of import taxes on capital goods not produced in the country.

Roberto Lavagna in a news conference also said Argentina would create a special programme or promoting industry and was studying a system of temporary, automatic and generalised admission of goods from neighbouring Brazil.
Lavagna said the measures were in line wth an adjustment in economic policy to stall a new upsurge in inflation.
The government last week froze prices and wages and devalued the Austral six pct aganst the dollar.
Allis-Chalmers Corp said it asked lenders nd other groups to approve a restructuring plan that would cause a dilution of the company's existing common stock.

The company said it would sell all of its businesses other than he American Air Filter business, make a public financing of more than 100 mln dlrs and pay part of the currently outstanding debt with the proceeds.

Under the plan, which was presented to institutional lenders, the company's unions nd the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, "substantial amounts" of institutional debt would be converted to common stock of the restructured company.
Allis-Chalmers said it wll exchange existing preferred stock for common.
The exchange of the institutional debt and preferred stock for common equity will cause a "resulting dilution o the existing common stock," Allis-Chalmers said in a statement.
nder the plan, holders of existing common would hold about 15 pct of the restructured common stock.
olders of existing preferred would hold about 35 pct of the new common.
llis-Chalmers said its only alternative to the plan is bankruptcy.
he restructuring must be approved by creditors, common and preferred holders,and present and former employees.
llis-Chalmers said a bankruptcy filing "appears to represent the company's only alternative if agreement upon the terms of the plan cannot be reached."
The spokesman said in response to an inquiry that he was not aware of ay extraordinary charge against earnings that would result from the restructuring.
"It is too early to talk about a charge" because the plan must still b approved by the lenders and unions, he said.
Also under the plan, payments to Allis-Chalmers' priate lenders would be deferred.
Trade payables and obligations incurred in the ordinar course of business will be met.
Payment of health benefits for active and retired employees would be made "at substantially redced levels."

Allis-Chalmers, once one of the leading farm equipment companies, sold all of its farm equipment operations to Deutz of West Germany for 107 mln dlrs, leaving te company with businesses in lift trucks, air conditioning, fluids handling and solid materials processing.
Last year, Allis-Chalmers sold the lift truck business to AC Material Handling C of Columbus, Ohio.
Under the restructuring plan, Allis-Chalmers will sel its solid materials processing and fluids handling businesses.
Solid materials processing, which makes equipment to crush stones for highway construction, accouned for 288 mln dlrs of Allis-Chalmers's total 1985 revenues of 886 mln dlrs.
The company will also sell is fluids handling operations, which makes pumps and valves.
That business accounted for 196 mn dlrs of the company's 1985 revenues.
Allis-Chalmers in 1986 reported a net loss of 8.6 mln dls, or 1.09 dlrs a share.
In 1985, the company lost 16.4 mln dlrs, or 12.27 dlrs a share.
The ompany's last profit was in 1980, when it earned 52.4 mln dlrs on sales of 2.1 billion dlrs.

Piedmont Aviation Inc said its board meeting recessed toay without taking action on proposals to combine Piedmont with other corporations.
Piedmont has received opposing bids from Norolk Southern Corp and US Air Corp.
Earlier today, Trans World Airlines Inc offered to either buy Piedmont suitor US Ar or, alternatively, to merge with Piedmont and U.S. Air.
IN a prepared statement, Piedmont said there would be no further announcements concerning thi situation today.
The company declined to say when te board would meet again.
U.S. Trade Representative Clayton Yeutter said he expects imports to fall soon but he was concerned about the lak of improvement in U.S. exports given the dollar's decline in the last 18 months.
"I'm convinced we're about t see an improvement on the import side.
I'm more concerned about te export side," he told a House Appropriations subcommittee.

Part of the blame goes on other countries which have not generated the economic growth to increase demand fr U.S. goods and part to some U.S. companies which are not generating competitive exports, he said.
A former TRW Inc controller told a Conressional hearing that the company had acted unethically in its defense contracts with the government.
"It is my contention that the company clled TRW is not ever vigilant and highly ethical as a defense contractor.
TRW only pretends to be an honest citizen when that scheme best fits their financial interests," Larry Eagleye said in testimony at a House Oversight subcommitee hearing.
Eagleye as a controller at TRW's compressor components division in Cleveland.

Subcommittee chairman John Dingell, -Mich, said he did not understand why the Defense Department had taken no action against TRW even though it admitted in the 1984 report that it had substantially overcharged the government for military aircraft parts.

"In 1984, TRW officials amitted to the Defense Department Inspector General that they had evidence of two sets of books and other problems in one of the company's divisions in Cleveland and that there had been substantial overcharging of the federal government on various military aircraft parts," Dingell said.

"For example, by falsifying ts books and records, TRW inflated the price of a military engine blade by two to three times higher than the price of a virtually identical commercial engine blade," Dingell said in a statement.
Eagleye and two other former employees filed a suit against TRW last year charging the company with overcharging the governmen.
The Justice Department later joind the suit.

"While employed by TRW and while under investigation by TRW, I disclosed to TRW's legal department and higher management, any flagrant and obvious violations of law, company policy and ethical conduct.
None of this evidence was included in TRW's (1984) repot to the government," he said.
The U.S. Army has delayed plans to buy a European anti-aircraft misile to help protect U.S. ground forces from Soviet attack helicopters, Defense Department officials said.
The Army has been considering buying some British Rapier missiles or Frnch and German Roland missiles as a stop-gap partial replacement this year for the flawed U.S. Sgt.
York Division Air Defense (DIVAD) gn which was canceled in 1985.

Despite recent indications by the service that it intended to buy the missiles soon, defense officials told Reuters a final decision had ben suspended because some Army officials favored a more versatile gun-missile combination.
The gun-missile combination would open te competition wide to U.S. firms.
The missile option is on hold now and no decision has been made," said one of the Pentagon official, who asked not to be identified.
There is some sentiment to take things more slowly and see if we can avoid a stop-gap system until we can come up with an integrated system of our own," said another official.
rmy Lt. Col. Craig McNab said, however, that Ronald and Rapier "are not out of the picture by a long shot."
here has been strong sentiment in the Army to reject a missile only and to opt for a more versatile combination gun and missile system mounted on a tracked vehicle.
Such a move would throw he competition wide open to U.S. firms, including General Electric Co <GE>, Boeing Co <BA>, FMC Corp <FMC> and Martin Marietta Corp <ML>.
But some Pentagon officials have exressed fears that an "off-the-shelf" gun-missile combination could not be fielded quickly enough.
Defense Seretary Caspar Weinberger canceled the Sgt.

York gun, made by Ford Motor Co <F> Aerospace and Comunications Corp, after the Pentagon had already spent 1.8 billion dlrs on the system and then decided it could not shoot down attack helicopters at the proper range.

The Army later expanded the division air defense concept, announcing it would divide the system into fie different components for the 1990s at a cost of more than 10 billion dlrs, including a missile and gun-system combination on a tracked vehicle.
TRW Inc, responding to allegations by an ex-employee tht it was unethical in defense contract dealings, said it had previously informed the government of the billing problems.

"We heard nothing of substance as far as allegations by former employees that were not related t findings that we had reported to the government of misdeeds at our compressor components group," a TRW spokesman said.
The spokesman said he company conducted an internal investigation and presented the findings to the government beginning in late 1984.

Record high borrowing of 376 billion lrs in 1986 on international capital markets was supported by a large volume of debt refinancing and growing integration between national and international markets, the OECD said.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said in its latest Financial Market Trends report the 34 pct rise over 1985 volume was accompanied by major changes in th relative importance of the instruments used in international financing.
Straight bond offerings, equity related securities and euro-commercial paper programmes as a share in total financing rose to their highest levl this decade.
The markets for floating-rate notes and for note issuance facilities decline.

The OECD said another striking feature of international capital markets in 1986 was the unprecedented concentration of lending to the OECD group of western industrialised countries, which accounted for 90 pct of total borrowin.
Factors behind the heightened pace of activity included a notable decline in interest rates which boosted borrowin through the flotation of fixed-interest securities.
This in turn was stimulated by growing familiarity with new techniques such as interest rate and urrency swaps.
Stockmarket buoyancy supported the expansion of equity-related bond issues and favoured the expansion of a rapidly expandin market for euro-equities.
A slowdown in net demand for funds by sovereign borrowers was more than offset by a larg volume of refinancing operations induced by improved market conditions and stronger debt management policies.
Growing integration with national markets meant the arrival of a large number of new plaers on international markets.

It added the development of a smoothly-functioning market for short-term euro-notes made committee and non-underwrittn issuance facilities an increasingly popular alternative to traditional forms of bank lending.
Turning to 1987, the OECD pointed to indications of a possible slowdown of international markets expansion and possibly less easy borrowing terms in a number of market areas.
It said many market participants saw little scope for a further decline in long-term rats and anticipate a slowdown in the pace of fixed-rate activity in the months ahead.

It saw little reason for a turnaround in the decline in demand of recent years, although i was likely more borrowers would try to make use of cost-reducing opportunities provided by the market for euro-commercial paper.

"It remains to be seen however to what extent the ECP market will be ready to aborb a significant volume of paper from lower-rated borrowers," the report said, adding that any major advance in the euro-note market's absorptive capacity would require a significantly broader investor base.
Trading in energy futures on he New York Mercantile Exchange will change dramatically over the next five to 10 years as the market matures, according to outgoing chairman Michel Marks.

"Energy futures trading is going through a tremendous period of transition tat will last five to 10 years," Marks said, adding that volume will soar, international participation will increase, and activity of producing countries, major oil companies, and speculators will grow.
Marks steps down as chairman ater an nine-year tenure when board elections are held March 17.
He will continue as chairman of a long-range planning committee a NYMEX.
"The priority of the next 10 years is operational efficiency versus the last 10 years when it was new product developmen," said Marks.

Marks said it is imperative for NYMEX, which is running out of trading space, to process greater volumes expeditiouly in order to handle the growth in volumes and new contracts that are already planned.
Marks said crude futures volume could more than double by the end of the decade to 250,000 contracts daily and combned products volume could soar to 100,000 contracts a day.
Much of the increased activity will come from the international secto, according to Marks.
"That's a huge growth area," he said, adding that it will rn the gamut from foreign producer countries to foreign independent operators.
He said it would be difficult to develop a futures contract baed on an internationally traded crude although he previously said the exchange is exploring that possibility.
"Trying to develop a futures contract in any other crude besides Wet Texas Intermediate will be a tough task" he said.
Marks said it is more likely a futures contract based on a international product rather than an international crude will be developed since the products market is more diverse.
He said previously the exhange is studying the possibility of developing a non-U.S. deliverable products contract.

Other sources of growth for U.S. energy futures are th major oil companies, which already trade on the NYMEX, and institutional funds such as investment houses, pension funds, and insurance companies, Marks said.
"The commodities markets have becoe financial markets and should pursue a partnership with financial intermediaries," Marks said.
He said speculators will increase their share of the energy futures markets in the coming years from the current shar of about 30 pct.
Hedgers, as a result, will lose some of their 0 pct share.

NBI inc said it has reduced prices of on its 5000 sries publishing workstations by 30 pct and has introduced a new electronic publishing workstation, a mini-computer and an image scanner at the Corporate Electronic PUblishing Systems Show.
All of NBI's 5000 Series re included in the new pricing including the Integrated workstation formerly priced at 14,490 dlrs and the pro publisher formerly priced at 15,490 dlrs.
The Philippines and its bank advisory committee completed a second day of talks on the country's requst to reschedule 9.4 billion dlrs of debts, bankers said.
They declined to disclose details of the negotiations, but said it would be unrealistic to expect n outcome until next week at the earliest.

Talks with Argentina over 2.15 billion dlrs of new loans and a multi-year rescheduling also continued n New York, with the Citibank-led advisory committee making a counter-proposal to Argentina's original offer.
Bankers remain hopeful that an agreement can be reaced by the middle of the month.
The House Ways and Means trade subcommittee postponed until next week its opening session to start drafting major changes o U.S. trade laws, a committee aide said.
Th subcommittee had not yet completed the preparatory work to start writing the legislation, the aide said.

Regal International Inc said it poposed to submit a plan of reorganization with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court under which it will acquire Bell Petroleum Services INc's by paying out all of its creditors and issue one share for each shares of Bell's stock.
This proposal as been amended from a previously rejected offer of .50 Regal share for each Bell share.
Regal said its will pursue the acquisition withou the support of Bell's management.
Bell Petroleum filed its Chapter 11 petition in November 1986 and has not, as yet, filed a plan of reorganization but has only sought an order extending the exclusive order, accordig to Regal.
Bell Petroleum President Ed Runyan said the company is evaluating Regal's latest offer and evaluating othr alternatives.
Runyan said Bell is meeting tomorrow with anothe potential suitor.
Southland Corp's Citgo Petrleum Corp said it raised the contract price i will pay for all grades of crude oil by one dlr a barrel, effective today.
The increase brings Citgo's posted prce for West Texas Intermediate to 17.00 dlrs a bbl.
West Texas Sour is also now priced at 17.00 dlrs/bbl, and Liht Louisiana South is posted at 17.35 dlrs/bbl.
On February 25 Citgo lowered its crude postings 50 cts to 1.0 dlrs per bbl, and cut WTI one dlr to 16.00.
Mazda Motor Corp of Japan reorted car sales in the U.S. during February of 10,049, down from 19,448 during February last year.
The company said year to dte car sales in the U.S. totaled 21,092, down from 38,441 a year earlier.
Truck sales in the U.S. totaled 8,558 in February, down from 9693 a year earlier.
Year to date U.S. truck sales totaled 16,17, compared to 18,341 a year ago.
