U.S. oil demand as measured by products supplied rose 2.1 pct in the four weeks ended February 27 to 16.39 mln barrels per day (bp) from 16.05 mln in the same period a year ago, the Energy Information Administration (EIA) said.
In its weekly petroleum status report, the Energy Department agency said distillate demnd was down 2.1 pct in the period to 3.37 mln bpd from 3.44 mln a year earlier.
Gasoline demand averaged 6.60 mln bpd, up 2.4 pct from 6.44 mln las year, while residual fuel demand was 1.47 mln bpd, up 1.9 pct from 1.44 mln, the EIA said.

Domestic crude oil production was estimated at 8.38 mln bpd, down 8.7 pct from 9.18 mln a year ago, and gross daily crude imports (exclding those for the SPR) averaged 4.11 mln bpd, up 36.9 pct from three mln, the EIA said.
Refinery crude runs in the four weeks were 12.21 mln bp, up 2.2 pct from 12 mln a year earlier, it said.
Year-to-date figures will not become available until March 26 when EI's Petroleum Supply Monthly data for January 1987 becomes available, the agency said.
The Securities Industry Association endorsed legislation expected to come before the Senate Banking Committee tomorrow imposing a moratorium n new powers for commercial banks.

Robert Gerard, managing director of Morgan Stanley and Co, told reporters his group, which mainly represents investment banking firms, supported committee members who want the Federal Reserve Board to postpone action on applications by three bank holding comanies seeking new powers.
"The Fed ought to hold those applications in abeyance pendng congressional review," Gerard said.
The legislation before the committee would recapitalize a federal desposit insurance fund for savings and loan associations and proibit new nonbank banks.
erard said the securities association had no position on nonbank banks.
The ssociation wants Congress to undertake a comprehensive study before changing the Glass-Steagall Act, which separates commercial and investment banking activities, Gerard said.
Until the tudy is completed, the Fed should not act on the applications by Citicorp, J.P. Morgan and Co. and Bankers Trust New York Corp to underwrite and deal in securities, he said.
The tudy was likely to show substantial benefits from continuing the separation of commercial and investment banking, he said.

Gerard said the group believes a proposal by House Speaker Jim Wright for a tax on securities was unjustified and wold hurt individual investors and beneficiaries of pension funds that invest in securities.
It may reduce the volume of activity, but the tax is a tax on the saver and investor," Gerard said.
n addition, a U.S. tax would drive business from the United States to other countries, he said.
he sharp fall in international coffee prices will not affect colombia's external credit situation, finance minister cesar gaviria told reuters.
"our foreign debt is high, but we can pay, and I hope te foreign banking community will maintain its position toward us," he said.
He said the current decline on world coffee markets was not totally unexpeted and would have no immediate bearing on colombia's financial state, which he described as sound.
Gaviria said the decline in coffee prices could mean a loss of 15 billion dlrs in revenues for 1987.
The conservative party and the country's largest trade union called this week fr the debt to be rescheduled following the price drop.
Colombia, the only major latin american country not to have rescheduled its externl public debt, has a total foreign debt of 13.6 billion dlrs.

Gulf States Utilities Co said it asked the Public Utility Commission of Texas to remove a condition that it secure a line of credit before the emergency rates can be put into effect in the Texas servce area.
The commission granted it a 39.9 mln dlrs interim rate increase February five, contingent upon Gulf States obtaining a 250 ml dlr line of credit.
A motion for rehearing wll be considered at as commission meeting on March 11, it said.
Gulf States said it is concerned the credit line requirement will give potential lenders an advantage that would be damaging o the company.

The package of proposed farm policy changes that the Reagan administration sent to Congress today includes a provision that would elminate minimum price support levels for upland cotton, rice and soybeans.

The package, obtained by Reuters, also includes a provision, outlined in advance by USDA officials, that would increase the annul permissible cut in the basic price support levels for all major crops to 10 pct from five pct.

Under current law, the basic support prices for upland cotton, rice and soybeans between 1987 and 1990 cannot be cu below 50 cents per lb, 6.50 dlrs per hundredweight and 4.50 dlrs per bushel, respectively.
USDA's intention to propose scrapping price floors for cotton, rie and soybeans had not been disclosed previously.
he ruling GATT Council today set up a formal dispute panel to examine a U.S. complaint that a Canadian law prohibiting export of unprocessed herring and salmon was discriminatory.
avid Wood, official spokesman of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), told a news briefing the decision was taken after bilateral consultations failed to resolve the row.
mbassador Michael Samuels charged during the Council debate that Canada was trying to preserve domestic jobs by insisting that herring and salmon be processed at home.
Robert White, Canada's deputy chief of delegation, replied the law was in line with GATT rules, and was for conservatons reasons.
But he agreed to setting up the dispte panel.

Opportunities for medium-sized banks to compete in the face of the increasing centralization of the financial services industry may be dwindling, according to John Rau, president of the Exchange Nationa Bank of Chicago.
"We're going to see a cotinued shaking-out of the banking industry," Rau told Reuters after a speech to securities analysts and investment advisors.

Rau said Exchange National Bank as concentrated its resources on financial services for medium-sized Chicago and Midwest businesses, asset-based lending to middle-market companies, and sales and trading of financial services.
"Most commercial bnks depend on relatively low cost consumer deposits for their income.
We decided o move our franchise into a less susceptible niche," Rau said.
"Nichemanship is a very difficult ting, especially in urban areas where inevitably banking franchises are mass-market oriented," Rau said.
"The dds are against other banks doing what we have done."
Exchange National ank is the principal subsidiary of The Exchange International Corp. With total assets of 1.9 billion dlrs, it is Chicago's fifth largest bank.
Net income ttalled 10.2 mln dlrs or 1.10 dlrs a share in 1986, up from 7.7 mln dlrs or one dlr a share in 1985.
South Africa's total gold and foreign asses rose by 700 mln rand in February to 6.2 billion rand after rising by almost one billion rand in January, Reserve Bank Governor Gerhard de Kock said.
De Kock, interviewed on state-run television, gave no breakdown f the reserves.
He also said hat to curb inflation, salary increases would have to be below the inflation rate.
The state must se an example by keeping wage increases below the inflation rate, he said.
Consumer prices rose by 16.1 pct in the year o January.
WTC International N.V. said t has sold its affiliates in South Africa to an independent trust, created to continue the operations in that country.

The purchase price was about 8.4 mln dlrs, represented y a ten-year interest-bearing note, payable annually at 11 pct, to be paid by the trust out of proceeds from the South African operations, the company said.
WTC said its board concluded in view of the social, political and economic situatin in South Africa, it was best to separate the company from its inerests there.
about 1,000 bolivian entral bank employees, more than 80 per cent of the workforce, accepted management terms to quit today, a union leader said.

"none of the employees who have ecided to resign from the institution is prepared to work again in the bank, unless many of the economic and social conditions improve," bank workers leader mario galindas told reuters.

The centre-right government of president victor az estenssoro had approved a restructuring plan which envisaged at least 600 redundancies, about half the bank's workforce, in line with its policy of streamlining the state sector.
Galindas said the bank needed at least 800 employees to keep up its presen functions.
The bank agreed to pay a 5,000 dollar bonus to every employee who resigned, as well as the legal redundancy terms of three months salary plus one fr every year worked.
Surinam's military government opens a four-day congress tomorrow to discuss te country's deepening economic crisis, the official Surinam News Agency reported.
Acting Prime Minister Jules Wijdenbosch will open the meeting which is being attended b government officials, political leaders and heads of labor unions.

Surinam's economy has suffered a sharp downturn in recent months as a result of guerrilla activities led by former soldier Ronny Brunswijk, who is seeking to overthow the government of Commander Desi Bouterse.
The guerrillas have forced the shutdown of most of Surinam's vital bauxite and aluminm industry, creating a foreign exchange crisis and food shortages.
Ivory Coast today predicted that the present coffee price crash recored after the collapse of the recent International Coffee Organisation (ICO) meeting in London would not last long.

Commenting on Monday's failure by producer and consumer nations to agree on new export quotas needed to tighten an oversupplied coffee maket, Ivorian Agriculture Minister Denis Bra Kanon told reporters that traders would eventually be obliged to restore their positions.
"I am convinced the market is going to reverse by Apil," he told a news conference here at his return from the failed London talks.
Robusta coffee beans for May delivery ended the day in London down about 50 sterling at 1,265 sterling a tonne, th lowest since 1982.

Bra Kanon estimated at at least 535 billion CFA francs (1.76 billio dlrs) the overall loss in revenues earned by Ivory Coast from all its commodities exports this year if the slide on the world markets continues.
He disclosed that his country - the world's biggest cocoa producer an the third largest for coffee -- would spearhead an African initiative to reach a compromise formula by the end of next month.
Ivory Coast has been chosen by the Abidjan-based Inter-African Coffee Organisation (IACO) to speak on behalf of the continent's 25 producer nations at the London talks
"An initiative from IACO is likely very soon," e said without elaborating.
"Following the London collapse, we have immediately embarked on a concertation course to avoid breaking an alredy fragile market," he said.

Questioned by journalists, the minister said President Felix Houphouet-Boigny estimated for the moment that his government would not be forced to reduce the price guaranteed by the state to Ivorian coffee-growers for the currnt season.
Last year, the West African nation announced that the coffee producer price would stay at 200 CF francs (65 cents) per kilo.
Bra Kanon said that his country would strive to diversify its agricultural production to avoid beeing to dependent from world market fluctuation.

A communique read over the sate-run television tonight said that during today's weekly cabinet meeting, the veteran Ivorian leader reaffirmed "his faith in Ivory Coast's bright (economic) future" despite the commodities price slide.
The Agriculture Mnister also announced the government decided to earmark a sum of 7.5 billion CFA francs (24.71 mln dlrs) to support the country's small farmers.
Financially-strapped Ivory oast, long regarded as one of Africa's showpiece economies, is going through difficult times following the sharp slump in the world price of cocoa and coffee.
Ivory Coast's eal gross domestic product is expected to grow only one pct this year compared to five pct in 1986, according to a recent Finance Ministry estimate.
New Zealand's current account deicit narrowed to 180 mln N.Z.
Dlrs in January from 203 mln, revised from 207 ml, in December and 305 mln in January 1986, in a smoothed measurement, the Statistics Department said.
Unsmoothed figures show a deficit of 162 mln dlrs fr January against 107 mln, revised from 75 mln for December 1986 and 575 mln in January 1986.

The smoothed series -- adjusted to iron out random fluctuations -- shows a widening surplus on merchandise trade to 46 mln from a surplus of 33 mln, revised from 43 mln dlrs in December and a 71 mln defiit in the a year ago period.

Exports were 905 mln dlrs against 929 mln, revised from 971 mln in December and 816 mln a year earlier, while imports fell to 858 mln from 895 mln, revised from 928 mln in December and 888 mln i January 1986.
Unadjusted merchandise figures show a surplus of 53 mln dlrs vs 141 mln, revised from 203 mln surplus in Decembr 1986 and a 323 mln deficit a year earlier.
The deficit on invisibles on unsmoothed figures eased to 215 mln dlrs from 248 mln, revised from 277 mln i December and 252 mln in January 1986.
The smoothed deficit on invisibles fell to 226 mln from 237 mln, revised from 250 mln in December and 234 mln in the year ago period
Buttes Gas and Oil Co said it filed a plan of reorganization in a U.S Bankruptcy court handling its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case.
The company said the plan wll provide for distribution of cash, promissory notes and stok among 12 classes of creditors and equity interests.
The rally Wednesday in U.S. interest rate futures left the Treasury bond contract above the top of a three month trading range which signals a bullish cart breakout, financial analysts said.
In addition, sluggish U.S. economic data and little sign tat the economy will pick up its pace in the near future may be enough to send bond futures to all-time highs, the analysts said.
"The market is paying mre attention to the weakened state of the economy right now," said Refco analyst Mike Connery.
Connery said the four ct drop in January U.S. factory orders reinforced sentiment that first quarter economic growth will be slow.
Connery and other analysts nted that talk of a cut in the Lombard rate after sluggish West German industrial production figures also provided some support.

"The domestic economies of the ajor trading partners of the U.S. may deteriorate to such an extent that they will be forced to ease," thus paving the way for a more accomodative U.S. credit policy, added John Michael, analyst at First Options of Chicago.
Michael pointed ut, however, that trimming the U.S. trade deficit -- the ultimate aim of the recent meeting of major industrial countries -- may not necessarily aid bond prices.
"The surplus for exporters to the U.S.) is bullish for bonds because they (exporters) have a lot of dollars.
Rather than tanslate those into their own currencies and suffer exchange rate risk, they buy dollar-denominated instruments," Michael said.
Indeed, futures traders with cash bond connections said some of the late strength in the bond markt resulted from buying by Japanese interests.
But the analysts said the heavy buying in futures occurred after the June bond broke above stif resistance at 101-2/32.
"The breakout is pretty important," said chartist Leslie Keef of Technical Data Corp of Boston.
"Not only did bonds close above recent highs but they were also above the sideways pattern we'v been in for the last three months."
Also positive on a technical basis was the fact that the June bond contract held chart supprt early near 100-4/32, and that the rally occurred on heavy volume, Keefe said.
Keefe said the next level of significant chart resistance will be t 101-24/32 to 101-28/32.
Furthermore, "we still have the April (1986) highs t contend with," which in the nearby contract is 105-15/32.
Michael said the breakout projects gains to 103 i June T-bonds and "there is an outside chance to reach 106."
Keefe warned, however, that confirmation also is needed frm other technical indicators such as relative strength indexes and short-term momentum indicators.
"Without them, sustained strngth is in question," Keefe said.
New Zealand agreed with the Meat Producers Board to write off 1.03 billion NZ.
Dlrs of debt incurred on behalf of farmer under the Meat Price Stabilisation Scheme, Finance Minister Roger Douglas said.

Douglas and Agriculture Minister Colin Moyle said in a join statement the agreement concludes one of the major refinancing arrangements announced in the July 1986 budget, which removed subsidies from the farming sector.
The write-off applies to debt occurring prior to October 1985, when stabilisation payments for sheepmeat ceased under an industry restructuring which allowed privat marketing.

President Reagan, fighting to regain public confidence in the wake of the Iran arms scandal, admitted tonight that the clandestine operation wound up as an arms-for-hosages deal and, "It was a mistake."
"When it came to managing the NSC (National Security Council) staff, let's face it, my style didn't match its previous track record," Reagan said i a television address to the American people.
"I have already begun correcting this," h added in his prepared remarks.

Reagan's speech, widely regarded as critical to his hopes of repairing his presidency, was his first detailed response to last week's scorching Tower commission reprt on the secret sale of arms to Iran and diversion of profits to U.S.-backed contra rebels in Nicaragua.
Reagan said he had been silent on the scandal while he waited for the truth to come out and admitted, "I've paid a price fr my silence in terms of your trust and confidence."
He sai that a few months ago, he told the American people he did not trade arms for hostages in the 18-month covert operation.
"My heart and my best intentions still tell me that i true, but the facts and the evidence tell me it is not," Reagan said.
"There are reasons why it happeed, but no excuses.
It was a mistake," e said.
Reagan again said that the original Iran initiative was to develop relations with those who might assume leadershp in a post-Khomeini government.
"It's clear from the Board's report however that I let my personal concern for the hostages spill ver into the geo-political strategy of reaching out to Iran.
"I asked so many questions about the hostages' welfare that I didn't ask enough about the specifics f the total Iran plan," he said.

The commission, headed by former Republican Sen. John Tower, said Reagan's "intense compassion" for Americans being held y pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon had resulted in an unprofessional and unsatisfactory policy.
It portrayed 76-year old Reagan as a man ho did not know or care much about the wide-ranging, probably illegal activities of his National Security Council (NSC) staff, which hatched the operation.

Reagan said he endorsed all of the Tower comission's recommendations about the running of the NSC, adding, "In fact, I'm going beyond its recommendations, so as to put the house in even better order."

He noted that he had appointed former Senate Reublican leader Howard Baker as his new chief of staff and said he hoped Baker would help him forge a new partnership with Congress, "especially on foreign and national security policies."
He said his new national security adviser, Frank Carlucci, ws rebuilding the national security staff "with proper management discipline."
Reagan said that almost haf the NSC professional staff now consisted of new people.
He said that FBI Director William Webster, his new noinee to head the CIA, "understands the meaning of 'rule of law'".
Reagan also announced that Tower had agreed to serve a a member of his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, which acts as a watchdog on the nation's covert activities.
But he said that he had issued a directive baring the NSC staff itself from undertaking covert operations -- "No ifs, ands, or buts."
Tonight's speech was a far cry from Reagan's initial strong defense of is Iran policy.
In a televised speech lst November 13, Reagan called charges that he ransomed hostages and undercut the U.S. war on terrorism "utterly false."
As recently as two mnths ago in his State of the Union speech, Reagan said that "serious mistakes were made" but defended the basic policy as one that had worthy goals.
By contrast, tonight's speech ad an apologetic tone that was a marked departure from Reagan's usual upbeat, confident demeanor.
He said he took fll responsibility for his own actions "and for those of my administration."
"As angry as I ay be about activities undertaken without my knowledge, I am still accountable for those activities.
As disappointed as I may be in sme who served me, I am still the one who must answer to the American people for this behavior," Reagan said.

Reagan said the message that the nation should move on had come from Republicans and Demcrats in Congress, from allies around the world -- "and if we're reading the signals right, even from the Soviets."
His remark seemed to be a reference o a new Soviet willingness to reach an agreement on eliminating medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

President Reagan said improper ecord keeping of meetings and decisions made on the Iran arms initiative led to his failure to recollect whether he approved arms shipments by Israel before or after the fact.
In a tlevised address to the American people Reagan said he is still upset that no-one kept proper records -- a complaint made by the Tower commission.
The rms shipment was made in August of 1985 by Israel.
"I id approve it; I just can't specifically say when," Reagan said.
Reagan added: Rest assured, there's plenty of record-keeping now going on at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue (the White House)."
The timing of Reagan's approval of the Israeli shipment is important beause it could determine whether the sale violated various laws, including the Arms Export Control Act.
Gold rose b about 50 U.S.
Cents an ounce, following a statement by President Ronald Reagan that te arms-for-hostages deal with Iran "was a mistake," dealers said.
Bullion rose to 409.40/90 dlrs from an initial lo of 408.90/409.40.
This compares with the opening of 409.00/50 and New York's close f 410.00/50.
Dealers noted mild short-covering in the metal after some initial selling y local investors.
Trading was fairly quiet tis morning partly owed to the slow U.S. Dollar activities, they added.
However, Reagan's remarks had only a short-lived bullish impact on the gold price, which is now stabilising t 409.10/60 dlrs, dealers said.
On th local market, the metal traded in a narrow range of 3,800 and 3,805 H.K.
Dlrs a tael aganst yesterday's 3,778 close.
The central bank has issued 7.08 billion dlrs worth of certificates of deposit (CDs), bringing the value of CD issues so far this year to 93.29 billion, a ban spokesman told Reuters.
The new CDs, with maturities of six months, one year and two years, carry interes rates ranging from 3.9 to 5.15 pct.
The issues are designed to help curb the growth of the M-1B money supply whih has expanded along with Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves, the spokesman said.
The reserves reached a record high of more than 51 billion U.S. Dls Wednesday.
Iranian troops are fighting on two widely separated fronts in a new offensive in the mountains of Kurdistan in northern Iraq, Tehran's IRNA news agency sad.
Baghdad war communiques made no mention of fresh fighting on northern or southern sectors, but a military spokesman threatened a resumption of air raids on Irania towns.
IRNA, monitored by the BBC in London, said Iran had seized several strategic heights in the norther assault, which started on Tuesday.
It said at least 2,000 Iraqi troops had bee killed, wounded or captured.
The offensive is in the Haj Omran area of Kurdistan, scene of fierce fighting i 1983.
Tehran radio reported last night that Iranian forces were in control of four mountain areas, bringing seveal Iraqi towns with troop concentrations within artillery range.
In the south, IRNA said, Iranian forces captured several Iraqi defence posts east of Iraq's second city Basra, in a drive north along the Shatt al-Arab waterway.
Today is he end of a two-week-long Iraqi moratorium on air raids declared on condition that Iran stop attacking Iraqi territory and shelling its towns.
Iraq's war sokesman said Iran had kept up its attacks and had made "boasts of illusory victories."
President Francesco Cossiga meets political leaders o discuss how to form a new government following the resignation of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi.

Craxi's Socialist Party has said it will not serve under Foreign Minister Gulio Andreotti, who has been prime minister five times previously and whom the majority Christian Democratic Party has said it wants to take on the job again.

The Socialist Party, the second biggest in the outgoing five-party coalition, said t would accept only Ciriaco De Mita, Christian Democratic Party secretary, or the party's president, Arnaldo Forlani, for the job of prime minister.
Political sources said talks are likely o be difficult and could take several days due to rivalry between the two leading parties.
In Craxi's 3-1/2 years as prime miniter, the Christian Democrats have become increasingly irritated at being denied the prime minister's job.
The sources said early geeral elections are likely unless agreement can be reached.
Cossiga is due to meet former presidents before holding taks with party leaders, including the opposition Communists and the junior coalition members -- Republicans, Liberals and Social Democrats.
After the consultations, Cossiga will name a prime minister-designate wo will try to form a government.
Abnormally warm and dry weather over most parts of China i seriously affecting crops, the New China News Agency said.
It said the drought has made rice planting difficult in eiht provinces, including Guangxi, Sichuan and Hunan.
Plant diseases and insect pests have increased in wheat-producing areas, i said.
The agency said some areas of Guangxi, Hubei, Shanxi and other provinces have been suffering a drought for more than seen months.

The agency said the dry weather had reduced the amount of water stored by more than 20 pct compared with las March, lowered the water level of many rivers, reduced hydroelectric power supplies and caused water shortages for industry and consumers.
The upper reaches of the Yangtze are at their lowest levels in a century, causing many ships t run aground and making harbour manoeuvres difficult, it said.
The drought has also increased the number of foret fires.
More than 1,000 fires in southern China had destroyed 13,340 hectares of forest b mid-February, it said.
Taiwan's state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp (CSBC) plans to seek joint production agreements with Japan and further diversify into ship repairing to try to trim its debts chairman Louis Lo said.
He told Reuters in an interview that CSBC's first joint production venture, to build two hulls for <Onomichi Dockyard Co Ltd>, was a succes.
Talks on similar projects have been held with other Japanese firms, including Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Co Ltd <MITH.T> and Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries Co Ltd <JIMA.T>, h said.
Lo said CSBC delivered the hulls f two 2,200-TEU (twenty foot equivalent unit) container ships this year to Onomichi, which would complete production.
"We expect the successful cooperation between s and Onomichi will pave the way for further cooperation with other Japanese shipbuilders in the future," Lo said.
He said Japanese firms would gain fom the lower cost of shipbuilding in Taiwan while CSBC would benefit from Japanese technology and marketing.
This would pose a challenge t competitors in Europe and South Korea.
Lo said CSBC has made losses of about 100 mln U.. Dlrs since beginning operations in 1975.
Its total debt now stands at about 500 mln dlrs, wih annual interest payments of nearly three mln dlrs.
But he said the company, which is Taiwan's largest shipbuilder, stll has full government support and had begun diversifying into ship repairing and manufacture of pipes and other machinery.
"We hope we can survive ad prosper through diversification," he said.
Lo said income from ship repairing almost doubled to 20 mln U.S. Dlrs i the year ended June 1986 compared with the previous financial year.
He estimated income would rise to mor than 25 mln dlrs in 1986/87.
CSBC has orders to build 10 ships totalling 460,000 dead weight tons (dwt) this financial year, compared with 11 ships of 462,000 dwt in 1985/86, he sai.
Lo said the prospects for shipbuilding were gloomy at least until 1991 due t overtonnage, but the outlook for ship repairing was bright.
<Hyundai Motor Co> exported 49,822 cars in the first two months of 1987, up from 37,272 in the same period of last year, mainly due to booming sales in the U.S And Canada, company officials said.
They told reporters Hyundai Motor expects to export 450,000 cars in 1987, including 250,000 to the U.S., After a record total last year of 300,200, in large part due to 168,90 initial U.S.
Sales of the Pony Excel sub-compact
They said the company plans to lift annual output capacity to 750,000 cars by end-year fro 600,000 now.
Net profit hit a record 38.3 billion won in 1986 from 28.8 billio in 1985.

A group of creditor banks hopes to work out a rescue package for Japan Line Ltd <JLIT.T>, one of the world's largest tanker operators, b the end of Japan's business year on March 31, a spokesman for the Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd <IBJT.T> (IBJ) said.
Japan Line's cumulative debt was 68.98 billion yen at the end of Septemer, which exceeded shareholders' equities and reserves totalling 63.40 billion.
In December, Japan Line asked banks to shelve repayment of about 124 billion yen in outstanding loans and about 153 billion in loans to its subsidiares.
Japan Line said then that the yen's steep rie and the world shipping recession had hit the company hard.

The Japanese daily Asahi Shimbun said today that IBJ and three other banks plan to abandon a total of 16 billion yen in loans to Japan Line and a group of creditor banks plans to buy seven billion ye of new Japan Line shares.
The spokesman for IBJ, Japan Line's largest creditor, said the package may write off part of the outstanding loans and will be worked ou before long.
Commenting on th article, he said the details of the package have not yet been settled.

Argentina will tell its ceditors it needs an extension of deadlines for payment of capital and interest on its 50 billion dlr foreign debt, Industry and Foreign Trade Secretary Roberto Lavagna told reporters.
"We, the developing countries, are going to insist on the application of contingency clauses, to extnd deadlines for the payment of capital as well as interest," he said.
He said this could bring about what he called a possible automatic capitalisation of those parts of debt interest that could not be paid and even the elimination of a porion of the debt.
Indonesia heads for general elections in six weeks' time wih its economy in the worst shape in 20 years, economists and officials said.

The government expects no spillover of "people power" from the neighbouring Philippines to unsettle the 20-year rule of President Suhato, victory for whose ruling Golkar party in the coming parliamentary elections is assured.
However, Western diplomats aid it is the country's deteriorating economic position that is the main threat to its stability.
Last year's collapse n oil prices dealt a heavy blow to Indonesia, halving its revenue from oil and gas exports to 6.5 billion dlrs last year from 12.4 billion in 1985.
Oil nd gas account for 70 pct of export income.
The result is hat in the run-up to April 23 elections, Suharto, far from wooing his 168 mln countrymen with pay increases or tax cuts, is busy slashing budget spending.
The government has lso recently increased transport fares and frozen the pay of the civil service and the army for the second year running, despite inflation now estimated at 8.8 pct.
he current account deficit rose to 4.09 billion dlrs in 1986 from 1.8 billion in 1985, while the debt service ratio widened to 33.2 pct for 1987 from 25 pct in 1986.
Foreign debt repayments of 4.6 billion dlrs account for almost a third of te 1987/88 budget.
A recent U.S. Embassy report on the economy said 1986 gross domestic product groth was the lowest since the mid-1960s when Suharto came to power.
Western economists said GDP registered nil growth or contracted last year after 1.9 pt growth in 1985, and predicted only a one pct rise this year.
In its efforts to return to growth seen in the oil-boom years of the 1970s when the economy grew an average seven pct, the government is nw relying more on foreign borrowings.
Indonesia has asked foreign governments to finance its share of new projects being built with overseas money, because it cannot afford even to meet local cost.
In the last three months Indonesia has taken out new loans totalling 1.55 billion dlrs, on top of its extenal debt of 37 billion dlrs.
Western bankers said more will be needed, and th country now ranks sixth among Third World debtors.
A 350 mln dlr commercial loan signed in Tokyo in December was followed in the first wek of February with a 300 mln dlr loan from the World Bank to support the balance of payments.
Last month, Japan's Export-Import Bank agreed a 900 mln dlr loan to meet Indonesia's share of 21 World Bank projects which would otherwise have been scraped or postponed.
More loans are on the way, including two more from the World Bank worth a total 300 mln dlrs for oads and irrigation.
mbassador Paul Wolfowitz said in a recent speech that economic growth remains the key to preserving Indonesia's fundamental stability.
The largest Moslem nation in the world, Indonesia has so far avoided some of the more extreme paths of other Mosle countries.
Bu the World Bank has warned that mounting unemployment could start causing severe social strains unless it is tackled.
It said n its annual report on Indonesia last June that unless economic growth is revived, unemployment could reach what it termed "unacceptable levels."
Unemployment was oficially put at 4.8 pct at the end of last year, but those considered underemployed number around 35 pct.

What path to take appears to be a matter of some dispute within Suharto's government, with his Western-trained technocrats advocating more of the classic remedies supported by the international fnancial community.
But another roup supports a protected economy, with more import substitution, the U.S. Embassy report said.

The government devalued the rupiah y 31 pct against the dollar last September to help exports and curb imports, and is currently working on a series of measures to further encourage foreign investment and boost exports outside the oil sector.
The direction Suharto takes could affect Indonesia's ability to raise new lons in the future, Western bankers say.

So far, despite three packages of economic measures over the past nine months, he has not touched key monopolies that are linked t businesses controlled either by his family or by business associates, diplomats and bankers say.
Diplomats and investors are now looking for action on monopolies and the loss-making state sector as signs that Suharto is serious about tackling the county's problems.
Australian wheat shipments rose to 1.33 mln tonnes i February from 1.01 mln in January, an Australian Wheat Board official said.
February's shipments were down o the 1.54 mln tonnes shipped in February 1986.
Cumulative shipments for the first five months of te October/September wheat year were 6.12 mln tonnes, as against 6.54 mln a year earlier, the official said.
The major destinations in February were: China (419,196 tonns), Egypt (301,909), Iraq (142,055), Japan (110,261), South Korea (100,847) and the Soviet Union (100,056 tonnes).

Republicans in Congress hailed President Reagan's speech on the Iran arms scanda as candid and constructive while Democrats, who control both houses, said Reagan would now have to match his words with action.
Senate Majority Leader Robert Byrd (Democrat) of West Virginia said in a television interview he was heartened that Reagan had acknowledged some of his mitakes.
"But one spech is not enough to rebuild trust."
"President Reagan told the American people what they needed t hear, that mistakes were made and he made them," Senate Republican Leader Robert Dole of Kansas said.

Reagan, responding to the Tower Commission report criticising his role in the Iran arms scandal, said for the first tie the Iran arms policy, and not just its implementation, was a mistake and accepted responsibility for the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan contra rebels.

Senator Bill Bradley (Democrat) of New Jersey said the administration would "remain under a cloud" until several key figures i the scandal, including fired National Security Council (NSC) aide Oliver North and his boss Adm. John Poindexter, have told "the whole truth."

Republicans and Democrats praised the appointment on Friday of former Senate Republican leader Howard Baker to replace Donald Regan as chief of staff, and the replacement of Poindexter with Frak Carlucci to head the NSC.
Assistant House Republican Leader Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he believed Reagan took the rigt measure in admitting mistakes without apologising for them.
Some House Democrats, including Speaker James Wright of Texas, said earlier they would delay ther reaction until tomorrow in order to study the speech overnight and assess its impact.

OPEC countries are all sticking firmly to official crude oil prices but th volatility of spot prices is likely to continue into the third quarter, Indonesian Minister of Mines and Energy Subroto told Reuters.
Subroto, attending a Pacific Energy Cooperation conference, blamed recent rapid spot price changes on unbalanced supply and demad.
"If we stick to the production limitation, the thir quarter will be in better balance."
He said the market is in a period of transition while the impat of OPEC's December agreement to cut output and fix prices at an average 18 dlrs a barrel is worked through.

Asked whether OPEC members of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) had any concrete proposals to help Qatar sell its crude oi in the face of strong resistance to its official prices, Subroto said: "Apparently they have taken care of that."
"They (the GCC) meet very ofen among themselves.
I think they'll help each other" he said.
Subroto said that as he was not a member of OPEC's Price Differentials Committee he did not know why the meeting ha been postponed from its scheduled April 2 date.
"Maybe they find it is better not to have the meeting because ... Everyone is sticking to official prices," h said.
Thai coffee exports rose to 22,068 tonnes in 1986 from 20,430 a yea earlier, the Customs Department said.

The easing of rules governing overseas use of the yen has caused an explosion of Euroyen bond activity but has failed to turn the yen int a truly international currency, bond managers and traders said.

Although yen bonds now rank second only to dollar issues in the Eurobond market, few foreigners are interested in keeping the yen they borow and no one wants the yen bonds but the Japanese, they said.
This lack of real yen demand through the freer Euroyen market i undermining the 1984 U.S. And Japanese accord to internationalise the yen, they said.
The borrowers want to take advantage of low Japanese interest rates bt have no need for yen.
They arrange primarily with Japanese banks to exchange yen funds into oter currencies, mainly dollars, bond managers said.
More than 5 pct of Euroyen bond issues are swap driven, they added.
"The borrowers dn't care which currency they use.
They are oly after attractive money," one bond trader said.

Issues doubled to more than 150 in 1986 from the prvious year, boosting Euroyen offerings to more than nine pct of the total Eurobond market, Koichi Kimura, managing director of Daiwa Securities Co Ltd, said recently.
Traders said some of the acivity stems from battles among Japanese and foreign securities companies and banks for the prestige of placing a larger share of issues.
Many even resort to "harakiri" swaps those with unprofitable pricing.
But the fever continues and the number of offerings could double again in 1987, said Naoki Yokoyama, manager of Nikko Securties Co Ltd's international capital markets operation.
The Euroyen bonds, once issued, are mostly picked up by Japanese trst banks, one trader said.
After a 90 day waiting period the bonds flow back to Jaan where investor appetite is strong, he added.
Foreign investors are reluctant to invest in yen when more attractive yields are offered on dollar and other currency investments, trades said.
"Even aggressive foreign investors have stopped investing (in yen)," said Masaki Shimazu, manager o Daiwa's bond department.

While few foreigners are interested in the secondary market, Japanese commercial banks, regional banks, life insurers and other financial institutions are eager to buy the bonds ad await their flow back to Japan since they offer little currency risk, traders said.
The Finance Ministry last April shortened the waiting period before issues could flow bac to Japan to 90 days from 180.
A ministry official said it verified thrugh sampling that reflow was fairly small.
"We believe the Euroyen bond should remin mainly in the Euroyen market," he said.
One trader said that although demand from Japanese investors is heavy, it may prove t be only short-term.
He said many investors plan to sell their bonds if Japanese or U.S. Interest rate decline further.

To encourage further international use of the yen, the ministry is considering allowing the issue of Euroyen commercial pape, the official said, adding that it is studying demand from potential borrowers.
Securities company sources believe the ministry will permit non-residents to issue Euroyen commercial paper within the next few monts.
But they expect it to continue to ban domestic participation in the market for som time to come.
Japanese banks object to the short-term paper market which they se encroaching on their business territory.
Traders said Euroyen commercial paper could spur more demand overseas fr the yen by allowing opportunities to shift into shorter-term securities if need be.
"Commercial paper might encourage fewer swps," one bond manager said.
If more financial instruments were availble, there might be more trades in yen, he added.
Euroyen bonds must now carry a five-year maturity, though some reent issues which are callable in three years work as if they had shorter maturities, traders said.
The ministry is expected to alow four-year Euroyen bond maturities within a few months.
One yen bond manager said Japanese financial authorities are giving up a lt of their control in liberalising the rules governing international transactions of the yen.
But freer use of the yen could encourage more trade settlements in te Japanese currency, he said.
"If exporters or importers can raise funds in yen, they will be mor willing to agree to using the Japanese yen as a settlement currency," he added.
The Finance Ministry official said the government must constantly consider ways to impove markets for the benefit of borrowers and investors.
"No major market can keep its staus without change," he said.

South Korea's M-2 money supply rose 0.39 pct to 33,992.0 billion won in February from 33,858.4 billion in January, when it fell a revised 0.04 pct from December, provisional Bank of Kore figures show.
The February figure was up 18.89 pct from a yea earlier.
M-1 money supply rose 4.13 pct to 8,492.1 billion won in February from January, when it fell 7.82 pct fro December.
The February figure marked a year-on-year rise of 18.45 pct
The bank previously said M-2 fell 0.06 pct n January.
Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves fell to 8.43 billion rupees in February from 8.96 billion in January, comared with 12.97 billion in February 1986, the State Bank of Pakistan said.
The bank gave no reason for the fall but local bankers said big import bills had affcted the reserves.
The Federal Bureau of Statistics has not yet relased last month's import and export figures.
Austria has decided to redeem six years early a 20 billion yen, 12-year, 8.5 pct samurai bond due on August 18, 1993, Daiwa Securities Co Ltd said as lead maager.
It will redeem 18.4 billion yen at 103.00 and the rest at par this August 18 under an annual redemption obligation, probably because of declining yen interest rates, Daiwa sid.

Thailand's main paddy rop is expected to fall to 15.4 mln tonnes in the 1986/87 (Nov/Oct) season from a previous 15.68 mln estimate in November and an actual 17.35 mln a year ago, the Thai Rice Mills Association said.

It said a oint field survey late last month by the association, the Commerce Ministry and the Bank of Thailand indicated that paddy output in Thailand's northeast region is lower than expected because of a drought in several provinces.
The association said rice growing areas in Nakhon Ratchasima, Chaiyaphum, Khon Kaen and Mahasarakam were especially affected by low rainfalls n the second half of 1986.
It said last November that the drought reduced total national areas sown with paddy to some 8.25 mln hectares this year, down from 8.84 mln a year go.
The main crop represents about 85 pct of Thailand's paddy output

New Zealand learing house <DataBank Systems Ltd> said it will know tomorrow what services it will be able to provide during a strike by bank officers against trading banks and DataBank set for March 9 and 10.

Trading banks olled by Reuters said their ability to offer money market services during the strike depends on whether Databank remains open, and whether the banks have enough staff to process transactions.
A spokesman for the New Zealand Foreign Exchange Association said delers would be able to trade during the strike.
But the spokesman added that from March 6 to 10 te value date of currency transactions will be March 16.
Trading bank spokesmen told Reuters they will try to honour transctions in which an offshore party sought payment on March 9 or 10, but they could not guarantee settlement.
The Futures Exchange said trading members and their clients will b able to continue trading provided they have made suitable financial arrangements.
The trading banks affected are the <Bank of New Zealand>, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd <ANZA.S>, Westpac Banking Corp <WSTP.S> and <National Bank of ew Zealand Ltd>.

Hoechst AG HFAG.F> said its group pre-tax profit in 1986 would be slightly lower than the 3.16 billion marks posted in 1985, while parent company pre-tax profits rose slightly from the 1.62 billion in 1985.
Group turnover ell slightly to 38 billion marks from 42.72 billion in 1985, and parent company turnover fell to around 14 billion marks from 15.35 billion, the company said in a statement.
The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd <BRKN.S> (BHP) said it plans a renounceable one-for-three issue f rights to float a new company, <BHP Gold Mines Ltd> (BHPGM), which will hold most of BHP's gold interests.
In a statement BHP said the 25-cent ar rights would be priced at 50 cents for 430 mln of the BHPGM shares on offer.
BHP will subscribe for the remaining 540 mln shares, or 56 pct of issued capital, on the sae terms.
BHPGM will pay 440 mln dlrs for BHP's gold interests, excluding its stake in Papua New Guinea's <O Tedi Mining Ltd> and those interests held by BHP's <Utah International Inc>.
The BHP statement said the issue will be mae to shareholders registered on March 27.
It opens April 4 and closes April 29, an is underwritten by <J.B.
Were and Son>
Rights will be traded on Australian stock excanges from March 23 to April 22, and the new shares will be quoted from June 4.
BHP said the new company will be ne of Australia's larger gold producers, with annual output exceeding 170,000 ounces.
It said there are plans to boost production to 300,000 ounces by he early 1990s.
BHPGM's portfolio will include several Australian mines -- 30 pct of Telfer, 100 pct of Ora Banda and Browns Creek and 20 pct of the ew Boddington development.
The statement said BHPGM would also hold BHP's 45 pct stake in the Coronation Hill Proerty in the Northern Territory, and its 55 pct stake in a new venture near Gympie, Queensland.
BHPGM chairman-designate John Gough sad it was a quality gold stock.
"The diversity and depth of BHP Gold's portfolio ... Gie the company a sound foundation in current gold production and an exciting potential for growth," he said.

The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp <HKBH.HK> is likely to show a rise in profit of between 10 and 13 pct for 1986 reflecting stronger than expected loan growth, share analysts polled by Reuters said.
Their estimates of the bank's net earnings for last year ranged frm 2.99 to 3.1 billion H.K.
esults will be announced on Tuesday.
he 1985 net profit was 2.72 billion.
They orecast a final dividend of 29 cents for a total of 42 cents for the year against 38 cents in 1985, adjusted for a one-for-five bonus issue.
Analysts aid they expected the bank to recommend a bonus issue this year, probably one for three or one for five.
The ank's 61.5 pct subsidiary Hang Seng Bank Ltd <HSGH.HK> is to report its 1986 results on Friday.
Analysts expect Hang Seng to announce net profit o more than one billion dlrs for the first time, an increase of 10 to 12 pct.
They expect Hang Seng to pay a final diviend of 1.37 dlrs for a total of 1.75 dlrs for the year against 1.60 in 1985.

Analysts said that while the use of undisclosed inner reserves by banks here makes forecasting very imprcise, Hongkong Bank benefited from the unexpected strength of the Hong Kong economy in 1986, when gross domestic product grew by nearly nine pct against an initial forecast of 4.5 pct.
"They benefited considerably from the pickup in loan deand, as their loan portfolio is well balanced," an analyst at Mansion House Securities (F.E.)
Government figures show that total loans and advances rose by 138 pct in 1986, compared with a 4.5 pct increase in 1985.
Loans to finance Hong Kong's visible trade, the mainstay of te local economy, rose by 15.1 pct against a decline of five pct in 1985.
Low interest raes also helped the bank.
Interest received on loans was low, with the prime rate a 6.5 pct at end-1986, but interest paid on savings was two pct.
Hongkong Bank and Hang Seng Bank control half of all deposts in the banking system, giving them access to a large base of low-cost funds.
The strength of the real-estate market was another majo income source for the bank group.
Loans to finance property development and instalment mortgages ose sharply.
"The Hongkong Bank group is still the leader in mortgage business despite tough competition from the ank of China group and other foreign banks," one analyst said.
The high level of activity on the capial and equities markets in 1986 contributed to a sharp improvement in Hongkong Bank subsidiaries Wardley Ltd <WAIA.HK> and <James Capel and Co>, analysts said.
"Wardley had a tremendous year acting as financial advier and underwriter," an analyst said.
Wardley was underwriter for last year's billion-dlr flotation of <Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd>, of which Hongkon Bank owned 30 pct at the time.
The bank's stake has since been cut to 16.4 pct in return for 1.57 billion dlr.
It also sold its entire 48.8 pct stake in <South China Morning Post Ltd>, the larer of two English-language daily newspapers here, for 1.18 billion dlrs.
The proceeds will go to reserves for acquisitions and will not show up in the proit and loss accounts, analysts said.
Analysts said the bank had also been helped by a reduced need to write off bd debts.

"The need for provisions was much lower than the year before," said Tony Measor of Hong Leong Secuities Co Ltd. "Last year's profits should have been 2.8 to 2.9 billion dlrs if not for the huge provisions."
Former Hongkong Bank chairman Michael Sandberg said the bak wrote off hundreds of millions of dollars against its shipping exposure in 1985.
Lesley Nickolds of County Securities Asia Ltd said se saw no major shipping writeoffs in 1986.
She forecast profit of 2.99 billion dls.
The bank's Latin American exposure, mainly through its 51pct owned Marine Midland Banks Inc <MM>, appears to have improved substantially, analysts said.
Marine idland's 1986 fourth-quarter loan-loss provisions fell to 44.1 mln U.S. Dlrs from 89.2 mln a year before.
Its 1986 net profit rose to 145 mln U.S. Dlrs from 125 mln n 1985.
The irectors of Hughes Tool Co <HT> said they would recommend to shareholders that they reject a merger with Baker International Corp <BKO> today.
Hughes vice-president Ike Kerridge said the recommendation wuld be put to shareholders at a meeting scheduled for 10 A.M. Local time (1600 GMT) to discuss the proposed merger.
Kerridge said the bard met yesterday to discuss the merger but decided against it.
The Hughes board objected to a U.S. Deprtment of Justice requirement that Baker sell off several specialised subsidiaries in businesses related to oil-drilling.
The Hughes board last week indicated that t might cancel the merger because of the Department of Justice requirement.
The board of directors of the California-based Baker had approved th merger.
O February 17 Baker said it had signed an agreement to sell one of the subsidiaries.
The companies had been given until April 22 to compy with the Justice Department requirement, Kerridge said.
The Bank of Japan will sell tomorrow 500 billion yen of financing bills it holds to help absob a projected money market surplus, money market traders said.
Of the otal, 300 billion yen will yield 3.9989 pct on the sales from money houses to banks and securities houses in 27-day repurchase agreement, due April 2.
The remaining 00 billion yen will yield 3.9994 pct in a 39-day repurchase pact maturing on April 14, they said.
The repurchase areement yields compare with the 4.0625 pct one-month commercial bill discount rate today and the 4.50/43 pct rate on one-month certificates of deposit.
Tomorrow's surplus n the money market is estimated at 420 billion yen, mainly due to payment of national annuities, money traders said.
The operation will ut the outstanding bill supply at about 1,300 yen.
McDonalds Corp is raising 75 mln Australian dllars through a 14-5/8 pct bullet eurobond priced at 101-1/4 and maturing November 5, 1991, lead manager Bayerische Vereinsbank AG said.
Investors will pay for the bond on ay 5, 1987 and the bond pays annual interest on November 5, beginning in 1988.

Gunze Sangyo Inc of Tokyo is launching a 25 mln Swiss franc convertible notes issue due May 31, 1992 with a coupon indication of 1-5/8 pct, lead manager Swiss Volksbank sai.
Conditions will be set on March 11 ad payment date is March 30.

Group shr 18.34 yen vs 58.72 Net 10.73 billion yen vs 37.06 billion Pretax 27.76 billion yen vs 84.78 billion Operating 30.06 billion yen vs 88.81 billion Sals 889.22 billion vs 955.78 billion Note - The company attributed the profit fall largely to the yen's appreciation during the period.

Oesterreichische Draukraftwerke AG of Klagenfurt is launching a 100 mln Swiss franc 4-3/4 pct 10-year bond pricd at 100-1/4 pct, lead manager Swiss Bank Corp said.

The highly visible drama involving the yen's sharp rise against the U.S. Dollar is obscuring the fact that the Japanese currency has hardly budged against major European currencies, thus creating a new set of exchange rate distortions, Japanese and European reseach officials said.

The officials, looking beneath the rhetoric of statements by the Group of Five (G-5) industrial nations, told Reuters the currency movements of the past two years are also creating a fundamentally new world trade picture, which is throwing up new trde tensions and imbalances.
Trade figures how that the new currency alignments are already changing the Japan-U.S. Trade axis into a Japan- European Community (EC) axis, to the discomfort of Europe.

In many ways, not least n terms of rare international cooperation, the September, 1985 New York Plaza pact between the U.S., Japan, West Germany, Britain and France to cut down the value of the dollar was a historic one.

But it is the underlying eaks and troughs of the major currency movements which lay bare the real picture, in which the Plaza pact appears as an event of prime importance, but not necessarily central significance, the officials said.
The officials sad that when the Plaza agreement took place, the dollar was already on its way down.
The agreement simply helped i on its way.
Senior EC financial expert in Tokyo Tomas de Hora ha watched the movements closely.
"You have to look at the dollar's peak compared wih now, and that was well before Plaza," he said.
On February 25, 1985, the dollar peaked against the ye at 263.15 yen.
On September 20, the Friday before Plaza, it was 24.
Since then, despite massive Bank of Japan intervention and periodic market frights about furher G-5 concerted action, the dollar trend has been down, down, down.
et the ECU is now around 173.4 yen.
he historical cross rates for sterling and the mark tell much the same story.
he European currencies are moving back up against the yen.
he close relationship between exchange rates and trade flows makes it difficult to see which is driving which, but undoubtedly the trade equation between the big three is changing.
n 1986, Japanese imports and exports with the EC both grew by around 50 pct in dollar terms, five pct in yen.
This gave Japan a 16 bilion dlr trade surplus.
Last January, Japanese exports to the EC totalled half of o sales to the U.S, against about a third in recent years.
Trade with the U.S in 1986 rose 23 pct for exports and 12 pct for imports in dollar terms, but fel 13 pct for exports and 21 pct for imports in yen terms.
"The basic meaning for Europe is that Japanese firms have a tremendous interest in exporting to Europe, where every unit sod maximises profits in yen terms, which is what is important to them.
Suddenly, instead of the U.S., It is Europe that is laing the golden egg," said de Hora.
The EC is worrie.
EC business also had a remarkable year in Japanese sales, but this can be explained partly due to its start from a small base, compared with total Japan-.S. Trade.
The Japanese think EC firms are now more competitive thn U.S. Firms, a factor which is aggravating the exchange rate imbalance, and which will cause problems.
"This currency alignment between Japan and the EC is reflcting the excellent performance of the EC countries.
But therefore, Japanese goods may keep their price competitive ede," said Azusa Hayashi, Director of the First International Economic Affairs Division of the Foreign Ministry.
"If you want my objective view, I don't expect a drastic improvement in our trae imbalance.
Last year, we asked for moderation in exports, and this year we may have t do so again," he said.
Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Treasurer Paul Keating said the government's 1986/87 Budget defcit could hit four billion dlrs against the official forecast of 3.5 billion.
Hawke told a Sydney radio station the deficit "may urn out at four billion."
He and Keating last week warned that the budget deficit was running above target and vowed sharp decisions on pending in a May 14 economic statement.
A four billion dollar Budget deficit would be in line with private economists' forecasts and compares with a 1985/86 hortfall of 5.73 billion dlrs.
Hawke said the 1986/87 deficit would be equal to 1.5 pct of forecast Gross Domestic Product against five pct hen he took office during the 1982/83 year.
"In money term (the deficit has been reduced) from the 9.6 billion dlrs that we inherited ... Down to about 3.6 billion, it may turn out at four billion dlrs," Hawke said.
In a separate interview Keating said: "The deficit for this yer, projected, was 3.5 billion ....
t is in fact running ... Over four billion and we will be trying to bring that in close to target."

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia s issuing a novel 100 mln Australian dlr eurobond due April 6, 1992 paying an initial coupon of 16 pct and priced at 101 pct, lead manager Swiss Bank Corporation International said.
The coupon will then be re-fixed annually at the oe-year Australian Treasury rate.
There will also be an investor put option annually t par.
The selling concession is 3/4 pct while management and underwritng combined pays 3/8 pct.
The non-callable bond is guaranteed by Australia and will e listed in Luxembourg.
It is aailable in denominations of 1,000 and 10,000 Australian dlrs and the payment date is April 6.
Thailand exported 1,816 tonnes of tin metal in January, up from 1,731 in December and 1,330 a year ago, the Mineral Resorces Department said.
It said major buyers last month were Singapore, Japan, Britin, the Netherlands, Malaysia and the U.S. REUTER 

Caisse Centrale de Credit Cooperatif is lunching a privately-placed 1.2 billion franc bond issue in three tranches of 400 mln francs and with maturities of seven, eight, and ten years respectively, lead-managers Credit Lyonnais and Banque Francaise de Credit Cooperatif said.
Interest on the three variable-rate tranches isued at par will be based on annualised money market rates (TAM) for the February preceeding each payment.
The setlement date is March 23 1987.
The Bank of England said it ad invited an early round of bill offers from the discount houses.
The Bank forecast he shortage in the system today at around 1.15 billion stg.
Among the main factors affecting liquidity, bills maturing in official hands and the take-up of treasury bills will drain some 732 mln stg and exchequer transactions som 245 mln.
In addition, bankers' balances below target and a rise in note circulation will dran a further 135 mln stg and 30 mln stg respectively.

The Belgo-Luxembourg Economic Union (BLEU) moved into a narrow trade surplus of 4.7 billion francs in 1986 after a 140.4 billion franc deficit in 1985, figures givn by a spokesman for the National Statistics Institute show.
He said imports fell last year to 3,061.8 billion francs from 3,304.1 in 1985 while exports were also lower at 3,0666 billion francs against 3,163.7 billion.
In December, the BLEU had an 1.9 billion franc trade surplus after a 10.9 billion franc surplus in November and a 2.3 billion franc surplus in December 1985.
The Bank of Spain said it raised the reserve requirement for banks and svings banks to 19 pct of deposits from 18 pct to drain excess liquidity which threatened money supply and inflation targets.
In a statement issued late last nght, the central bank said the measure would take effect from March 13.
"In recent weeks, there has been excess liquidity in the Spanish economy which, if not controlled, would threaten the monetary an inflation targets set by the government," the statement said.
Banking sources said the measure would drain about 200 billion pesets from the system.
The maximum reserve requirement allowed by law i 20 pct.
The move follows a half-point increase yesterday in the Bank of Spain's key overnight call money rate, which now stands a 13.5 pct.
At today's auction, however, the bank left th rate unchanged.

Spain's principal measure of money supply, the broad-based liquid assets in public hands (ALP), grew at annualised rae of 8.3 pct in January compared with 11.4 pct during the whole of 1986 and a target of eight pct for 1987.

Banking sources said that although the January money supply figures were good, compared with annualised rates of 139 pct in December and 10.2 pct in January 1986, ALP growth appeared to have accelerated in February, raising government concern.
Regarding inflation, recent figures hae suggested that prices were under control.

Secretary of State for Trade, Miguel Angel Fernandez Ordonez, said this week that the annualised inflation rate for February, not yet officially announced, fell to 5.5 pct from six pct in January, compared with inflation of 8.3 pct during 1986 and a government target o five pct for this year.
The state-owned Minerals and Metals Trading Corp will send a team to Japan next week to negotiate an iron ore export contract for 1987/88 beginning April 1, trade sources sad.
Japan, the biggest buyer of Indian iron ore with imports of around 23 mln tonnes a year, has asked Inia to reduce prices from the current average of 18 dlrs a tonne, the sources said.
"Japan has said it may be forced to reduce ore imports from India next year if New Delhi fails t reduce the price," one source said, but declined to give further details.

Japanese reditor banks are close to a decision to jointly establish an offshore firm to which they will transfer part of their title to possibly unrecoverable debts owed by developing nations, international financial sources told Reuters.
etails of the deal are likely be decided next week and the firm set up before the end of the month, they said.
The cheme is intended to improve financial management at the banks and reduce the risk of problems in the event of debts turning bad, the sources said.

Last week's nnouncement by Brazil that it would indefinitely suspend interest payments on an estimated 68 billion dlrs owed to commercial banks prompted Japanese creditors to finalise the project, the sources said.
Major apanese banks have been considering a plan to avoid a debt crisis since the start of the year, they said.
There re likely to be at least 10 participating banks, and perhaps as many as 28, they said.
About 30 Japanese commercial bnks have outstanding loans totalling over 10 billion dlrs to Brazil, accounting for about 15 pct of all commercial loans to that country.
The most likely venue or the envisaged firm is the Caribbean tax haven of the Cayman Islands, the sources said.
The idea is to ceate a pool of funds in the firm with participating creditor banks holding the firm's stock.
The firm will then se the funds to buy from its stock-holding banks title to repayments of specified foreign loans which are potentially bad, the sources said.
The stock-holding bnks will draw up a list of such loans.
Subject to the scheme would be loans extended to debtridden countries such as Mexico and Argentina, they said.
The financial sourcs said interest payments to the firm would not be taxed because of its location.
Japanese banks have asked the finance ministry to increase tax breaks on loan loss reserves, but the mnistry has not yet complied.
A senior mnistry official welcomed the scheme and said it may encourage new lending to developing countries.

The ministry instructs banks to establish reserves for up to five pct of their loans to 35 financially troubled countries, but it only grants tax breaks on reserves accounting for one pct of the loans

The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has not yet set a car export quota or <Daihatsu Motor Co Ltd> which is scheduled to start exports to the U.S. Later this year, a ministry official said.
Several local newspapers said the ministry had set a quota of about 1,000 cars.
Daihatsu is owned 1.1 pct by Toyota Motor Corp <TOYO.T>.
Quotas for nine car makers, including Daihatsu, re likely to be set before the end of March, the official said.
CSR Lt <CSRA.S> said it will sell its head office group of five buildings in central Sydney as part of plans to decentralise.
The ,750 square metre site will be repurchased under existing lease-back agreements and then sold by public tender, it said in a statement.
CSR's sugar and oi divisions have already moved to Brisbane and the company said it plans further moves from central Sydney to reduce its head office staff to about 100 from 550.
Iran said its troops repulsed heavy Iraqi counter-attacks and continued their adance through the rugged mountains of Iraqi Kurdistan in overnight fighting on the northern war front.
Iran launched the new offensive, codenamed Karbala-7, on Tuesday night among te snow-capped peaks of the Haj Omran border area of northeast Iraq.
The Iranian news agency IRNA, received in London, said the troops "contnued their successful advance ... With more thrusts into enemy positions."
It said "remnants of Iraqi Brigade 604 was shattered and 200 o its personnel killed or wounded."
One battalion of the 25th Division's Third Brigade thrown into counter-attacks toay suffered 70 pct losses, the agency added.
Some 208 prisoners of wr had been taken from the front.
IRNA said the Iranian forces backed by heavy artillery fire were continuing t advance.
No Iranian casulties were given.
The area between Haj Omran and the Kurdish town o Rawandiz some 65 km inside Iraq was the scene of heavy fighting in 1983.
Iran has backed dissident Kurds in the area in attack on government positions and installations in northern Iraq.
IRNA said the Iranian forces captured large amounts of munitions in the laest fighting.
The Iraqis have made no comment so far on the Kurdistan fighting, or on advances Tehran reported yesterday on the southern war front east of te strategic Iraqi port of Basra.
IRNA said today a group of its reporters visited newly-captured areas on the southern front and found the battlefield littered with the bodies of Iraqi soldirs and burnt military equipment.
They quoted an Iranian soldier, Hamid Dehqani, as saying heavy rainfall during the past few days "had paralysed the Iraqi enemy from embarking on any action against the attacking Iranians.
IRNA referred to the "Fish Canal" -- the man-made Fish Lake -- made by the Iraqis as a defensive barrier on the eastern side of te Shatt al-Arab waterway.
The agency yesterday said infantry and armour of the Revolutionary Guards had captured strong defences west of the canal in bitter fighting with Iraqi troops
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a new high of more than 51 billion U.S. Dlrs on March 4, compared with 50 billion in mid-February ad 25.1 billion a year earlier, the central bank said.
Bank governor Chang Chi-Cheng told reporters the increase came mainly from the bank's purchases of more than one billion U.S. Dlrs on the local interbnk market between February 18 and March 4.
He said the rise showed signs of slowing, however, because Taiwan has liberaised import policy and expects its trade surplus to decline over the next few months as a result.
Chang declined to predict how high the reserves might rise, but local economsts have forecast they will hit 60 billion U.S. Dlrs by the end of 1987.
In January, Taiwan reduced import tariffs of up to 50 pct on som 1,700 foreign products.
It had been under growing U.S. Pressure to cut its 1986 recod 13.6 billion dlr trade surplus with the U.S. Taiwan's 1985 surplus with the U.S. Was 10.2 billion, according to official statistics.
Wang Chang-Ming, Vice Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, told Reuters the government is planning another roun of deep tariff cuts in the second half of this year.
The reserves could support imports of more than two years for Taiwan, compared with about three months for Japan an the U.S. REUTER 

Mitsui and Co Ltd said it plans to issue 300 mln Eurodollar warrant bonds in two tranches with payment on March 30 through a syndicate led by Nomura International Ltd. One tranche is of five-year, 150 mln dlr bonds while the rest is of seven-year, 150 mln dlr bonds, but other issue terms have not yet ben decided.
A limited Belgian issue of silver Ecu coins with a face value of five Ecus will go on sale from March 23 at a price of 500 Belgian francs each, a Finance Ministry spokesman said
Gold Ecu coins with a fce value of 50 Ecus will be sold from the same day.
The spokesman told Reuters the price for these would be fixed just before they go on sale but was likely to be between 8,500 an 9,000 francs.
At least two mln silver coins and several hundreds of thousands of the gold coins will be minted, h said.
They will be sold boh in Belgium and abroad.
The coins will be the first ever denominated in the Ecu, the "basket" comprised of the 12-nation European Community's currencies except the Spanish peseta an the Portuguese escudo.
The issue is being made to mark the 30th anniversary of the EC's founding Treaty of Rome this mont.

Finance Minister Mark Eyskens, who currently presides over the EC's council of economic and finance ministers, has called the issue a political act of symbolic value whih aimed to make the Community's goal of monetary integration more concrete.
The coins will be legal tender in Belgium but most demand is expected t come from coin collectors.
The Bank of England said it provided just 17 mln stg assistance to te money market in response to an early round of bill offers.
Earlier, the Bank had estimated the shortage in the system today at around 1.1 billion stg.
he central bank purchased bills for resale to the market on April 2 at an interest rate of 10-15/16 pct.
he Chinese state-owned Bank of Communications Ltd Hong Kong branch is planning a 200 mln H.K.
lr certificate of deposit issue, banking sources said.
hey said the five year issue, which matures March 23, 1992, carries a 7.05 pct coupon payable quarterly.
Management fee is 1 basis points.
Payment date is Marh 23.
China Development Finance C (H.K.)
Ltd, a Bank of China unit, is lea manager of the issue.

The Rank Organisation Plc said it has appointed County Natwest Capital Markets Ltd, Smuel Montagu and Co Ltd and Swiss Bank Corporation International as dealers in a 100 mln stg commercial paper program.
The notes will be issued in ny maturity of between seven and 364 days and the funds will be used for the company's general financing requirements.
Arranger for the facility is County Ntwest Capital Markets Ltd while National Westminster Bank Plc will act as issuing and paying agent, Rank added.

The French sugar market intervention board, FIRS, raised its estimate of 1986/87 beet sugar production in the 12-member European Community to 13.76 mln tonnes white equivalent in its end-February reprt from 13.74 mln a month earlier.
Its forecast for total EC sugar production, including cane and molasses, rose to 14.10 mn tonnes from 14.09 mln.
Portugal, which joined the Community in January 1986, was estimated at 12.75 mln tonnes whie equivalent, unchanged from the previous forecast and compared with 12.41 mln tonnes for 1985/86.
Production for the current campaign in Spain was higher than reported last month at 1.0 mln tonnes compared with 997,000 tonnes.

Beet sugar production, expressed as white equivalent, was estimated at 3.44 mln tonnes in France, 3.17 mln tonnes in West Germany, 1.72 mln in Itay, 1.30 mln in Britain, 1.22 mln in the Netherlands, 936,000 tonnes in Belgium/Luxembourg, 499,000 in Denmark, 287,000 in Greece, 183,000 in Ireland and 4,000 in Portugal.

Sri Lanka's largest bank, the government-owned Bank of Ceylon, plans to adopt a more aggressive and selective interest rate policy to reduce excess liquidity, estimaed at some 500 mln rupees, and enlarge the country's export manufacturing base, the bank's new chairman Nimal Sandaratne told Reuters in an interview.
The bank aims to reduce terms for pime customers and is holding talks with the Export Development Board on details to be announced later, he said.
Sandaratne was head of research at the Cntral Bank of Ceylon, the nation's central bank, until January.
A Swiss-based non-governmental group, which Sandaratne declined o identify, has agreed in principal to guarantee export credits, he said, but refused to elaborate further.

The bank may also consider more actively participating in the foreign exchange markets in light of its substantial non-resident foreign currency holdings of about 473 mln rupees, or abot 70 pct of the total market, he said.
Sandaratne said the bank may sell 60 pct of is shares in its wholly-owned subsidiary, Merchant Bank of Sri Lanka Ltd.
The Asian Development Bank and a foreign bank operating hee have already expressed interests in acquiring a stake in MBSL, Sandaratne said.
He tentatively estimated the Bank of Ceylon's net profits fr calendar 1986 at 163 mln rupees up from 133 mln the previous year.
The increase was eroded b increased provisions for bad debts, he said.
About 50 mln was written off ad 17 mln allotted for general provisions, he added.
The Papua New Guinea Government will establish a public corporation to invest i resources projects, Minerals and Energy Minister John Kaputin said.
"We intend to provide a means through which less privileged individuals can becme part owners and beneficiaries from the development of mining and petroleum projects," he told Parliament.
Existing policy allowing the state up to 30 pct equity in major mining projects and 22.5 pct in oil an gas projects would be maintained, he said.
The planned agency could take over the state's equity n current developments.
Kaputin said Papua New Guinea was experiencing a boom with exploration companies spending about 60 mln kina annually on abou 150 mining and 23 petroleum projects.
"The Government is determined to ensure that Papua New Guinean ownership in minerals and petroleum projects increases in an ordely way," he said.

Kaputin did not ay when the corporation would be established or exactly what form it would take, but said the government would study whether it should be directly involved in exploration or development.
The igerian naira firmed 2.6 pct against the dollar after 17 banks were disqualified from bidding at today's weekly foreign exchange auction, the central bank said.
he naira finished at 3.8050 to the dollar, against 3.9050 last week.
Only 8.39 mln dlrs of the 50 mln dlrs on offer was sold, with all 27 bidding banks successfully obtaining hard currency.
The effective rate, including a central bank levy, for transactions in the coming week, was 3.8241 against 3.926 last week.
The failure to sell the whole allocation was due to the central bank's unprecedented disqualification of 17 bank as punishment for inadequate documentation in previous transactions.

Banks are required to submit proof that their bids are based on valid commercial transactions and the central bank has complained in the past that many are failing to produce the right paperwork within th specified time.
Canada Zero, a sole purpose company incorporated in the Cayman Islands, is issuing a zero coupon eurobond with a total redemption amount of 150 mln Canadian dlr, lead manager CIBC Ltd said.
The issue matures on May 1, 2001 and is priced at 3 pct.
It is secured with Canadian governent bonds.
The selling concession is 3/4 while management and underwriting each pay 1/ pct.
The payment date is April 30
Listing is in Luxemburg.
A CIBC spokesmn said the issue yields 49 basis points over equivaent Canadian Treasury bonds.
