Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) on Tuesdayhose former Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita to b the next prime minister, replacing Yasuhiro Nakasone whose term ends on October 30.
LDP officials told Reuters the choice was made by Nakasone after Takeshita and to other contenders failed in marathon closed-door meetings to agree who should be Japan's next leader.
They were vying for the presidency of the LDP, a post which automatically caries with it the premiership by virtue of the party's parliamentary majority.

The Louvre accord on currency stability, which has maintained an uneasy calm in currency markets since last February, appeared in serious danger today as a transatlantic dispute over West German interest rates cme to the boil, foreign exchange dealers said.

But as the dollar slid against the mark and world stock and bond markets plunged, officials in the major industrial countries played down the dispute as a bilateral problem between the United Stats and West Germany and insisted that the currency pact was still alive.
U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker sparked the market fears when he attacked the rise in West Germn short-term interest rates.
"That's not in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to as recently as earlier this month i Washington," Baker said in a U.S. Television interview on Sunday.
He was referring to the meetings of Finance Ministers from the Group of Seven (G7) leading industrial nations whic reaffirmed the pact.
Under the Louvre Accord West Germany and Japan, who both have large trade surpluses, pledged to boost their economi growth to take in more exports from the U.S., While the U.S.
Agreed to stop talking th dollar down.
However, Baker said on Saturday that while the Louvre agreement was still operative, the West German interest rate move would force the U.S. T re-examine the accord.
"The foreign exchange market has been told by Baker that he's going to hamme Germany ...
He has just declared all bets are off in terms of currency cooperation," Chris Johns, currency analyst at UBS-Phillips and Drew in London sai.

But a Bank of Japan official took a much more sanguine view, telling Reuters that "the exchange market is apparently reacting too much, and anyone who sol the dollar on the Baker comment will regret it later on."
French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur, who hosted the Louvre meeting, was the only one of the G7 Finance Ministers to respond directly to Bakers remarks.
e called for "a faithful and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
Neither the West German Finance Ministry nor the British Treasury commented on he row.
ut a Japanese Finance Ministry official said that despite U.S.
rustration over higher interest rates abroad, "this does not represent its readiness to scrap the basic framework of the Louvre Accord."

In Frankfurt F. Wilhelm Christians, joint chief executive of West Germany's largest bank, Deutsche Bank, said that following recent meetings with Baker, he believed that the U.S. Was still committd to the accord.

In a move which the market interpreted as a possible gesture of reconciliation, the Bundesbank added short-term liquidity to the West German money market at 3.80 pct on Monday, dow from the 3.85 pct level at which it injected medium-term liquidity last week.
The Bank of France also stepped into the French money market to hold down rats, injecting short-term liquidity at 7-3/4 pct after rates rose close to eight pct.

The Bundesbank will not hold a news conference after its regular fortnightly central bank council meeting on Thursday a spokesman said in answer to enquiries.
The council is meeting in West Berlin, where i meets once a year.
It also meets once a year in another Germn city.
These meetings outside Frankfurt are traditionally followd by a news conference.
The spokesman declined to comment furter.
In Bonn a finance ministry spokesman said Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg would take part in the meeting in West Berli.
His participation was arranged log ago, he added.

A shareholder group led by Barris Industries Inc <BRSS.O> said it acquired a 9.8 pct stake in Media General Inc Class A common stock ad may seek seek contorl of the company.

Mining group Boliden AB said it had agreed with Saudi state agency General Petroleum and Mineral Organisation (Petromin) to opn a gold mine in Saudi Arabia to exploit one of the world's richest deposits of the metal.
Boliden spokesman Goran Paulson told Reuters the Swedish group wold be responsible for the technical side of the operation and would have no control over the product itself.
He said one option under discussion for refining the god ore would be to ship it to Boliden's Ronnskar copper smelter in northern Sweden.
Paulson eclined to give a figure for the deal but said it was strategically important since it increased Boliden's presence in Saudi Arabia.
"Representatives rom Petromin have visited Ronnskar already...We see Saudi Arabia as the expansion area of the future," he said.

The new ine, which is being developed at Mahd adh Dhahab in the west of the country and should open in the first half of 1988, would have an annual output of about 3,000 kilos of gold smelted from around 120,000 tons of ore, he said.
Boliden lready owns 50 pct of a gold ore deposit in Saudi Arabia, but the new venture will be the first Saudi mine to open in modern times.
"This s a breakthrough for Boliden's sales of mining technology and knowhow," said the group's chief executive, Kjell Nilsson.

ang Laboratories Inc announced four additions to its VS line of minicomputers which it said will offer double the capacity of the older models they replace.
ompany officials told a news conference that Wang will also announce new entry level and high end computers within the next 12 months and a family of powerful work stations by the end of this year.

an Diery, Wang's senior vice president of U.S. operations, said the new models are lower priced than comparable computers from Digital Equipment Corp <DEC>, the world's largest maker of minicomputers.
inicomputers are medium sized machines usually used within a department or work group of a larger company and typically cost between 10,000 and 500,000 dlrs.
The VS 5E will replace Wang's entry level VS 5
Priced at 13,000 dlrs, it can support up to 16 users, double the eight supported by the five and has three times the disc capacity of the oder system.
The VS 6E can support up to 32 users, double the capacity of the model six it replaces, and has three times the storage capacity of the oder model.
The 6E is priced at 22,000 drs.
The VS 75E, which relaces the 65, can support 64 users, 60 pct more than the older model and has twice the main memory capacity.
It s priced at 44,000 dlrs.
The new VS 7010, which acts as an entry level system for Wan's more powerful 7000 family of minicomputers, can support between 30 and 55 users.
It is priced a 75,000 dlrs.
All the new systems are now availale, Diery said.

Bob Ano, Wang's senior vice president of corporate marketing, said that before the end of the company's fiscal year on June 30 it will introduce a entry level computer that will have four times the power of the 5E introduced today.
Within the next 12 to 18 months, e said, Wang will announce a more powerful high-end machine that will offer double the price/performance of its 7000 series.
Ano said the new family of work staions planned for this year will have a 32-bit semiconductor and be able to support the industry standard MS-DOS and UNIX operating systems.

Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman David Ruder said a brief trading halt has been disussed as one way of restoring order to the stock market, but stressed he is not recommending one at present.
Speaking to reporters, Ruder said he has been in frequent contact with Nw York Stock Exchange Chairman John Phelan about the market's record drop today.

"I'm not afraid to say that there is some point, and I don't know what that point is, that I would be quite anxious to tal to the New York Stock Exchange about a very temporary halt in trading," Ruder said.
Ruder, who spoke to reporters after addressing an American Stock Exchange-sponsored investors' confernce here, said that the SEC does not have the legal authority to order a trading halt.
Any trading halt, which would probably last no more than a half-hour, woud have to be approved by the stock exchanges, Ruder said.

British Sugar Plc was forced to shut its Ipswich sugar factory on Sundy afternoon due to an acute shortage of beet supplies, a spokesman said, responding to a Reuter inquiry Beet supplies have dried up at Ipswich due to a combination of very wet weather, which has prevented most farmers in the factory's catchment area from harvesting, and last week's hurricane which blocked roads.
The Ipswich factory ill remain closed until roads are cleared and supplies of beet build up again.
This is the first time in many years that a factory has been closed in mid-campaign, the spokesma added.
Other factories are continuig to process beet normally, but harvesting remains very difficult in most areas.
Ipswich is one of 13 sugar factories operated y British Sugar.
It processes in excess of 500,000 tonnes of beet a year out of an annual beet crop f around eight mln tonnes.

Despite the closure of Ipswich and the severe harvesting problems in other factory areas, British Sugar is maintaining its estimate of sugar production this campaign at around 1.2 mln tonnes, white value, against 1.34 mln ast year, the spokesman said.
British Sugar processes all sugar beet grown in th U.K.
The sugar beet processing campaign, which began last month, is expected to run until the end of Jnuary.
Sugar factories normally work 24 hours a day seven days a week during the campaign.
As of October 11, 12 pct of the U.K. Sugar crop had been harvested, litle different to the same stage last year when 13 pct had been lifted.
Since then, however, very wet weather has severel restricted beet lifting.
Harvesting figures for the week to October 1 are not yet available.

In a suit filed in U.S. District Court, International Mutifoods said Bregman Partners and its affiliates, who reportedly hold 7.4 pct of the company's shares, tried to induce Multifood's management to join them in an effort to take the company private and give controlling interest to Bregman Partners.
Bregman Partners includ the interests of the Belzberg families of Canada.
The complaint also discloses that on each occasion, Multifoods management rejected the group' overtures.
Multifoods is asking Bregman's group to divest its shares in open market sales in a manner not to further disrupt the market place, according to he suit.
The suit seeks compensatory and punitive damages in an amount to be deermined.
In addition, Multifoods is seeking to stop Bregman Partners from acquiring any more stock, or voting the shares it reportedl owns, the suit said.
According to Multifoods, the actions proposed by Bregman Partners would prevent shareholders from realizing the full benefits of the compan's restructuring.

In the past three years, Multifoods has substantially altered its domestic business mix by divesting its U.S. consumere foods operation and emphasizing growth in selected segments of the U.S. foodservice industry.

<Salomon Brothers Inc> is not withdrawing as a maket maker in euroyen bonds, contrary to strong market rumours circulating in London, a London-based spokeswoman for the company's New York headquarters said.
Earlier, a spokesman for Salomon Brothers' London operations declned to comment at all on rumours that have been circulating here.
Euroyen bond traders had said they were informally contcted by their counterparts at Salomon and told that they would no longer be market makers in those securities.
The traders said that Salomon had not notified the Association of International Bond Dealers (AIBD) of its plan to withdraw as a market maker.
Under new rules recently adopted by the AIBD, notification would be required if the firm decided it n longer wished to make two-way prices at all times in euroyen bonds.
According to dealers at several Japanese banks, Salomon's euroyen bond traders have been in a meeting and unavailale to make prices.
Market sources said that Salomon had offered the traders a chance to remain with the firm if thy were willing to trade eurobonds denominated in other currencies.

Dealers noted that at one point this year, euroyen bond issuance had actually outpaced that of eurodollar denominated bonds, the first time the U.S. Unit has been eclipsed a the currency of choice for international borrowers.
Dealers said that given the dollar's recent weakness, the yen could once again top te eurobond issuance tables.
Last week, Salomon Brothers announced it would trim its worldwide staff by 800 and withdra from several areas of business, most specifically short term bank lending.

The Canadian division of General Motors Corp will mae its first economic offer later Monday in contract negotiations with 40,000 members of the Canadian Auto Workers, the union said.

The union is seeking the same contract pattern it has reached at the Canadian units of Fod Motor Co and Chrysler Corp including partial pension indexation and wage increases in each year of a three-year pact.
The union hareatened to strike at 10 a.m. EDT on Thursday unless General Motors of Canada Ltd meets the pattern and settles a host of locl issues at 11 plants in Quebec and Ontario.
West German government sources said Bonn remained committed to the Louvre Accord t stabilise currencies, which was struck by leading western democracies in Paris last February.
Over the weekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker criticised recent rises in Wes German short-term interest rates and said such developments were not in the spirit of the Louvre pact.
He said he agreement may have to be re-examined.
The sources said the West Grman interest rate rises had to be seen in the context of interest rate developments worldwide.
The recent sharp rise in U.S. interest rates sparked turmoil in the fixed-income markets, but underwriters said they doubt company treasuers will rush to borrow before rates increase further.
"Corporate treasurers will continue to issue new debt when they believe they are borrowing at an attractive rate," said an underwrite with a major Wall Street house.
Said another, "We will not see a flood of new offerigs.
Treasurers are reassessing the markt.
We will no see new issuance dry up either."
Still, the pace of corporate borowing in the public finance market has slowed, according to a Reuter tabulation.
Last week, which was shortened y the Columbus Day holiday, saw issuance of 1.3 billion dlrs of new debt.
That was down from the prio week's tally of slightly more than two billion dlrs of new debt.

In contrast, a year ago it was not unusual to see those amounts of new offerings in a single day as companies took advantage of the then decline i interest rates to refinance old, higher-cost debt or to expand operations via financings at low, attractive rates, underwriters noted.
"Companies will conduct financings that they believe are essential," said an underwriter with a medium-ized Wall Street firm.
"But we will not see much more tha that until the market stabilizes."
In the meantime, treasurers will probably prefer shoter term issues, analysts said.
For instance, of last week's nine issues, only one had a maturity of more than 10 year.
The other offerings had maturities of two to seven years, with most clustered in the two t three year area, according to a Reuter tabulation.
That is because single-digit interest rates were had las week only among two-year securities.
"If people think that interest rates will continue to head higher, then we could see treasurers rushng to market," said a trader with a medium-sized securities house.

"But if people think last week's sharp interest rate rise is a fluke, treasurers will sit back and wait for rates to decline before issuing new debt, hoping of course that they ar not missing the boat by doing so," she added.
Another impediment to new issuance is the lukewarm reception to new issues by institutional and retail investors n recent weeks, traders pointed out.
Many investors refrained from buying because they believed ate would rise further.
"We saw a lot of buying interest last week, but people are not yet willing to pull th trigger," a broker said.
"They would rather wait and see if the recet rate increase can be sustained."
Conflicting forecasts on the likely direction of interest rates did not hlp, analysts said.

For instance, Henry Kaufman, chief economist with Salomon Brothers Inc, said n his weekly "Comments on Credit" that the yields of U.S. Treasury bonds would probably rise further because the marketplace expects inflation to rise and the dollar to continue to decline.
In contrast, Standard and Poor's Crp said on Friday that prices of debt securities in the fixed-income markets would recover.
The rating agency said neither the economy nor the dollar justify curret high yields.
Meanwhile, he Chicago Board of Trade is slated to hold a press briefing on Tuesday in New York about its plans to list a futures contract based on a corporate bond index.

That ollows last week's announcement by Commodity Exchange Inc, Comex, that it plans to list on October 29 a new futures contract based on the investment-grade corporate bond index of Moody's Investors Service Inc. Reuter 

"The potential for greater interest rate rises gives s concern.

ederal funds opened at 7-5/8 pct and remained at that level late this morning, compared with an average effective rate of 7.55 pct Friday.

Industrial Equity (Pacific) added it is considering launching a tender offer for Calmat stock or making a merger proposal to the company, but said it has not decided wheher it will pursue a Calmat acquisition on a non-negotiated basis.

Industrial Equity (Pacific), which currently holds 5.83 mln Calmat common shares, said it is also evaluating the company's recently adopted shareholder rights plan and its potential effect on Calat and on possible acquisition proposals made to the company.

The increase brings West Texas Intermediate to 9.00 dlrs a barre and West Texas Sour to 18.10 dlrs a barrel.

An Iowa State University study showed pork contains considerably less fat than indicated by long-established U.S. Department of Agriculture statistics, the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) sai.
Six of the seven muscle cuts evaluated in the study averaged 4.3 pct ft or less, well below American Heart Association guidelines for recommended foods.
Eighty pct of all the raw boneless rib chops evaluated in the study contained less than six pc fat, the NPPC said.
Meanwhile, USDA Handbook 8-10 - long used as the established authority on nutrient composition, indicates a fat contnt for center loin pork of 7.3 pct, the NPPC said.
Robin Kline, a dietitian and Director of Consumer Affairs for the NPPC said he was not surprised t the wide discrepancy between the study and the USDA handbook.
"Handbook 8-10 is based to a certain extent on information that has been accumulated over the past 0 years.
The statistics in it about pork do not reflect the hog of today which is about 50 pct leaner than it was 20 or 30 yeas ago, thanks to genetic improvements and better feeding practices," Kline said.
The study, funded by NPPC with producer checkoff money, evaluated pork carcasses fro 47 Iowa producers in categories from 0.7 to 1.3 inches of backfat.
Researchers measured the fat content of the seven muscles before cooking, and te fat, moisture and tenderness of cooked boneless rib chops.
The Soviet Union outlined its economic targets for 1988 on Monday, stressing the need to improve standards in the country's sluggish engineerin industry.
Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet industrial output should rise by 4.5 pct in 1988, up from a planned 4. pct in 1987.
It rose 3.6 pct in Jan-Spt 1987.
Talyzin said national income, the nearest Soviet equivalent to gross national product, should rise by 4.3 pct against a planned 4.1 pc this year.
ross national product measures the output of a country's goods and services.
e said the Kremlin planned to produce 235 mln tonnes of grain in 1988 versus a planned 232 mln this year.
oscow produced 210 mln tonnes in 1986.
remlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described machine-builing as a sector whose rapid modernization is essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.
Certain difficulties have arisen this year in the machine-building industry.
he economy is not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires," said Talyzin, who heads the state planning committee GOSPLAN.

Soviet data show the machine-building industry, hich makes machine tools, instruments and other engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of 1987 compared with the same period last year.
However, this was ar below the 7.3 pct increase planned for the industry for the whole of 1988.
Talyzin said the uling Politburo had concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended to a large extent on conserving resources better.
"Large-scale masures are planned to save resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Gotev told the Supreme Soviet that defense spending in 1988 would total 32 billion dlrs, the same figure as was announced last year.

Western governments view official Soviet estimates for defense spending as hihly understated, but say the real figure is hard to calculate because Soviet military industries are intertwined with the civilian economy.
Talyzin said the Kremlin also decided to increase spending next yer on medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes.
The official Soviet nws agency Tass denounced a U.S.
Attack on an Iranian oil-drilling platform in the Gulf on Monday as military adventurism and said it would brin no dividends to the Reagan administration.

Tass commentator Mikhail Krutikhin said the administration had embarked on an adventurist path in order to deflect attention from the scandal in which the United States sold arms to Iran and the profits were diverted to Nicaragua rebels.
"The confrontation is a fct now.
What is obvious is that the latest military adventure will not bring political dividends to the American administration," Kruikhin said.

Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and Foreign Minster Eduard Shevardnadze abruptly left a parliamentary session earlier on Monday, sparking diplomatic speculation that they were concerned with an urgent matter of foreign affairs.
Soviet officials have previously criticized the Uited States for sending naval forces into the Gulf, saying their presence serves to increase tension.
Moscow is officially nutral in the war between Iran and Iraq.
It is a major arms supplier o Iraq but has also sought broader contacts with Iran in the last year.
Krutikhin said: "The United States has undrtaken an act of armed aggression against Iran, the probability of which has long been spoken of by Washington officials."
U.S. Energy Secretary John Herrington arived in Rabat on Monday after a tour of the Gulf and the Middle East.
Herrington, who is scheduled to met King Hassan during his 24-hour official visit, said on arrival he would discuss regional and international issues with Moroccan leaders.
Morocco is the last stop of a tour that has taen Herrington to Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and Egypt.

The International Telecommunications Union, which regulates communications worldwide, decided at the end of a five-week conference to allow mobile phone systems to be linked with satellites, telecommuncations officials said.
Until now, car phones have been linked with land stations ad have been limited mainly to urban areas.
The new ruling will make it easier for calls to be made from reote regions.

The meeting, which finished over the weekend, also decided to allow a "radio determination satellite system," which would enable fleet owners to trace to within about 15 metres the movements of ther lorries or cars or ships around the world.

CalFed Inc said strong loan olume and higher net increase income at its principal subsidiary, the California Federal Savings and Loan Association, contributed to the best third-quarter and nine-month results in the company's history.

Security Pacific Corp <SPC> said growth in its third-quarter earnings was slowed by the purchase of Rainier Bancorp and te suspension of interest payments on Brazilian and Ecuadorian loans that were placed on a non-accrual status earlier this year.

Other non-interest expense, composed of staff and other expenses, was 757.6 mln dlrs, u from 616.2 mln.

Excluding Orbanco and Arizona Bancwest, average loans grew 1 pct.

Australian Minister for Trade Negotiations Michael Duffy said his contry and Third World commodity producers have formed an effective lobby group against farm export subsidies and market access restrictions.
Duffy told a press conference the Cairns Group of 1 major agricultural producers, to which Australia and Thailand belong, has emerged as an important third force in any multilateral trade talks.

"There's no doubt that the Cairns Group is being seen as a third force to be reckoned with boh inside the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and in other international trade negotiations," he said.

Duffy, here on a three-day visit after talks in the United States, The European Community (EC) and Latin America, said considerable progress has been made by the group towards fighting costly protectionist policies pursued by develope countries.
The minister said the EC Commission's new farm trade paper will recognise the heavy financial burdens imposed by its Common Agricultural Policy and its future expansio.
He said the Reagan Administration has also displayed a determination to resist the currently strong protectionist sentiment n the U.S. Congress.
Turkey's current account deficit widened in July to 674 mln dlrs from 454 mln in June but fell from 1.2 billion in July last year, the State Statistics Institute said.
The cumulative rade position in July showed a 1.85 billion dlr deficit after 1.33 billion in June and 1.89 billion a year earlier, with exports at 4.91 billion and imports, both FOB, at 6.76 billion.
The government aims to narrow the current account deficit for the whole of 1987 to 975 mln dlrs, compared with .52 billion last year, up from 1.01 billion in 1985.
Bankers forecast the 1987 deficit will exceed one billion dlrs, because a spurt in exports is expected to slow considerably n the last five months following a massive drawdown of inventories.

Sun Microsystems Co's TOPS subsidiary said it will have upgraded versions of its NetPrint and LAN -- local area network -- softare packages available early next month.
The company said version 2.0 of its NetPrint will b available November 10 at a suggested retail price of 189 dlrs.

NetPrint is software that enables International Business Machines Corp <IBM> personal computers and compatibles print directly to Apple Computer Inc <AAPL.O> LaserWriters or other PostScript compatible printers on an ApplTalk network.

TOPS said it will begin shipping version 2.0 of its LAN software packages providing file sharing among Apple macintosh computers, IBM PCs and compatibles, and UNIX-based systems to retailers Noveber six.
It said the TOPS/DOS version 2.0, which will have a suggested reail price of 189 dlrs, allows PCs on the network to access dedicated printers fomerly availabe to only one user.
The TOPS/Macintosh version 2.0, also listed at 189 dlrs, introduces a "remeber" function that allows users to make files available to the network and access remote files automatically.
In addition, the software is nw fully compatible with all Apple File Protocol applications.
Both LAN's include FlashTalk, a recently announced PC-to-PC communications architecture that operaes at three-times TOPS' AppleTalk speed and is slated to sell for 239 dlrs.

Today's sharp sell-off of Swiss stocks and matching falls around Europe may have been overdone, bt the mood on financial markets is precarious, Swiss securities analysts and economists said.
Panic selling took Swiss shares down six pct at the opening on enormous volume, triggered b the slide on Wall Street and the threat of renewed currency instability.
"I have never experienced anything like this, and I've been i the business for 20 years," said Bernhard Wyttenbach, head of European research at Union Bank of Switzerland.
The analysts blamed the sell-off i Europe on U.S. Monetary authorities.
This weekend, U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker publicly voiced his displasure with West German monetary policy.

He said the eight-month-old Louvre accord to stabilise currencies was still working, but added: "On the other hand, w will not sit back and watch surplus countries jack up interest rates and squeeze growth on the expectation that the United States will raise rates."
Hans Peter Ast of Societe Generale Alsacienne (Sogenal) in Zuich said: "The situation is very dangerous.
Statements by te U.S.
Authorities have fulled anxiety about interest rates."

Herbert Fritschi, director of Zurich Cantonal Bank's financial research depatment, called the sell-off "overdone," but warned that the situation could worsen unless central banks loosen their monetary policy.
"I think the trend toard higher interest rates is over," he said.
"The Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank have to step in with an easy mony policy, or else there is going to be an economic catastrophe.
They have to at quickly."
Wyttenbach said the "Black Monday" sell-off was clearly exaggerated, with Swiss Reinsurance Co particpation certificates falling 20 pct in value at one point.
But Wyttenbach said he did not beleve that a correction would come soon.
First, the bad news will reach small investors only in time for tomorrow's maret, when there could be another, smaller selling wave.
"As soon as the dollar stabilises -- nd that's the key -- then we'll get a strong movement upward," Wyttenbach said.
But tat may not come soon.
"People are simply worried that in America, were the market has now fallen by 18 pct since August, the bull market is over," he said.
"People are afraid tat we'll have a recession in 1988."
Baker was wrong to blame the West German for the current problems and the weak dollar, Wyttenbach said.
"We do not have a mark problem, we have a dollar problem," he added, but said the biggest culprit was the new chairman of the U.. Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan.
Wyttenbach recalled that Greenspan had suggested that the dollar might be too high in the medium term and that interest rates might hae to rise.
"As a central banker he shouln't do that," Wyttenbach said.
"There is a danger that we will fall back into the 1970s," h said.
"We have a real crisis o confidence in Greenspan.
I would much rather have a Volckr."
Paul Volcker retired as Fed chairman on August 11
Cantonal Bank's Fritschi said: "I'm relatively optimistic because th situation looks too bad.
The Fed certainly has o intervene."
He said he did not expect the Swiss National Bank to take any significant steps, adding tat the focus of attention remains on the United States.
"The panic started in New York, it has o end there."
The Cantonal Bank sent an advisory to customers suggesting they not sell into a panicked market, but wait a whil before deciding what to do.
Soviet Planning chief Nikolai Talyzin told the Supreme Soviet (parliament) industrial output is planned to rise by 4.5 pct i 1988, up from a planned 4.4 pct in 1987.
In the first nine months o this year, industrial output rose by 3.6 pct.
Talyzin said national income, the nearest Soviet equivalent to gross national produt, is planned to rise by 4.3 pct against a planned 4.1 pct this year.
He said grain production is planned at 235 mln tonnes in 198, compared with a planned 232 mln this year.
The Soviet Union produced 210 mln tonnes of grain in 1986 ad the Soviet press has said heavy rain has affected the harvest this year.

Talyzin said the 1988 Soviet plan stressed the engineering industry, which Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev has described as a sector where rapid modernisation i essential if the Soviet Union is to compete effectively on world markets.
"Certain difficulties have arisen this yer in the machine-building industry.
The economy s not receiving a considerable amount of the equipment that it requires," said Talyzin, who heads the state planning committee Gosplan.

Soviet data show the machine-building idustry, which makes machine tools, instruments and other engineering goods, increased output by 3.3 pct in the first nine months of this year against the same period of 1986.
This is ell below the 7.3 pct rise planned for the industry for all of 1988.
Talyzin said the ruling Politburo concluded at a recent meeting that an improvement in economic performance depended to a large extent on conserving rsources better.
"Large-scale masures are planned to save resources," he said.
Finance Minister Boris Guste told the Supreme Soviet defence spending in 1988 would total 20.2 billion roubles, the same as announced last year.

Talyzin said the Kremlin also had decided to increase spending next year on medical services, education, pensions and social insurance schemes He said state expenditures in these fields would reach 171 billion roubles in 1988, or 3.5 billion roubles more than had originally been envisaged in the 186-1990 Five-Year Plan.
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) said he Kansas City Board of Trade's (KCBT) one-minute audit trail system was adequate and accurate.

American Telephone and Telegraph Co said it plans to build a new computer that incorrates a unified version of its UNIX System IV operating syste and Sun Microsystems Inc's recently annouced SPARC micropocessor.
The SPARC chip is based on reduced instruction-set computing, or RIS, technology.

ATT said the version of UNIX used by the new computer will incorporate po;ular features of the Berkeley 4.2 system, a dirative of the UNIX system used widely in scientific and engineering markets, as well as features of SunOs, a variant of th Berkely system sold by Sun.

"It's the software that will determine the availability of products based o SPARC," he said.
Eventually ATT's entire line of 3B mini computers will be converte to the SPARC architecture, Cassoni said.
The investment of all current users will be protected, meaning that they will be able to maintain the software used on the current 3 line, he said.

However, "demand for the new products is way, wa above expectation," he stated.

Autolatina, Volkswagen G <VOWG.F> and Ford Motor Co's <F> Latin American joint venture, was expected to make losses of 500 mln marks from Brazilian operations in 1987, VW spokesman Ortwin Witzel said.

ord holds 49 pct of Autolatina.

U.S. warships attacked and destroyed an Iranian oil platform on Monday in retalition for Friday's Iranian attack damaging a U.S.-flagged ship, U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said.
When asked how much was left of the oil platfor, Weinberger said, "Nothing."
"There was no Iranian reaction, he said.
"... We consider this matter is now closed.
Weinberger said four U.S. destroyers attacked the platform about 120 miles east of Bahrain in the central Gulf with fir at 0700 EDT, Weinberger said.
"We chose a platform used by the Iranians to interfere with and be a source of potential attack on convoys..," Weinberger said at a Pentagon briefing.

We know it has been used indeed, to not only launch small boat attacks on shipping but to fire on U.S. helicopters... "It's removal will contribute significantly to the safety of U.S. forces in the future," Weinberger said of the U.S. Navy's operation to escort oil tankers through the Gulf.
We do not seek further confrontation with Iran but we will be prepared to meet any escalation of military actions by Iran with stronger countermeasures," Weinberger said.
e said the 20 to 30 Iranian personnel on the oil platform were given a 20-minute warning to abandon the platform.
As far as we know they did abandon the site," he said.
Weinberger was asked why the United States had chosen to attack a oil platform rather than Iranian Silkworm missile platforms blamed by Washington for Friday's attack.

Ogden said 66 of the 75 municipalities in the count have signed letters of intent to be served by the facility.

Cable and Wireless Plc <CAWL.L> said its subsidiary <Hong Kong Telepone Co Ltd> would cease to be a listed company, following the restructure of the company's Hong Kong units.

Earlier today the company announced that Hong Kong Telephone and Cable and Wireless Hong Kong, in which the territory's government hs a 20 pct stake, would become subsidiaries of a newly formed holding company, Hong Kong Telecommunications.

In exchange for the Cable and Wireless Hong Kong capital, Hong Kong Telecommunications will issue 4.18 billion new shares to Cable and Wireless Plc's Cable and Wireless (Far East) Ltd. That subsidiary now holds the group's 80 pc stake in Cable and Wireless Hong Kong and about 22 pct of H.K.
It will issue an additional 1.05 billion shares to th goverment.
That will leave the Cable and Wireless group with an 80 pct stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications, the governmen 11 pct and nine pct in public hands.
But that will be reduced early next year after a placement of 11 pct of the issued shares f Hong Kong Telecommunications by both Cable and Wireless and the government.
Texaco Inc said it has been asked by a committee of shareholders about the possibility of the company paying a preferred stock dividend to shareholders
The company said the inquiry, from the Equity Security Holders Committee, outlines the committee's ideas on ho such a dividend might be paid.
Texaco said it would explore the committee's outline, as well as other options that would support shareholders interests and assets.
GAF Corp said the management group led by chairman Samuel J. Heyman intends to reconsider its proposal o acquire GAF.
On September 8, the group offered 64.00 dlrs in cash and 2.50 dlrs principal amount of 15 pc junior subordinated debentures due 2007 for each GAF share.
Heyman owns about 2,700,000 of GAF's 33.5 mln shars outstanding.

In a letter to the committee of independent directors formed to consider the offer, Heyman said it will have to modify the terms of the offer if it is to continue the bid, due to risig interest rates and financial market conditions.

Heyman said "In the considerable time that as elapsed since our original proposal was submitted, the credit and financial markets have experienced extraordinary and almost unprecedented deterioration.

As of the present time, the average interest rate on the financing wich we proposed to raise in connection with the acquisition has increased, since the original proposal, by approximately 150 basis points."
He said the group intends to proptly review all available options, including the revision of its offer to reflect current market conditions.

Tandem Computers Inc said it has introduced an 84-gigabyte write-once, read-many-times optical disk library subsystem called the 5200 Optical Storage Facility for use with Tandem NonStop computr systems VLX, TXP, NonStop II, EXT25 and EXT10.
The company said the facility contains two read/write disk drives, a formatter and a automatic changer for up to 32 disk cartridges, each holding 2.62 gigabytes of data.
It said the 52oo provides an average access time of 250 milliseconds for dat on an optical disk cartridge already mouinted and 17 seconds when a cartridge must be changed.
Tandem said deliveries wil start this quarter.
It said the 5200 is priced a 155,000 dlrs.

It said the software initial license fee is 5,300 dlrs and the monthly license fee is 100 dlrs with the NonStop VLX, TXP, NonStop I and EXT25 systems and the fees are 2,650 dlrs and 50 dlrs respectively with the EXT10 system.

South Korea's national news agency, Yonhap, said this year's current account surplus will near 10 billion dlrs amid signs of continuing high wold demand for the country's cheap cars and electronic goods.
Bank of Korea officials would neither confirm nor deny the Yonhap forecst, saying only that the bank would issue its own figures later in the week.
Yonhap said the January-September surplus in the current account, which covers trde in goods and services, totalled 7.03 billion dlrs.

This already exceeds the seven billion dlr ceiling for the whole of 1987 that the government set in June during talks with te International Monetary Fund aimed at averting a too rapid revaluation of the won against the dollar.
The agency said the Setember surplus was 1.4 billion dlrs, up from 468.1 mln in August and 899 mln a year earlier.
"Exports in October could be relatively modest due o many public holidays, but by the end of this year the surplus will be well over nine billion dollars, close to ten," Yonhap said.
The sharp rise in he September surplus came from a resumption of export deliveries delayed by strikes the previous month.
More than 3,300 companies, inluding car manufacturers, electronic and electric firms, were hit by labour unrest between July and September.
The South Korean government originally targeted a five billion dr current account surplus this year, but had to raise this to seven billion to reflect a startling first-half export boom.

If confirmed, the soaring 1987 current account surplus seemed certain to trigger tougher pressure from the United States whch recorded a 7.4 billion dlr trade deficit with Seoul last year, government economists said.
The U.S. Government, trying to stem protectionist pressure at hoe, has called on South Korea to open more markets to American goods and revalue the won faster.
The won was fixed at 804.90 against the dollar o Monday, representing a 7.01 pct gain so far this year.

Unidentified jets attacked three Iranian oil rigs in the southern Gulf early on Monday, setting at least on of them ablaze, regional shipping sources said.

Earlier today in Washington, U.S. Television networks had reported that American forces launched a retaliatory strike against Iran late Sunday, attacking two Iranian offshore ol drilling platforms and setting them ablaze.
The shipping sources said Iran's Sassan, Rostam and Rakhsh offshore oilfields were attacked at 0700 local (0300 GMT) by a wave of jet fighter bomber.
Smoke was seen spiralling up from te Rostam field soon after.
At least one of the other two targets was also believed to be ablaze the sources said.
The Sassan and Rostam fields have been targets for Iraqi air strikes in the past, but Baghdad had not reported any southern Glf missions prior to news of the latest attack.
Shipping and military sources in the rgion have said Iran used its southern Gulf rigs as bases to launch helicopter and later speedboat attacks on neutral ships in the waterway.
U.S. Officials had been meeting on a response since Friday when an attack on a Kuwaiti port everely damaged a U.S.-flagged ship.
President Reagan said on Sunday he had already ade a decision on the U.S.
Response to Friday's Iran attack but would not sa what the decision was.
Deutsche Bank AG joint chief executive Friedrich Wilhelm Christians said he believed the Louvre accord on currency stabilit was still intact.
hristians told a news conference he met U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker in the last two weeks, after short term German interest rates had risen twice.
I am sure that with 1.7720 marks the dollar is still within the Louvre agreement.
I do not see that the accord has ben terminated," Christians said.
He was responding to questions about comments by Baker, who said the Louvre accord was still operativ but criticised rises in West German interest rates.

The product will use a proprietary NeoRx method of attaching the radioisotope technetium-99m to Genentech's blood clot dissolving drug tissue plasminogen activator, r Activase.

Saudi Arabia is likely to remain the key supplier of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to Japan for at least the ext five years, oil industry sources said.
Japan, while diversifying its supply sources of propane and butane for stable supplies, will continue to bank on Saudi Arabian PG, the sources said.
They aid Saudi's supply capabilities of LPG, an associate of crude oil, is guaranteed by its crude output capacity.
"Saudi is a reliable supplier in that sene," said one trader.
Japan imports about 50 pct of its LG from Saudi Arabia.
No single nation could substitute for Saudi Arabia as an LPG supply source to Japn, the sources said.

"Saudi Arabia has committed itself to Japanese LPG buyers, which has quelled fears that LPG supplies from the Mideast Gulf could easily be disrupted in the wake of heightened hostiliies in that area," said another trader.
Saudi Arabia cut LPG shipments to Japan and elsewhere by 20 pct in September aftr a fire put a major gas plant at Al-Juaimah out of operation.
October shipments were back to contractual volums as Saudi was able to boost exports from other ports.
Attacks on Gulf sipping by Iran and Iraq centered on crude rather than products carriers, which has lulled fears of LPG supply disruptions, traders said.
They said an ranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz was unlikely because it would block Iran's oil shipments.
Industry sources said apan's LPG imports will not greatly rise or fall as its domestic demand growth is estimated at a moderate 2.1 pct a year from 1986 through 1991.
Japanese term buyers of Saudi LPG are expected to lift slightly lower volumes from January 1987, when imports from Indonesia are slated to increase, the source said.

The customers are unlikely to slash Saudi term purchases in large scale when Japan increases annual imports of Indonesian LPG to 1.95 mln tonnes in early 1989 from 319,000 tonnes in the year ende March 1987, the sources said.
But when demand is sluggish in summer, they will phase down term purchases of Saudi LPG and secure lower-priced cargoes on the spot market, they said
Japan imports some 12 mln tonnes of LPG a year, of which 5.3 mln tonnes are supplied by Saudi Arabia, 3.3 mln under term contracts an two mln through spot purchases.
Some 80 pct of Japan's LPG imports are fom the Middle East.

Saudi Arabia's state owned oil company Petromin has made some concessions on term prices to Japanese customers i the recent round of contract renewal talks, and it is likely the Japanese will accept the offer, the sources said.
The Japanese term customers, however, have so far ben unsuccessful in establishing a transparent price formula to replace the existing unilateral monthly price notice.
Japanese buyers pay Saudi Arbia a price notified by Petromin each month.
Most recently the FOB price was set at 8 pct of the 17.52 dlrs per barrel government selling price (GSP) of Arabian Light.
Buyers reserve the right to phase down or ot liftings should the monthly price be set at over 95 pct of Arabian Light's GSP.
Petromin has offered to lower this rate to 90 pct from the 95 pt for contracts with Japanese customers from next January, the trade sources said.
Petromin also suggested that a seller's option of supplying up to 20 pct mor than the contractural volume be subject to seller-buyer agreement.
Under the present contract, Petromin can automatically cut supplies up to 10 pct o the contractual volume.
"If you want to import LPG from Saudi Arabia on a profitable basis, you have to set the price factor at 80 to 85 pct," said a official at a major importer.
"Freight costs re higher for cargoes coming from the Gulf than Southeast Asia due to a longer haul and war risk insurance payments."

Japanese customers will visit audi Arabia this month to finalise their separate contract talks, now focusing on contractual period and volume, which could be very similar to current levels, the sources said.
"When we alk business, we would seek profitability and sometimes forget vulnerability of high dependence on a single supplier," said one.

The thriving market in Luxembourg franc bond issues has been temporarily stalled by the Belgian government crisis which hs put the franc under pressure and forced up interest rates, banking sources said.
On Monday, King Baudouin accepted the resignation of Belgian Prme Minister Wilfried Martens' coalition and asked him to try to form a new government.

Because of the crisis, Banque Generale du Luxembourg SA (BGL) has delayed a public issue for one billion Luxembour francs, originally scheduled for the end of last week, BGL director Robert Sharfe said.
He said the issue would probably go ahead later ths week.
It is likely there will be an upward adjustment in interest rates on Luxembourg franc bond private placements, bankng sources said.
However, no new placements are scheduled for another 10 days
The latest issue last Friday for Swedish Export Credit Corp (SEK) carried a coupon of 7-1/2 pct, whereas i previous issues the interest was set lower at 7-3/8 pct.
Interest rates on the Luxembourg franc, which is in parity with the Belian franc, are strongly affected by Belgian rates.
On Friday, Belgium increased the rate on three-month Treasury certificates by 0.5 pt to 7.15 pct as the Belgian franc came under pressure.
Private placements in Luxembourg francs have become increasingly popular, particularly with Scandivanian borrowrs, because they carry a relatively low interest rate.
Private investors also have flocked to buy Luxembourg franc bond issues because te franc was seen as a fairly strong currency.
U.S. television networks said on Mnday that U.S. forces launched a retaliatory strike against Iran late Sunday, apparently attacking two Iranian offshore oil drilling platforms.
NBC News sid it understood six Iranians had been pulled from the sea.

It said cautiously that U.S. forces attacked late Sunday and that wo Iranian oil platforms east of Bahrain were ablaze as a result, but CBS News and other networks said flatly that U.S. forces attacked the Iranian oil platforms.
U.S. fficials had been meeting on a response since Friday when an attack on a Kuwaiti port severely damaged a U.S.-flagged ship.
President eagan said on Sunday he had already made a decision on the U.S. response to Friday's Iran attack but would not say what the decision was.
Defense ecretary Caspar Weinberger said on Saturday the attack on a U.S.-flagged ship in Kuwaiti waters on Friday was almost certainly by an Iran Silkworm missile.
Thai raders plan to establish a company to regulate maize forward trading, in what could be a first step towards a commodities futures exchange, maize dealers said.

Traders and Internal Trade Department oficials agreed last week to commission a study on a structure to regulate maize forward trading and to set up a company, Thailand Commodity Exchange Co Ltd, with 30 businesses as shareholders who will act as brokers in the futures market.
Chanthong Pattamapong, a commodities trader asked to to draw up the study, said if the maize futures market succeeds it may be extended o other commodities, perhaps sugar and rubber.
The Reserve Bank of India said it was tightening its credit policy for commercial banks by raising their cash reserve ratio by 0. pct to 10 pct, effective from October 24.
The move, announced last weekend, is part of the bank's policy for the second half of fiscal 1987/88 ending March and is aied at curbing excess bank liquidity.
The central bank also put selective controls on bak advances to the oilseeds, vegetable oils and foodgrains trades.
"The policy's main objective is to fully meet the credit requirements of agriculture, industry and exports, while preventing excessive monetary expansion," bank Govenor R.N.
Malhotra told an earlier meeting of chief executives o banks.
Malhotra said the rate of monetary expansion must be kept under control in the second half o the current financial year.
Bank deposits rose 75.40 billion rupees in the first six months of fiscal 1987/88 against 66.92 billon in the same period last year, according to the bank.
Bankers said the bank's move to raise the cash reserve ratio by 0.5 pct will mean impoundig about five billion rupees from the banking system.
Banks' total deposits are estimated at around 1,00 billion rupees.
They said banks are under pressure because of low returns on commercial lending and investments i government securities.
"Already many banks are finding it difficult to maintain their statutory liquidity and cash reserve ratos and are resorting to heavy inter-bank borrowings," said one banker.
Malaysian police denied rumours of race riots in Kuala Lumpur after an armed man killed one person and injured two others in an attack on two petrol stations in a racially-sensitive are of the city.
A police statement broadcast over official Radio Malaysia called on the public not to listen t the rumours and go about their normal business.
"Everything is under control
It's only a small matter and there is no cause for alarm," a police spokesman tol Reuters after confirming the shooting on Sunday night.

However, rumours that riots had broken out hit the stock market and shares on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange fell across the board in heavy nervous selling when the market opened thi morning, brokers said.
Police said they cordoned off the district of Chow Kit and set up road blocks from midnight after the man, armed with a rifle, killed one Maly and injured another Malay and a Chinese.
He set fire to one of te petrol stations.
Puma AG Rudolf Dassler Sport <PUMA.F> said t posted a 1987 first-half group loss of about 14 mln marks, of which the largest portion was in the U.S.
Managing board chairman Armin Dassler told the anual shareholders' meeting parent company turnover was expected to fall to 650 mln marks over the whole year from 698.4 mln in 1986.
No comparative figure or 1986 first half group loss was available.
In the whole f 1986 Puma posted a group consolidated loss of 41.05 mln marks.
Dassler said Puma hped to improve performance in the U.S.
This year, where heavy losses were mainly responsible for the 1986 deicit.
He said Puma expected to post a group loss in the second half of this year bu the shortfall would be lower than in the first half.
The same applied to expected parent company losses, e added.
Dassler said Puma had taken measures to improve futue performance.
Dassler said the measures included changing Puma's product range, closing down some unprofitable factories in West Germny and France and introducing general cost-cutting.
He said Puma hoped to break even in 1988 in the U.S., Its most important export markt.
Dassler said a personal payment he wuld make to shareholders instead of a 1986 dividend was a goodwill gesture which would not be repeated.
Dassler said the payment to holders f Puma's 280,000 non-voting preference shares would amount to about 1.2 mln marks, or 4.50 marks per share.
Armin Dassler and is brother Gerd hold all of Puma's 720,000 ordinary voting shares.
They offered the preerence shares to the public in July last year.
Dassler said shareholders wuld benefit if Puma improved performance next year.
He id not elaborate.
Dassler said e and his brother were planning to leave the managing board and join the supervisory board.
He said e was leaving for health reasons and because he wanted to make way for a new chairman from outside the company.
His sccessor has not been made known yet.
Dassler said oday's meeting was expected to approve Manfred Emcke as Puma's new supervisory board chairman, replacing Vinzenz Grothgar.

A U.S. Defense Department spokesman said he had no information on London oil and stock market rumors that the United States had launched a retaliatory strike against Iran for an attack on Friday that damaged a U.S. shi "I don't hae anything," Major Randy Morger said.
"I have no information at al."
President Reagan said on Sunday he had already made a decision on the U.S. response to Friday's Iran attack but wold not say what the decision was.
Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said on Saturday the attack on a U.S.-flagged ship in Kuwaiti waters on Friday was almost certanly by an Iran Silkworm missile.
Some of the rumors in the London markets were that the United States had launche an offshore strike against Iranian missile installations.
South Yemen is planning a major oil pipeline system to be completed in 18-months time to start exports at a initial rate of 100,000 barrels per day, (bpd) th Middle East Economic Survey (MEES) said.

MEES said government approval for the export pipeline followed a visit to Aden by a high ranking delegation from the Soviet Union, which will help South Yemen construct the line The engineering studies for the pipeline are nearly finished and construction is expected to stat early next year, the industry newsletter said.
The pipeline will run about 170-200 kms (105-125 miles) from Shabwa oilfields to a coastal terminal t Bir 'Ali on the Gulf of Aden, MEES said.

MEES said the Soviet firm Technoexport, which is developing oilfileds for South Yemen, has substantially increased it initial reserve estimates and recommended a pipeline with an eventual 500,000 bpd capacity.

The discovery of commercial quaotities of oil was confirmed by Technoexport earlier this year in three structures in the Shabwa region in the Northwestern part of the country, 200 kms east of Nort Yemen's Alif oilfield.
Trafalgar House Plc <TRAF.L> said it has acquired the entire share capital o <Capital Homes Inc> of the U.S. For 20 mln dlrs in cash.
Capital Homes builds single family homes in the Washington D.C. Area and i also active as a land developer both for its own use and for sale to other builders.
In the financial year to end February, 1987, Capital recorded pre-tax profits o 3.7 mln dlrs on a turnover of 58 mln dlrs from the sale of 421 homes.
Capital has a land bank of some 2,600 units and in the curent year the company expects to sell 500 homes, Trafalgar House said.

Sprint II, a special purpose corporation based in the Cayman Islands, is issuing 35 mln dlrs of floating rate bods due November 6, 1992 and priced at 100.10, said Fuji International finance Ltd as lead manager.
The bonds are backed b a pool of 48.7 mln dlrs of Japanese ex-warrant bonds.
The bonds are priced to yield 20 basis points ovr the six month London Interbank Offered Rate.
They are available in denominations of 100,000 dlrs and are payable on November 6
There is a seven basis point management and underwriting fee, an eight basis point sellin concession and a two basis point praecipuum.
Kuwait's oil exports have not been affected by the seven-year Iran-Iraq war, Kuwait Oil Tanker Company (KOTC) Chairman and Managing Director Abdul Fattah al-Bader told a Kuwait newspaper.
"Kuwait has exploited all available opportunities to continue exporting its oil without any reduction," te Al-Anbaa newspaper quoted him as saying.

He said KOTC made profits of more than two mln dinars (seven mln dlrs) in the fiscal year ending last June, but predicted lower profits this year due to higher costs for chartering an operating vessels.

Toyota Motor Corp <TOYO.T> and Volkswagen AG <VOWG.F> are considering raising the local procurement rate at their West German joint venture to at least 60 pct from an earlier planned 50 pct after on year's output, a Toyota spokesman said.

The two carmakers agreed ast June to start jointly producing a Toyota-designed light truck at VW's Hanover plant from early 1989 at a rate of 7,000 to 8,000 the first year, rising to 15,000 from 1990.
They may equip the light truck with a Volkswagen-made engine to reach a local procurement rat of 60 pct, he said.
The two companies need to raise the value of locally procured parts to 60 pct t avoid tariffs when they export to other European markets, industry sources said.
Karl Otto Poehl, ead of West Germany's central bank, and Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg are normally so much in agreement that some foreigners doubt the central bank's independence.

But a rare public row between the eullient Poehl, president of the Bundesbank, and Stoltenberg, over a controversial investment tax proposal, has added to the woes of the country's already nervous financial markets, bankers said.

Poehl told an investment symposium in Frankfurt ast Thursday he feared the tax would raise borrowing costs and interest rates Stoltenberg quickly issued a statement rebutting Poehl's criticism, saying West Germany would remain an attractive place for foreign investors.
"The obvious lack of coordination between the Bundesbank and Finance Ministry does not instil confidence in foreign investors," said one economist for a London broker, who asked not t be identified.
Bankers here expressed confidence the two top financial poliy-makers would quickly patch up their relationship to steer the economy through a particularly difficult time.
"There are plenty of objective pressures which will result in things getting back to normal again after a period of ill feeling," said Commerzbank AG chief economist Juergen Pfiser.
News on October 9 that the government was planning a 10 pct withholding tax wiped billions o marks off shares and bonds in a market already reeling from rising interest rates at home and abroad.

Bankers said the Bundesbank was angered by the way the finance ministry announced the plan -- without consulting the Bundesbank adequately, and allowing apparently conflicting detils to dribble out into an unprepared and uncertain market.
Both Poehl, 57, and Stoltenberg, 59, hav been under extraordinary pressures lately.

Poehl has had to switch to the hard line promoted by his deputy, Helmut Schlesinger, jacking up interest rates to fight inflationary fears and abandoning te pragmatic policies he had pursued so far this year to promote currency stability.
In recent statements Poehl has sounded mor like Schlesinger.
For years the softly-spoken economist has been warning in speech after speech tha excessive money supply growth would eventually lead to rising prices.
Schlesinger now has a majority of support in the Bundesbank council, and since late summer Poehl has had to represent his views bankers said.
"Poehl is in a minority in his own house," said Commerzban's Pfister.
"Poehl s in a dilemma.
He must follow a policy that is not entirely his on," said another economist.
The dilemma is that if German interest rates rise too far, they will attract funds into the country, pushing up the mrk and hurting West German exporters.
The dollar has now sed some seven pfennigs since the Bundesbank's new tack became clear in early October.
Since last Thursday, United States Treasury Secretary James Baker has criticized th Bundesbank rate increases.

Bankers said this could freshadow a revival of the 1986 war of words between the U.S. And West Germany, in which U.S. Officials talked down the dollar to force West Germany to stimulate its economy and thus suck in more U.S. Exports.
One way est Germany agreed to do this was making a round of tax cuts worth 39 billion marks from 1990.
But financing hese tax cuts has proved more difficult for Stoltenberg than he had bargained for.

The cool, unflappable northerner, who was regularly voted most popular government politician last year, had to face resistance from local baons in the government coalition parties and from trade unions to his planned subsidy cuts.
The withholding tax was intended t plug one gap by raising 4.3 billion marks.
But it has caused an outcry among bankers, who say i will push up borrowing costs.
The extra amount this costs the government could wipe out te revenue the tax brings in.
Meanwhile Stoltenberg is dealing with a local political row which hs turned into the country's worst political scandal.
Stoltenberg had o leave monetary talks in Washington last month early to sort out a row in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, where he heads the ruling CDU party.
The state's DU premier, Uwe Barschel, had to resign after allegations of a "dirty tricks" election campaign led to heavy losses for the CDU in state elections.
Barschel as found dead in a hotel bath in Geneva last weekend.
Police ay the death appears to have been suicide.
Cooperation between oehl and Stoltenberg is all the more remarkable as Poehl is in the opposition Social Democrats, and was appointed by former chancellor Helmut Schmidt.
When Poehl's contract came p for renewal earlier this year, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's CDU-led coalition government gave Poehl another eight-year term.
Werner Chrobok, managing partner t Bethmann Bank, said he hoped the two men would soon be of one opinion again.
But when Poehl criticized Stoltenberg's tax plans he was not only voicing what many bankers felt but demonstrating the Bundesbank's independence f government, Chrobok said.

Venezuelan Central Bank President Hrnan Anzola has submitted his resignation and asked President Jaime Lusinchi to transfer him to a post in the oil industry, two leading Venezuelan newspapers reported.
The El Universal and El Nacional paprs said Anzola would leave his position soon.
Lusinchi already has decided on his succesor, the El Nacional reported.
Central Bank officials were not available fr comment.
Banking sources said Anzola differed with the Finance Ministry over economic policy, particlarly over the direction of interest rates.
He favoured raising the rates, which are currently well below the annual inflaton rate of 33.2 pct.
But the sources said he ran into opposition from Finance Ministry and governent officials who thought an interest increase would fuel inflation.
French Finance Minister Edouard Balladur issued a firm call fr the continued faithful application of the Louvre accords on currency stability by all major industrial countries.

Balladur, responding to weekend remarks by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker that the U.S. Would take another look a the accords, said "I firmly desire a faithfull and firm adherence by all the major industrial countries to the Louvre accords -- in both their letter and spirit."
On Sunday, Baker said last week's rise in shor-term West German interest rates was not in keeping with the accords.
The Louvre accords, agreed in Paris last February, caled for stability among the major currencies after a prolonged dollar slide.
The accords were reaffirmed b the Group of Seven Finance Ministers in Washington last month.
But Baker said at the weekend that the Wet German rate rise was "not in keeping with the spirit of what we agreed to."
"What I'm really saying is that they should not expect us to simply sit back here ad accept increased tightening on their part on the assumption that somehow we are going to follow them," he added.

King Baudouin is expected to accept the resignation of Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens's centre-right coalition government afte last-ditch talks failed to solve a language row, state-run RTBF radio said.
The King could ask Martens or another political leader to put together a new governmet or to form a caretaker administration with elections at the end of November or in early December.
The King has so far withheld a decision on whether to accept the resignation last Thursday of Martens's coalition o Dutch and French speaking parties over the linguistic conflict.

Martens has used the breathing space to try to put together a compromise solution but RTBF and the Belgian news agency Belga said leading ministers ended their talks early on Monday mornng without agreement.
"The resignation of the government will no doubt be accepted by the King in the near future," RTB said.
The King has no formal deadline for announcing his decision but has been widely expected to do so on Mondy.

Banks are being invited to join the facility at 10 mln stg for 0.05 pct and at five mln st for 0.04 pct.
There will be a renewal fee of 0.01 pct unde the evergreen option.

The main road between Kampala and the Kenya border, Uganda's most important trade artery, reoened to civilian traffic on Saturday after rebels who closed it on Friday disappeared back into the bush, travellers said.
The government's National Resistance Army (NRA) closed the road on Friday after the rebel Holy Spirit Movement of priestess Alice Lakwea reached a village on the road, said.
But by the time NRA reinforcements arrived the rebels had disappeare into thick forest.
The road and a parallel railway line, which closed last weekend, carry 90 pct of Uganda's foreign trade to the Kenya port of Mombasa.
Iran warned the United States on Monday against exacerbating the Gulf crisis saying it would endanger American interests.

Tehran Radio, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation, said a spokesman for Iran's War Information Headquarters was responding "to U.S. Officials' remarks about taking military action against Irn."
The radio also quoted an Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying Irn would respond decisively to any aggressive measure by the United States.
The radio said the spokesman made the statement "following the attack on a Kuwaiti ship under th U.S.
Flag and comments by American officials on carrying out retaliatory actio against Iran."

The spokesman said, "Any U.S. Military aggression against Iran will certainly be the beginning of an extensive clash in the Persian Gulf, and amidst this our principled policy is to confront any ac which escalates tension."

Norway's current account showed a .9 billion crown deficit for the first seven months of 1987, against a 19.7 billion crown deficit for the same year-ago period, the Central Bureau of Statistics said.

The West erman Finance Ministry declined to comment on weekend criticism by U.S. Treasury Secretary James Baker of recent West German interest rate increases.

The rise in West Germany short term interest rates was not in the spirit of a agreement by these nations in Washington, which reaffirmed the Louvre pact, he said.
A Finance Ministry spokesman, asked for an official ministry reaction to Baker's remarks, said he coud make no comment.

The Cyprus vessel Fearless, 31,841 tonnes dw, which was on fire, grounded then towed to Yanai, China, in August, had all its cargo reloaded but the cargo in the no.
3 hold caght fire on October 15.

The Finnish State launched two bonds totalling one billion markka with loan periods of 10 years and five years and annual interest rtes of 7.75 and 7.25 pct respectively.
The bonds sell concurrently until the total is reached and nominal values are 25,000 markka, 10,000 markka, 5,000 markka and 1,000 markka, th Finance Ministry said.

It was decided with the banks the rates should be 025 pct less than the eight and 7.5 pct rates respectively of 10-year and five-year bonds launched by the State on August 17, a Ministry statement said.

Malaysia's recovery from the worst recession in 20 years should receive a boost on Friday when the government announces a reflationary budget for calendar 1988 aftr seven years of austerity, economists said.
"Our country is walking on one leg now," said Ismail Salleh, an economst with the Institute of Strategic and International Studies.
"It has to depend on public sector investment for faster growth if te private sector is not moving."
Gross domestic product grew one pct i 1986 after shrinking one pct in 1985.
The fiscal year end December 31.
The government has said it expects 1987 growth to be under two pct but some analysts believe it will be neare three pct because prices for commodity exports have risen sharply.
Malaysia is a leading exporter of rubber, palm oil, tin and semiconductors and a major producer of cocoa, timber and ol.
The government slashed development spnding to 9.8 billion ringgit this year from 14.5 billion in 1986.
Economists said unemployment is exected to exceed 10 pct in 1988 against about 9.5 pct this year.
Local investment also has stagnated, with businessmen blaming inconsistent economic poicies and lack of incentives.
One businessman said too many politicians give the impression tha Malaysia was unstable.
"If we can ake care of investment confidence, the potential to recover strongly is great," a banker said.
Malaysia's 1987 current account is expected to be in the black with the Central Bank projecting a 500 ml ringgit surplus compared with last year's 1.2 billion ringgit deficit.
The government has said its fiscal policies will balance th budget by 1989.
The defiit in 1986 was 952 mln ringgit.
The government will also repay some of its external debt, which stood at 51 billion ringgit at the en of 1986.
Political leaders have said he budget will not hurt ordinary people as taxes on basic food and other essential goods are unlikely to change.
Businessmen said they hope he government also will cut the corporate tax, now between 45 and 48 pct, to enable Malaysia to compete for investors with neighbouring states.
Lloyds Shipping Intelligence service sid the British bulk carrier Envoy, 75,453 tonnes dw, was grounded at Mile 190 in the Orinoco river on October 16.
The vessel was on a voyage from Trombetas, Brazil, to Matanzas, Cua, carrying 50,000 tonnes of bauxite.
Its draught wa 36 feet.
Attempts to refloat the vessel with the help of six tugs hae been unsuccessful.

China expects its 1987 grain harvest to e 397 mln tonnes, eight mln tonnes short of its target, the New China News Agency quoted a State Statistical Bureau spokesman as saying.
The harvest will be China's second highest n history but poor weather and low incentives for grain-producing farmers have kept yields down, earlier Chinese press reports said.
Industry sources expect China to import at last 10 mln tonnes of grain this year because of the harvest shortfall.
Chinese customs figures showed grain imports of 959 mln tonnes in the first eight months of 1987, compared with 6.09 mln in the same 1986 period.
Agriculture Minister He Kang said last month sate prices for grain purchase from growers were to be adjusted to increase the incentive for grain production.
China could not afford to beome a major food importer, he said.
The State Statistics Bureau spokesman also said China's 1987 cotton output ws expected to rise 10 pct over 1986 to 390 mln tonnes.

The Philippine 1987 inflation rate will rise to 4.8 pct from 0.74 pct in 1986 if the government implements an employers' association recomendation for a 10 pct increase in the 54 peso minimum daily wage this month, Economic Planning Secretary Solita Monsod said.

The government's wn proposal for an across-the-board daily pay rise of six pesos for non-agricultural workers and eight pesos for agriculture workers, would push the full year average higher to 5.4 pct, she told the Senate last week.
The 0 pct rise in the minimum wage is recommended by the Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOP).
The COP proposal would push the year-on-year inflation rate to 11.6 pct in December compared with the predicted 14.4 pct if the government's recommendation is implemented, Solita said.
oth were proposed last month.
Annual inflation for 1987 was forecast at four to 4.5 pct by the National Economic and Development Authority early this month
In the first three months of the year, inflation was a negative 0.5, 0.6 and 0.7 pct respectively, rising to 1.0, 2.5 and 4.6 pct in April May an June, the National Statistics Office said.
The annual inflation rate rose to 5.8 pct in June, 6.2 pct in July and 6.15 and 6.188 pct in August and September respectively, the National Statistcs Office said.
It attributed the acceleration to higher fuel an water prices.
The government's six and eight peso wage increases would displace up to 20,000 workers, Monsod said, bringing the number of unemployed to 4.2 mln or 19.2 pc of the population.

South Africa must drive down its inflation rate to much lower levels to prevent a further declne in the rand, said Volkskas Bank in its monthly economic review.
The bank said that without a major drop in the inflation rate, the rand was bound o eventually decrease even more, regardless of a sharp rise in the gold price.
Inflation is running at an annual rate of some 17 pct and the rand is around 49.5 U.S.
Most ecoomists estimate continued high inflation.
Volkskas predicted the rand will remain fairly seady for the rest of 1987 and then ease slightly next year.
A sharp rise in Soviet sugar consumption snce the start of the Kremlin's anti-alcohol drive indicates home brewing is costing the state 20 billion roubles in lost vodka sales, Pravda said.
The Communist Party newspaper said sugar sales had increased by one mln tonnes a year, enough to be turned into two billion bottles of moonshine

At current vodka prices of 10 roubles a bottle, it said, this meant illicit alcohol consumption had reached the equivalent of 20 billion roubles a year, or annual revenues from vodka sales before the May 1985 anti-alchoho decree.
"Official statistics show a reduction in consumption of vodka, but this is a deceptive statistic -- it does no count home-brew," Pravda said.
"The epidemic first engulfed the villages and has now also firmly settled int cities, where the availability of natural gas, running water and privacy has made it much easier."

Kremlin leader Mikhail Gorbachev launched the anti-alcohol campaign shortly after taking office in March 1985 as a first step to improving Soviet economic performance, which hd been seriously hurt by drunkenness among the working population.
Equiticorp Holdings Ltd <EQUW.WE> now owns or has received acceptances representing 59.93 pt of the issued ordinary share capital of Guinness Peat Group Plc <GNSP.L>, Equiticorp said in a statement.
